  1027. Yukonic Plague
  1028. Zerline
  1029. Zeus
  1030. Zodiac

Accordion

Accordion

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (8%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To discard all the cards.

Layout

•stock (top left, face down) -  Turn over 1 card at a time to the tableau by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (bottom right) - where cards are automatically moved out of play.
•tableau  - where cards are dealt from the stock.  Cards are dealt in a row.  Any card may be moved onto the card immediately previous to it or onto the card 3 cards previous to it if the cards are of the same suit or rank.  For example, if the cards in the row are the 3 ♣, 5 ♥, 9 ♦ , 9 ♣, the 9 ♣ can be moved on either the 9 ♦ (because they are the same rank and the 9 ♦ is one card previous) or the  9 ♣ can be moved on the 3 ♣ (because they are the same suit and the 3 ♣ is 3 cards previous).  When cards reach the end of the screen the cards will go down to the next row in serpentine fashion.

Options

AutoPlay - AutoPlay has a special function in this game.  When AutoPlay is on, at the start of the game all of the cards in the deck will be dealt out.  This is useful because dealing out all the cards at the beginning is the best strategy.

History

Accordion is also known as Idle Year, Tower of Babel, or Methuselah.

Similar Games

Royal Marriage

Push-Pin

Ace of Hearts

Ace of Hearts

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (95%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundation.

Layout

•1 foundation piles (top) - build up regardless of suit from the Ace of Hearts to King, wrapping to Ace and back up until all 52 cards are built.
•7 tableau piles (below foundation) - build down by suit.  Groups of cards may be moved regardless of any sequence.  Fill spaces with Kings or a group of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd pile, and so on.
•stock (top left, face down) -Deal one card to each tableau pile, by clicking.  No redeals.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Ace of Hearts is a variation of Queenie and was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Queenie

Yukon

Aces and Kings

Aces and Kings

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (5%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (middle) - build the first 4 piles from Ace to King up regardless of suit, build the last 4 piles from Kings to Aces down regardless of suit.
•4 tableau piles (below foundations, on right) - storage spaces for cards.  Only one card allowed per pile.  Spaces are filled from the stock.  When the stock is empty, spaces are filled by any card.  One card is dealt to each pile at the start of the game.
•2 reserve piles (top) - Top card available for play on the foundations.  13 cards are dealt to each reserve at the start of the game.
•stock (bottom left, face down) -  Turn over 1 card at a time to the waste pile by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•  It is allowed (in fact is it necessary in order to win)  to move cards from one foundation pile to another, in particular from Ace foundations to King foundations and vice versa.
•Play consists of moving cards from the reserves, waste, and tableau to the foundations, and especially in strategic movement of cards within the foundations to allow more cards to be played there.

History

Aces and Kings is based on several common solitaire games, but this particular variation was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Acey and Kingsley

Deuces and Queens

Racing Aces

Double Aces and Kings

Aces and Kings Easy

Five Little Guys

Aces and Kings Easy

Aces and Kings Easy

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (90%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (middle) - build the first 4 piles from Ace to King up regardless of suit, build the last 4 piles from Kings to Aces down regardless of suit.
•4 tableau piles (below foundations, on right) - storage spaces for cards.  Only one card allowed per pile.  Spaces are filled from the stock.  When the stock is empty, spaces are filled by any card.  One card is dealt to each pile at the start of the game.
•2 reserve piles (top) - Top card available for play on the foundations.  13 cards are dealt to each reserve at the start of the game.
•stock (bottom left, face down) -  Turn over 1 card at a time to the waste pile by clicking.  One redeal.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•  It is allowed (in fact is it necessary in order to win)  to move cards from one foundation pile to another, in particular from Ace foundations to King foundations and vice versa.
•Play consists of moving cards from the reserves, waste, and tableau to the foundations, and especially in strategic movement of cards within the foundations to allow more cards to be played there.

History

Aces and Kings Easy is Aces and Kings with a redeal.

Similar Games

Aces and Kings

Acey and Kingsley

Deuces and Queens

Racing Aces

Double Aces and Kings

Aces Up

Aces Up

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (4%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To remove all the cards from the tableau except the 4 Aces.

Layout

•4 tableau piles (top) - cards are dealt here 1 to each pile from the stock.  The top card of each pile is available for play.  Any top card that is of lower rank and the same suit of another top card may be removed by clicking on it. Aces are considered to be of the highest rank.  Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (face down) - deal 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.  No redeals.

Notes

•Play consists of removing all but the highest rank exposed card of each suit.  The only way to get at cards beneath an Ace is to move the Ace to an empty pile.

Similar Games

Firing Squad

Suits Up

Aces Up Pairs

Aces Up Pairs

Aces Up Pairs

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (55%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To remove all the cards from the tableau except the 4 Aces.

Layout

•4 tableau piles (top) - cards are dealt here 1 to each pile from the stock.  The top card of each pile is available for play.  Any top card that is of lower rank and the same suit of another top card may be removed by clicking on it. Also, any top card that is of the same rank as another top card (except for Aces) may also be removed (that is, any card that is one of a pair - you can select either card of the pair, but not both). Aces are considered to be of the highest rank.  Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (face down) - deal 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.  No redeals.

Notes

•Play consists of removing all but the highest rank exposed card of each suit or one card of any pair.  The only way to get at cards beneath an Ace is to move the Ace to an empty pile.

Similar Games

Aces Up

Firing Squad

Suits Up

Aces Wild

Aces Wild

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (90%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Twos to King, then Aces.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color, or play an Ace on any card or any card on an Ace.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color (except no group containing an Ace may be moved).  Fill spaces with Kings or a group of cards headed by a King. At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 3 cards at a time to the waste by clicking during the first deal, 2 cards at a time during the 2nd deal, and 1 card at a time during the last deal.  Two redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

In the tableau, you can play any card on an Ace or play an Ace on any card, effectively making Aces as wild cards.  However, the flip side is that you may not move any group of cards containing an Ace.

History

Aces Wild is a variation of Gold Rush invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Gold Rush

Klondike

Spike

Thieves Rush

Double Gold Rush

Acey and Kingsley

Acey and Kingsley

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (5%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (middle) - build the first 4 piles from Ace to King up regardless of suit, build the last 4 piles from Kings to Aces down regardless of suit.  At the start of the game 4 Aces and 4 Kings are dealt here.
•4 tableau piles (below foundations, on right) - storage spaces for cards.  Only one card allowed per pile.  Spaces are filled from the stock.  When the stock is empty, spaces are filled by any card.  One card is dealt to each pile at the start of the game.
•2 reserve piles (top) - Top card available for play on the foundations.  13 cards are dealt to each reserve at the start of the game.
•stock (bottom left, face down) -  Turn over 1 card at a time to the waste pile by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•  It is allowed (in fact is it necessary in order to win)  to move cards from one foundation pile to another, in particular from Ace foundations to King foundations and vice versa.
•Play consists of moving cards from the reserves, waste, and tableau to the foundations, and especially in strategic movement of cards within the foundations to allow more cards to be played there.

History

Acey and Kingsley is a variation of Aces and Kings.

Similar Games

Aces and Kings

Deuces and Queens

Racing Aces

Aces and Kings Easy

Acme

Acme

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (15%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Aces to Kings. At the beginning of the game the Aces are dealt here.
•4 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are filled from the reserve if possible, then by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time, by clicking.  1 redeal.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card always available for play on the tableau or foundations.
•reserve (left of tableau) - Top card always available for play on the tableau or foundations.  At the start of the game 13 cards are dealt here.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Acme is a century old game similar to Canfield.

Similar Games

Canfield

Coyote

Runner

Double Acme

Acquaintance

Acquaintance

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (50%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - build up regardless of suit from Ace to King.
•4 reserve piles (below foundations) - cards are dealt here from the stock.  The top card of each pile is available for play.  Move cards to the foundations by clicking.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (face down) - deal 1 card to each reserve pile by clicking.  Two redeals.

History

Acquaintance is a variation of Auld Lang Syne.  It is the same as Auld Lang Syne except that it has two redeals.  This makes it easier to win and adds more skill to the game.

Similar Games

Auld Lang Syne

Acquaintance One

Sir Tommy

Lady Betty

Tam O'Shanter

Quadrennial

Mutual Acquaintance

River Doon

Old Fashioned

Antique

Acquaintance One

Acquaintance One

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (20%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - build up regardless of suit from Ace to King.
•4 reserve piles (below foundations) - cards are dealt here from the stock.  The top card of each pile is available for play.  Move cards to the foundations by clicking.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (face down) - deal 1 card to each reserve pile by clicking.  One redeal.

History

Acquaintance One is a variation of Auld Lang Syne and Acquaintance.  It is the same as Auld Lang Syne except that it has one redeal.  This makes it easier to win than Auld Lang Syne but harder than Acquaintance.

Similar Games

Acquaintance

Auld Lang Syne

Tam O'Shanter

Mutual Acquaintance

Acute Triangle

Acute Triangle

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (95%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King. At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - deal 1 card to each tableau pile, by clicking.  No redeals.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Acute Triangle is an easier version of Small Triangle.

Similar Games

Hypotenuse

Adela

Adela

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (2%)  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•24 foundation piles (left and right) - place Kings in the Kings piles, Queens in the Queens piles.  In the center Jack piles, start each pile with a Jack, build down in suit from Jacks to Aces.
•9 tableau piles (center) - build up in suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are filled from the stock.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (bottom center, face down) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile.  No redeals.

Options

AutoPlay

Adelaide

Adelaide

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Easy (95%).  Skill/Luck Balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - Build down in suit.  Groups of cards may be moved regardless of sequence. Spaces filled by Kings or groups of cards headed by a King. At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt to each pile.

 

•stock (top left) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste pile by clicking.  One redeal.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Adelaide is an easy variation of Outback.

Admiral's Patience

Admiral's Patience

 Top  Previous  Next

4 Decks.  Hard (30%). Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•16 foundation piles (left, across top, right) - build up in suit from the rank of first card in the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•11 tableau piles (bottom row, center) - build down in suit, wrapping from Ace to King if necessary.  Only the top card of each pile may be moved.  Spaces are filled automatically from the stock, or from the waste when the stock is empty.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•reserve (above tableau) - top card is available for play on the foundations only.  At the start of the game 13 cards are dealt here.
•stock (middle left, face down) - turn over cards 1 at a time to the waste by clicking.  One redeal.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Admiral's Patience is a 4 deck variation of General's Patience.  It was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

General's Patience

Double Signora

Terrace

Empress of Italy

Blondes and Brunettes

Captain's Patience

Agnes Bernauer

Agnes Bernauer

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (50%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces are filled by a card or legal group of cards headed by a card one rank below the foundation base card.  At the start of the game, 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, up to 7 cards dealt to the 7th pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - Deals 1 card to each reserve pile, by clicking.  No redeals.
•7 reserve piles (bottom) - top card is available for play on the tableau or foundations. No building.

History

Agnes Bernauer, like Agnes Sorel, is a variation of Klondike.  Both games have been called Agnes.  David Parlett gave them their separate names.

Similar Games

Agnes Sorel

Agnes Three

Seymour

Prince Albert

Agnes Two

Agnes Four

Agnes Four

Agnes Four

 Top  Previous  Next

4 Decks.  Medium (80%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 26 cards.  Only two piles for each suit allowed.
•13 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color, wrapping from Ace to King if necessary.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces are filled by a card or legal group of cards headed by a card one rank below the foundation base card.  At the start of the game, 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, up to 13 cards dealt to the 13th pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - Deals 1 card to each reserve pile, by clicking.  No redeals.
•13 reserve piles (bottom) - top card is available for play on the tableau or foundations.  At the start of the game one card is dealt to each pile. No building.

History

Agnes Four is a 4 deck version of Agnes Three invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Agnes Three

Agnes Bernauer

Agnes Two

Agnes Sorel

Agnes Sorel

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Hard (<1%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by the same color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by the same color.  Spaces are not filled.  At the start of the game, 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, up to 7 cards dealt to the 7th pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - Deals 1 card to each tableau pile, by clicking.  No redeals.

History

Agnes Sorel, like Agnes Bernauer, is a variation of Klondike.  Both games have been called Agnes.  David Parlett gave them their seperate names.

Similar Games

Agnes Bernauer

Agnes Three

Agnes Three

Agnes Three

 Top  Previous  Next

3 Decks.  Easy (90%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•12 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•13 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces are filled by a card or legal group of cards headed by a card one rank below the foundation base card.  At the start of the game, 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, up to 13 cards dealt to the 13th pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - Deals 1 card to each reserve pile, by clicking.  No redeals.
•13 reserve piles (bottom) - top card is available for play on the tableau or foundations.  At the start of the game one card is dealt to each pile. No building.

History

Agnes Three is a 3 deck version of Agnes Bernauer invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Agnes Bernauer

Agnes Sorel

Agnes Two

Agnes Four

Agnes Two

Agnes Two

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (80%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces are filled by a card or legal group of cards headed by a card one rank below the foundation base card.  At the start of the game, 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, up to 10 cards dealt to the 13th pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - Deals 1 card to each reserve pile, by clicking.  No redeals.
•10 reserve piles (bottom) - top card is available for play on the tableau or foundations.  At the start of the game one card is dealt to each pile. No building.

History

Agnes Two is a 2 deck version of Agnes Bernauer.

Similar Games

Agnes Bernauer

Agnes Sorel

Agnes Three

Agnes Four

Alaska

Alaska

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (15%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King. Move Aces here as they become available.
• 7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build up or down by suit.  Move groups of cards regardless of sequence.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 28 cards are dealt into 7 piles, face down as in Klondike.  Then the remaining 24 cards are dealt face up in the rightmost 6 piles, 4 in each pile.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

• Any face up card in the tableau may be built upon another, no matter how deep it is in a pile.  All cards covering it are moved together.  When a face down card is uncovered, it is automatically turned face up and is available for play.

History

Alaska is a variation of Yukon.

Similar Games

Yukon

Russian Solitaire

Moosehide

Double Alaska

Alcides

Alcides

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (25%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To pair up all the cards and move them to the waste pile.

Layout

•10 tableau piles (across top) - the top card is available for play.  Pair up cards of the same rank.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•2 extra cards (below tableau) - each card is available for play to be paired with cards in the tableau.
•waste pile - Where paired cards go out of play.

History

Alcides is a variation of Heracles and Nestor.

Similar Games

Nestor

Doublets

Vertical

Heracles

Alexandria

Alexandria

 Top  Previous  Next

3 Decks.  Easy (90%).  Skill/luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•12 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•13 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Groups of cards in sequence down by alternate color may be moved as a unit.  Spaces may be filled only by Kings.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 to the 2nd, 3 to the 3rd, 4 to the 4th, 5 to the 5th, 6 to the 6th, 7 to the 7th, 6 to the 8th, 5 to the 9th, 4 to the 10th, 3 to the 11th, 2 to the 12th, and 1 to the 13th.
•stock (bottom left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  One redeal.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Alexandria is a 3 deck version of Thieves of Egypt invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Thieves of Egypt

Alexander the Great

Alexander the Great

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (15%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (left) - build the Aces up in suit to King and the Kings down in suit to Ace.  At the start of the game two Aces of one color and two Kings of the opposite color are dealt here.
•12 fans (right of foundations) - build up or down by suit.  The top card is available for play on the foundations or another fan.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are filled only by Aces or Kings.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Since there are only 4 remaining Aces or Kings, only 4 empty fans can be filled.

History

Alexander the Great is a variation of Clover Leaf invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Clover Leaf

La Belle Lucie

House on the Hill

Algerian Patience

Algerian Patience

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Easy (98%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top) - build first 4 up in suit from Ace to King, build last 4 down in suit from King to Ace. The first 4 piles start with an Ace of each suit, the last 4 piles start with a King of each suit.  The Kings are dealt at the start of the game, Aces are moved here as they become available.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - build up or down by suit, wrapping Kings and Aces if necessary.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are filled by any available card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•6 reserve piles (bottom) - Top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt to each pile.  When a reserve pile is completely empty, it may be used as a storage cell to store one card from the tableau.
•stock (face down, top left) - clicking deals 2 cards to each reserve pile, except for the last time it deals 1 card to each tableau pile.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Algerian Patience is a rare game of unknown origin found in David Parlett's book "Teach Yourself Card Games for One".  Parlett's rules have been changed slightly to make the game come out.

Similar Games

Carthage

Cicely

Kingsdown Eights

Tournament

Algiers

Algiers

 Top  Previous  Next

3 Decks.  Easy (95%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•12 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•12 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are filled by any available card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•9 reserve piles (bottom) - Top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt to each pile.  When a reserve pile is completely empty, it may be used as a storage cell to store one card from the tableau.
•stock (face down, top left) - clicking deals 2 cards to each reserve pile.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Algiers is a 3 deck variation of Carthage and Algerian Patience.

Similar Games

Algerian Patience

Carthage

Ali Baba

Ali Baba

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (50%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.  At the beginning of the game the Aces are dealt here.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Groups of cards in descending sequence down in suit may be moved as a unit. Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  Unlimited redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Similar Games

Big Forty

Cassim

Alhambra

Alhambra

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Very Hard (<1%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build first 4 up in suit from Ace to King, build last 4 down in suit from King to Ace. At the start of the game an Ace and King of each suit is dealt.
•8 reserve piles (below foundations) - No building.  Play cards to the foundations or waste.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile.
•stock (bottom left, face down) - move 1 card to waste by clicking.  Two redeals.
•waste (beside stock) - Build up or down by suit, wrapping as necessary (Aces may be built on Kings and Kings may be built on Aces).  The top card is available for play on the foundations.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Alhambra is an unusual game in that there is no building except upon the waste.

Similar Games

Granada

Reserves

All in a Row

All in a Row

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Hard (1%).  All Skill.

Object

To move all the cards in a row in the waste pile.

Layout

•waste pile (bottom) - begins with any card, build up or down regardless of suit, with Ace and King considered consecutive.
•13 Fans  - the top card is available for play to the waste.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile.

Tips

•All in a Row is easy to play, but requires a great deal of advance calculation to win.  Map out the cards you wish to play to the waste before you play them.
•If you cannot play a card to the waste, the game is lost.

Similar Games

Black Hole

Golf

Alleys

Alleys

 Top  Previous  Next

4 Decks.  Hard (10%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•16 foundation piles (across top, left, right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Only one card at a time may be moved. Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 8 cards are dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Alleys is a variation of Eighty Thieves.

Similar Games

Eighty Thieves

Forty Thieves

Sixty Thieves

Malmaison

Streets

Alliance

Alliance

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (25%).  Skill/luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top) - Build the top piles down in suit from Jacks to Ace, King, Queen.  Build the lower piles up in suit from Queens to King, Ace to Jack.   Each group of 4 piles should have a pile of each suit.
•16 tableau piles (below foundations) - top card is available for play on the foundations.  Spaces are not filled.  No building until the last redeal is completed.  After the last redeal, build up or down by suit.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - deal one card to each tableau pile, by clicking.  When the stock is empty, the tableau is redealt in the following way by clicking on the empty stock: the cards in the last pile of the last row are picked up and turned over.  The top card is dealt to the pile where the cards were taken, the remainder are dealt to the first pile in the first row and across until the cards run out.  This can be repeated for each pile in the tableau, moving from the bottom right pile to next pile to its left.  There are 16 redeals, one for each pile.

Options

AutoPlay

 

Notes

Because of the way the redeal is structured, if the pile that is to be redealt has 0 or 1 cards, nothing will happen.

History

Alliance is just like Matrimony, except after the last redeal you can build cards in the tableau, which makes the game easier and adds some skill to the game.  It was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Matrimony

Alloway Kirk

Alloway Kirk

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (35%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (across top) - build up regardless of suit from Ace to King.
•4 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Groups of cards cannot be moved.  Spaces can be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) -deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.  No redeals.

 

History

Alloway Kirk is the game Tam O'Shanter with the ability to move cards among the tableau piles.

 

 

Similar Games

Tam O'Shanter

Assembly

Millennium

Alternation

Alternation

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (85%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - Build first and third piles up by alternate color from Ace to King.  Build second and fourth piles down by alternate color from King to Ace.  Two Aces and Kings of each color are dealt here at the start of the game.
•4 tableau piles (below foundations) - cards are moved here from the waste. The top card of each pile is available for play on the foundations.
•stock (face down) - deal 1 card to the waste pile by clicking.  Two redeals.
•waste (under stock) - Top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Similar Games

Sir Tommy

Lady Betty

Strategy

Alternations

Alternations

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Very Hard (<1%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Fill spaces with any card or legal group of cards.   At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt to each pile, alternating face up and face down.
•stock (face down) - turn over cards one at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (below stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Alternations is a variation of Interchange.  It dates back to at least 1905.

Similar Games

Interchange

Unlimited

Breakwater

Forty-Nine

Unlimited Alternative

Amazons

Amazons

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck (with the 2's thru 6's and Kings removed).  Medium (40%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace, then Sevens to Queens.
•4 reserve piles (below foundations) - cards are dealt here from the stock.  The top card of each pile is available for play only on the foundation pile immediately above it (except for Aces, which are played to the first empty foundation pile).  Move cards to the foundations by clicking.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (face down) - deal 1 card to each reserve pile by clicking.  When a foundation pile is complete (built to a Queen) no more cards are dealt to the reserve pile immediately below it. Redeals are permitted until the game is won or no moves have been made in the last 2 deals.

History

Amazons is a short pack variation of Auld Lang Syne.

Similar Games

Auld Lang Syne

American Canister

American Canister

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (2%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color. Spaces may be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt to the first 4 piles, 6 cards are dealt to the last 4 piles.

Options

AutoPlay

History

American Canister is a variation of British Canister and Canister.  It is essentially FreeCell without cells and unlimited group moving.

Similar Games

Canister

British Canister

Scottish Canister

FreeCell

American Toad

American Toad

 Top  Previous  Next

Two Decks.  Easy (95%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (in middle) - Build up in suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - Build down in suit, wrapping from Ace to King as necessary.  Groups of cards may be moved as a unit if they are in sequence down in suit.  Spaces are filled from the reserve (when the reserve is empty, spaces may be filled from the waste, or when the waste is empty, by any card).  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•reserve Pile (top) - Top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 19 cards are dealt to the reserve.
•stock (top left, face down) - Turn over cards 1 at a time to the waste by clicking.  One redeal.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card is available for play.

Options

AutoPlay

History

American Toad is a two-pack variation of Canfield.

Similar Games

Canfield

Double Canfield

Anno Domini

Anno Domini

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (80%).  Skill/luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from the rank of the base card, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.  Each pile must be of a different suit.  The base card is determined by the current year.  Each card is one rank higher than the corresponding digit of the year, with zeros being represented by Tens.  For example, the year 2001 corresponds to the base cards 3, Jack, Jack, 2.  When all the cards have been played to the foundations, the final cards will then be 2, Ten, Ten, 1, representing the year.
•4 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time, by clicking.  Two redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card always available for play on the tableau or foundations.

History

Anno Domini is a modification of a century old game.

Similar Games

Assembly

Antares

Antares

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (95%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•4 cells (top left) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.

 

•8 tableau piles (below foundations and cells) - on the left most 4 piles (called the Scorpion piles), build down in suit.  Groups of cards (regardless of any sequence) can be moved.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.  On the rightmost 4 piles (called the FreeCell piles), build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color and if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.  Spaces can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt face up to the Scorpion piles, 7 cards are dealt face up to the FreeCell piles.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•The tableau piles are divided into two parts: the Scorpion piles (left) and the FreeCell piles (right), divided by a line.  The Scorpion piles are built down in suit while the FreeCell piles are built down by alternate color. Groups of cards may be moved from one tableau pile to another, if they form a legal sequence in their current pile.  For example, a sequence down by alternate color (if there are a sufficient number of empty cells available to store the cards individually) may be moved from the FreeCell piles to the Scorpion piles, since that is the legal sequence for the FreeCell piles.  Also, any group of cards may be moved from the Scorpion piles to the FreeCell piles (assuming the head card of the group can be moved there).   These kinds of groups transfers are called "shifts".  Shifts of groups down by alternate color are allowed from FreeCell piles to Scorpion piles, while shifts of any group of cards are allowed from Scorpion piles to FreeCell piles.  Once a shift has been made from Scorpion piles to FreeCell piles, the cards in the groups cannot again be moved as a group unless they are of sequence down by alternate color.  In short, the Scorpion piles have the same building rules as in the game Scorpion, and the FreeCell piles have the same building rules as in the game FreeCell.
•Groups of cards in the FreeCell piles of the tableau can only be moved as a group if there are a sufficient number of empty cells available to store the cards individually.  The ability to move cards as a group is only a shortcut to moving the group one card at a time.  In the Scorpion piles, groups of cards may be moved regardless of any sequence.

Tips

•Try to keep as many cells empty as possible.

History

Antares is a combination of the games Scorpion and FreeCell.  The tableau is divided into two parts as in the game Demons and Thieves.  Antares was invented by Thomas Warfield.  It is named after the brightest star in the constellation Scorpius.

Similar Games

Scorpion

FreeCell

Demons and Thieves

Shaula

Antique

Antique

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (70%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - build up regardless of suit from Ace to King.
•6 reserve piles (below foundations) - cards are dealt here from the stock.  The top card of each pile is available for play.  Move cards to the foundations by clicking.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (face down) - deal 1 card to each reserve pile by clicking.  Two redeals.

History

Antique is Old Fashioned with 2 redeals, or Acquaintance with 6 piles.  It was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Auld Lang Syne

Old Fashioned

Acquaintance

Anubis

Anubis

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (45%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To pair up all the cards in the deck in pairs of cards whose ranks total to 13.

Layout

•A Pyramid of 50 cards.  Only uncovered cards are available for play.  Discard pairs of cards whose ranks add to 13.  Kings are discarded singly.  To discard a pair, drop one card on the other, or right-click on one of the cards.
•stock (bottom left) - turn over one card to each of 3 waste piles by clicking.  Two redeals.
•3 waste piles (below stock) - The top card of each pile is available for pairing with uncovered cards in the pyramid or another top card of a waste pile.

Notes

•Any pair of cards whose values add to 13 can be discarded.  The valid pairs are Queen-Ace, Jack-Two, 10-3, 9-4, 8-5, 7-6.  Kings are discarded singly.  To discards Kings, simply click on them.

History

Anubis is Double Pyramid with 3 waste piles.

Similar Games

Pyramid

Double Pyramid

Apophis

Aphrodite

Aphrodite

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (75%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King. At the start of the game one row of cards is dealt face down, two rows of cards are dealt face up, and one more row face down.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 3 cards at a time to the waste by clicking during the first deal, 2 cards at a time during the 2nd deal, and 1 card at a time during the last deal.  Two redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Aphrodite is a variation of the game Athena.

Similar Games

Hera

Athena

Minerva

Klondike

Gold Rush

Apophis

Apophis

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (33%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To pair up all the cards in the deck in pairs of cards whose ranks total to 13.

Layout

•A Pyramid of 28 cards.  Only uncovered cards are available for play.  Discard pairs of cards whose ranks add to 13.  Kings are discarded singly.  To discard a pair, drop one card on the other, or right-click on one of the cards.
•stock (top left) - turn over one card to each of 3 waste piles by clicking.  Two redeals.
•3 waste piles (below stock) - The top card of each pile is available for pairing with uncovered cards in the pyramid or another top card of a waste pile.

Notes

•Any pair of cards whose values add to 13 can be discarded.  The valid pairs are Queen-Ace, Jack-Two, 10-3, 9-4, 8-5, 7-6.  Kings are discarded singly.  To discards Kings, simply click on them.

History

Apophis is Pyramid with 3 waste piles.

Similar Games

Pyramid

Double Pyramid

Anubis

Applegate

Applegate

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (12%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards into 4 sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace within the tableau.

Layout

•  7 tableau piles (top) - build down in suit, wrapping from Ace to King as necessary.  Groups of cards (regardless of any sequence) can be moved.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt to each pile.  In the first pile all of the cards are face up, in the rest of the piles 2 cards are face down and 5 cards are face up.

 

•3 reserve cards (left) - Each card is available for play on the tableau.  These cards cannot be replaced.

Notes

•Any face up card, regardless of where in a pile it is, can be moved, along with all cards above it (this is like Yukon).

History

Applegate is closely related to Scorpion.  It may be an older version of that game.

Similar Games

Scorpion

Scorpion Head

Suits in Line

Appreciate

Appreciate

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (5%).  Skill/Luck Balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (across top) - build first pile up by ones from the starting card dealt (for example: 4, 5, 6, etc), second pile up by twos from the starting card dealt (for example: 3, 5, 7, etc.), third pile up by threes from the starting card dealt (for example: 5, 8, J, etc.), and fourth pile up by fours from the starting card dealt (for example: 7, J, etc.). All building is regardless of suit, until the pile contains 13 cards.  The starting card for each pile will vary based on the 4 cards dealt at the start of the game.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) -   The top card of each pile is available for play.  Move cards to the foundations by clicking.  In the first (leftmost) two piles, building is down regardless of suit.  In the 2nd two piles, building is down by twos, regardless of suit.  In the 3rd two piles, building is down by threes, regardless of suit.  In the 4th (rightmost) two piles, building is down by fours, regardless of suit.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt face up to each pile.

History

Appreciate is a variation of One234 invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

One234

Calculation

Betsy Ross

Arabella

Arabella

 Top  Previous  Next

3 Decks.  Medium (85%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•12 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•13 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit.  Spaces can be filled only by a King or a group of cards headed by a King.   At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.

History

Arabella is a 3 deck variation of Lady Jane invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Lady Jane

Double Jane

Great Triangle

Pumpkin Spice

Aracnida

Aracnida

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Easy (98%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards in sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace.

Layout

•10 tableau piles - build down regardless of suit, or in the same rank.  Groups of cards in sequence down in suit (or of the same rank) may be moved as a unit (groups moved as a unit cannot contain both cards descending in sequence and multiple cards of the same rank at the same time).  A space can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 6 cards each are dealt to the first 4 piles, 5 cards each to the remaining piles.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.  All tableau piles must be filled before dealing.

Notes

•Whenever a sequence of 13 cards down in suit from King to Ace is formed, it will automatically be removed from play.

History

Aracnida is Spider with some elements of Curds and Whey.  It was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Spider

Curds and Whey

Rank Spider

Aragonese Patience

Aragonese Patience

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (90%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.

 

•11 tableau piles (left of foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces may be filled with any card.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt face up to each pile, except for the last 3 piles, which are dealt 4 cards.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Aragonese Patience is a variation of Spanish Patience.  It has two fewer tableau piles.

Similar Games

Spanish Patience

Baker's Dozen

Portuguese Solitaire

Castles in Spain

Good Measure

Archway

Archway

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks. Very Hard (<1%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (bottom left and right) - build the Aces up in suit to Kings, build the Kings down in suit to Aces.  At the start of the game an Ace and a King of each suit are dealt.
•4 tableau piles (middle) - top card is available for play on the foundations.  No building.  Spaces may be filled a single card.  At the start of the game 12 cards are dealt to each pile.
•13 reserve piles (left, top, right) - each pile contains cards of the same rank, starting from Aces and Twos in the lower left around to Queens and Kings on the lower right.  The top card of each pile is available for play on the foundations, and all cards are available.  Right  click on the pile to cycle through all the cards in the pile.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

• Cards may be moved between Foundations when the Foundations of the same suit meet.
•Play consists entirely of moving cards to the Foundations.

Tips

• Since the cards in the reserve are always available, you should play to remove as many cards from the tableau piles as possible.

History

Archway is an open version of the game Lady of the Manor.  It was invented by David Parlett.

Similar Games

Lady of the Manor

Arizona

Arizona

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (90%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - build the piles up in suit from Ace to King.
•6 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Groups of cards may be moved as a unit if they are in sequence down regardless of suit.  Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt to each pile.
•16 reserve piles (left and right) - each pile contains 1 card, available for play on the foundations or tableau.  Spaces are not filled.

Options

AutoPlay

Similar Games

Phoenix

FreeCell

Kleine Napoleon

Arsenal

Arsenal

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (2%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Twos to Kings, then Aces.
•4 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color, wrapping from Ace to King as necessary.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces are filled from the first reserve, then the second reserve, then by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time, by clicking.  2 redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card always available for play on the tableau or foundations.

 

•2 reserves (left of tableau) - Top card always available for play on the tableau or foundations.  At the start of the game 13 cards are dealt to each pile.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Arsenal is a variation of Canfield.

Similar Games

Canfield

Storehouse

Assembly

Layout

•4 foundation piles (across top) - build up regardless of suit from Ace to King.
•4 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Groups of cards cannot be moved.  Spaces can be filled from the waste.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time, by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card always available for play on the tableau or foundations.

Assembly Rush

Assembly Rush

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck. Easy (98%).  Skill/luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (across top) - build up regardless of suit from Ace to King.
•4 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Groups of cards cannot be moved.  Spaces can be filled from the waste.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 3 cards at a time to the waste by clicking during the first deal, 2 cards at a time during the 2nd deal, and 1 card at a time during the last deal.  Two redeals.
•
•waste (next to stock) - Top card always available for play on the tableau or foundations.

Athena

Athena

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (50%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King. (See KingOnly for option).  At the start of the game a row of cards is dealt face down, another face up, another face down, and finally a row face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 or 3 cards (see rules below) at a time, by clicking.  Unlimited redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

Rules - selects whether 1 card or 3 cards at a time are turned over from the stock. (See Options menu)

KingOnly   AutoPlay

History

Athena is Klondike with a different opening tableau layout.

Similar Games

Minerva

Klondike

Hera

Attraction

Attraction

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (15%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit.  Fill spaces with Kings or a legal group of cards headed by a King (see KingOnly option).  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd pile, and so on.
•2 fans (top, stacked horizontally) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•reserve (Far left, under leftmost fan) - Any card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.  To play a buried card, click on it to move it to the top of the pile.  Then move the card to its destination. At the start of the game 12 cards are dealt face up to this pile.

Options

AutoPlay

KingOnly

History

Attraction is a variation of Fascination.  It was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Fascination

Wildflower

Auld Lang Syne

Auld Lang Syne

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Hard (<0.1%).  All Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - build up regardless of suit from Ace to King.  At the start of the game the Aces are dealt here.
•4 reserve piles (below foundations) - cards are dealt here from the stock.  The top card of each pile is available for play.  Move cards to the foundations by clicking.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (face down) - deal 1 card to each reserve pile by clicking.  No redeals.

History

This is an old and classic solitaire game.  It is also known as Patience.  It is difficult to win and involves no skill. Sir Tommy is a variation of this game that is easier to win and involves some skill.

Similar Games

Acquaintance

Acquaintance One

Sir Tommy

Lady Betty

Tam O'Shanter

Leap Year

Quadrennial

Cup of Kindness

River Doon

Old Fashioned

Reveillion

Aunt Mary

Aunt Mary

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (1%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•6 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King. At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt to each pile, 6 face up in the first pile, 5 in the 2nd, and so on.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time, by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Aunt Mary is a variation of Klondike.

Similar Games

Klondike

Australian Patience

Australian Patience

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (20%).  Skill/Luck Balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - Build down in suit.  Groups of cards may be moved regardless of sequence. Spaces filled by Kings or groups of cards headed by a King. At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile.

 

•stock (top left) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste pile by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Australian Patience is a variation of Klondike that was sent to the author by a Pretty Good Solitaire player in Australia.

Similar Games

Brisbane

Klondike

Yukon

Outback

Darwin

Canberra

Tasmanian Patience

Hawaiian Solitaire

Double Australian

Australian Spider

Australian Spider

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (25%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards into 4 sets of 13 cards in sequence down by alternate color from King to Ace.

Layout

•7 tableau piles  - build down regardless of suit.  Move groups of cards regardless of any sequence.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.   At the start of the game 1 card is dealt the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd pile, and so on.  The top card is face up.  Then 4 additional face up cards are dealt to the 2nd through 7th piles.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Any face up card in the tableau may be built upon another, no matter how deep it is in a pile.  All cards covering it are moved together.  When a face down card is uncovered, it is automatically turned face up and is available for play.

History

Australian Spider is an easier variation of Yukon Spider.

Similar Games

Yukon Spider

Yukon

Yukon Kings

Backbone

Backbone

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (2%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top, each side) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved. Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•2 reserve piles (the backbone) - no building.  Top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 11 cards are dealt to each pile and another card is placed on top of both piles.
•stock (bottom center, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Backbone is a game of Victorian origin.

BakerCell

BakerCell

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (15%).  Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•4 cells (top left) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.  The card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each cell.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations and cells) -  build down in suit.  The top card is available for play on the foundations, cells, or another tableau pile.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit and if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.  Fill spaces with any available card.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt face up to each pile.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Note that groups of cards in the tableau can only be moved as a group if there are a sufficient number of empty cells available to store the cards individually.  The ability to move cards as a group is only a shortcut to moving the group one card at a time.
•BakerCell is identical to FreeCell except that the tableau is built down in suit rather than down by alternate color and cards are dealt to the cells at the start of the game.  This makes BakerCell more challenging.

 

•The game number deals #1 to #1000000 are compatible with the games in the standard Windows FreeCell.  For more information about FreeCell type games, see http://www.freecell.org.

Tips

•Try to keep as many cells empty as possible.

History

BakerCell is a more difficult variation of Baker's Game.

Similar Games

Baker's Game

FreeCell

ForeCell

Sea Towers

Eight Off

Baker's Dozen

Baker's Dozen

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (95%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•13 tableau piles (left of foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are not filled.  At the start of the game 4 cards each are dealt to each pile.  Kings are moved to the bottom of the piles in the deal.

Options

AutoPlay

Tips

•Don't let one foundation get too far ahead of the others.
•Watch for piles that contain a lower card of a suit below a higher card of the same suit.

History

This is a game of skill, related to Beleaguered Castle and Martha.

Similar Games

Portuguese Solitaire

Good Measure

Spanish Patience

Castles in Spain

Martha

Castles End

Vineyard

Catalan

Baker's Score

Baker's Game

Baker's Game

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (30%).  Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•4 cells (top left) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.  The card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations and cells) - The entire deck is dealt to these 8 piles (7 cards to the first 4 piles, 6 cards to the next 4 piles) .  The piles are built down in suit.  The top card is available for play on the foundations, cells, or another tableau pile.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit and if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.  Fill spaces with any available card (see KingOnly for option).

Options

KingOnly   AutoPlay

Notes

•Note that groups of cards in the tableau can only be moved as a group if there are a sufficient number of empty cells available to store the cards individually.  The ability to move cards as a group is only a shortcut to moving the group one card at a time.
•Baker's Game is identical to FreeCell except that the tableau is built down in suit rather than down by alternate color.  This makes Baker's Game more challenging.
•The game number deals #1 to #1000000 are compatible with the games in the standard Windows FreeCell.  For more information about FreeCell type games, see http://www.freecell.org.

Tips

•Try to keep as many cells empty as possible.

History

Baker's Game is the original game from which FreeCell and all its variations came.  It is named after the mathematician C.L. Baker.

Similar Games

FreeCell

ForeCell

Sea Towers

Eight Off

BakerCell

Eighty-Six

Baker's Score

Baker's Score

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (99%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•21 tableau piles (left of foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are not filled.  At the start of the game 5 cards each are dealt to each pile, except for the last pile which is dealt 4 cards.  Kings are moved to the bottom of the piles in the deal.

Options

AutoPlay

Tips

•Don't let one foundation get too far ahead of the others.
•Watch for piles that contain a lower card of a suit below a higher card of the same suit.

History

This is a 2 deck version of Baker's Dozen.

Similar Games

Baker's Dozen

Portuguese Solitaire

Good Measure

Spanish Patience

Balcony

Balcony

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (90%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up by alternate color from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Only the top card of each pile may be moved.  Spaces are filled automatically from the stock, or waste if the stock is empty.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•reserve (left) - top card is available for play on the foundations only. At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt here.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over cards 1 at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Balcony is a one deck variation of Terrace.  It was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Terrace

Blondes and Brunettes

Bald Eagle

Bald Eagle

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (90%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•8 tableau piles (the wings) - build down in suit, limit of 3 cards per pile, wrapping from Ace to King as necessary.  Groups of cards may be moved as a unit if they are in sequence down in suit.  Spaces are filled from the reserve until it is empty, then by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•reserve (middle) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 17 cards are dealt to this pile.
•stock (face down, bottom left) - turn over 3 cards at a time to the waste by clicking during the first deal, 2 cards at a time during the 2nd deal, and 1 card at a time during the last deal.  Two redeals.

 

•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Similar Games

Eagle Wing

Wings

Bandit

Bandit

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (15%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•9 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Only the top card of each pile may be moved.  Spaces filled by any card.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste pile by clicking.   No redeals.

 

•3 waste piles (next to stock) - top card of each pile is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

 

Options

AutoPlay

History

Bandit is a variation of Maria with 3 waste piles invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Maria

Three Pirates

Midshipman

Forty Thieves

Barcelona

Barcelona

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (80%).  Mostly Skill.

 

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.

 

•14 tableau piles (left of foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces may be filled only by a King.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to 13 piles and one pile is empty.

Options

AutoPlay

History

This is a variation of Catalan.

Similar Games

Catalan

Castles in Spain

Baker's Dozen

Barney's Spider

Barney's Spider

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (80%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Move groups of cards only if they are in sequence down in suit.  Fill spaces with any card.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (bottom left, face down) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Barney's Spider is a harder variation of Fred's Spider.

Similar Games

Fred's Spider

Barricade

Barricade

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Very Hard (1%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•14 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color. Only one card may be moved at a time. Spaces are filled automatically from the stock, unless the stock is empty, then spaces can be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 2 cards are dealt face up to each pile, any card dealt that can be moved to the foundations is moved immediately.
•stock (face down, top left) - fills spaces in the tableau only .

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

The only way to bring new cards into the game is to create spaces in the tableau.  The game is very easily blocked.

History

Barricade is an easier version of Block, with rules modifications suggested by Richard Mechen and Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Block

Blockade

Bastille Day

Bastille Day

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (25%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (middle row) - build up in suit from Aces to Kings.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Groups of cards in sequence down by alternate color may be moved as a unit.  Spaces are filled by any card.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile, the top card face up.
•reserve (top right) - top card is available for play on the foundations and tableau. At the start of the game 9 cards are dealt here.
•stock (top far left, face down) - turn over cards 1 at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations and tableau.
•The Bastille (face down, next to waste) - after the reserve is empty, turn over cards 1 at a time by clicking.  The top turned over card is available for play on the foundations and tableau. During the initial deal, 4 cards are dealt face down to the Bastille, then the 8 Kings are dealt face down on top of the 4 cards.

Options

AutoPlay

Similar Games

Terrace

Bastion

Bastion

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (80%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build up or down by suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved (unless there are empty cells or tableau piles, see the notes).  Spaces may be filled by any available card.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•2 cells (top left) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each cell.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Groups of cards in the tableau can only be moved as a group if there are a sufficient number of empty cells or tableau piles available to store the cards individually.  The ability to move cards as a group is only a shortcut to moving the group one card at a time.

History

Bastion is a variation of Fortress.  It is just like Fortress except for the additional cells.  The cells make Bastion easier to win than Fortress.

Similar Games

Fortress

Beleaguered Castle

Streets and Alleys

Citadel

Chessboard

Ten By One

Fortress Moat

Bataillion Carre

Bataillion Carre

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (5%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.  At the start of the game the Aces are dealt here.
•12 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color. Only one card at a time may be moved. Spaces can be filled only by Kings.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt face up to each pile.  As the cards are dealt, any cards that can be moved to the foundations are moved there (and not replaced).
•stock (face down, top left) - move one card to waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (beside stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Bataillion Carre is an easier version of Carre Napoleon.

Similar Games

Carre Napoleon

Napoleon's Square

Forty Thieves

Bath

Bath

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (40%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Aces to Kings.
•10 tableau piles - build down by alternate color.  Only one card at a time may be moved (however, the game will allow you to move 2 or 3 cards as a group as a shortcut if there are empty cells available).  Spaces can be filled only with a King.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on, until the the 9th and 10th piles, which are dealt 8 cards each.
•2 cells (top left) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.

History

Bath is a variation of Somerset.

Similar Games

Somerset

Batsford

Batsford

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (8%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Groups of cards in sequence down by alternate color may be moved as a unit.  Spaces are filled only by Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.  The top card is turned face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play.
•reserve (bottom left) - Storage location for Kings.  Up to 3 Kings may be placed here.  The top King is available for play.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•When a King becomes available and there is no empty tableau pile for it, it may be placed on the Reserve for storage until needed.  Up to 3 Kings may be placed in the Reserve at any one time.

History

Batsford is a variation of Gargantua.

Similar Games

Batsford Again

Batsford Rush

Gargantua

Double Klondike

Batsford Again

Batsford Again

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Easy (99%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Groups of cards in sequence down by alternate color may be moved as a unit.  Spaces are filled only by Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.  The top card is turned face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card to the waste by clicking.  One redeal.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play.
•reserve (bottom left) - Storage location for Kings.  Up to 3 Kings may be placed here.  The top King is available for play.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•When a King becomes available and there is no empty tableau pile for it, it may be placed on the Reserve for storage until needed.  Up to 3 Kings may be placed in the Reserve at any one time.

History

Batsford Again is a variation of Batsford with a redeal.

Similar Games

Batsford

Batsford Rush

Gargantua

Double Klondike

Batsford Rush

Batsford Rush

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (25%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Groups of cards in sequence down by alternate color may be moved as a unit.  Spaces are filled only by Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.  The top card is turned face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 3 cards at a time to the waste by clicking during the first deal, 2 cards at a time during the 2nd deal, and 1 card at a time during the last deal.  Two redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play.
•reserve (bottom left) - Storage location for Kings.  Up to 3 Kings may be placed here.  The top King is available for play.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•When a King becomes available and there is no empty tableau pile for it, it may be placed on the Reserve for storage until needed.  Up to 3 Kings may be placed in the Reserve at any one time.

History

Batsford Rush is a variation of Batsford.

Similar Games

Batsford

Batsford Again

Gargantua

Double Klondike

Bavarian Patience

Bavarian Patience

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (17%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To create 8 piles in ascending sequence of 13 cards, regardless of suit, in the tableau.

Layout

•10 tableau piles (across top) - build up regardless of suit, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until 8 piles contain 13 cards.   Only the top card of each pile may be moved.   At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to the first 8 piles.
•stock (face down, bottom left) - turns over 1 card to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the tableau.

History

Bavarian Patience is a variation of German Patience.  The two extra tableau piles makes it somewhat easier to win.  It was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

German Patience

Bedeviled

Bedeviled

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.   Hard (20%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build left 4 piles up in color from Ace to King (2 leftmost with red X's start with red Aces, next 2 in green with black Aces), drop entire 13 card sequences down by alternate color from the tableau on the right 4 piles (2 starting with red X's with red Kings, 2 rightmost in green with black Kings).
