•9 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Groups of cards in sequence down by alternate color may be moved as a unit.  Spaces are filled only by Kings or legal groups of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 9 cards are dealt to the first pile, 8 cards to the 2nd pile, and so on until 1 card is dealt to the 9th piles.  The top card of each pile is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - move 1 card to waste by clicking.  One redeal.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Notes

•The first 4 foundations are built up card by card as is normal, but the right 4 foundations are built in the tableau.  When an entire 13 card sequence from King to Ace is built, it can be dropped on the right 4 foundations.

 

•There is no AutoPlay in this game, so all cards must be moved by dragging or right-clicking on the card.

Tips

•Keep in mind at all times that you are not only trying to build on the left 4 foundations up in color, but also you must build 4 complete 13-card sequences down by alternate color, much like they are built in Spider.  Whether to move a card to the 4 left foundations or to keep it in the tableau for building one of the sequences is a choice you are faced with often.

History

Bedeviled is a variation of Diavolo.

Similar Games

Rouge et Noir

Diavolo

Beetle

Beetle

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (80%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards in sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace within the tableau.

 

Layout

•10 tableau piles - build down regardless of suit.  Groups of cards in sequence down by suit may be moved as a unit.  A space can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt to the first 4 piles, and 4 cards to the remaining piles.  All of the cards are face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.

Notes

•Groups of cards not of the same suit cannot be moved.

 

History

Beetle is a variation of Spider where all the cards are face up.

Similar Games

Spider

Black Widow

Brown Recluse

Beleaguered Castle

Beleaguered Castle

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (25%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (middle) - build up in suit from Ace to King.  At the start of the game the Aces are dealt here.
•8 tableau piles (around foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Only the top card of each pile is available for play.  Spaces may be filled by any available card.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt face up to each pile.

Options

AutoPlay

Tips

•Don't let one foundation get too far ahead of the others
•Try to create a space as quickly as possible.

History

This is a game of skill, related to Baker's Dozen and Martha.

Similar Games

Selective Castle

Fortress

Streets and Alleys

Stronghold

Citadel

Chessboard

Bastion

Bell Towers

Bell Towers

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (90%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•6 tableau piles  - build down by color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by color and if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.  Fill spaces with any card.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•Middle Tower (face down, in middle of tableau) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.  No building, spaces cannot be filled. At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt here, the top card is face up.
•Bell Towers (left and right) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.  No building, spaces cannot be filled.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile, the top card is face up.
•4 free cells (top left) - Storage cells for 1 card each.  No building. The card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Bell Towers is a variation of Towers.  It was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Towers

FreeCell

Betsy Ross

Betsy Ross

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (20%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 Place cards (across top) - An Ace, Two, Three, and Four form a row across the top.  These cards serve only to tell how the foundations below them are built.  No building on these cards.
•4 foundations (below Place cards) - build first pile up regardless of suit by ones, second pile up regardless of suit by twos, third pile up regardless of suit by threes, and fourth pile up regardless of suit by fours.  See chart below.

 

1:  2 3 4 5 6 7 8 9 T J Q K

2:  4 6 8 T Q A 3 5 7 9 J K

3:  6 9 Q 2 5 8 J A 4 7 T K

  4:  8 Q 3 7 J 2 6 T A 5 9 K

•stock (face down) - Turn over cards 1 at a time to the waste pile by clicking.  Two redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card is available for play on the foundations.

History

Betsy Ross is a variation of Calculation.  It is also known as Four Kings, Musical Patience, Fairest, Plus Belle, and Quadruple Alliance.

Similar Games

Calculation

One234

Numeration

Big Apple

Big Apple

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks. Hard (4%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit.  Spaces may be filled by any card from the stock or cells.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left, face up) - top card is available for play on the foundations, tableau, or cells.  No redeals.
•3 cells (below stock) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Big Apple is a variation of New York.

Similar Games

New York

Gotham

Big Bertha

Big Bertha

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Easy (98%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations and King pile.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (left) - build up in suit from Ace to Queen.
•15 tableau piles (center) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.   Spaces are filled by any card or legal group of cards.   At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•King pile (right of bottom tableau row) - Kings are moved here as soon as they become available (Kings are not moved to the regular foundations.
•14 reserve cards (on right) - each card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.

Options

AutoPlay

Similar Games

King Albert

Big Dozen

Big Dozen

 Top  Previous  Next

3 Decks.  Easy (90%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•12 foundation piles (left and right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•12 cells (across top) - storage locations for cards.  Build down by alternate color.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt face up to each pile, only the top card is visible.

 

•12 tableau piles (below cells) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color and if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.  Spaces can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.   At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt to each pile, only the top card face up.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Groups of cards in the tableau can only be moved as a group if there are a sufficient number of empty cells available to store the cards individually.  The ability to move cards as a group is only a shortcut to moving the group one card at a time.

History

Big Dozen is a 3 deck FreeCell type game invented by Thomas Warfield.

Big Forty

Big Forty

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (45%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Groups of cards in descending sequence down in suit may be moved as a unit. Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  Unlimited redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Similar Games

Ali Baba

Forty Thieves

Big Harp

Big Harp

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (60%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.   Spaces are filled by a King or a group of cards headed with a King.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 to the 2nd, and so on.  All cards are face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 3 cards to the waste by clicking.  2 redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Big Harp is a variation of Harp and Klondike.

Similar Games

Harp

Endless Harp

Klondike

Gargantua

Double Klondike

Eternal Triangle

Lyre

Big Spider

Big Spider

 Top  Previous  Next

3 Decks.  Medium (85%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards in sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace.

Layout

•13 tableau piles - build down regardless of suit.  Groups of cards in sequence down in suit may be moved as a unit.  A space can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt to each pile.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.  All tableau piles must be filled before dealing.

Notes

•Whenever a sequence of 13 cards down in suit from King to Ace is formed, it will automatically be removed from play.

Tips

•Same suit sequences should be preferred even though building is down regardless of suit.  The object is to build down in suit sequences.
•Spaces should be made as soon as possible, and used to move cards into groups by suit.

History

Big Spider is a 3 deck version of the classic 2 deck Spider.

Similar Games

Spider

Big Spider One Suit

Big Spider Two Suits

Huge Spider

Big Spider One Suit

Big Spider One Suit

 Top  Previous  Next

3 Modified Decks (only Spades).  Very Easy (99%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards in sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace.

Layout

•13 tableau piles - build down in suit.  Groups of cards in sequence down in suit may be moved as a unit.  A space can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt to each pile.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.  All tableau piles must be filled before dealing.

Notes

•Whenever a sequence of 13 cards down in suit from King to Ace is formed, it will automatically be removed from play.

Tips

•Spaces should be made as soon as possible, and used to move cards into groups by suit.

History

Big Spider One Suit is Big Spider with only Spades.

Similar Games

Big Spider

Big Spider Two Suits

Spider

Big Spider Two Suits

Big Spider Two Suits

 Top  Previous  Next

3 Modified Decks (only Hearts and Spades).  Easy (90%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards in sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace.

Layout

•13 tableau piles - build down regardless of suit.  Groups of cards in sequence down in suit may be moved as a unit.  A space can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt to each pile.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.  All tableau piles must be filled before dealing.

Notes

•Whenever a sequence of 13 cards down in suit from King to Ace is formed, it will automatically be removed from play.

Tips

•Same suit sequences should be preferred even though building is down regardless of suit.  The object is to build down in suit sequences.
•Spaces should be made as soon as possible, and used to move cards into groups by suit.

History

Spider Two Suits is Big Spider with only Hearts and Spades.

Similar Games

Big Spider

Spider

Binary Star

Binary Star

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (5%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the two center piles, the Binary Star.

Layout

•2 Stars (center piles) - begin with the Ace ♠ and the King ♥, build up or down regardless of suit, with Ace and King considered consecutive.  Cards may be moved from one star to the other.
•17 Fans  - the top card is available for play to the Stars.  No building.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt to each pile.

Notes

•It does not matter how many cards are in each Star, as long as all of the cards have been moved to one or the other.

Tips

•Advance calculation of the cards you need to play is required.

History

Binary Star is a 2 deck variation of David Parlett's game Black Hole.  Binary Star was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Black Hole

Bisley

Bisley

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (25%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (right) - build the left column up in suit starting with Aces, build the right column down in suit starting with Kings.  It does not matter where the two piles of the same suit meet.  At the start of the game an Ace of each suit is dealt to the left column.
• 12 tableau piles (left of foundations) - build up or down by suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are not filled.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt face up to each pile.

Options

AutoPlay

Similar Games

Double Bisley

Indefatigable

Royal Family

Janet's Bisley

Bitter Fan

Bitter Fan

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck. Medium (60%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•13 tableau piles  - build down in suit.  Groups of cards can be moved if they are in sequence down in suit.  Spaces are filled by Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile.
•stock (left, no cards) - clicking on the stock collects all the cards from the tableau and redeals them.  Two redeals.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•When play on the tableau comes to a standstill, the tableau can be redealt by clicking on the stock.  The cards are collected from the tableau starting with the last pile (lower right) of the tableau back to the first pile (top left), with the cards from the last pile on the bottom.  They are then redealt 4 cards to a pile starting with the first pile.
•Because of the way the cards are redealt, if no moves are made in the tableau the cards will be redealt back exactly the same way they were previously.  Therefore, after every deal you must be able to make at least one move in the tableau or the game is lost.  Also, some moves may not affect the order of the redeal.

Similar Games

Ripple Fan

Cruel

Black Hole

Black Hole

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (80%).  All Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the center pile, the Black Hole.

Layout

•Black Hole (center pile) - begins with the Ace ♠, build up or down regardless of suit, with Ace and King considered consecutive.
•17 Fans  - the top card is available for play to the Black Hole.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt to each pile.

Tips

•Black Hole is easy to play, but requires a great deal of advance calculation to win.  Map out the cards you wish to play to the Black Hole before you play them.

History

Black Hole was invented by David Parlett.

Similar Games

Binary Star

Four Leaf Clovers

All in a Row

Black Widow

Black Widow

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Easy  (90%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards in sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace within the tableau.

Layout

•10 tableau piles - build down regardless of suit.  Groups of cards in sequence down regardless of suit may be moved as a unit.  A space can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt to the first 4 piles, and 5 cards to the remaining piles.  Only the top card is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.  All tableau piles must have at least one card in them before you can do this.

Notes

•  The objective is to group all the cards in sets of 13 cards, from King to Ace down in suit.  Whenever such a group is formed in a pile, it is automatically removed from play.
•  When the stock is empty and you are unable to form the tableaus into sets of 13 cards of each suit, the game is lost.

History

Black Widow is a variation of the classic game Spider.  The difference between Spider and Black Widow is that in Spider only groups of cards down in suit may be moved, while in Black Widow any group in sequence down regardless of suit may be moved.

Similar Games

Spider

Spider One Suit

Tarantula - Spider Two Suits

Jumping Spider

Blind Alleys

Blind Alleys

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (92%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•6 tableau piles (below foundations) - Build down by alternate color.  Groups of cards may be moved if they form a sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces filled by any card.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt to each pile, 2 face down and 1 face up.
•stock (top left) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste pile by clicking.  One redeal.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

History

Blind Alleys is similar to Pas Seul.

Similar Games

Pas Seul

Easthaven

Double Easthaven

Stalemate

Blind FreeCell

Blind FreeCell

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (90%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•4 cells (top left) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.

 

•8 tableau piles (below foundations and cells) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color and if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.  Spaces can be filled by a King or group of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt face to the each pile, the top card is face up.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Groups of cards in the tableau can only be moved as a group if there are a sufficient number of empty cells available to store the cards individually.  The ability to move cards as a group is only a shortcut to moving the group one card at a time.

Tips

•Try to keep as many cells empty as possible.

History

Blind FreeCell is a non-open version of FreeCell, where all the cards except the top row are face down.  More accurately, it is related to ForeCell, since 4 cards are also dealt to the cells.

Similar Games

FreeCell

ForeCell

Blind Patience

Blind Patience

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (16%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Only one card at a time may be moved. Spaces may be filled by any card.  Also, any card may be played on a face down card. Face down cards are turned face up by clicking on them.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt face down to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Tips

•Try to get a space in the tableau as quickly as possible.

History

Blind Patience is a unique variation of Forty Thieves.

Similar Games

Forty Thieves

Block

Block

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Very Hard (<<1%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•12 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit. Only one card may be moved at a time. Spaces are filled automatically from the stock, unless the stock is empty, then spaces can be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 2 cards are dealt face up to each pile, any card dealt that can be moved to the foundations is moved immediately.
•stock (face down, top left) - fills spaces in the tableau only .

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

The only way to bring new cards into the game is to create spaces in the tableau.  The game is very easily blocked, hence the name.

History

Block is a variation of Blockade.  See Barricade for an easier variation.

Similar Games

Barricade

Blockade

Block Eleven

Block Eleven

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Hard (2%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To play all of the cards to the tableau.

Layout

•stock (face up, left) - play cards to the tableau.
•16 tableau piles - play cards from the stock - play cards that have ranks that add to 11 (Ace-10, 2-9, 3-8, 4-7, 6-5).  Jacks, Queens, and Kings can be played on any card of rank Ten or less (that is, not a Jack, Queen or King).  Once a Jack, Queen, or King is played on a pile, it blocks any further play on that pile.   At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.

Notes

You can play as many cards to a tableau pile as you like (putting cards on other cards so that the ranks add to 11), but once a Jack, Queen, or King is played to a pile, no more cards can be played to that pile.

Block Ten

Block Ten

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (5%).  All Luck.

Object

To discard all the cards in pairs.

Layout

•9 tableau piles - the top card is available for play.  Pair up cards that have ranks that add to 10 (Ace-9, 2-8, 3-7, 4-6, 5-5).  Jacks, Queens, and Kings are paired together (J-J, Q-Q, K-K).  Tens cannot be paired and block any further play.  Spaces are automatically filled from the stock.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (face down, left) - fills spaces in the tableau.
•waste (far right)  - Where paired cards go out of play.

History

Block Ten is a variation of Simple Pairs.  Since when Tens appear they reduce the number of available piles, it is difficult to win.

Similar Games

Simple Pairs

Blockade

Blockade

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Easy (85%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•12 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit. Groups of cards in sequence down in suit may be moved as a unit. Spaces are filled automatically from the stock, unless the stock is empty, then spaces can be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (face down, top left) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.  No redeals.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Blockade is a variation of Napoleon's Square.

Similar Games

Block

Napoleon's Square

Carre Napoleon

Blondes and Brunettes

Blondes and Brunettes

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (30%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (middle) - build up by alternate color from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•9 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Only the top card of each pile may be moved.  Spaces are filled automatically from the stock, or waste if the stock is empty.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•reserve (top) - top card is available for play on the foundations only. At the start of the game 10 cards are dealt here.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over cards 1 at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Blondes and Brunettes is a variation of Terrace.

Similar Games

Signora

Falling Star

Wood

Terrace

Redheads

General's Patience

Empress of Italy

Bloody Mary

Bloody Mary

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (20%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit.  Fill spaces with any card. At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 3 cards at a time to the waste by clicking.  One redeal.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.

History

Bloody Mary is a hard variation of Lady Jane invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Lady Jane

Double Jane

Arabella

Inquisitor

Quizzie

Guildford

Blue Jacket

Blue Jacket

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (15%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•Twos foundations (first row),  Threes foundations (second row), Fours foundations (third row) - Build up in suit by threes.  Two piles (top row) are built  2, 5, 8, Jack, Three piles (second row) are built 3, 6, 9, Queen, Four piles (third row) are built 4, 7, 10, King.   An empty space can only be filled by a Two (top row), a Three (second row), or a Four (third row).   All spaces in any row must be filled prior to the next deal from the stock.  Top card only is available for play.  At the beginning of the game a Two, Three, and Four of different suits are dealt to the first pile of each row, then one card is dealt to each of the remaining piles.
•A Two, Three, or Four outside its proper row may be interchanged with another Two, Three, or Four outside its proper row if by interchanging them they are moved to their proper rows (To interchange cards, just drop one on the other).
•Ace foundation (left) - build Aces only until the pile contains all 8 Aces.
•8 reserve piles (bottom row) - top card is available for play on any of the foundations. No building.  Spaces can be filled by any card.
•stock (top left, face down) - Deals 1 card to each reserve pile, only when all of the Two, Three, and Four foundation piles are filled.  No redeals.

Notes

•The objective is to get all Twos to start piles in the top row, all Threes to start piles in the second row, and all Fours to start piles in the third row.
•Once a Two, Three, or Four is placed in its proper row, you can build up in suit by threes on it, at the end each pile will contain 4 cards.   Aces are removed and placed in the Ace pile.
•The catch is that any space in the 3 foundation rows must be filled before you can deal out another set of cards to the reserve.  This means that before you can move any card in a foundation row to another foundation pile, you must have a Two, Three, or Four (depending on the row) available to move into the created space.  When all the cards in the stock have been dealt out, spaces are no longer an issue.
•Aces in the reserve can be immediately played to the Ace foundation.  Aces in the foundation rows can be moved when there is a Two, Three, or Four (depending on the row) available to fill the space.  It is useful to hold Aces in the foundation rows as long as possible so as to be available later when a Two, Three, or Four becomes available.
•Spaces in the reserve can filled by any card, but you must remember that if you take a card from the Two, Three, or Four rows those spaces must be filled before the next deal.

History

Blue Jacket is Virginia Reel with the ability to play any card to spaces in the reserve.

Similar Games

Virginia Reel

Royal Parade

Three Up

Bobby

Bobby

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (<1%).  All Luck.

Object

Move all cards to the foundation piles.

Layout

•2 foundation piles (top) - build up or down regardless of suit, wrapping from Ace to King if necessary.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile.  Any card can be played to start the other pile.
•stock (face down) - turn over 1 card to the waste by clicking.  Two redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundation.

History

Bobby is a variation of Robert.

Similar Games

Robert

Bonanza Creek

Bonanza Creek

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (50%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Move groups of cards regardless of any sequence.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.   At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to the first pile, 1 card face down and 2 face up to the 2nd pile, 1 card face down and 5 face up to the 3rd and 4th piles, 2 cards face down and 4 face up to the 5th and 6th piles, 3 cards face down and 3 face up to the 7th and 8th piles, and 4 cards face down and 2 face up to the 9th and 10th piles.

 

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Any card in the tableau may be built upon another, no matter how deep it is in a pile.  All cards covering it are moved together.

History

Bonanza Creek is a Yukon type game, it is Russian Solitaire with more piles.  It was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Yukon

Russian Solitaire

Bonmaison

Bonmaison

 Top  Previous  Next

4 Decks. Easy (90%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•16 foundation piles (across top, left, right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.   Groups of cards can be moved if they are in sequence down in suit.  Spaces filled by any card.  At the start of the game 8 cards are dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  2 redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Bonmaison is an easier version of Rueil and Malmaison suggested by Richard Mechen.

Similar Games

Rueil

Malmaison

Josephine

Marie Rose

Eighty Thieves

Book Scorpion

Book Scorpion

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (20%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards into 4 sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace within the tableau.

Layout

•6 tableau piles (top) - build down in suit.  Groups of cards (regardless of any sequence) can be moved.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 8 cards are dealt to each pile.  In the first 4 piles, 3 cards are face down and 5 face up, in the next 2 piles all cards are face up.

 

•reserve (top left, face down) - Clicking deals 1 card to each of the first 4 tableau piles (this can be done only once).

Options

KingOnly

Notes

•Any face up card, regardless of where in a pile it is, can be moved, along with all cards above it (this is like Yukon).

Tips

•It is imperative that the face down cards be uncovered as soon as possible.  There are often several choices of builds to make and it is beneficial to work through possibilities.  This is very much a game of skill, and it is difficult.

History

Book Scorpion is a more difficult version of the game Scorpion.

Similar Games

Scorpion

Scorpion II

Boots

Boots

 Top  Previous  Next

2 separate decks.  Medium (70%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (center top) - build up in suit from Aces to Kings.
•6 Left tableau piles (below foundations, on left) - On the left part, build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards regardless of sequence.  Fill spaces with Kings (or groups of cards headed by a King). At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face down to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.  Then 5 face up cards are dealt to each pile.
•7 Right tableau piles (below foundations, on right) - build down by alternate color.  Groups of cards can be moved if they are in sequence down by alternate color.   Fill spaces with Kings (or groups of cards headed by a King).  At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•4 cells (top left and right) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.  At the start of the game one card is dealt face up to each cell.

 

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Boots starts with 2 separate decks.  The first deck is dealt to the Left tableau with one card remaining dealt to the first cell, the other deck is dealt to the Right tableau with 3 cards dealt to the remaining cells.

History

Boots is a variation of Prince Serg invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Prince Serg

Boudoir

Boudoir

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks. Hard (1%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards except one set of Queens and one set of Jacks to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top and bottom) - build up in suit from Aces to Kings on the 4 piles at the top, build down in suit from Tens to Aces to Kings on the 4 piles at the bottom.  Start with 4 Aces of different suits and 4 Tens of different suits.
•4 Queens (one of each suit) - dealt at the start of the game, are not used.
•4 reserve piles (below Queens) - place one Jack of each suit on these piles.  Be sure not to place two Jacks of one suit on these piles, as you will then not be able to win the game.
•stock (left, face down) - turn over 1 card to waste by clicking.  2 redeals.
•waste (below stock) - top card available for play on the foundations.

Options

AutoPlay

Box Fan

Box Fan

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (65%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (left) - build up in suit from Ace to King.  At the beginning of the game, the Aces are dealt here.
•16 fans (beside foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Only one card at a time may be moved to the foundations or another fan.  Spaces are filled only by Kings.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt face up to each pile.

Options

AutoPlay

Similar Games

Midnight Clover

Fan

Box Kite

Box Kite

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks. Hard (7%). Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (in center box) - build top 4 down in suit from King to Ace (King-foundations) and bottom 4 up in suit from Ace to King (Ace-foundations).  At the start of the game an Ace and King of each suit is dealt here.
•12 tableau piles (around foundations) - build up or down regardless of suit, wrapping from Ace to King or King to Ace as necessary.  The top card is available for play on the foundations or another tableau pile.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Empty piles are not filled.  At the start of the game 8 cards are dealt face up to each pile (only the top card can be seen).

History

Box Kite is a variation of St. Helena.

Similar Games

St. Helena

Boxing the Compass

Boxing the Compass

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (40%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (on the 4 sides) - build up in suit from Ace to King.  At the start of the game the Aces are dealt here.
•16 tableau piles (4 each adjacent to each pair of foundations) - No building.  Top card is available for play on the foundations   Spaces are filled from the waste or another tableau pile.  Spaces may only be filled by a card of the same suit as the suit of the foundation piles adjacent to the space.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (middle, face down on left) - move 1 card to waste by clicking.  1 redeal.
•waste (beside stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or spaces in the tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Boxing the Compass is a 2 deck version of Four Winds.

Similar Games

Four Winds

Brazilian Patience

Brazilian Patience

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (8%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color. Move groups of cards as a unit if they are in sequence down by alternate color.   Spaces may be filled with Kings.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.
•stock (upper left, face down) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.

Options

AutoPlay

History

This is a 2 deck Klondike game.  It comes from Brazil (hence the name).

Similar Games

Klondike

Breakwater

Breakwater

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (50%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down regardless of suit.  Fill spaces with any card or legal group of cards.   At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt to each pile, alternating face up and face down.
•stock (face down) - turn over cards one at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (below stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Breakwater is a variation of Interchange.  It is the easiest game in the Interchange class of games.

Similar Games

Interchange

Alternations

Unlimited

Forty-Nine

Bridesmaids

Bridesmaids

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Hard (<1%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (center) - build each pile up in suit, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary.  On the top foundation, any card of the same suit in sequence as the first card dealt may be played.  On the lower foundations, start with a card of the same rank as the first card dealt, then play cards in sequence of that suit where a card of the same rank has already been played to the foundation immediately above.
•stock (face down, top left) - Turn over cards three at a time to the waste pile.  Unlimited redeals.

 

•waste (below stock) - The top card of the waste pile is available for play on the foundations.

History

Bridesmaids is similar in concept to Osmosis.

Similar Games

Osmosis

Peek

Brigade

Brigade

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (85%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.  At the start of the game the Aces are dealt here.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are filled by any card.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•reserve  (left) - All cards available for play on the foundations or tableau.  Click on card to move it to the bottom of the stack, then move to either the foundations or tableau.   At the start of the game 13 cards are dealt to this pile.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Brigade is a variation of Flower Garden.

Similar Games

Flower Garden

Stonewall

Brisbane

Brisbane

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (80%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Move groups of cards regardless of any sequence.  Spaces may be filled by any card. At the start of the game 1 card is dealt the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd pile, and so on.  The top card is face up.  Then the remainder of the deck is dealt face up across all the pile until the deck is fully dealt.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Brisbane is a variation of Klondike (with an initial layout similar to Yukon) and Australian Patience.  It came from Australia.

Similar Games

Australian Patience

Klondike

Yukon

Bristol

Bristol

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (95%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - build up regardless of suit from Ace to King.
•8 Fans (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Only the top card of each pile is available for play.  Spaces are not filled.

 

•stock (face down) - Turn over cards 3 at a time, one to each waste pile.  There are no redeals.

 

•3 waste piles (to the right of the Stock) - The top card of each waste pile is available for play.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Bristol was invented by Albert Morehead and Geoffrey Mott-Smith.

Similar Games

New York

Dover

Vincent

Cardiff

British Canister

British Canister

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (10%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Only the top card of each pile may be moved. Spaces may be filled only with a King.  At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt to the first 4 piles, 6 cards are dealt to the last 4 piles.

Options

AutoPlay

History

British Canister is a variation of Canister.  It dates back to the 1890s in Britain.

Similar Games

Canister

American Canister

Scottish Canister

British Constitution

British Constitution

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks (minus Kings and Queens).  Very Easy (98%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top) - up in suit from Ace to Jacks.  At the start of the game the Aces are dealt here.
•4 rows of 8 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  The top card of each pile in the top row is available for play on the foundations.  The top card of each pile in the 2nd row is available for play on the top row, and so on, cards in each row are only available for play on the row immediately above.  Spaces may only be filled by an available card from the row immediately below.  Spaces in the bottom row are immediately filled from the waste.
•stock (bottom left) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste pile by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the bottom row of the tableau only.

Options

AutoPlay

British Square

British Square

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Easy (93%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (far right) - build up in suit from Ace to King, then another King, and down in suit back to Aces.
•16 tableau piles (center) - build up or down by suit (once a direction is selected, it must remain for the rest of the game) .  Only top card available for play.  Empty piles are filled by the waste or stock.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - move 1 card to waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (below stock) - top card available for play.

Options

AutoPlay

History

British Square is related to the Busy Aces-Deuces family of games.

Similar Games

Busy Aces

Deuces

Brown Recluse

Brown Recluse

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (40%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards in sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace in the tableau.

Layout

•10 tableau piles - build down regardless of suit, wrapping from Ace to King as necessary.  Groups of cards in sequence down in suit may be moved as a unit.  A space is filled automatically from the waste or, if empty, the stock.  When the stock and waste are empty, spaces may be filled by a King or a sequence of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the tableau.

Tips

•Same suit sequences should be preferred even though building is down regardless of suit.  The object is to build down in suit sequences.

History

Brown Recluse is a variation of Spider invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Spider

Beetle

Black Widow

Bucket

Bucket

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (5%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Only one card at a time may be moved. Spaces may be filled with any card.  At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt to the first 4 piles, 6 cards are dealt to the last 4 piles.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Bucket is FreeCell with no cells and a variation of Canister.

Similar Games

Canister

FreeCell

Buffalo Bill

Buffalo Bill

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Easy (98%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build left 4 piles up in suit from Ace to King, right 4 piles down in suit from Kings to Aces.
•26 Fans (below foundations) - top card is available for play on the foundations or reserves.  No building on the fans.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile.
•8 reserve piles (bottom) - each pile may hold one card from the fans. Cards from the reserves may be played to the foundations (but not to the fans).

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Play in the game consists of moving cards to the foundations, putting cards in the reserves in order to get at blocked cards in the fans.  Obviously, if all the reserves become full you are in trouble.

History

This game was invented by David Parlett (inventor of Black Hole, Penguin, and other games).  It is based on a game called "Little Billie" by Mary Whitmore Jones in one of her circa 1900 solitaire game books.

Similar Games

Little Billie

Bunker

Bunker

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck. Hard (5%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the tableau.

Layout

•8 tableau piles  - build up regardless of suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces can be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (below tableau, face down on left) - move 1 card to waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (below stock) - top card available for play.

Notes

The idea is to get all of the cards in play by grouping cards in piles up regardless of suit, which brings more cards into play via the empty spaces created.  The game is won if all cards are moved from the stock and waste onto the tableau.

Similar Games

Trusty Twelve

Sweet Sixteen

Knotty Nines

Up and Up

Busy Aces

Busy Aces

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (65%).  Mostly Luck.

 

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•12 tableau piles (below foundations on right) - build down in suit.  Only top card available for play.  Empty piles can be filled by any card. At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (below foundations, face down on left) - move 1 card to waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (below stock) - top card available for play.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•  There is no reason to not play cards to the foundation.
•The AutoPlay feature will automatically play cards to the foundations, if possible.  This is a big time saving feature in this game.  However, you should be aware that there are situations where there are two possibililities for play on the foundations, since there are two decks.  There may be two 8 of ♠, for example, that could be played on a certain foundation.  The AutoPlay function may not move the same eight to this spot that you might.

History

Busy Aces is the first game of a family that includes Deuces, Three's Company, and Fours Up.  It is the easiest to win of the family.  First known reference is in 100 Games of Solitaire in 1939 under the name of Courtyard.

Similar Games

Deuces

Three's Company

Fours Up

Penta

Sixes and Sevens

Eights Down

Cast Out Nines

Dimes

Jacks in the Box

Cadran

Cadran

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (7%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved. Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile.
•stock (bottom left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.  All cards in the waste are visible.

Options

AutoPlay

Tips

•Try to get a space in the tableau as quickly as possible.

History

Cadran is a variation of Forty Thieves.  The only difference between Cadran and Forty Thieves is that the entire waste pile is visible to the player, rather than just the top card.

Similar Games

Forty Thieves

Forty Bandits

Calculation

Calculation

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (80%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (across top) - build first pile up regardless of suit by ones, second pile up regardless of suit by twos, third pile up regardless of suit by threes, and fourth pile up regardless of suit by fours.  See chart below.  At the start of the game an Ace, Two, Three, and Four are dealt.

1:  A 2 3 4 5 6 7 8 9 T J Q K

2:  2 4 6 8 T Q A 3 5 7 9 J K

3:  3 6 9 Q 2 5 8 J A 4 7 T K

  4:  4 8 Q 3 7 J 2 6 T A 5 9 K

•4 reserve piles (below foundations) - cards are played here from the stock.  The top card of each pile is available for play to the foundations only.  Move cards to the foundations by clicking.
•stock (face down) - Top card is available for play on the reserves or foundations.  No redeals.

History

This is an old and popular variation of Sir Tommy.  It has about the same chances of winning as Sir Tommy, but is much more complicated to play.

Similar Games

Sir Tommy

Betsy Ross

One234

Numeration

Calculation FreeCell

Calculation Klondike

Old Calculation

Calculation FreeCell

Calculation FreeCell

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Easy (>99%).  Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build first pile up in suit by ones, second pile up in suit by twos, third pile up in suit by threes, and fourth pile up in suit by fours.  See chart below.   Each pile must be of a different suit.

1:  A 2 3 4 5 6 7 8 9 T J Q K

2:  2 4 6 8 T Q A 3 5 7 9 J K

3:  3 6 9 Q 2 5 8 J A 4 7 T K

  4:  4 8 Q 3 7 J 2 6 T A 5 9 K

•4 cells (top left) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.

 

•8 tableau piles (below foundations and cells) - build down by alternate color, wrapping from Ace to King as necessary.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color and if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.  Spaces can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt face up to the leftmost 4 piles, 6 cards are dealt face up to the remaining piles.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Groups of cards in the tableau can only be moved as a group if there are a sufficient number of empty cells available to store the cards individually.  The ability to move cards as a group is only a shortcut to moving the group one card at a time.

History

Calculation FreeCell is a combination of Calculation and FreeCell.  It was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Calculation

FreeCell

Calculation Klondike

Calculation Klondike

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (25%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build first pile up in suit by ones, second pile up in suit by twos, third pile up in suit by threes, and fourth pile up in suit by fours.  See chart below.   Each pile must be of a different suit.

1:  A 2 3 4 5 6 7 8 9 T J Q K

2:  2 4 6 8 T Q A 3 5 7 9 J K

3:  3 6 9 Q 2 5 8 J A 4 7 T K

  4:  4 8 Q 3 7 J 2 6 T A 5 9 K

 

•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Fill spaces with any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over  3 cards at a time, by clicking.  Unlimited redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Calculation Klondike is a combination of Calculation and Klondike.

Similar Games

Calculation

Klondike

Calico Bandits of Cairo

Calico Bandits of Cairo

 Top  Previous  Next

4 Decks.  Medium (80%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 26 cards. Only two piles for each suit allowed.
•13 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color, wrapping from Ace to King as necessary.  Groups of cards in sequence down by alternate color may be moved as a unit.  Spaces may be filled only by Kings.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 3 to the 2nd, 5 to the 3rd, 7 to the 4th, 9 to the 5th, 11 to the 6th, 13 to the 7th, 12 to the 8th, 10 to the 9th, 8 to the 10th, 6 to the 11th, 4 to the 12th, and 2 to the 13th.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  One redeal.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Calico Bandits of Cairo is a 4 deck version of Thieves of Egypt invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Thieves of Egypt

King of Egypt

Camaraderie

Camaraderie

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (35%)  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - build up regardless of suit from Aces to Kings.  At the start of the game the Aces are dealt here.
•4 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces are filled by a King or a group of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - deals one card to each reserve pile.
•4 reserves (far right) - Top card always available for play on the tableau or foundations.  Spaces are not filled (except by a deal from the stock).  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.

Options

AutoPlay

Canberra

Canberra

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (80%).  Skill/Luck Balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - Build down in suit.  Groups of cards may be moved regardless of sequence. Spaces filled by Kings or groups of cards headed by a King. At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile.

 

•stock (top left) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste pile by clicking.  One redeal.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Canberra is Australian Patience with one redeal.

Similar Games

Australian Patience

Raw Prawn

Candike

Candike

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (60%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces are filled from the reserve if possible, then by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile face down, then 1 card is dealt face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 3 cards at a time, by clicking.  Unlimited redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card always available for play on the tableau or foundations.
•reserve (left of tableau) - Top card always available for play on the tableau or foundations.  At the start of the game 13 cards are dealt here.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Candike is a variation of the strict 3 card deal Canfield.

Similar Games

Whistler

Canfield

Cerulean

Canfield

Canfield

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (35%)  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•4 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces are filled from the reserve if possible, then by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 or 3 cards at a time, by clicking.  Unlimited redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card always available for play on the tableau or foundations.
•reserve (left of tableau) - Top card always available for play on the tableau or foundations.  At the start of the game 13 cards are dealt here.

Options

•Rules - selects whether 1 card or 3 cards at a time are turned over from the stock.  This option is set in the options menu.

AutoPlay

History

Canfield is named after the owner of a gambling salon in Saratoga in the 1890s, who sold decks of cards to customers for $50 and paid 5 dollars for each card played to the foundations during the game.  In England this game is called "Demon".  Mary Whitmore Jones in her 1899 book Games of Patience says that Demon (Canfield) "is by far the best game for one pack that has yet been invented."

Similar Games

Double Canfield

Triple Canfield

Quadruple Canfield

Superior Canfield

Variegated Canfield

Chameleon

Storehouse

Rainbow

American Toad

Demon

Whistler

Candike

Inverted Canfield

Canfield Rush

Canfield Rush

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (20%)  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•4 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces are filled from the reserve if possible, then by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 3 cards at a time to the waste by clicking during the first deal, 2 cards at a time during the 2nd deal, and 1 card at a time during the last deal.  Two redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card always available for play on the tableau or foundations.
•reserve (left of tableau) - Top card always available for play on the tableau or foundations.  At the start of the game 13 cards are dealt here.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Canfield Rush is Canfield with a variable number of cards dealt from the stock.

Similar Games

Canfield

Gold Rush

Thieves Rush

Canister

Canister

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (50%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Groups of cards in sequence down regardless of suit may be moved as a unit. Spaces may be filled with any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt to the first 4 piles, 6 cards are dealt to the last 4 piles.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Canister is a common type of solitaire game.  The fact that all the cards are laid out face up makes it mostly a matter of skill to win.

Similar Games

British Canister

American Canister

Beleaguered Castle

Bucket

Capricieuse

Capricieuse

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (80%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (left and right) - on left piles build up in suit from Ace to King, on right piles build down in suit from King to Ace.
•12 tableau piles (middle) - build up or down by suit, no wrapping.  Top card is available for play on the foundations or another tableau pile, only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are filled by any card.  At the start of the game 8 cards are dealt to each pile.  During the deal, as each card is dealt it is moved to the foundations if possible and replaced.
•stock (top left) - Two redeals.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•During the deal if a card can be played to the foundations, it is played there and replaced by the next card.  Hence many of the foundations will already have several cards in them at the beginning of the game, and there will be varying numbers of cards in each tableau pile.

History

Capricieuse is a variation of Nationale.

Similar Games

Nationale

Captain's Patience

Captain's Patience

 Top  Previous  Next

4 Decks.  Medium (40%). Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•16 foundation piles (left, across top, right) - build up in suit from the rank of first card in the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•11 tableau piles (bottom row, center) - build down by alternate color, wrapping from Ace to King if necessary.  Only the top card of each pile may be moved.  Spaces are filled automatically from the stock, or from the waste when the stock is empty.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•reserve (above tableau) - top card is available for play on the foundations only.  At the start of the game 13 cards are dealt here.
•stock (middle left, face down) - turn over cards 1 at a time to the waste by clicking.  One redeal.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Captain's Patience is an easier variation of Admiral's Patience.

Similar Games

Admiral's Patience

General's Patience

Double Signora

Terrace

Empress of Italy

Blondes and Brunettes

Captive Queens

Captive Queens

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (75%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations and reserves.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top and bottom) - build the top piles starting with Fives down in suit to Aces, then Kings.  Build the bottom piles starting with Sixes up in suit to Jacks.
•4 reserve piles (center) - place Queens here.  No building.  The Queens are held "captive".
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card to waste by clicking.  Two redeals.
•waste (bottom left, under stock) - top card available for play.

History

This game is easy to win.  It is also known as Quadrille.

Similar Games

Sixes and Sevens

Caramel

Caramel

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (30%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Move groups of cards regardless of any sequence.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.   At the start of the game 8 cards are dealt to the first 4 piles and 7 cards are dealt to the next 4 piles.  3 cards in the each pile are face down.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Any face up card in the tableau may be built upon another, no matter how deep it is in a pile.  All cards covering it are moved together.  When a face down card is uncovered, it is automatically turned face up and is available for play.

History

Caramel is a variation of Geoffrey.

Similar Games

Geoffrey

Yukon

Cardiff

Cardiff

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (80%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•8 Fans (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Only the top card of each pile is available for play.  Spaces are not filled.

 

•stock (face down) - Turn over cards 3 at a time, one to each waste pile.  There are no redeals.

 

•3 waste piles (to the right of the Stock) - The top card of each waste pile is available for play.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Cardiff is a variation of Bristol with standard foundation building.

Similar Games

Bristol

Dover

Vincent

Carlton

Carlton

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (5%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Groups of cards may be moved if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Fill spaces with any card or group of cards.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to the first pile, 2 to the 2nd, and so on.
•stock (bottom left, face down) - deal one card to each tableau pile, by clicking.  No redeals.

History

Old Carlton is the same game except that groups of cards may be moved regardless of sequence.

Similar Games

Old Carlton

McCarver

Carlton Cell

Eternal Triangle

Steve

Great Triangle

Miss Milligan

Milligan Harp

Rouge et Noir

Leicester

Carlton Cell

Carlton Cell

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (30%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Groups of cards may be moved if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Fill spaces with any card or group of cards.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to the first pile, 2 to the 2nd, and so on.
•stock (bottom left, face down) - deal one card to each tableau pile, by clicking.  No redeals.

 

•1 cell (bottom) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in the cell.  The card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

History

Carlton Cell is the game Carlton with 1 cell.

Similar Games

Carlton

McCarver

Old Carlton

Steve

Carol

Carol

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (50%).  Skill/luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build left 4 piles up in suit from Ace to King, right 4 piles down in suit from Kings to Aces. Each group of 4 piles should have a pile of each suit.
•13 tableau packs (below foundations) - piles are numbered from 1 to 13.  No building.  Top card is available for play on the foundations.  Empty piles can be filled only by a card of the same rank as the number of the pile.
•stock (bottom left, face down) - clicking turns over the top card.  The tableau pile corresponding to the rank of this card is spread out at the bottom of the screen.  All the cards in that pile become available for play on the foundations, including the top card of the stock, which is placed in position to become the top card of the tableau pile.   The order of the cards can be changed (the cards may be rearranged in the bottom row).  The farther to the right a card is, the closer to the top of the tableau pile it will become.   When all possible plays have been made, clicking on the stock again picks up all of the remaining cards, returns them in the same order to the tableau pile, and then the next card in the stock is turned over and the process repeats.  When the stock is empty there is no redeal.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•The Initial Deal - The 2 decks are dealt as follows: the cards are dealt in sequence to the 13 tableau packs.  If the card dealt to a pile is of the same rank as the number of the pile (for example, a Three on the 3rd pile), then the next card to deal is dealt face down to the stock, and the deal continues.  If the card dealt is an Ace or a King, then the next card to deal is dealt face down to the stock, and the deal continues.  When the deal reaches the end of the 13 piles, then a card is dealt face down to the stock, and the deal continues with the first pile again.  Note that if an Ace is dealt to the first pile, two cards are dealt face down to the stock, and if a King is dealt to the 13th pile, 3 cards are dealt face down to the stock.  The stock therefore will contain a variable number of cards from game to game.
•Rearranging the cards in a tableau pile when it is spread out along the bottom row is critical for success.  Even if you can't immediately play a card, it pays to rearrange the cards so that the cards that will be needed first will be at the top of the tableau pile.
•Play consists of playing all cards that are available to the foundations, then clicking on the stock to make more cards available based on the rank of the cards in the stock.

Similar Games

Thirteen Packs

Carousel

Carousel

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (65%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•Ace foundation (top left) - build with Aces only, alternating in color until the pile contains all 8 Aces.
•Evens foundations (top) - build up in suit by twos, starting with Twos. (Two, Four, Six, Eight, Ten, Queen).
•Odds foundations (under Evens) - build up in suit by twos, starting with Threes. (Three, Five, Seven, Nine, Jack [there are no Kings]).
•8 tableau piles (under Odds) - top card is available for play on the foundations.  Build down in suit. Only one card at a time may be moved. Spaces are filled by 4 cards from the waste, unless the waste is empty, when they are filled by the stock (if the stock is empty, they are filled by any card).  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (bottom left, face down) - Turn over 1 card to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (under stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations.

History

Carousel is a slightly easier variation of Great Wheel.

Similar Games

Great Wheel

Greater Wheel

Mount Olympus

Carpet

Carpet

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (92%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (left and right, starting with Aces) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•20 reserve piles (between foundations) - The top card of each pile is available for play on the foundations.  Spaces are filled from the waste or stock. Each pile may contain only one card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (left, face down) - deal 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (beside stock) - top card is available for play foundations or reserves.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Carpet is a very simple game and is easy to win.

Similar Games

Twenty

Colorado

Carre Napoleon

Carre Napoleon

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (2%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.  At the start of the game the Aces are dealt here.
•12 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit. Only one card at a time may be moved. Spaces can be filled only by Kings.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt face up to each pile.  As the cards are dealt, any cards that can be moved to the foundations are moved there (and not replaced).
•stock (face down, top left) - move one card to waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (beside stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Carre Napoleon is a French, older version of Napoleon's Square.

Similar Games

Bataillion Carre

Napoleon's Square

Forty Thieves

Carthage

Carthage

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (60%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are filled by any available card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•6 reserve piles (bottom) - Top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt to each pile.  When a reserve pile is completely empty, it may be used as a storage cell to store one card from the tableau.
•stock (face down, top left) - clicking deals 2 cards to each reserve pile.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Carthage is a variation of Algerian Patience.

Similar Games

Algerian Patience

Cassim

Cassim

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (40%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.  At the beginning of the game the Aces are dealt here.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Groups of cards in descending sequence down in suit may be moved as a unit. Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  Unlimited redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Similar Games

Ali Baba

Big Forty

Cast Out Nines

Cast Out Nines

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (10%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Nines to King, then Ace up to Eight.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Groups of cards may be moved if they are in sequence down in suit.  Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (face down on left) - move 1 card to waste by clicking.  No redeals
•waste (below stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Cast Out Nines is a member of the Busy Aces family of games. Cast Out Nines was invented Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Busy Aces

Deuces

Three's Company

Fours Up

Penta

Sixes and Sevens

Eights Down

Dimes

Jacks in the Box

Castile

Castile

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (35%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•8 Fans (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Only the top card of each pile is available for play.  Spaces are filled only by Kings.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt to each pile.

 

•4 reserve piles (bottom) - No building.  Top card is available for play on the foundations or fans.  Spaces are not filled.  At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt to each pile.

 

Options

AutoPlay

History

Castile is an open game based on the game Bristol.  It was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Bristol

Castle Mount

Castle Mount

 Top  Previous  Next

3 Decks.  Medium (30%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•12 foundation piles (middle) - build up in suit from Ace to King.  At the start of the game the Aces are dealt here.
•12 tableau piles (around foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Groups of cards can be moved if they are in sequence down in suit.  Spaces may be filled by any available card.  At the start of the game 12 cards are dealt face up to each pile.

Options

AutoPlay

History

This is a 3 deck variation of Beleaguered Castle invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Beleaguered Castle

Fortress

Palace

Castle of Indolence

Castle of Indolence

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (65%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (middle) - build up regardless of suit from Ace to King.
•8 tableau piles (around foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Only the top card of each pile is available for play.  Spaces may be filled by any available card.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt face up to each pile (7 cards to the left piles).
•4 reserve piles (bottom) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 13 cards are dealt to each pile.
•

Options

AutoPlay

Tips

•Because one of the decks is in the 4 reserve piles, it is imperative to pull as many cards as possible out of these piles.

History

Castle of Indolence is based on a 19th century game of the same name.  The layout was changed by Thomas Warfield to more closely resemble Beleaguered Castle and to make the game more interesting and playable.

Similar Games

Beleaguered Castle

Castles End

Castles End

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (80%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from the rank of the first card moved to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.

 

•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build up or down by alternate color.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces can be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•2 reserve piles (top left) - At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.  The card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.  Cards cannot be replaced once moved.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•To begin the game, choose a card to move to the first foundation pile (far left at top).  All the other foundation piles will then begin with the same rank as this card.

History

Castles End is a variation of Good Measure, and is similar to Bastion and Chessboard.

Similar Games

Baker's Dozen

Good Measure

Bastion

Chessboard

Spanish Patience

Castles in Spain

Martha

Vineyard

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.

 

•13 tableau piles (left of foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces may be filled with any card.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile.

Options

AutoPlay

History

This is a variation of Baker's Dozen.

1 Deck.  Medium (30%).  Mostly Skill.

 

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.

 

•14 tableau piles (left of foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces may be filled only by a King.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to 13 piles and one pile is empty.

Options

History

This is a variation of Spanish Patience and Castles in Spain.
