Ceiling Fan

Ceiling Fan

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (60%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•18 fans (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Only one card at a time may be moved to the foundations or another fan.  Spaces are filled only by Kings.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt face up to each pile (the last 2 piles only have 2 cards).

Options

AutoPlay

History

Ceiling Fan is an easier variation of Fan.

Similar Games

Fan

La Belle Lucie

Cell 11

Cell 11

 Top  Previous  Next

3 Decks.  Easy (90%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations

Layout

•12 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•11 cells (below foundations) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.  The card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to leftmost and rightmost cells.
•12 tableau piles (below foundations and cells) - build down by alternate color.  The top card is available for play on the foundations, cells, or another tableau pile.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color and if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.  Fill spaces with any card or legal group of cards.   At the start of the game 13 cards are dealt to each pile (except for the center two piles, which start with 12).

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Note that groups of cards in the tableau can only be moved as a group if there are a sufficient number of empty cells available to store the cards individually.  The ability to move cards as a group is only a shortcut to moving the group one card at a time.

Tips

•Try to keep as many cells empty as possible.

History

Cell 11 is a variation of Triple FreeCell.

Similar Games

FreeCell

Double FreeCell

Triple FreeCell

Cerulean

Cerulean

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (50%)  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces are filled from the reserve if possible, then by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 3 cards at a time, by clicking.  Unlimited redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card always available for play on the tableau or foundations.
•reserve (left of tableau) - Top card always available for play on the tableau or foundations.  At the start of the game 13 cards are dealt here.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Cerulean is a 7 pile Canfield game similar to Candike.

Similar Games

Canfield

Candike

Whistler

Challenge FreeCell

Challenge FreeCell

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (95%).  Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•4 cells (top left) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.

 

•8 tableau piles (below foundations and cells) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color and if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.  Spaces can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game the Twos are dealt to the leftmost 4 piles, the Aces are dealt to the right 4 piles, then 6 cards are dealt face up to the leftmost 4 piles, 5 cards are dealt face up to the remaining piles.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Groups of cards in the tableau can only be moved as a group if there are a sufficient number of empty cells available to store the cards individually.  The ability to move cards as a group is only a shortcut to moving the group one card at a time.

History

Challenge FreeCell is a variation of FreeCell.  It is a harder game since the Aces and Twos are dealt out first and are buried at the bottom of each pile at the start of the game.  Challenge FreeCell was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

FreeCell

Super Challenge FreeCell

Chameleon

Chameleon

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Hard (1%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•3 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down regardless of suit.  Spaces are filled from the reserve if possible, then by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over one card at a time to the waste, by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.
•reserve (left of tableau) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 12 cards are dealt here.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Chameleon is a variation of Canfield.

Similar Games

Canfield

Storehouse

Charlie

Charlie

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (10%)  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit.  Spaces are filled by Kings or a legal group of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile, alternately face up and down.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time, by clicking.  One redeal.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card always available for play on the tableau or foundations.
•reserve (left of tableau) - Top card always available for play on the tableau or foundations.  At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt here.

Options

AutoPlay

Similar Games

Munger

Mystique

Minerva

Charlotte

Charlotte

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (50%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards into 4 sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - move entire 13-card King to Ace down in suit sequences from the tableau.
•7 tableau piles - build down regardless of suit.  Groups of cards in sequence down in suit may be moved as a unit.  A space can be filled by any card or legal group of cards. At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt face up to each pile, then one more card is dealt face up to the first, fourth, and seventh piles.

 

•stock (top left, face down) - Clicking deals 1 card to each tableau pile.
•reserve  (below stock) - storage location for any number of cards.  Any available card or legal group of cards may be moved here.  The cards are available for play on the tableau.  No building on cards that are in the reserve.

Tips

•Same suit sequences should be preferred even though building is down regardless of suit.  The object is to build down in suit sequences.

History

Charlotte is a variation of Spider Web.  The differences are that you must move the 13 card King to Ace sequences to the foundations yourself, and spaces in the tableau do not need to be filled before a deal from the stock, and you cannot build on cards in the reserve.

Similar Games

Spider Web

Chateau

Chateau

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (80%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•12 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down regardless of suit.  Spaces may be filled only by a King or a group of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 8 cards are dealt face up to each pile.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Chateau is a two deck Beleaguered Castle type game.

Similar Games

Beleaguered Castle

Chatham

Chatham

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (15%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in color from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Fill spaces with cards of rank one below the foundation base card (or Kings if the base card is an Ace).  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste, by clicking.  One redeal.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.

History

Chatham is a variation of Springfield.

Similar Games

Springfield

Little Napoleon

Forty Thieves

Rochester

Chelicera

Chelicera

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (50%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards into 4 sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace within the tableau.

Layout

•7 tableau piles (top) - build down in suit.  Groups of cards (regardless of any sequence) can be moved.  Spaces are filled automatically from the stock by a group of 3 cards until the stock is empty, then spaces may be filled by a King or groups of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt face up to the first 4 piles, then 7 cards are dealt face up to the last 3 piles.

 

•stock (top left, face down) - cards fill spaces in the tableau automatically.

Notes

•Any face up card, regardless of where in a pile it is, can be moved, along with all cards above it (this is like Yukon).

History

Chelicera is a variation of Scorpion.  It was invented by Erik den Hollander.

Similar Games

Scorpion

Scorpion II

Cheops

Cheops

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard  (2%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To pair up all the cards in the deck into pairs of cards.

Layout

•A Pyramid of 28 cards.  Only uncovered cards are available for play.  Discard pairs of cards of the same rank or of consecutive ranks.  Aces are not consecutive with Kings.  For example, a Four can pair with a Three, Four, or Five.  An Ace pairs with another Ace or a Two.  To discard a pair, drop one card on the other, or right-click on one of the cards.
•stock (bottom left) -  move cards one at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - The top card is available for play.

Notes

•Any pair of cards of the same rank or of consecutive ranks can be paired and removed from play.  Be careful when choosing pairs because it is very easy to pair off cards in such a way that you are left with some cards that cannot be paired.

History

Cheops is a variation of Pyramid.

Similar Games

Pyramid

Giza

Pharaohs

Pyramid Golf

Pyramid Rank

Chessboard

Chessboard

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (30%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from the rank of the first card moved to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build up or down by suit.  Only the top card of each pile is available for play.  Spaces may be filled by any available card.  At the start of the game 6 cards each are dealt to the first 2 piles, 5 cards each to the remaining piles.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•To begin the game, choose a card to move to the first foundation pile (far left at top).  All the other foundation piles will then begin with the same rank as this card.

History

Chessboard is a variation of Fortress, which is a variation of Beleaguered Castle.  The difference between Fortress and Chessboard is that Chessboard gives you the choice of the first foundation card.

Similar Games

Fortress

Beleaguered Castle

Selective Castle

Castles End

Chequers

Lasker

Morphy

Chequers

Chequers

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Very Easy (99%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top) - build left 4 piles up in suit from Ace to King, right 4 piles down in suit from Kings to Aces. Each group of 4 piles should have a pile of each suit.
•25 tableau piles (below foundations) - build up or down by suit.  Only the top card of each pile is available for play.  Spaces are filled from the reserve, when the reserve is empty spaces may be filled by any available card.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile.
• reserve pile (top left, face down) - Cards fill spaces in the tableau automatically.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Chequers is a 2 deck version of Chessboard.

Similar Games

Chessboard

Fortress

Chinaman

Chinaman

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (20%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by any suit but the same.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by any suit but the same.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards with a King at the bottom. At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 3 cards at a time, by clicking.  One redeal.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Chinaman is a variation of Klondike.

Similar Games

Klondike

Thumb and Pouch

Different Left

Chinese FreeCell

Chinese FreeCell

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Modified Decks (no Clubs).   Easy (95%).  Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•6 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•11 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by any suit but the same.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by any suit but the same and if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards with a King at the bottom.  At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt face up to each pile, except for the middle pile which is dealt 8 cards.
•4 cells (top left) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.

Notes

•Groups of cards in the tableau can only be moved as a group if there are a sufficient number of empty cells available to store the cards individually.  The ability to move cards as a group is only a shortcut to moving the group one card at a time.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Chinese FreeCell is FreeCell with 2 decks but only 3 suits.

Similar Games

FreeCell

Chinese Klondike

Chinese Spider

Chinese Klondike

Chinese Klondike

 Top  Previous  Next

4 Modified Decks (no Clubs).   Medium (90%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•12 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•12 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by any suit but the same.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by any suit but the same.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards with a King at the bottom. (See KingOnly for option).  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.  The top card is face up.
•stock (bottom left, face down) - turn over 1 or 3 cards (see rules below) at a time, by clicking.  Unlimited redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

Rules - selects whether 1 card or 3 cards at a time are turned over from the stock. (See Options menu)

KingOnly   AutoPlay

History

Chinese Klondike is Klondike with 4 decks but only 3 suits

Similar Games

Klondike

Chinese FreeCell

Chinese Trigon

Chinese Spider

Chinese Spider

 Top  Previous  Next

4 Modified Decks (no Clubs).  Medium (80%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards in sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace.

Layout

•12 tableau piles - build down regardless of suit.  Groups of cards in sequence down in suit may be moved as a unit.  A space can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt to each pile.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.  All tableau piles must be filled before dealing.

Notes

•Whenever a sequence of 13 cards down in suit from King to Ace is formed, it will automatically be removed from play.

Tips

•Same suit sequences should be preferred even though building is down regardless of suit.  The object is to build down in suit sequences.
•Spaces should be made as soon as possible, and used to move cards into groups by suit.

History

Chinese Spider is a variation of Spider with 4 decks but only 3 suits.  This makes it easier than Spider, but harder than Spider One Suit

and Spider Two Suits.

Similar Games

Spider

Spider One Suit

Spider Two Suits

Big Spider

Chinese FreeCell

Chinese Trigon

Chinese Trigon

 Top  Previous  Next

4 Modified Decks (no Clubs).   Medium (70%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•12 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•12 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards with a King at the bottom. (See KingOnly for option).  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.  The top card is face up.
•stock (bottom left, face down) - turn over 1 or 3 cards (see rules below) at a time, by clicking.  Unlimited redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

Rules - selects whether 1 card or 3 cards at a time are turned over from the stock. (See Options menu)

KingOnly   AutoPlay

History

Chinese Trigon is a variation of Chinese Klondike.

Similar Games

Chinese Klondike

Trigon

Klondike

Chinese FreeCell

Cicely

Cicely

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (90%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (left and right) - build the piles on the left up in suit from Ace to King, build the piles on the right down in suit from King to Ace.  Each group of 4 piles should have a pile of each suit.
•8 tableau piles (face up in the middle) - top card is available for play on the foundations or reserves.  Build up or down by suit, Kings and Aces do not wrap.  Spaces are not filled except by the stock (when the stock is clicked).  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile.
•8 reserve piles (across top) - each pile may contain 1 card, available for play on the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - clicking deals 4 cards to each tableau pile.  No redeals.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•When the foundation piles of the same suit meet, is its allowable to move cards from one foundation to the other.

History

Cicely is a variation of Tournament and Kingsdown Eights.

Similar Games

Tournament

Kingsdown Eights

Algerian Patience

Circle Eight

Circle Eight

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck. Medium (50%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the tableau.

Layout

•8 tableau piles (around the stock and waste) - build up regardless of suit.  Cards are played here only from the waste pile.  Once a card is played to a pile it cannot be moved.  A pile can contain any number of cards.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (center, face down) - deals 1 card to the waste pile by clicking.  One redeal.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the tableau piles.

Notes

The idea is to get all of the cards in play by building cards from the waste to the tableau piles up regardless of suit.  The game is won if all cards are moved from the waste onto the tableau.

Similar Games

Circle Nine

Circle Nine

Circle Nine

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck. Medium (20%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the center pile.

Layout

•1 foundation pile (center pile) - begins with the first card dealt to the pile, build up regardless of suit, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until all the cards are played here.
•9 tableau piles (around the foundation pile) - top card is available for play on the foundation pile.  Spaces are filled immediately from the   stock.  Building is allowed from the stock pile only.
•stock (top left) -  top card is available for play on the foundation pile or any of the tableau piles.

Notes

If no cards can be played to the foundation, cover cards in the tableau piles with cards in the stock until cards can be played to the foundation pile again.  Be careful not to block yourself by covering up cards that you will need first later.

Similar Games

Circle Eight

Citadel

Citadel

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (50%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (middle) - build up in suit from Ace to King.  At the start of the game the 4 Aces are dealt here.
•8 tableau piles (around foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Only the top card of each pile is available for play.  Spaces may be filled by any available card.  At the start of the game, 6 cards are dealt to each pile.  As the cards are dealt, any cards that can be moved to the foundations are moved there.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Citadel is a version of Beleaguered Castle.  The play is the same, but since cards are moved to the foundations during the deal, it is easier to win.

Similar Games

Beleaguered Castle

Cleopatra

Cleopatra

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (80%).  Skill/luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•13 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 to the 2nd, 3 to the 3rd, 4 to the 4th, 5 to the 5th, 6 to the 6th, 7 to the 7th, then 6 to the 8th, 5 to the 9th, and 4 to the 10th, 3 to the 11th, 2 to the 12th, and 1 to the 13th.  Some cards are face down in alternating fashion.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Cleopatra is a variation of Forty Thieves invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Thieves of Egypt

Forty Thieves

Clock

Clock

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Easy (98%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•12 foundation piles (the clock) - Build up in suit until the top card is the same number as the number on a clock in that position.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•8 tableau piles (left) - Build down regardless of suit.  Spaces are filled with any card.  Only the top card is available for play.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt to each pile.

History

This is one of a large number of different games known as Clock.  It is also sometimes called Grandfather's Clock.

Similar Games

Dial

Order Time

Cloud Nine

Cloud Nine

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (20%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•9 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.   Groups of cards can be moved if they are in sequence down in suit.  Spaces filled by any card or any legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Tips

•Try to get a space in the tableau as quickly as possible.

History

Cloud Nine is an easier version of Nine to Five.

Similar Games

Nine to Five

Forty Thieves

Clover Leaf

Clover Leaf

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (90%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (left) - build the Aces up in suit to King and the Kings down in suit to Ace.  At the start of the game two Aces of one color and two Kings of the opposite color are dealt here.
•16 fans (right of foundations) - build up or down by suit.  The top card is available for play on the foundations or another fan.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are filled only by Aces or Kings.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt to each pile.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Since there are only 4 remaining Aces or Kings, only 4 empty fans can be filled.

History

Clover Leaf is a fan type variation of La Belle Lucie, Shamrocks, and Trefoil.  It is a one deck version of House on the Hill.  Clover Leaf was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

La Belle Lucie

Alexander the Great

Shamrocks

Trefoil

House on the Hill

House in the Wood

Three Shuffles and a Draw

Club

Club

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (45%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Aces to Kings.
•11 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Empty piles can be filled by any card.  Cards in the top 3 piles (top row) cannot be moved to piles in the bottom 2 rows (cards in the bottom two rows can be moved to any pile).  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt to each pile (1 face down, 2 face up).
•stock (middle left, face down) - Turn over 1 card to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Similar Games

Easthaven

Colonel

Colonel

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (15%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (middle) - build up in suit from the rank of first card moved to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit, wrapping from Ace to King if necessary.  Groups of cards in descending sequence down in suit may be moved as a unit.  Spaces are filled automatically from the waste, or stock if the waste is empty.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•reserve (top) - top card is available for play on the foundations only. At the start of the game 11 cards are dealt here.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over cards 1 at a time to the waste by clicking.  One redeal.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•The game begins by choosing a card to move to the first foundation pile.  The rank of this card becomes the base card for all the other

foundation piles.  This first move is very important.

History

Colonel is a variation of General's Patience and Signora invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

General's Patience

Signora

Terrace

Colorado

Colorado

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Easy (80%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top)  - build the first 4 piles up in suit from Ace to King (1 ace of each suit), the last 4 down in suit from King to Ace (1 King of each suit).
•20 tableau Piles (below foundations) - top card is available for play on the foundations only.  Building from the waste is without regard to suit or rank. Spaces are filled automatically from the stock.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (bottom right, face down) - deals 1 card to the waste pile by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.  The card must be moved before another card can be moved to the waste pile.

Notes

•The waste card may be moved to any tableau pile.  Cards cannot be moved from one tableau to another.

History

Colorado is related to Twenty.

Similar Games

Twenty

Carpet

Colours

Colours

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (33%).  Skill/luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation (across top) - build up in color from the starting card, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.  The first cards are a Two, Three, Four and Five of alternating colors (if the Two is red, the Three must be black).
•6 waste piles (below foundations) - cards are played here from the stock.  The top card of each pile is available for play.  Move cards to the foundations by clicking.
•stock (far left, below foundations) - Top card is available for play on the waste piles or foundations.  No redeals.

History

Colours is a variation of Lady Betty.

Similar Games

Lady Betty

Sir Tommy

Compass

Compass

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (25%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•1 center card (center) - dealt to the center pile at the start of the game.  This card determines the rank of the base cards of the other 4 piles.  This card is available for play on the 4 foundation piles if necessary and can be replaced by another card of the same rank.  There is no building on this card.
•4 foundation piles (corners, in the 4 directions) - build the top and bottom (North and South) piles up regardless of suit from the rank one higher than the rank of the center card, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary.  Build the left and right (East and West) piles down regardless of suit from the rank one lower that the rank of the center card, wrapping from Ace to King as necessary.  Each pile can contain any number of cards.
•stock (face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  Two redeals.

 

•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations.

Notes

Unlike in most games, the 4 foundation piles do not have to contain 13 cards each at the end of the game.  As long as all of the cards are played to the 4 piles, the game is won.  Cards can be, and should be, moved between the 4 piles at will.

Cone

Cone

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Very Hard (1%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (right) - build up in suit from Ace to King, wrapping to Ace and then to King again, until each pile contains 26 cards.
•7 tableau piles (across top) - build down by alternate color, wrapping from Ace to King if necessary.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color. Spaces may be filled by any card or group of cards (All spaces must be filled before cards are dealt from the stock).  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the 1st and 7th piles, 2 cards to the 2nd and 6th, 3 cards to the 3rd and 5th, and 4 cards to the 4th pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.  When only 4 cards remain, 1 card is dealt to each of the reserve piles. No redeals.
•4 reserve piles (below stock) - cards are dealt here from the stock when the stock contains only 4 cards.  The cards are available for play on the foundations or tableau. No building.

Options

AutoPlay

Similar Games

Carlton

Giant

Miss Milligan

Yucone

Congress

Congress

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (60%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (in center box) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•8 tableau piles (to left and right of foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Spaces are filled from the waste.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (upper left, face down) - 1 card at a time moved to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Tips

•Do not move cards to the foundations unnecessarily; they may be needed for lower cards in the tableau.

History

Congress is related to Forty Thieves.

Similar Games

Parliament

Diplomat

Lady Palk

Wheatsheaf

Octave

Forty Thieves

Constellation

Constellation

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (50%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (middle, upper and lower)  - build the upper 4 piles up in suit from Ace to King (one for each suit), the lower 4 down in suit from King to Ace (one for each suit).  No cards can be played to the foundations until the stock and waste are empty.
•8 reserve piles, also known as the "Equator" (center) - storage location for one card.   Only 1 card allowed in each reserve.  The card is available for play on the tableau piles, and on the foundations when the stock and waste are empty. At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•24 tableau piles, also known as the "Zodiac" (around all the other piles) - build up or down by suit, Aces and Kings are not consecutive.  Sequences can change up or down within the same pile.  Top card is available for play on the foundations when the stock and waste are empty.  Cards can be moved from one tableau pile to another. At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (middle left, face down) - Turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  Unlimited redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card is available for play on the tableau or reserve piles.

Notes

Because cards cannot be played to the foundations until the stock and waste are empty, the game divides into two parts.  In the first part, the cards from the waste and reserve piles are played to the tableau piles until all the cards are either on the tableau or reserve piles.  If you cannot bring all the cards into play, then the game is lost.  In the second part, the cards are played from the tableau or reserve piles to the foundations.  Only if all the cards can be played up to the foundations without blocking can the game be won.

History

Constellation is an easier version of Zodiac.

Similar Games

Zodiac

Contradance

Contradance

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Very Hard (<1%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•16 foundation piles (top 2 rows) - build piles starting with Fives down in suit to Aces then Kings, build piles starting with Sixes up in suit to Queens.  At the start of the game the Fives and Sixes are dealt here.
•stock (bottom right, face down) - turn over 1 card to waste by clicking.  One redeal.
•waste (bottom right, next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations.

History

This game is easy to play, but the odds of winning are against you.  It is related to the Busy Aces family, in particular Sixes and Sevens.

Similar Games

Sixes and Sevens

Cornelius

Cornelius

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (60%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Move groups of cards regardless of any sequence.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.   At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  One redeal.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Any card in the tableau may be built upon another, no matter how deep it is in a pile.  All cards covering it are moved together.

History

Cornelius is a cross between Yukon and Forty Thieves.  It was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Yukon

Forty Thieves

Hawaiian Solitaire

Corners

Corners

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (8%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (corners left and right) - build up in suit from the rank of first card dealt to each pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•5 reserve piles (forming cross) - Storage locations for one card.  Spaces are filled automatically from the stock.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (top, face down) - turn over cards one at a time to the waste by clicking.  Two redeals.

 

•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Corners is a variation of Four Seasons and Czarina.

Similar Games

Four Seasons

Czarina

Corner Suite

Corner Suite

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (90%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (corners left and right) - build up in suit Ace to King.
•9 tableau piles (center) - build down regardless of suit.  Only the top card of each pile is available for play.  Spaces may be filled only from the waste.  At the start of the game these piles are empty.
•stock (top, face down) - turn over cards one at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.

 

•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Corona

Corona

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (25%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•12 tableau piles (left of foundations) - build down in suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are filled from the waste, or the stock if the waste is empty.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (face down, top left) - turn over 1 card to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (under stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

This is a game in the Forty Thieves family.

Similar Games

Richard's Patience

Quadrangle

Triple Line

Busy Aces

Limited

Forty Thieves

Crown

Cotswold

Cotswold

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (80%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King, wrapping to Ace and then to King again, until each pile contains 26 cards.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color, wrapping from Ace to King as necessary.  Groups of cards in sequence down by alternate color may be moved as a unit.  Spaces are filled by any card.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt to each pile, then 1 card is dealt to the 2nd pile, 2 cards to the 3rd, and so on.  Only the top card of each pile is face up.
• 2 reserve piles (left and right) - All cards available for play on the foundations or tableau.  Click on card to move it to the bottom of the stack, then move to either the foundations or tableau.   At the start of the game 26 cards are dealt to each pile.

Options

AutoPlay

Similar Games

Glocestershire

Flower Garden

Brigade

Stonewall

Countess

Countess

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (75%).  Skill/luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from the rank of first card played to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•4 tableau piles (below foundations on right) - build down by alternate color, wrapping from Ace to King if necessary.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces are filled by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 3 cards at a time to the waste by clicking during the first deal, 2 cards at a time during the 2nd deal, and 1 card at a time during the last deal.  Two redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.
•4 reserve piles (left of tableau) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt face up to each pile.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Countess is a variation of Dutchess invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Dutchess

Canfield

Canfield Rush

Duke

Courtyard

Courtyard

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks. Medium (40%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (in box in middle) - build up in suit from Aces to Kings.
•12 tableau piles (in a ring around the foundations) - build down in suit.  Only the top card available for play.  Empty piles are filled automatically from the waste (or the stock if the waste is empty).  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - move 1 card to waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (below stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Courtyard is a variation of Deuces.

Similar Games

Deuces

Fours Up

Cousin Fred

Cousin Fred

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (75%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Move groups of cards only if they are in sequence down in suit.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Cousin Fred is a variation of Fred's Spider.

Similar Games

Fred's Spider

Fred's Three

Spider

Spidike

Coyote

Coyote

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck. Medium (20%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Aces to Kings. At the beginning of the game the Aces are dealt here.
•4 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit.  Spaces are filled automatically from the reserve, if possible, otherwise by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time, by clicking.  1 redeal.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card always available for play on the tableau or foundations.
•reserve (left of tableau) - Top card always available for play on the tableau or foundations.  At the start of the game 13 cards are dealt here.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Coyote is a variation of Acme.

Similar Games

Acme

Canfield

Runner

Crazy Quilt

Crazy Quilt

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks. Medium (50%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations

Layout

•8 foundation piles (left and right) - build left piles up in suit from Aces to Kings, build right piles down in suit from Kings to Aces.
•tableau (center) -  At the start of the game 64 cards are dealt out in an 8x8 square, with every other card rotated 90 degrees.  Only cards which have a short side not blocked by another card are available.  In the initial configuration, 16 of the 28 cards on the outside edge are available.  As cards are removed, interior cards will become available.  Available cards from the tableau can be built onto the foundation piles.  Also, an available card in the tableau can be played on the waste pile if it is in sequence up or down by suit.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over cards one at a time to the waste pile by clicking.  One redeal.
•waste (beside stock) - top card available for play on the foundations. An available card in the tableau can be played on the waste pile if it is in sequence up or down by suit.

Similar Games

Indian Carpet

Persian Rug

Knitting Pairs

Crescent

Crescent

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks. Hard (20%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (left and right) - on left piles build up in suit from Ace to King, on right piles build down in suit from King to Ace.  When the two piles of a suit meet, cards may be transferred from one to the other.  At the start of the game an Ace and King of each suit is dealt to each pile.
•16 tableau piles (middle) - build up or down by suit, wrapping from Ace to King or King to Ace as necessary.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces cannot be filled.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left) - 3 redeals.  A redeal takes the bottom card of each pile and moves it to the top of the pile.  All other cards remain in the same order.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Some versions of this game have all the cards of each tableau pile except the top card face down.  However, turning all cards face up adds some element of skill to the game.

Similar Games

Crescent Four

Crescent Fan

Crescent Fan

Crescent Fan

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (25%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•18 fans (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved to the foundations or another fan.  Spaces are filled only by Kings.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt face up to each pile (the last 2 piles only have 2 cards).
•stock (top left) - 2 redeals.  A redeal takes the bottom card of each pile and moves it to the top of the pile.  All other cards remain in the same order.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Crescent Fan is Fan with a redeal like Crescent.

Similar Games

Fan

Crescent

Crescent Four

Crescent Four

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks. Medium (30%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (left and right) - on left piles build up in suit from Ace to King, on right piles build down in suit from King to Ace.  When the two piles of a suit meet, cards may be transferred from one to the other.  At the start of the game an Ace and King of each suit is dealt to each pile.
•16 tableau piles (middle) - build up or down by suit, wrapping from Ace to King or King to Ace as necessary.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces cannot be filled.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left) - 4 redeals.  A redeal takes the bottom card of each pile and moves it to the top of the pile.  All other cards remain in the same order.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Crescent Four is the game Crescent with a 4th redeal, making the game a little bit easier.

Similar Games

Crescent

Crimean Solitaire

Crimean Solitaire

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Hard (1%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards into 4 sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - move entire 13-card King to Ace down in suit sequences from the tableau.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit, wrapping from Ace to King if necessary.  Move groups of cards regardless of any sequence.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards with headed by a King.   At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt to each pile, with 1 card face down in the second pile, 2 cards face down in the 3rd pile, and so on.
•3 reserve piles - available for play on the tableau.  At the start of the game one card is dealt to each reserve pile.  No building.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Any face up card in the tableau may be built upon another, no matter how deep it is in a pile.  All cards covering it are moved together.  When a face down card is uncovered, it is automatically turned face up and is available for play.

History

Crimean Solitaire is Ukrainian Solitaire with the last 3 cards dealt available for play as reserve cards.

Similar Games

Ukrainian Solitaire

Kiev

Dnieper

Russian Solitaire

Criss Cross

Criss Cross

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (3%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To discard all the cards in pairs.

Layout

•5 tableau piles - the top card is available for play.  Pair up cards of the same rank.  Spaces are automatically filled from the stock.  No building, except for the middle pile, which can be built on from the stock.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (left) - Top card of the stock can be paired with the top card of a tableau pile, if possible.  Otherwise, the top card of the stock must be played to the middle pile of the tableau.
•waste (right)  - Where paired cards go out of play.

Similar Games

Simple Pairs

Cromwell

Cromwell

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (20%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•26 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Groups of cards in sequence down in suit may be moved as a unit.  Spaces are not filled.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt face up to each pile. Once per game a draw (or merci) is available.  Right-clicking on any buried card will move that card to the top of its pile.  This can only be done once in each game.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Cromwell was invented by Charles Jewell.

 

Similar Games

House on the Hill

House in the Wood

Crossroads

Crossroads

 Top  Previous  Next

4 Decks.  Very Hard (2%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•16 foundation piles (left and right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (between foundations) -  build down by alternate color.  Groups of cards in sequence down by alternate color may be moved as a unit. Spaces are filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt to each pile, alternating face up and face down.
•stock (top left) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste pile by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

History

Crossroads is a variation of Junction.

Crown

 Top  Previous  Next

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•12 tableau piles (left of foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are filled from the waste, or the stock if the waste is empty.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (face down, top left) - turn over 1 card to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (under stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Cruel

Cruel

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (20%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.  At the start of the game the Aces are dealt here.
•12 tableau piles (center) - build down in suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are not filled.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile.
•stock (left, with green arrow) - clicking on the stock collects all the cards from the tableau and redeals them.  Unlimited redeals.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•When play on the tableau comes to a standstill, the tableau can be redealt by clicking on the stock.  The cards are collected from the tableau starting with the last pile (lower right) of the tableau back to the first pile (top left), with the cards from the last pile on the bottom.  They are then redealt 4 cards to a pile starting with the first pile.
•Because of the way the cards are redealt, if no moves are made in the tableau the cards will be redealt back exactly the same way they were previously.  Therefore, after every deal you must be able to make at least one move in the tableau or the game is lost.

Similar Games

Unusual

Ripple Fan

Lucky Thirteen

Cup of Kindness

Cup of Kindness

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck. Medium (30%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - build up or down regardless of suit, wrapping Ace to King or King to Ace as necessary.  At the start of the game one card is dealt to each pile.  With the exception of the first card dealt to the pile, cards may be moved from one foundation pile to another.
•4 reserve piles (below foundations) - No building.  Cards are dealt here from the stock.  The top card of each pile is available for play.  Cards are available for play on the foundations only.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (face down) - deal 1 card to each reserve pile by clicking.  No redeals.

History

Cup of Kindness is a variation of the game Auld Lang Syne.

Similar Games

Auld Lang Syne

Acquaintance

Sir Tommy

Tam O'Shanter

Reveillion

Curds and Whey

Curds and Whey

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (60%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards into 4 sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace within the tableau.

Layout

•13 tableau piles - build down in suit, or in the same rank.  Groups of cards in sequence down in suit (or of the same rank) may be moved as a unit (groups moved as a unit cannot contain both cards descending in sequence and multiple cards of the same rank at the same time).  Spaces are filled by a King or a legal group of cards headed with a King.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile.

Notes

•The tableau piles are built down in suit, or in the same rank. That is, if the exposed card of a pile is the 7 ♠, the 6 ♠ or another 7 (such as the 7 ♥) may be played on it.

 

History

Curds and Whey was invented by David Parlett.  It is a member of the Spider family of games.

Similar Games

Miss Muffet

Spider

Aracnida

Scorpion

Will o the Wisp

Simple Simon

Rank Spider

Object

Layout

•4 foundation piles (corners) - build up in suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•5 tableau piles (forming cross) - build down regardless of suit, wrapping from Ace to King as necessary.  Spaces are filled automatically from the stock.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (face down) - turn over cards one at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.

 

•waste (below stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Darwin

Darwin

 Top  Previous  Next

3 Decks.  Hard (20%).  Skill/Luck Balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•12 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - Build down in suit.  Groups of cards may be moved regardless of sequence. Spaces filled by Kings or groups of cards headed by a King, unless the stock is empty, in which case spaces can be filled by any card. At the start of the game 8 cards are dealt to each pile.

 

•stock (bottom left) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste pile by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Demon

Demon

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (75%)  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces are filled from the reserve if possible, then by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 3 cards at a time, by clicking.  Unlimited redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card always available for play on the tableau or foundations.
•reserve (left of tableau) - Top card always available for play on the tableau or foundations.  At the start of the game 40 cards are dealt here.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Demon is a 2 deck relative of Canfield.  In England the game Canfield is often called Demon.

Similar Games

Demon Fan

Demon Fan

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (99%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (left) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•18 fans (right of foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are not filled.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt to each pile (except for the last 2 piles, which have just 2 cards).  Only the top card is face up.
•stock (bottom left, no cards) -  There are 6 redeals.  After all possible plays have been made, redeal by clicking on the green arrow.  

Options

AutoPlay

History

Demon Fan is a Fan type game, slightly unusual in that some cards are dealt face down.

Similar Games

Fan

La Belle Lucie

Demons and Thieves

Demons and Thieves

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Easy (96%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•9 tableau piles (below foundations) - build first 4 (left of line) down by alternate color.  Build remaining 5 (right of line) down in suit, wrapping from Ace to King if necessary in both cases.  Move groups of cards if they form a legal descending sequence for that pile.  Spaces can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt each to the left 4 piles, and 8 cards are dealt to each of the remaining 5 piles.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  Two redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.
•reserve (below stock, next to tableau) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 13 cards are dealt here.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•The tableau piles are divided into two parts: the Left tableau and the Right tableau, divided by a line.  The 4 Left tableau piles are built down by alternate color.  The 5 Right tableau piles are built down in suit.  Groups of cards may be moved from one tableau pile to another, if they form a legal descending sequence in their current pile.  For example, a sequence down by alternate color may be moved from the Left tableau to the Right, since that is the legal sequence for the Left tableau.  However, a sequence down by alternate color cannot be moved from the Right tableau to the Left, since that sequence is not legal on the Right.  These kinds of groups transfers are called "shifts".  Shifts of groups down by alternate color are allowed from Left to Right, while shifts of down in suit cards are allowed from Right to Left.  Once an shift has been made, the cards in the groups cannot again be moved as a group, since they will no longer be a legal group for their side of the tableau.

 

 

Tips

•The secret to success is strategic shifting between the the left tableau and the right tableau.

 

History

Demons and Thieves is a complicated cross between Canfield and Forty Thieves.  It's name derives from Canfield's common name "Demon" and the "Thieves" in Forty Thieves.  The Reserve pile and the Left Tableau resemble Canfield, while the Foundations and Right Tableau resemble Forty Thieves.

 

Demons and Thieves was invented by Thomas Warfield. Demonthief is the same as Demons and Thieves except there are no redeals.

Similar Games

Demonthief

Demons Rush

Triple Demons

Quadruple Demons

Canfield

Forty Thieves

Antares

Yukon Puzzle

Demons Rush

Demons Rush

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Easy (90%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•9 tableau piles (below foundations) - build first 4 (left of line) down by alternate color.  Build remaining 5 (right of line) down in suit, wrapping from Ace to King if necessary in both cases.  Move groups of cards if they form a legal descending sequence for that pile.  Spaces can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt each to the left 4 piles, and 8 cards are dealt to each of the remaining 5 piles.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 3 cards at a time to the waste by clicking during the first deal, 2 cards at a time during the 2nd deal, and 1 card at a time during the last deal.  Two redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.
•reserve (below stock, next to tableau) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 13 cards are dealt here.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•The tableau piles are divided into two parts: the Left tableau and the Right tableau, divided by a line.  The 4 Left tableau piles are built down by alternate color.  The 5 Right tableau piles are built down in suit.  Groups of cards may be moved from one tableau pile to another, if they form a legal descending sequence in their current pile.  For example, a sequence down by alternate color may be moved from the Left tableau to the Right, since that is the legal sequence for the Left tableau.  However, a sequence down by alternate color cannot be moved from the Right tableau to the Left, since that sequence is not legal on the Right.  These kinds of groups transfers are called "shifts".  Shifts of groups down by alternate color are allowed from Left to Right, while shifts of down in suit cards are allowed from Right to Left.  Once an shift has been made, the cards in the groups cannot again be moved as a group, since they will no longer be a legal group for their side of the tableau.

 

 

Tips

•The secret to success is strategic shifting between the the left tableau and the right tableau.

 

History

Demons Rush is a variation of Demons and Thieves invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Demons and Thieves

Demonthief

Demonthief

Demonthief

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (75%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•9 tableau piles (below foundations) - build first 4 (left of line) down by alternate color.  Build remaining 5 (right of line) down in suit, wrapping from Ace to King if necessary in both cases.  Move groups of cards if they form a legal descending sequence for that pile.  Spaces can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt each to the left 4 piles, and 8 cards are dealt to each of the remaining 5 piles.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.
•reserve (below stock, next to tableau) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 13 cards are dealt here.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•The tableau piles are divided into two parts: the Left tableau and the Right tableau, divided by a line.  The 4 Left tableau piles are built down by alternate color.  The 5 Right tableau piles are built down in suit.  Groups of cards may be moved from one tableau pile to another, if they form a legal descending sequence in their current pile.  For example, a sequence down by alternate color may be moved from the Left tableau to the Right, since that is the legal sequence for the Left tableau.  However, a sequence down by alternate color cannot be moved from the Right tableau to the Left, since that sequence is not legal on the Right.  These kinds of groups transfers are called "shifts".  Shifts of groups down by alternate color are allowed from Left to Right, while shifts of down in suit cards are allowed from Right to Left.  Once an shift has been made, the cards in the groups cannot again be moved as a group, since they will no longer be a legal group for their side of the tableau.

 

 

Tips

•The secret to success is strategic shifting between the left tableau and the right tableau.

 

History

Demonthief is Demons and Thieves without any redeals, making it slightly harder.

 

Similar Games

Demons and Thieves

Canfield

Forty Thieves

Deuces

Deuces

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks. Medium (25%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations

Layout

•8 foundation piles (in box in middle) - build up in suit from Deuces (Twos) to King to Ace.  At the start of the game the Twos are dealt here.
•10 tableau piles (in a ring around the foundations) - build down in suit.  Only the top card available for play.  Empty piles can be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - move 1 card to waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (below stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Deuces is a game in the Busy Aces family.  Deuces is slightly harder to win than Busy Aces.  Although in the beginning the first card in each foundation is already played for you (unlike Busy Aces, where you must wait for all the aces to come out), because there are only 10 tableau piles rather than the 12 of Busy Aces, it is harder to win.

Deuces originally appeared under the name "Le Deux" in Le Livre Illustre des Patiences in 1860.

Similar Games

Courtyard

Busy Aces

Three's Company

Fours Up

Penta

Eights Down

Cast Out Nines

Dimes

Jacks in the Box

Deuces and Queens

Deuces and Queens

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (65%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (middle) - build the first 4 piles up regardless of suit from Twos to Kings to Aces, build the last 4 piles down regardless of suit from Queens to Aces to Kings.
•4 tableau piles (below foundations, on right) - build up or down regardless of suit, wrapping from Ace to King or King to Ace if necessary.    Spaces are filled from the stock.  When the stock is empty, spaces cannot be filled.  One card is dealt to each pile at the start of the game.
•3 reserve piles (top) - Top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.  13 cards are dealt to each reserve at the start of the game.
•stock (bottom left, face down) -  Turn over 1 card at a time to the waste pile by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•It is allowed (in fact it is necessary in order to win)  to move cards from one foundation pile to another, in particular from Two foundations to Queen foundations and vice versa.
•Play consists of moving cards from the reserves, waste, and tableau to the foundations, and especially in strategic movement of cards within the foundations to allow more cards to be played there.
•Because Aces and Kings are the last cards played to each foundation (whether they go up or down), these cards require great care in their placement.

History

Deuces and Queens is a variation of Aces and Kings.  It was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Aces and Kings

Devil's Yukon

Devil's Yukon

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (60%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build left 4 piles up in color from Ace to King (2 leftmost with red X's start with red Aces, next 2 in green with black Aces), drop entire 13 card sequences down by alternate color from the tableau on the right 4 piles (2 starting with red X's with red Kings, 2 rightmost in green with black Kings).
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards regardless of any sequence.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.   At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd pile, and so on.  The top card is face up.  Then 4 additional face up cards are dealt to the first pile and 5 additional cards dealt to each of the 2nd through 10th piles.

Notes

•The first 4 foundations are built up card by card as is normal, but the right 4 foundations are built in the tableau.  When an entire 13 card sequence from King to Ace is built, it can be dropped on the right 4 foundations.

 

•There is no AutoPlay in this game, so all cards must be moved by dragging or right-clicking on the card.

Tips

•Keep in mind at all times that you are not only trying to build on the left 4 foundations up in color, but also you must build 4 complete 13-card sequences down by alternate color, much like they are built in Spider.  Whether to move a card to the 4 left foundations or to keep it in the tableau for building one of the sequences is a choice you are faced with often.

History

Devil's Yukon is a combination of Diavolo and Double Yukon suggested by Bastiko Pradhana.

Similar Games

Diavolo

Double Yukon

Rouge et Noir

Lady Cadogan

Dial

Dial

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Easy (99%).  All Luck.

Object

To arrange all the cards in the form of a clock, with all the Queens in a pile at the top, then clockwise around Aces, Twos, up to Jacks, and Kings in the middle.

Layout

•13 tableau piles (the clock) - build in the same rank by alternate color. Spaces may be filled only by a card of the same rank as the clock position of the pile (Queens for the top pile, Aces for the next, and so on, and Kings in the middle).
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste, by clicking.  Two redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the tableau.

History

Dial is one of many variations of the game Clock.

Similar Games

Clock

Dial Harder

Dial Harder

Dial Harder

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (30%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To arrange all the cards in the form of a clock, with all the Queens in a pile at the top, then clockwise around Aces, Twos, up to Jacks, and Kings in the middle.

Layout

•13 tableau piles (the clock) - build in the same rank by alternate color. Spaces may be filled only by a card of the same rank as the clock position of the pile (Queens for the top pile, Aces for the next, and so on, and Kings in the middle).
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste, by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the tableau.

History

Dial Harder is a harder version of Dial.

Similar Games

Dial

Clock

Diavolo

Diavolo

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Very Hard (1%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build left 4 piles up in color from Ace to King (2 leftmost with red X's start with red Aces, next 2 in green with black Aces), drop entire 13 card sequences down by alternate color from the tableau on the right 4 piles (2 starting with red X's with red Kings, 2 rightmost in green with black Kings).
•9 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Groups of cards in sequence down by alternate color may be moved as a unit.  Spaces are filled only by Kings or legal groups of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 9 cards are dealt to the first pile, 8 cards to the 2nd pile, and so on until 1 card is dealt to the 9th piles.  The top card of each pile is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - move 1 card to waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Notes

•The first 4 foundations are built up card by card as is normal, but the right 4 foundations are built in the tableau.  When an entire 13 card sequence from King to Ace is built, it can be dropped on the right 4 foundations.

 

•There is no AutoPlay in this game, so all cards must be moved by dragging or right-clicking on the card.

Tips

•Keep in mind at all times that you are not only trying to build on the left 4 foundations up in color, but also you must build 4 complete 13-card sequences down by alternate color, much like they are built in Spider.  Whether to move a card to the 4 left foundations or to keep it in the tableau for building one of the sequences is a choice you are faced with often.

History

Diavolo is a variation of Rouge et Noir.

Similar Games

Rouge et Noir

Lady Cadogan

Forty Devils

Numeration

Devil's Yukon

Dieppe

Dieppe

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Easy (95%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•8 tableau piles (under foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Groups of cards in sequence down regardless of suit may be moved as a unit.  Spaces may be filled by any available card.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt to each pile.
•stock (lower left, face down) - 1 card at a time moved to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•During the initial deal, after each set of 8 cards is dealt to the tableau, any cards that can be moved to the foundations are automatically moved and spaces filled.  Therefore it is possible that there will be cards already played to the foundations before actual play begins.

History

Dieppe is a variation of Congress and related to Wheatsheaf and Red and Black.

Similar Games

Rouen

Normandy

Congress

Diplomat

Lady Palk

Wheatsheaf

Red and Black

Different Left

Different Left

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (85%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by different suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by different suit.  Spaces are filled automatically by the face up card or group of cards in the pile immediately to the right of the open space.  Empty piles are not filled, except the rightmost pile, if empty, may be filled with a King or a legal group of cards headed by a King. At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 to the 2nd pile, and so on.  The top card is face up.
•stock (bottom left, face down) - turn over cards one at a time to the waste, by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Different Left is a variation of Single Left.

Similar Games

Single Left

Moving Left

Triple Left

Chinaman

Diffusion

Diffusion

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (40%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (center) - build each foundation in suit, regardless of order.  On the top foundation, any card of the same suit as the first card dealt may be played.  On the lower foundations, start with a card of the same rank as the first card dealt, then play any card of that suit where a card of the same rank has already been played to the foundation immediately above.
•4 reserve or tableau piles (left of foundations) - top card is available for play on the foundations.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt to each pile, the top card is face up.
•stock (face down, right) - Click to play one card to each reserve.  One redeal.

 

•3 reserve piles (below stock) - The top card of each reserve pile is available for play on the foundations.

Notes

•Play consists entirely of playing cards to the foundations.
•For example, suppose the first card dealt to the first foundation is the 10 ♥.  Then any ♥ from the reserve or waste could be played to the first foundation pile.  Suppose you can play the Ace, Five, and King ♥.  The 3 foundations below must be founded with the other 3 Tens, as they become available.  Suppose the 10 ♠ is available.  It is played to start the second foundation.  Then only the Ace, Five, or King ♠ could be played to the second foundation, since these are the only ranks in the first foundation pile.  Suppose the Ace ♠ can be played to the second foundation.  Then in the third foundation, first a remaining Ten and then only the Ace of the same suit could be played.   The effect is that the ranks filter down through the foundations.

History

Diffusion is a variation of Osmosis.

Similar Games

Osmosis

Peek

Bridesmaids

Four by Five

Dimes

Dimes

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks. Medium (25%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations

Layout

•8 foundation piles (in box in middle) - build up in suit from Dimes (Tens) to King to Ace to Nines.  At the start of the game the Tens are dealt here.
•8 tableau piles (around the foundations) - build down in suit.  Only the top card available for play.  Empty piles can be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - move 1 card to waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (beside stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Dimes is a variation of Deuces.
