Jacks in the Box

Diminishing Reserves

Diminishing Reserves

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (15%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top right) - build the upper 4 piles up in suit from Ace to King, build the lower 4 piles down in suit from Kings to Aces.  At the start of the game one Ace and one King of each suit are dealt here.
•5 reserve piles (below foundations) - storage spaces for cards.  No building.  Top card is available for play on the foundations or Queen reserve.  Cards are dealt here from the stock.  Two cards are dealt to each pile at the start of the game.
•Queen reserve (top left) - begins with the Queen ♣. Build down regardless of suit.  Top card is available for play on the foundations.
•stock (left, face down) -  clicking plays cards to the reserve piles.  On the first deal, one card is dealt to each of the 5 piles.  On the 2nd deal, one card is dealt to the first 4 piles.  On the 3rd deal, one card is dealt to the first 3 piles.  On the 4th deal, one card is dealt to the first 2 piles.  On the last deal, one card is dealt to the first pile only.  Click on the empty stock to redeal.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

• The first deal after a redeal (and the initial deal at the start of the game) deals 2 cards to each pile.
•Although the Queen ♣ can be played to the foundations at the start of the game, if you do so you will not be able to use the Queen reserve to store any other cards.

Diplomat

Diplomat

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (65%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) -  build down regardless of suit.  Only the top card of each pile may be moved.  Spaces filled by any card.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (bottom left) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste pile by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

 

History

Diplomat is very similar to Congress.  For an easier game, see Rows of Four.

Similar Games

Dnieper

Dnieper

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (30%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards into 4 sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - move entire 13-card King to Ace down in suit sequences from the tableau.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit, wrapping from Ace to King as necessary.  Move groups of cards regardless of any sequence.  Fill spaces with any card.   At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt face down to each pile and one card is dealt is face up.
•stock (top left) - deals one card to each tableau pile by clicking.  No redeals.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Any face up card in the tableau may be built upon another, no matter how deep it is in a pile.  All cards covering it are moved together.  When a face down card is uncovered, it is automatically turned face up and is available for play.

History

Dnieper is a slightly easier variation of Kiev.

Similar Games

Kiev

Ukrainian Solitaire

Russian Solitaire

Dominion

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (5%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (middle) - build up regardless of suit from Ace to King.
•8 tableau piles (top) - No building.  Top card available for play on the foundations.  Spaces are filled automatically from the stock.  When the stock is empty, spaces may be filled by any card.
•stock (bottom, face down) - move 1 card to waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations.

History

Doorways

Doorways

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (80%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•5 foundation piles (across top) - build up or down regardless of suit, wrapping from Ace to King or King to Ace if needed, from the first card played to each pile.  Any number of cards may be played to each pile.
•5 tableau piles (below foundations) - build up or down regardless of suit, wrapping from Ace to King or King to Ace if necessary.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence up in suit or in sequence down in suit.  Fill spaces with any card or legal group of cards.   At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt to each pile, alternating face up and face down.
•stock (face down) - turn over cards one at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (beside stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Doorways is a game like Single Interchange.  It is deceptively easy, but the unusual foundation pile building can require care.

Similar Games

Single Interchange

Interchange

Dorothy

Dorothy

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (8%).  All Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•12 foundation piles (right) - build top 4 piles down in suit by twos starting with Tens (10,8,6,4,2), build the middle 4 piles up in suit starting with Jacks (J,Q,K), and the bottom 4 piles down in suit by twos starting with Nines (9,7,5,3,Ace).
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card to waste by clicking.  One redeal.
•waste (below stock) - top card available for play on the foundations.

Double Aces and Kings

Double Aces and Kings

 Top  Previous  Next

4 Decks.  Medium (50%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•16 foundation piles (middle) - build the top 8 piles from Ace to King up regardless of suit, build the bottom 8 piles from Kings to Aces down regardless of suit.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - storage spaces for cards.  Only one card allowed per pile.  Spaces are filled from the stock.  When the stock is empty, spaces are filled by any card.  One card is dealt to each pile at the start of the game.
•4 reserve piles (top) - Top card available for play on the foundations.  13 cards are dealt to each reserve at the start of the game.
•stock (bottom left, face down) -  Turn over 1 card at a time to the waste pile by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•It is allowed (in fact is it necessary in order to win)  to move cards from one foundation pile to another, in particular from Ace foundations to King foundations and vice versa.
•Play consists of moving cards from the reserves, waste, and tableau to the foundations, and especially in strategic movement of cards within the foundations to allow more cards to be played there.

History

Double Aces and Kings is a variation of Aces and Kings invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Aces and Kings

Racing Aces

Double Acme

Double Acme

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (20%)  Skill/luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Aces to Kings. At the beginning of the game the Aces are dealt here.
•5 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit.  Spaces are filled from the reserve if possible, then by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time, by clicking.  1 redeal.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card always available for play on the tableau or foundations.
•reserve (left of tableau) - Top card always available for play on the tableau or foundations.  At the start of the game 19 cards are dealt here.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Double Acme is a two deck version of Acme.

Double Acquaintance

Double Acquaintance

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (50%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top) - build up regardless of suit from Ace to King.
•8 reserve piles (below foundations) - cards are dealt here from the stock.  The top card of each pile is available for play.  Move cards to the foundations by clicking.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (face down) - deal 1 card to each reserve pile by clicking.  Two redeals.

History

Double Alaska

Double Alaska

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (70%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build up or down by suit.  Move groups of cards regardless of any sequence.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.   At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd pile, and so on.  The top card is face up.  Then 4 additional face up cards are dealt to the first pile and 5 additional cards dealt to each of the 2nd through 10th piles.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Any face up card in the tableau may be built upon another, no matter how deep it is in a pile.  All cards covering it are moved together.  When a face down card is uncovered, it is automatically turned face up and is available for play.

Tips

•Uncover the face down cards as soon as possible.  Don't let one foundation get too far ahead of the others.

History

Double Alaska is a 2 deck version of Alaska.

Similar Games

•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - Build down in suit.  Groups of cards may be moved regardless of sequence. Spaces filled by Kings or groups of cards headed by a King. At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile.

 

•stock (top left) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste pile by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Double Bisley

Double Bisley

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (40%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•16 foundation piles (left and right) - build the left columns up in suit starting with Aces, build the right columns down in suit starting with Kings.  It does not matter where the two piles of the same suit meet.  At the start of the game the Aces are dealt to the left columns.
• 16 tableau piles (in between foundations) - build up or down by suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are not filled.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt face up to each pile.

Options

AutoPlay

Similar Games

Bisley

Indefatigable

Double Canfield

Double Canfield

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Very Easy (99%).  Skill/luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•5 tableau piles (below foundations on right) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces are filled from the reserve if possible, else by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (left below foundations, face down) - turn over 1 or 3 cards at a time to the waste, by clicking.  Unlimited redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.
•reserve (left of tableau, next to Waste) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 13 cards are dealt here.

Options

Rules - selects whether 1 card or 3 cards at a time are turned over from the stock.  (See options menu).

AutoPlay

History

Double Canfield is a two-deck version of the single deck game Canfield.

Similar Games

Canfield

Triple Canfield

American Toad

Double Dot

Double Dot

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (98%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit by Twos.  The first two piles start with Aces (Ace, 3,5,7,9,J,K,2,4,6,8,10,Q), the next 2 piles start with Twos (2,4,6,8,10,Q,A,3,5,7,9,J,K).  2 Aces and 2 Twos of different colors are dealt here at the start of the game.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit by twos, wrapping if necessary.  For example, a 6 can be played on an 8 or a Queen on an Ace.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down regardless of suit by twos.  Spaces can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top right, face down) - Deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.  No redeals.

Similar Games

Odd and Even

Double Duke

Double Duke

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks. Easy (95%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Aces to Kings.
•6 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces are filled by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste, by clicking.  Two redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.
•6 reserve piles (left of tableau) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt face up to each pile.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Double Duke is a two deck version of Duke.

Similar Games

Duke

Canfield

Dutchess

Double Easthaven

Double Easthaven

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Deck.  Hard (10%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Fill spaces with any card or legal sequence of cards.  At the start of the game, 3 cards are dealt to each pile, 2 face down and 1 face up.

 

•stock (top left, face down) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Double Easthaven is a two deck version of Easthaven.

Similar Games

Easthaven

Triple Easthaven

Double Eight Off

Double Eight Off

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (80%).  Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•8 cells (around top left corner) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell. At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each cell.

 

•12 tableau piles (below foundations and cells) -  build down in suit.  The top card is available for play on the foundations, cells, or another tableau pile.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit and if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.  Fill spaces with Kings or a group of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 8 cards are dealt face up to each pile.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Groups of cards in the tableau can only be moved as a group if there are a sufficient number of empty cells available to store the cards individually.  The ability to move cards as a group is only a shortcut to moving the group one card at a time.

Tips

•Try to keep as many cells empty as possible.

History

Double Eight Off is a 2 deck version of Eight Off.

Similar Games

Eight Off

FreeCell Duplex

FreeCell

Double FreeCell

FreeCell Twice

Double Fives

Double Fives

 Top  Previous  Next

2 separate decks.  Very Easy (98%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from the rank of first card moved to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Only the top card of each pile may be moved.  Spaces may be filled by any available card.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•2 reserve piles (top) - one of the two cards is moved to the first foundation pile to become the base.  The other card is then available for play on the foundations or tableau.
•stock (bottom left, face down) - the first time through the deck deals 1 card to 5 waste piles clicking.  Each of the 5 cards are available for play on the foundations or tableau.  When the next set of 5 cards are dealt, any cards remaining in the 5 waste piles are moved out of play until the redeal.  One redeal.  The redeal collects all the unplayed cards from the first deal to form the new stock.  After the redeal, clicking on the stock deals 1 card to a waste pile.
•waste (next to stock) - Before the redeal there are 5 piles, after the redeal there is one. Top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Double Fives starts with 2 separate decks.  The first deck is dealt face up to the tableau (the two extra cards dealt to 2 reserve piles).  The other deck is dealt entirely to the stock.

History

Double Fives is an unusual variation of Forty Thieves.

Similar Games

Forty Thieves

Double Nickels

Double Fourteens

Double Fourteens

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Easy (86%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To pair up all cards and move them out of play to the waste pile.

Layout

•18 tableau piles - the top card of each pile is available.  Pair cards that total to 14.  For example, a King and an Ace, a Queen and a 2, or an 8 and a 6.  To remove a pair, pick up one card with the mouse and drop it on the other.  At the beginning of the game 6 cards are dealt to each of the first 16 piles, and 4 cards are dealt the remaining 2 piles.

 

•waste pile (far right) - where paired cards go out of play.

Notes

•Cards that pair to 14: King-Ace, Queen-2, Jack-3, 10-4, 9-5, 8-6, 7-7.

History

Double Fourteens is a two deck version of Fourteen Out.

Similar Games

Fourteen Out

Triple Fourteens

Double FreeCell

Double FreeCell

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Easy (90%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King, wrapping to Ace and then to King again, until each pile contains 26 cards.  At the beginning of the game an Ace of each suit is dealt here.
•6 cells (top left) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.  The card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations and cells) - The piles are built down by alternate color.  The top card is available for play on the foundations, cells, or another tableau pile.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color and if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.  Fill spaces with Kings or legal groups of cards headed by a King (see KingOnly for variation).  At the start of the game 10 cards are dealt to each pile.

Options

KingOnly   AutoPlay

Notes

•Note that groups of cards in the tableau can only be moved as a group if there are a sufficient number of empty cells available to store the cards individually.  The ability to move cards as a group is only a shortcut to moving the group one card at a time.

Tips

•Try to keep as many cells empty as possible.

History

Double FreeCell is a two-deck version of FreeCell.  It was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

FreeCell

Triple FreeCell

Repair

FreeCell Duplex

FreeCell Twice

Twenty Piles

Quadruple FreeCell

Double Gold Rush

Double Gold Rush

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Easy (90%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Fill spaces with Kings or a group of cards headed by a King. At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.  The top card is face up.
•stock (bottom left, face down) - turn over 3 cards at a time to the waste by clicking during the first deal, 2 cards at a time during the 2nd deal, and 1 card at a time during the last deal.  Two redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Double Gold Rush is a 2 deck variation of Gold Rush.

Similar Games

Gold Rush

Triple Gold Rush

Double Golf

Double Golf

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (10%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the waste pile.

Layout

•10 tableau piles (across top) - no building.  Top card of each pile is available for play on the waste pile.  At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (face down below tableau) - turn over 1 card to the waste by clicking.

 

•waste (next to stock) - build up or down in sequence regardless of suit.  No wraparound, only Twos can be played on Aces and nothing can be played on a King.

 

Notes

•Play cards from the tableau to the waste if possible.  Whenever there are no possible plays, turn over a card in the stock by clicking on it.  This card goes to the waste pile.

Tips

•Work out your sequences in advance.  Be careful to save queens for kings, and twos for aces.

History

Double Golf is a two deck variation of the classic game Golf.

Similar Games

Golf

Putt Putt

Panther Creek

Double Putt

Par 3

Double Jane

Double Jane

 Top  Previous  Next

4 Decks.  Easy (90%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•16 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•13 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit.  Fill spaces with a King or group of cards headed by a King. At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.

History

Double Jane is a 4 deck variation of Lady Jane.

Similar Games

Lady Jane

Arabella

Double Kingsley

Double Kingsley

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (1%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top) - build down in suit from King to Ace.
•9 tableau piles (below foundations) - build up by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence up by alternate color.  Fill spaces with Aces or groups of cards with an Ace at the bottom. At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.  The top card is face up.
•stock (bottom left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time, by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Double Kingsley is a two deck version of Kingsley.

Similar Games

Kingsley

Klondike

Triple Kingsley

Double Klondike

Double Klondike

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Very Easy (99%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•9 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Fill spaces with Kings or a legal group of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 to the 2nd pile, and so on.  The top card is face up.
•stock (bottom left, face down) - turn over 3 cards at a time to the waste, by clicking.  Unlimited redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

Rules - selects whether 1 card or 3 cards at a time are turned over from the stock. (See options menu).

KingOnly AutoPlay

History

Double Klondike, like Gargantua, is a two-deck variation of Klondike.

Similar Games

Gargantua

Klondike

Triple Klondike

Quadruple Klondike

Batsford

Harp

Steps

Moving Left

Klondike Twice

Double Limited

Double Limited

 Top  Previous  Next

4 Decks.  Medium (85%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•16 foundation piles (left and right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•16 tableau piles (between foundations) - build down in suit.  Move single cards only.  Fill spaces with any card.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 cards at a time to the waste, by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Double Limited is a 4 deck version of the 2 deck game Limited.

Similar Games

Limited

Double Minerva

Double Minerva

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (10%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•9 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards with a King at the bottom.  At the start of the game 6 rows of cards are dealt alternately face down and face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time, by clicking.  One redeal.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.
•reserve (left of tableau) - Top card always available for play on the tableau or foundations.  At the start of the game 13 cards are dealt here.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Double Minerva is a two deck version of Minerva invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Minerva

Triple Minerva

Double Moosehide

Double Moosehide

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (80%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in any suit but the same.  Move groups of cards regardless of any sequence.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.   At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd pile, and so on.  The top card is face up.  Then 4 additional face up cards are dealt to the first pile and 5 additional cards dealt to each of the 2nd through 10th piles.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Any face up card in the tableau may be built upon another, no matter how deep it is in a pile.  All cards covering it are moved together.  When a face down card is uncovered, it is automatically turned face up and is available for play.

Tips

•Uncover the face down cards as soon as possible.  Don't let one foundation get too far ahead of the others.

History

Double Moosehide is a 2 deck version of Moosehide.

Similar Games

Moosehide

Double Yukon

Yukon

Double Nestor

Double Nestor

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (75%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To discard all the cards in pairs.

Layout

•12 tableau piles (across top) - the top card is available for play.  Pair up cards of the same rank.  At the start of the game 8 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•8 extra cards (below tableau) - each card is available for play to be paired with cards in the tableau.

History

Double Nestor is a 2 deck version of Nestor.

Similar Games

Nestor

Doublets

Vertical

Heracles

Double Vertical

Double Nickels

Double Nickels

 Top  Previous  Next

2 separate decks.  Very Easy (98%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from the rank of first card moved to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Only the top card of each pile may be moved.  Spaces may be filled by any available card.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•2 cells  (top) - one of the two cards is moved to the first foundation pile to become the base.  The other card is then available for play on the foundations or tableau.  Any card may be moved to an empty cell.
•stock (bottom left, face down) - the first time through the deck deals 1 card to 5 waste piles clicking.  Each of the 5 cards are available for play on the foundations or tableau.  When the next set of 5 cards are dealt, any cards remaining in the 5 waste piles are moved out of play until the redeal.  One redeal.  The redeal collects all the unplayed cards from the first deal to form the new stock.  After the redeal, clicking on the stock deals 1 card to a waste pile.
•waste (next to stock) - Before the redeal there are 5 piles, after the redeal there is one. Top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Double Nickels starts with 2 separate decks.  The first deck is dealt face up to the tableau (the two extra cards dealt to 2 reserve piles).  The other deck is dealt entirely to the stock.

History

Double Nickels is a variation of Double Fives.

Similar Games

Double Fives

Forty Thieves

Double or Quits

Double or Quits

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (47%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards (except Kings) to the single foundation.

Layout

•1 foundation pile (lower center) - build pile from the starting card dealt by doubling ranks (subtract 13 if the rank is higher than 13).  The doubling sequence is A-2-4-8-3-6-Q-J-9-5-10-7 and back to Ace.  Kings are ignored.  This doubling sequence may start at any point of the sequence, depending on what card is dealt at the start of the game.
•7 reserve piles (around foundation) - each pile can contain 1 card.  No building.  Spaces are filled from the waste (if empty, from the stock).  When a pile contains a King the King cannot be moved for the rest of the game.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card to waste by clicking.  Two redeals.
•waste (top right, next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundation or reserves.

Options

AutoPlay

Double Putt

Double Putt

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (25%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the waste pile.

Layout

•10 tableau piles (across top) - no building.  Top card of each pile is available for play on the waste pile.  At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (face down below tableau) - turn over 1 card to the waste by clicking.

 

•waste (next to stock) - build up or down in sequence regardless of suit, wrapping Ace to King or King to Ace as necessary.

.

 

Notes

•Play cards from the tableau to the waste if possible.  Whenever there are no possible plays, turn over a card in the stock by clicking on it.  This card goes to the waste pile.

Tips

•Work out your sequences in advance.

History

Double Putt is a two deck variation of Putt Putt.

Similar Games

Golf

Putt Putt

Double Golf

Double Pyramid

Double Pyramid

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (5%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To pair up all the cards in the deck in pairs of cards whose ranks total to 13.

Layout

•A Pyramid of 50 cards.  Only uncovered cards are available for play.  Discard pairs of cards whose ranks add to 13.  Kings are discarded singly.  To discard a pair, drop one card on the other, or right-click on one of the cards.
•stock (top left) - turn over cards one at a time to the waste by clicking.  Two redeals.
•waste (below stock) - The top card is available for play.

Notes

•Any pair of cards whose values add to 13 can be discarded.  The valid pairs are Queen-Ace, Jack-Two, 10-3, 9-4, 8-5, 7-6.  Kings are discarded singly.  To discards Kings, simply click on them.

History

Double Pyramid is a two deck version of Pyramid invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Pyramid

Double Queenie

Double Queenie

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Easy (95%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Groups of cards may be moved regardless of any sequence.  Fill spaces with Kings or a group of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd pile, and so on.
•stock (top left, face down) -Deal one card to each tableau pile, by clicking.  No redeals.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Double Queenie is a two deck version of Queenie.

Similar Games

Double Rail

Double Rail

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (4%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•5 tableau piles (below foundations) -  build down regardless of suit.  Groups of cards can be moved if they are in sequence down regardless of suit.  Spaces are filled by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (bottom left) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste pile by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Similar Games

Double Russian

Double Russian

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (80%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Move groups of cards regardless of any sequence.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.   At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd pile, and so on.  The top card is face up.  Then 4 additional cards are dealt to the first pile, and 5 additional cards to the 2nd through 10th piles.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Any face up card in the tableau may be built upon another, no matter how deep it is in a pile.  All cards covering it are moved together.  When a face down card is uncovered, it is automatically turned face up and is available for play.

Tips

•Uncover the face down cards as soon as possible.  Don't let one foundation get too far ahead of the others.

History

Double Russian is a 2 deck version of Russian Solitaire.

Similar Games

Russian Solitaire

Triple Russian

Yukon

Triple Yukon

Quadruple Russian

Double Alaska

Triple Alaska

Double Scorpion

Double Scorpion

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Easy (85%).  Skill.

Object

To group all the cards into 8 sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace within the tableau.

Layout

•10 tableau piles - build down in suit.  Groups of cards may be moved regardless of any sequence.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 11 cards are dealt to each of the first 4 piles, 10 cards each to the remaining piles.  In the first 5 piles, 4 cards are face down, all others are face up.

Notes

The object of play is to manipulate the tableau into 8 piles, one for each suit, with the cards down in sequence from King to Ace.

History

Double Scorpion is a two-deck version of the game Scorpion.

Similar Games

Scorpion

Triple Scorpion

Quadruple Scorpion

Double SeaTowers

Double SeaTowers

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Easy (90%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (left and right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•9 cells (top center) - storage location for one card.   Only 1 card allowed in each cell.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the center 5 cells.
•11 tableau piles (below cells) - build down in suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit and if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.  Spaces can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.   At the start of the game 9 cards are dealt face up to each pile.

 

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Groups of cards in the tableau can only be moved as a group if there are a sufficient number of empty cells available to store the cards individually.  The ability to move cards as a group is only a shortcut to moving the group one card at a time.

Tips

•Try to keep as many cells empty as possible.

History

Double SeaTowers is a 2 deck version of Sea Towers invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Sea Towers

FreeCell

Baker's Game

Double Signora

Double Signora

 Top  Previous  Next

4 Decks.  Medium (20%). Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•16 foundation piles (left, across top, right) - build up by alternate color from the rank of first card moved to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•11 tableau piles (bottom row, center) - build down by alternate color, wrapping from Ace to King if necessary.  Only the top card of each pile may be moved.  Spaces are filled automatically from the waste, or stock if the waste is empty.   At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•reserve (above tableau) - top card is available for play on the foundations only.  At the start of the game 21 cards are dealt here.
•stock (middle left, face down) - turn over cards 1 at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

The game begins by choosing a card to move to the first foundation pile.  The rank of this card becomes the base card for all the other foundation piles.  This first move is very important.

History

Double Signora is a 4 deck version of the 2 deck game Signora.  It was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Signora

Empress of Italy

Terrace

Double Spidike

Double Spidike

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (60%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Move groups of cards only if they are in sequence down in suit.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.
•stock (top left, face down) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.

Options

AutoPlay

Tips

•Same suit sequences should be preferred even though building is down regardless of suit.  The foundations are built up in suit.

History

Double Spidike is a two deck variation of the game Spidike.  Double Spidike was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Spidike

Eternal Triangle

Triple Spidike

Double Stonewall

Double Stonewall

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (10%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top center) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•9 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Groups of cards in sequence down by alternate color may be moved as a unit.  Spaces are filled by any card.  At the start of the game 8 cards are dealt to each pile, alternating face up and face down.
•2 reserves (left) - All cards available for play.  Click on card to move it to the bottom of the stack, then move to either foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 16 cards are dealt to each pile.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Double Stonewall is a two deck variation of Stonewall.

Similar Games

Stonewall

Flower Garden

Brigade

Northwest Territory

Klondike Territory

Double Storehouse

Double Storehouse

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.   Easy (90%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Twos up to Kings, then Aces.  At the start of the game the Twos are dealt here.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit, wrapping from Ace to King as necessary.  Spaces are filled from the Storehouse if possible, then by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste, by clicking.  Two redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.
•reserve (the "Storehouse", left of tableau) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 19 cards are dealt to this pile.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Double Storehouse is a 2 deck version of Storehouse.

Similar Games

Storehouse

Canfield

Triple Storehouse

Double Trigon

Double Trigon

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Easy (80%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•9 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit.  Fill spaces with Kings or a legal group of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 to the 2nd pile, and so on.  The top card is face up.
•stock (bottom left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste, by clicking.  Unlimited redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Double Trigon is a variation of Double Klondike.

Similar Games

Trigon

Double Klondike

Three Bears

Quadruple Trigon

Double Vertical

Double Vertical

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (60%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To discard all the cards in pairs.

Layout

•11 tableau piles (across top) - the top card is available for play.  Pair up cards of the same rank.  At the start of the game 8 cards are dealt face up to each pile (except for the center three piles which are dealt 9 cards).   The cards are dealt in such a way that no two cards of the same rank are dealt to the same pile.
•13 extra cards (below tableau) - each card is available for play.

History

Double Vertical is a 2 deck version of Vertical.

Similar Games

Vertical

Nestor

Doublets

Double Nestor

Double Yukon

Double Yukon

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (80%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards regardless of any sequence.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.   At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd pile, and so on.  The top card is face up.  Then 4 additional face up cards are dealt to the first pile and 5 additional cards dealt to each of the 2nd through 10th piles.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Any face up card in the tableau may be built upon another, no matter how deep it is in a pile.  All cards covering it are moved together.  When a face down card is uncovered, it is automatically turned face up and is available for play.

Tips

•Uncover the face down cards as soon as possible.  Don't let one foundation get too far ahead of the others.

History

Double Yukon is a 2 deck version of Yukon.

Similar Games

Yukon

Triple Yukon

Quadruple Yukon

Russian Solitaire

Double Alaska

Yukon Twice

Devil's Yukon

Doublets

Doublets

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (35%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To discard all the cards in pairs of the same rank.

Layout

•12 tableau piles  - discard pairs of cards of the same rank.   The top card of each pile is available.  Spaces are automatically filled from the reserve.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile, only the top card is face up.
•reserve (far right, face down) - Used to fill spaces in the tableau.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt face down to this pile.

History

Doublets is related to Nestor and other pair-discard games.

Similar Games

Open Doublets

Nestor

Vertical

Simple Pairs

Patient Pairs

Doublet Cell

Doublet Cell

Doublet Cell

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (20%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To discard all the cards in pairs of the same rank and color.

Layout

•4 cells (top left) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.  A card may be paired with another card in a cell or the tableau of the same rank and color.

 

•8 tableau piles (below cells) - discard pairs of cards of the same rank and color (for example, two red Queens).  Cards can be moved to an empty cell.   Spaces cannot be filled.  At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt face up to the leftmost 4 piles, 6 cards are dealt face up to the remaining piles.

History

Doublet Cell is a combination of Doublets and FreeCell.

Similar Games

Fifteen Rush

Doublets

FreeCell

Doubtful Pairs

Doubtful Pairs

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck. Hard (5%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To discard all the cards in pairs of the same rank and different colors.

Layout

•13 tableau piles  - discard pairs of cards of the same rank and different colors (such as a Red Jack and a Black Jack) by dropping one of the cards onto the other.   The top card of each pile is available.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile.

History

Doubtful Pairs is a more difficult version of Patient Pairs.

Similar Games

Frustrating Pairs

Patient Pairs

Doublets

Nestor

Vertical

Simple Pairs

Dover

Dover

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks. Medium (45%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Aces to Kings.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces may be filled only from a waste pile.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - deals 1 card to each waste pile by clicking.  No redeals.
•3 waste piles (below stock) - discard piles, cards are moved here from the stock only.  Top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Dover is a 2 deck relative of Bristol.

Similar Games

Bristol

New York

Gotham

Downing Street

Downing Street

 Top  Previous  Next

4 Decks.  Medium (20%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•16 foundation piles (across top, left, right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color. Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color. Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 8 cards are dealt to each pile, alternating face up and face down.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Downing Street is a variation of Number Ten invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Number Ten
Eighty Thieves

Dreamer

Dreamer

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (20%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards in sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace.

Layout

•10 tableau piles - build down regardless of suit.  Groups of cards in sequence down in suit may be moved as a unit.  A space can be filled by any card or legal group of cards. At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 to the 2nd pile, and so on.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.  All tableau piles must be filled before dealing.

Notes

•Whenever a sequence of 13 cards down in suit from King to Ace is formed, it will automatically be removed from play.

Tips

•Same suit sequences should be preferred even though building is down regardless of suit.  The object is to build down in suit sequences.
•Spaces should be made as soon as possible, and used to move cards into groups by suit.

History

Dreamer is Spider with a Klondike type tableau.

Similar Games

Spider

Klondike

Duke

Duke

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck. Very Easy (99%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Aces to Kings.
•4 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces are filled from the reserve if possible, then by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste, by clicking.  Two redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.
•4 reserve piles (left of tableau) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt face up to each pile.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Duke is a variation of Canfield.

Similar Games

Canfield

Dutchess

Double Duke

Dumfries

Dumfries

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (20%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color or of the same rank of alternate color.  For example, on a red Ten you can play a black 9 or a black Ten.   Single cards can be moved and also entire piles (regardless of sequence).  No partial piles can be moved.   Spaces can be filled with any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt each pile.
•stock (top left, face up) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.  No redeals.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Dumfries is an easier version of Galloway.

Similar Games

Galloway

Dutchess

Dutchess

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (90%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from the rank of first card played to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•4 tableau piles (below foundations on right) - build down by alternate color, wrapping from Ace to King if necessary.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces are filled from the reserve if possible, else by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste, by clicking.  One redeal.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.
•4 reserve piles (left of tableau) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt face up to each pile.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Play begins by selecting an available card and moving it to the leftmost foundation to be the base card of the foundations.

History

Dutchess is a variation of Canfield invented by Albert H. Morehead and Geoffrey Mott-Smith.

Similar Games

Canfield

Duke

Countess

Dutch Solitaire

Dutch Solitaire

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (20%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•5 foundation piles (1 in center, 4 others diagonally around it in the center square) - build up or down regardless of suit, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary.  Each pile may contain any number of cards at the end of the game.  At the start of the game, 5 Aces are dealt here.
•6 tableau piles (top, bottom, left, and right outside the square) - build up or down regardless of suit, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary.  Spaces may be filled by any card. Top card only is available for play on the foundations or another tableau pile.  At the start of the game 10 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - the top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Dutch Solitaire has a similar layout to Windmill.

Eagle Wing

Eagle Wing

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (90%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•8 tableau piles (the wings) - build down in suit, limit of 3 cards per pile, wrapping from Ace to King as necessary.  Groups of cards may be moved as a unit if they are in sequence down in suit.  Spaces are filled from the reserve (or Trunk) until it is empty, then by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•reserve or Trunk (middle) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 13, 15, 17, 19 or 21 cards (depending on the setting in the Options menu) are dealt to this pile.
•stock (face down, bottom left) - turn over cards one at a time to the waste by clicking.  There are 0, 1, or 2 redeals (depending on the setting in the Options menu).

 

•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Eagle Wing can be very easy or very difficult depending on the settings.  A 13 card trunk with 2 redeals is fairly easy to win.  A 21 card trunk with no redeals is very difficult to win.  A happy medium, with a 17 card deck and 1 or 2 redeals, is generally the best to play.  The number of cards in the trunk and the number of redeals is controlled by the setttings in the Options menu.

Similar Games

Wings

Bald Eagle

EastCliff

EastCliff

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (80%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (middle) - build down by alternate color.  Only one card at a time may be moved.   Fill spaces with any card.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt to each pile, 2 face down and 1 face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste, by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (below stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

EastCliff is Westcliff with no moving of groups of cards.

Similar Games

Westcliff

Westcliff Rush

EastHaven

EastHaven

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (30%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Fill spaces with Kings or a legal group of cards headed by a King (see KingOnly for option).  At the start of the game, 3 cards are dealt to each pile, 2 face down and 1 face up.

 

•stock (top left, face down) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.

Options

KingOnly   AutoPlay

Tips

•The difficult part of this game is that the new cards dealt can completely ruin the tableau.  Not checking the KingOnly option makes the game somewhat easier to win.

History

EastHaven is a variation of Klondike.  It originally appeared under this name in The Complete Book of Solitaire & Patience Games.  It was known in previous books dating back to at least 1931 under the name Aces Up.

Similar Games

Klondike

Double Easthaven

Triple Easthaven

Blind Alleys

Spiderette

Easy Diavolo

Easy Diavolo

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.   Medium (50%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build left 4 piles up in color from Ace to King (2 leftmost with red X's start with red Aces, next 2 in green with black Aces), drop entire 13 card sequences down by alternate color from the tableau on the right 4 piles (2 starting with red X's with red Kings, 2 rightmost in green with black Kings).
•9 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Groups of cards in sequence down by alternate color may be moved as a unit.  Spaces are filled only by Kings or legal groups of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 9 cards are dealt to the first pile, 8 cards to the 2nd pile, and so on until 1 card is dealt to the 9th piles.  The top card of each pile is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - move 1 card to waste by clicking.  Two redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Notes

•The first 4 foundations are built up card by card as is normal, but the right 4 foundations are built in the tableau.  When an entire 13 card sequence from King to Ace is built, it can be dropped on the right 4 foundations.

 

•There is no AutoPlay in this game, so all cards must be moved by dragging or right-clicking on the card.

Tips

•Keep in mind at all times that you are not only trying to build on the left 4 foundations up in color, but also you must build 4 complete 13-card sequences down by alternate color, much like they are built in Spider.  Whether to move a card to the 4 left foundations or to keep it in the tableau for building one of the sequences is a choice you are faced with often.

History

Easy Diavolo is a variation of Diavolo.

Similar Games

Rouge et Noir

Diavolo

Bedeviled

Easy Eighteens

Easy Eighteens

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (15%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To discard all the cards.

Layout

•15 tableau piles - the top card is available for play.  Discard sets of cards that have ranks that add to 18, in sets of 4 cards. One of the 4 cards must be a Jack, Queen, or King, and the remaining 3 cards of lower ranks that add to 18 (the J-Q-K cards are not used in calculating the total).  In addition, no two cards can be of the same rank.  For example, a K-10-6-2 set is acceptable but a Q-6-6-6 set is not. Spaces are automatically filled from the stock.   Aces are discarded singly.  To discard a set of cards, move each card to the reserve pile in the lower left.  When a valid set is formed the cards are automatically discarded to the waste pile.   At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (face down, left) - fills spaces in the tableau.
•waste (far right)  - Where paired cards go out of play.
•reserve (lower left) - where sets of cards are formed.

Valid Discards

•Ace,   A Jack, Queen, or King and 3 cards of different rank of 10 or less that add to 18.

History

Easy Eighteens is an easier version of Eighteens.

Similar Games

Eighteens

Block Ten

Elevens

Pyramid

Fourteen Out

Fifteens

Easy Street

Easy Street

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (50%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color. Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Easy Street is an easier variation of Streets.

Similar Games

Number Ten

Rank and File

Forty Thieves

Napoleon's Folly

Eclipse

Eclipse

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (55%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.  At the start of the game the Aces are dealt here.
•13 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit. Groups of cards in sequence down in suit may be moved as a unit.  Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.  No redeals.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Eclipse is a variation of Waning Moon.

Similar Games

Eight by Eight

Eight by Eight

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Easy (95%).  Skill/luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Groups of cards in sequence down regardless of suit may be moved as a unit.  Spaces may be filled only by a single card, not a group of cards.  At the start of the game 8 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 3 cards at a time to the waste by clicking during the first deal, 2 cards at a time during the 2nd deal, and 1 card at a time during the last deal.  Two redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Similar Games

Loopy

Eight by Five

Eight by Five

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Easy (99%).  Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•5 cells (top) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.

 

•8 tableau piles (below cells) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color and if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.  Spaces can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt face up to the leftmost 4 piles, 6 cards are dealt face up to the remaining piles.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Groups of cards in the tableau can only be moved as a group if there are a sufficient number of empty cells available to store the cards individually.  The ability to move cards as a group is only a shortcut to moving the group one card at a time.

Tips

•Try to keep as many cells empty as possible.

History

Eight by Five is a variant of FreeCell, it is FreeCell with one more cell.

Similar Games

FreeCell

Seven by Five

Lower 48

Eight Off

Eight Off

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Easy (95%).  Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations

Layout

•4 foundation piles (right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•8 cells (bottom) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.  The card is available for play on the foundations or tableau. At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each of the left 4 cells.
•8 tableau piles (above cells) -   build down in suit.  The top card is available for play on the foundations, cells, or another tableau pile.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit and if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.  Fill spaces with Kings or a group of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt face up to each pile.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Groups of cards in the tableau can only be moved as a group if there are a sufficient number of empty cells available to store the cards individually.  The ability to move cards as a group is only a shortcut to moving the group one card at a time.

Tips

•Try to keep as many cells empty as possible.

History

Eight Off is an 8 cell version of Baker's Game.

Similar Games

Eight On

Baker's Game

FreeCell

ForeCell

Sea Towers

Double Eight Off

Eight On

Eight On

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (25%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations

Layout

•4 foundation piles (right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•8 cells (bottom) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.  The card is available for play on the foundations or tableau. At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each cell.
•8 tableau piles (above cells) -   build down in suit.  The top card is available for play on the foundations, cells, or another tableau pile.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit and if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.  Fill spaces with Kings or a group of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game the Aces are dealt to the first 4 piles, then 5 cards are dealt face up to each pile.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Groups of cards in the tableau can only be moved as a group if there are a sufficient number of empty cells available to store the cards individually.  The ability to move cards as a group is only a shortcut to moving the group one card at a time.

Tips

•Try to keep as many cells empty as possible.

History

Eight On is a variation of Eight Off invented by Thomas Warfield.  It is a much more difficult game than Eight Off.

Similar Games

Eight Off

Penguin

Challenge FreeCell

Eighteens

Eighteens

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (10%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To discard all the cards.

Layout

•12 tableau piles - the top card is available for play.  Discard sets of cards that have ranks that add to 18, in sets of 4 cards. One of the 4 cards must be a Jack, Queen, or King, and the remaining 3 cards of lower ranks that add to 18 (the J-Q-K cards are not used in calculating the total).  In addition, no two cards can be of the same rank.  For example, a K-10-6-2 set is acceptable but a Q-6-6-6 set is not. Spaces are automatically filled from the stock.   Aces are discarded singly.  To discard a set of cards, move each card to the reserve pile in the lower left.  When a valid set is formed the cards are automatically discarded to the waste pile.   At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (face down, left) - fills spaces in the tableau.
•waste (far right)  - Where paired cards go out of play.
•reserve (lower left) - where sets of cards are formed.

Valid Discards

•Ace,   A Jack, Queen, or King and 3 cards of different rank of 10 or less that add to 18.

History

Eighteens is a classic game of addition.

Similar Games

Easy Eighteens

Block Ten

Elevens

Pyramid

Fourteen Out

Fifteens

Eights Down

Eights Down

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (50%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (right) - build down in suit from Eights to Ace, wrapping to King to Nine.  At the start of the game the Eights are dealt to each pile.
•6 tableau piles (across top, left) - build up in suit, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary.  Groups of cards may be moved if they are in a sequence up in suit.  Spaces can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (bottom, face down on left) - move 1 card to waste by clicking.  One redeal.
•waste (beside stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Eights Down is a member of the Busy Aces family.  Eights Down was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games
