Eighty Thieves

Eighty Thieves

 Top  Previous  Next

4 Decks.  Hard (2%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•16 foundation piles (across top, left, right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved. Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 8 cards are dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Eighty Thieves is a 4 deck variation of Forty Thieves invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Forty Thieves

Sixty Thieves

Malmaison

Alleys

Eighty-Six

Eighty-Six

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (90%).  Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•6 cells (top left) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.  The card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations and cells) - The entire deck is dealt to these 8 piles (7 cards to the first 4 piles, 6 cards to the next 4 piles) .  The piles are built down in suit.  The top card is available for play on the foundations, cells, or another tableau pile.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit and if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.  Fill spaces with any available card.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Note that groups of cards in the tableau can only be moved as a group if there are a sufficient number of empty cells available to store the cards individually.  The ability to move cards as a group is only a shortcut to moving the group one card at a time.

 

Tips

•Try to keep as many cells empty as possible.

History

Eighty-Six is Baker's Game with 6 cells.

Similar Games

Baker's Game

Elba

Elba

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (20%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.   Spaces are filled by a King or a group of cards headed with a King.   At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt to each pile, 4 face down and 1 face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Elba is a Forty Thieves type game.

Similar Games

Forty Thieves

Eleven Triangle

Eleven Triangle

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (5%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To pair up all the cards in the deck in pairs of cards whose ranks total to 11.

Layout

•An inverted pyramid of 28 cards.  Only uncovered cards are available for play.  Discard pairs of cards whose ranks add to 11.  Jacks, Queens, and Kings are discarded in pairs of the same rank.  To discard a pair, drop one card on the other, or right-click on one of the cards.
•stock (top left) - turn over cards one to each waste pile by clicking.  No redeals.
•3 waste piles (below stock) - The top card is available for play.

Notes

•The valid pairs are Ace-Ten, 2-9, 3-8, 4-7, 5-6, J-J, Q-Q, K-K.

History

Eleven Triangle is a variation of Triangle.

Similar Games

Triangle

Pyramid

Eleventh Heaven

Eleven Up

Eleven Up

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck. Medium (80%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the tableau.

Layout

•11 tableau piles  - build up regardless of suit, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are filled automatically from the stock.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (left, face down) - automatically fills spaces in the tableau.

Notes

The idea is to get all of the cards in play by grouping cards in piles up regardless of suit, which brings more cards into play via the empty spaces created.  The game is won if all cards are moved from the stock onto the tableau.

Similar Games

Up and Up

Trusty Twelve

Sweet Sixteen

Knotty Nines

Bunker

Elevens

Elevens

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (33%).  All Luck.

Object

To discard all the cards.

Layout

•9 tableau piles - the top card is available for play.  Pair up cards that have ranks that add to 11 (Ace-10, 2-9, 3-8, 4-7, 5-6).  Jacks, Queens, and Kings are grouped as a triplet (J-Q-K).  Spaces are automatically filled from the stock.   To discard a J-Q-K triplet, move each card to the reserve pile in the lower left.  When all 3 cards have been moved, the J-Q-K triplet is removed from play.   At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.

               

•stock (face down, left) - fills spaces in the tableau.
•waste (far right)  - Where paired cards go out of play.
•reserve (lower left) - where J-Q-K triplets are formed.

Valid Discards

•Ace-10, 2-9, 3-8, 4-7, 5-6, Jack-Queen-King

History

Elevens is a classic game of addition.

Similar Games

Suit Elevens

Eleventh Heaven

Block Ten

Pyramid

Fourteen Out

Fifteens

Eighteens

Eleventh Heaven

Eleventh Heaven

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (25%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To discard all the cards.

Layout

•9 tableau piles - the top card is available for play.  Pair up cards that have ranks that add to 11 (Ace-10, 2-9, 3-8, 4-7, 5-6).  Jacks, Queens, and Kings are discarded in pairs of the same rank.  To discard a pair, drop one card on the other, or right-click on one of the cards.   At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.

               

•stock (face down, left) - fills spaces in the tableau.
•waste (far right)  - Where paired cards go out of play.

Valid Discards

•The valid pairs are Ace-Ten, 2-9, 3-8, 4-7, 5-6, J-J, Q-Q, K-K.

History

Eleventh Heaven is a variation of Elevens invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Elevens

Eleven Triangle

Suit Elevens

Emperor

Emperor

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (25%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) -   build down by alternate color.   Groups of cards cannot be moved.   Spaces are filled by any card.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile, 3 face down and 1 face up.
•stock (top left) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste pile by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

 

Options

AutoPlay

 

History

Emperor is the same as Rank and File except that groups of cards cannot be moved, making it a much harder game.

Similar Games

Rank and File

Emperor Penguin

Emperor Penguin

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (90%).  Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (right) - build up in suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.  At the start of the game the first 3 piles are dealt base cards of the same rank.
•7 cells or "flipper" piles (bottom) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.  The card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

 

•7 tableau piles - build down in suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit and if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.  Spaces can be filled only by cards one rank below the base card of the foundations (or Kings if foundations start with Aces).  At the start of the game the remaining base card of the foundations is always dealt first to the first pile (this card is called the "beak"), then 7 cards are dealt face up to each pile.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•You must free the "beak" card in order to build the fourth foundation.

 

•Groups of cards in the tableau can only be moved as a group if there are a sufficient number of empty cells available to store the cards individually.  The ability to move cards as a group is only a shortcut to moving the group one card at a time.

Tips

•Try to keep as many cells empty as possible.

History

Emperor Penguin is a more difficult version of Penguin.  It uses FreeCell's rules for moving groups of cards (you can only move groups when there are enough open cells) instead of allowing all in sequences groups to be moved.

Similar Games

Penguin

Opus

Tuxedo

FreeCell

Empire Spider

Empire Spider

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (35%).  Skill/luck balanced.

Object

To group all the cards in sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace.

Layout

•7 tableau piles - build down regardless of suit.  Groups of cards in sequence down in suit may be moved as a unit.  A space can be filled by any card or legal group of cards. At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.  The top card is face up.

 

•stock (above the tableau) - Clicking deals 1 card to each tableau pile.  All empty spaces must be filled before a deal.
•3 cells  (left) - Only 1 card allowed in each cell.  Any available single card can be moved here.

Notes

•Whenever a sequence of 13 cards down in suit from King to Ace is formed, it will automatically be removed from play.

Tips

•Same suit sequences should be preferred even though building is down regardless of suit.  The object is to build down in suit sequences.

History

Empire Spider is Spiderette with 3 cells.

 

Similar Games

Spiderette

Gotham

New York

Trapdoor Spider

Empress of Italy

Empress of Italy

 Top  Previous  Next

4 Decks.  Hard (8%). Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•16 foundation piles (left, across top, right) - build up by alternate color from the rank of first card in the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•11 tableau piles (bottom row, center) - build down by alternate color, wrapping from Ace to King if necessary.  Only the top card of each pile may be moved.  Spaces are filled automatically from the stock.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•reserve (above tableau) - top card is available for play on the foundations only.  At the start of the game 19 cards are dealt here.
•stock (middle left, face down) - turn over cards 1 at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Empress of Italy is a 4 deck variation of Terrace (also known as Queen of Italy) and Blondes and Brunettes.  It was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Double Signora

Terrace

General's Patience

Blondes and Brunettes

Admiral's Patience

Endless Harp

Endless Harp

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (80%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.   Spaces are filled by a King or a group of cards headed with a King.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 3 to the 2nd, 5 to the 3rd, 7 to the 4th, 9 to the 5th, 10 to the 6th, 8 to the 7th, 6 to the 8th, 4 to the 9th, and 2 to the 10th.  All cards are face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 3 cards to the waste by clicking.  Unlimited redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Endless Harp is a variation of Big Harp.

Similar Games

Big Harp

Harp

Klondike

Gargantua

Double Klondike

Eternal Triangle

Eternal Triangle

Eternal Triangle

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (7%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.   Spaces are filled by a King or a group of cards headed with a King.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 to the 2nd, and so on.  All cards are face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - deals one card to each tableau pile by clicking.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Eternal Triangle is a variation of Big Harp.  It is also known as Lobachevsky.

Similar Games

Right Triangle

Big Harp

Carlton

Great Triangle

Triple Triangle

Double Spidike

Exiled Kings

Exiled Kings

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (4%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (middle) - build up in suit from Ace to King.  At the start of the game the 4 Aces are dealt here.
•8 tableau piles (around foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Only the top card of each pile is available for play.  Spaces may be filled only by Kings.  At the start of the game, 7 cards are dealt to each pile.  As the cards are dealt, any cards that can be moved to the foundations are moved there.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Exiled Kings is a variation of Citadel and similar to Beleaguered Castle.  It is more difficult than Citadel because only Kings may be played in empty tableau piles.

Similar Games

Citadel

Beleaguered Castle

Exit

Exit

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (20%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To pair up all the cards and move them to the waste pile.

Layout

•10 tableau piles (left) - the top card is available for play.  Pair up cards whose ranks add to 11 (pairs are A-10, 2-9, 3-8, 7-4, 5-6).  Pair Queens with Kings as long as they are of different suits.  Pair Jacks together.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt face up to each pile.  If 3 Jacks are dealt to the same pile, the middle Jack is exchanged for the top card of the reserve.
•reserve (right of tableau) - top card is available for play.  At the start of the game 2 cards are dealt face up to this pile.
•waste pile - Where paired cards go out of play.

History

Exit was invented by David Parlett (see also Archway, Buffalo Bill, Black Hole, Curds and Whey, Penguin, and Striptease).

Fair Lucy

Fair Lucy

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Hard (2%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (left) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•18 fans (to right of foundations) - build by same rank, limit of 3 cards of a rank in a pile.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are not filled, except for the last (bottom right) pile, which may be filled by a King.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt to each pile (except for the last 2 piles, which have 2 cards).  Only the top card of each pile is face up.

Options

AutoPlay

Tips

Don't play cards to the foundations just because you can.  Cards may be needed in the fans to make plays to uncover other cards.

History

Fair Lucy is a variation of Fan.

Similar Games

Fan

La Belle Lucie

Fair Maids

Fair Maids

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (25%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards in sets of 13 cards in sequence down by alternate color from King to Ace.

Layout

•7 tableau piles - build down regardless of suit.  Groups of cards in sequence down by alternate color may be moved as a unit.  A space can be filled by any card or legal group of cards. At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile, 3 face down and 1 face up.

 

•stock (above the tableau) - Clicking deals 1 card to each tableau pile.  All empty spaces must be filled before a deal.

Notes

•Whenever a sequence of 13 cards down by alternate color from King to Ace is formed, it will automatically be removed from play.

Tips

•Alternate color sequences should be preferred even though building is down regardless of suit.  The object is to build down by alternate color sequences.

History

Fair Maids is a variation of Will o' the Wisp.

Similar Games

Will o' the Wisp

Spiderette

EastHaven

Falling Star

Falling Star

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (14%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (middle) - build up by alternate color, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Only the top card of each pile may be moved.  Spaces may be filled only from the waste pile.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•reserve (top) - top card is available for play on the foundations only.  At the start of the game 11 cards are dealt to this pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over cards 1 at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Falling Star is a variation of Terrace. It is an easier game than Terrace.

Similar Games

Wood

Terrace

Blondes and Brunettes

Redheads

General's Patience

Family Plot

Family Plot

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (5%).  Skill/luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (right) - build up in suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.  No cards can be played on the 2nd through 8th piles until all 13 cards have been played to the first pile.  The first pile is offset to the left of the other 7 piles.
•12 tableau piles (center) - build down in suit, wrapping from Ace to King as necessary.  Groups of cards can be moved if they are in sequence down in suit.  Spaces may be filled only from the waste.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.  Until the first foundation pile contains 13 cards, cards of the same rank as the first card of the first foundation pile cannot be built on other cards or built upon.
•stock (bottom left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste, by clicking.  One redeal.
•waste (below stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.
•reserve (top left, above stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 13 cards are dealt here.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Family Plot has three restrictions that make things difficult: 1) you cannot play any cards to the 2nd to 8th foundation piles until the first foundation pile contains all 13 cards.  The first pile is offset from the others to make it more visible.  2) cards in the reserve can be played to the tableau, but not to empty spaces, and 3) until the first foundation pile contains 13 cards, you cannot build or build upon cards of the same rank as the first card of the first foundation pile.

History

Family Plot is an easier version of The Plot.  It allows groups of cards to be moved where The Plot does not, it allows cards from the reserve to be played to non-empty tableau piles, and it adds a redeal.  It is still not easy to win.  Family Plot was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

The Plot

Single Plot

Famous Fifty

Famous Fifty

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (3%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved. Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Tips

•Try to get a space in the tableau as quickly as possible.

History

Famous Fifty is a variation of Forty Thieves.

Similar Games

Forty Thieves

Fan

Fan

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (38%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•18 fans (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved to the foundations or another fan.  Spaces are filled only by Kings.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt face up to each pile (the last 2 piles only have 2 cards).

Options

AutoPlay

History

Fan is the basis of all Fan type games.

Similar Games

La Belle Lucie

Shamrocks

Trefoil

Clover Leaf

Three Shuffles and a Draw

Demon Fan

Lucky Fan

Crescent Fan

Fan Albert

Fan Albert

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (70%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (far right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (across top) - build down by alternate color.  Only the top card of each pile may be moved to the foundations, another tableau pile, or a non-empty fan.  Spaces may be filled by any available card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd pile, and so on.
•8 fans (across bottom) - build down in suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved to the foundations, tableau, or another fan.  Spaces are filled only by a card from another fan (not from the tableau).  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt face up to each pile.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Fan Albert is a cross between Fan and King Albert.  It was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Fan

King Albert

Farmer's Wife

Farmer's Wife

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (40%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards into 4 sets of 13 cards in sequence down by alternate color from King to Ace within the tableau.

Layout

•10 tableau piles (top) - build down by alternate color.  Groups of cards (regardless of any sequence) can be moved.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.   At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt to each pile.  In the rightmost 3 piles, 3 cards are face down and 2 face up, in the other piles all cards are face up.

 

•reserve (bottom left) - both cards are available for play in the tableau at any time.

Notes

•Any face up card, regardless of where in a pile it is, can be moved, along with all cards above it (this is like Yukon).

History

Farmer's Wife is a variation of Three Blind Mice.

Similar Games

Three Blind Mice

How They Run

Fascination

Fascination

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (65%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Fill spaces with Kings or a legal group of cards headed by a King (see KingOnly option).  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd pile, and so on.
•2 fans (top, stacked horizontally) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•reserve (Far left, under leftmost fan) - Any card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.  To play a buried card, click on it to move it to the top of the pile.  Then move the card to its destination. At the start of the game 12 cards are dealt face up to this pile.

Options

AutoPlay

KingOnly

History

Fascination is a variation of Klondike where all cards are visible from the initial deal.  It was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Klondike

Willow

Attraction

Fascination Garden

Fascination Garden

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (60%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Fill spaces with Kings or a legal group of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd pile, and so on.
•reserve (Far left) - Any card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.  To play a buried card, click on it to move it to the top of the pile.  Then move the card to its destination. At the start of the game 16 cards are dealt face up to this pile.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Fascination Garden is a variation of Fascination and is related to Klondike and Flower Garden.

Similar Games

Fascination

Klondike

Flower Garden

Father

Father

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Easy (85%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top)  - build the first 4 piles up in suit from Ace to King (one for each suit), the last 4 down in suit from King to Ace (one for each suit).
•12 tableau piles (below foundations) - top card is available for play on the foundations only. Each pile may contain up to 2 cards.  Any card may be played on the first card.  Spaces may be filled from the waste.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (left, face down) - Turn over 1 card to the waste by clicking.  One redeal.
•waste (below stock) - Top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

History

Father is a more difficult but more strategic version of Grandfather invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Grandfather

Grandmother's

Sir Tommy

Twenty

Feisty Fifteens

Feisty Fifteens

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck. Medium (50%).  Skill/Luck Balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the tableau.

Layout

• 15 tableau piles  - build cards whose ranks add to 15,of different suits.  Aces can be played on any card of different suit.  Aces can be played on Aces, but no other card can be played on an Ace. Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are filled automatically from the stock.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left, face up) - automatically fills spaces in the tableau.  Top card is available for play on the tableau.

Notes

The idea is to get all of the cards in play by grouping cards in piles.  Allowable plays are 2-K, 3-Q, 4-J, 5-10, 6-9, 7-8, and Ace on any card and A-A.  All plays must be of different suits.  The game is won if all cards are moved from the stock onto the tableau.

Similar Games

Twisty Thirteens

Trusty Twelve

Sweet Sixteen

Knotty Nines

Up and Up

Fifteen

Fifteen

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (50%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (left and right) - on left piles build up in suit from Ace to King, on right piles build down in suit from King to Ace.
•15 tableau piles (middle) - build up or down by suit, no wrapping.  Top card is available for play on the foundations or another tableau pile, only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are filled by any card.  At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt to each pile, except for the last pile, which is only dealt 6.

Options

AutoPlay

Similar Games

Capricieuse

Nationale

Payday

Fifteen Peaks

Fifteen Peaks

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (80%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To pair up all cards and move them out of play to the waste pile.

Layout

•3 triangular peaks of cards and 8 piles of 3 cards each - the top card of each pile is available Only uncovered cards in the peaks are available for play.  Pair cards whose ranks total to 15, and pair Aces.   To remove a pair, pick up one card with the mouse and drop it on the other.  At the start of the game 28 cards are dealt face up to the 3 triangular peaks and 3 cards are dealt face up to the 8 piles.

 

•waste pile - where paired cards go out of play.

Notes

Cards that pair to 15: King--2, Queen-3, Jack-4, 10-5, 9-6, 8-7, Ace-Ace.

Similar Games

Fourteen Peaks

Fifteen Puzzle

Fifteen Puzzle

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (80%).  Skill.

Object

To move all the cards of each rank to the same pile, so that there are 13 piles of 4 cards of the same rank.

Layout

•15 tableau piles (2 begin empty) - Cards may be played on other cards of the same rank.  At most 4 cards are allowed in any pile.  Empty piles may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt face up to 13 of the piles.

Notes

•Cards may be played on other cards of the same rank.  For example, if the top card of a pile is a Three, another Three can be played on top of it.  The object is to move the cards so that there are 13 piles of 4 cards of the same rank, that is, one pile of 4 Kings, one pile of 4 Queens, and so on.

History

This game is named after a small plastic game consisting of numbers that slid around.  The numbers would be all jumbled up and the object was to put them in order.  This game is sort of a card game version of that game, which was very popular 30-40 years ago.

Similar Games

Yukon Puzzle

Fifteen Puzzle Cell

Fifteen Puzzle Cell

Fifteen Puzzle Cell

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (95%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards of each rank to the same pile, so that there are 13 piles of 4 cards of the same rank.

Layout

•15 tableau piles (2 begin empty) - Cards may be played on other cards of the same rank.  At most 4 cards are allowed in any pile.  Empty piles may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt face up to 13 of the piles.
•1 cell (top center) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in the cell.

Notes

•Cards may be played on other cards of the same rank.  For example, if the top card of a pile is a Three, another Three can be played on top of it.  The object is to move the cards so that there are 13 piles of 4 cards of the same rank, that is, one pile of 4 Kings, one pile of 4 Queens, and so on.

History

Fifteen Puzzle Cell is the game Fifteen Puzzle with a cell.

Similar Games

Fifteen Puzzle

Fifteen Rush

Fifteen Rush

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (85%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To discard all the cards.

Layout

•7 tableau piles - the top card is available for play.  Discard pairs of cards that have ranks that add to 15. Possible pairs are King-2, Queen-3, Jack-4, 10-5, 9-6, 8-7.  Aces are paired together (Ace-Ace). Spaces are filled from the stock, or the top card of the waste if the stock is empty.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over  3 cards at a time, by clicking.  Unlimited redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for pairing.

Valid Discards

•A-A, 2-K, 3-Q, 4-J, 5-10, 6-9, 7-8

History

Fifteen Rush is an addition game like Fifteens with a tableau like Klondike.  It was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Fourteen Demons

Fifteens

Doublet Cell

Klondike 13

The Ides of March

Fifteens

Fifteens

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (95%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To discard all the cards.

Layout

•16 tableau piles - the top card is available for play.  Discard sets of cards that have ranks that add to 15. Tens, Jacks, Queens, and Kings are discarded as a set (10-J-Q-K).  Spaces are automatically filled from the stock.   To discard a set of cards, move each card to the reserve pile in the lower left.  When a 10-J-Q-K set is formed, or when cards of rank 9 or under add to 15, the cards are automatically discarded to the waste pile.   Any number of cards of rank 9 or under can be used to make a set that adds to 15.  As a shortcut, pairs of cards that add to 15 (9-6, 8-7) can be discarded by dropping one on the other.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (face down, left) - fills spaces in the tableau.
•waste (far right)  - Where paired cards go out of play.
•reserve (lower left) - where sets of cards are formed.

Valid Discards

•10-Jack-Queen-King, any number of cards of rank 9 or less that add to 15

History

Fifteens is a classic game of addition.

Similar Games

Fifteens Suit

Block Ten

Elevens

Pyramid

Fourteen Out

Eighteens

Fifteens Suit

Fifteens Suit

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (5%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To discard all the cards.

Layout

•16 tableau piles - the top card is available for play.  Discard sets of cards that have ranks that add to 15 and are of the same suit. Tens, Jacks, Queens, and Kings are discarded as a set of the same  suit(10-J-Q-K).  Spaces are automatically filled from the stock.   To discard a set of cards, move each card to the reserve pile in the lower left.  When a 10-J-Q-K suit set is formed, or when cards of rank 9 or under add to 15, the cards are automatically discarded to the waste pile.   Any number of cards of rank 9 or under of the same suit can be used to make a set that adds to 15.  As a shortcut, pairs of cards that add to 15 of the same suit (9-6, 8-7) can be discarded by dropping one on the other.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (face down, left) - fills spaces in the tableau.
•waste (far right)  - Where paired cards go out of play.
•reserve (lower left) - where sets of cards are formed.

Valid Discards

•10-Jack-Queen-King of the same suit, any number of cards of rank 9 or less that add to 15 of the same suit

History

Fifteens Suit is a much harder version of Fifteens.

Similar Games

Fifteens

Fifty Bandits

Fifty Bandits

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (20%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Move groups of cards only if they are in sequence down in suit. Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt to each pile.
•stock (bottom left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.  All cards in the waste are visible.

Options

AutoPlay

Tips

•Try to get a space in the tableau as quickly as possible.

History

Fifty Bandits is a variation of Famous Fifty where groups of cards in sequence may be moved, making it a slightly easier game.

Similar Games

Forty Thieves

Famous Fifty

Forty Bandits

Firing Squad

Firing Squad

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (15%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To remove all the cards from the tableau except the 4 Aces.

Layout

•4 tableau piles (top) - cards are dealt here 1 to each pile from the stock.  The top card of each pile is available for play.  Any top card that is of lower rank and the same suit of another top card may be removed by clicking on it. Aces are considered to be of the highest rank.  Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•1 cell (right of tableau) - storage location for one card.  Once a card is moved here it can only be moved back to an empty tableau pile.
•stock (face down) - deal 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.  No redeals.

Notes

•Play consists of removing all but the highest rank exposed card of each suit.  The only way to get at cards beneath an Ace is to move the Ace to an empty pile.
•You cannot use the suit of a card in the cell to remove a card from the tableau.  Once a card is moved to the cell, it is essentially a dead card until it can be moved back into an empty tableau pile.

History

Firing Squad is a variation of Aces Up. It has an additional cell which makes the game easier and adds strategy.

Similar Games

Aces Up

Five and Diamond

Five and Diamond

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (11%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right, arranged in a diamond shape) - build up in color from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.  At the start of the game a card is dealt to the first pile (top).   The base cards for the other three (empty) piles will alternate colors and skip numbers until all four suits are represented.  For example, if the first card dealt is the 4 ♦, a black 6 must be played on the left pile, the 8 ♥ played on the bottom pile, and a black 10 of the black suit different from the suit of the 6 played on the right pile. Base cards may be played in any order (for example, in the above scenario, the 10 ♠/♣ may be played BEFORE the 6 of ♣/♠ or the 8 ♥).

 

•5 tableau piles (left) - Build down by twos in alternate color (i.e. a 3 ♠ could be played on a 5 ♦,  or a Queen ♥ on a Ace ♣), wrapping from Ace to King as necessary.  Groups of cards may be moved if they are in sequence. Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt to each pile, 2 face down and 1 face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over one card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

 

History

Five and Diamond is a variation on Canfield invented by Alex Bove.

Similar Games

Canfield

Five Little Guys

Five Little Guys

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (10%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (middle) - build the first 4 piles from Ace to King up regardless of suit, build the last 4 piles from Kings to Aces down regardless of suit.
•5 tableau piles (below foundations, on right) - storage spaces for cards.  Only one card allowed per pile.  Spaces are filled from the stock.  When the stock is empty, spaces are filled by any card.  One card is dealt to each pile at the start of the game.
•2 reserve piles (top) - Top card available for play on the foundations.  14 cards are dealt to each reserve at the start of the game.
•stock (bottom left, face down) -  Turn over 1 card at a time to the waste pile by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•  It is allowed (in fact is it necessary in order to win)  to move cards from one foundation pile to another, in particular from Ace foundations to King foundations and vice versa.
•Play consists of moving cards from the reserves, waste, and tableau to the foundations, and especially in strategic movement of cards within the foundations to allow more cards to be played there.

History

Five Little Guys is a variation of Aces and Kings invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Aces and Kings

Five Piles

Five Piles

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (4%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To pair up all cards and move them out of play.

Layout

•5 Piles (surprise!) - discard pairs of cards that add to 13, Kings singly.  The top card of each pile is available.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (far right, face down) - clicking deals 1 card to each of the 5 piles.

Notes

•Any pair of cards whose values add to 13 can be discarded.  The valid pairs are Queen-Ace, Jack-Two, 10-3, 9-4, 8-5, 7-6.  Kings are discarded singly.  To discards Kings, simply click on them.  When all possible pairs are discarded, deal another set of 5 cards onto the piles by clicking on the Stock.

 

•The last 2 cards in the stock form their own piles and can be discarded with cards from any of the 5 piles.
•The game will inform you if you win, or if you have no more possible moves.

History

5 Piles is an easy game to play, but fairly difficult to win.  It is also known as Baroness.

Similar Games

Thirteens

Pyramid

Five Stacks

Seven Piles

Five Pirates

Five Pirates

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (30%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved. Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile.
•stock (bottom left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to each waste pile by clicking.  No redeals.
•5 waste piles (next to stock) - top card of each pile is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Five Pirates is a variation of Forty Thieves with 5 waste piles.

Similar Games

Three Pirates

Forty Thieves

Five Stacks

Five Stacks

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (80%).  Skill/Luck Balanced.

Object

To pair up all the cards in the deck in pairs of cards whose ranks total to 13.

Layout

•5 tableau piles - Discard pairs of cards whose ranks add to 13.  Kings are discarded singly.  To discard a pair, drop one card on the other, or right-click on one of the cards.   At the start of the game 8 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) -  turn over cards one to each waste pile by clicking.  Unlimited redeals.
•waste  (beside stock) - The top card is available for play. Discard pairs of cards whose ranks add to 13.  Kings are discarded singly.

Notes

•Any pair of cards whose values add to 13 can be discarded.  The valid pairs are Queen-Ace, Jack-Two, 10-3, 9-4, 8-5, 7-6.  Kings are discarded singly.  To discards Kings, simply click on them.

History

Five Stacks is a variation of Nile and Five Piles.

Similar Games

Nile

Lake Victoria

Thirteens

Five Piles

Pyramid

Floradora

Floradora

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (3%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to Queen.
•King foundation (left under other foundations) - move all Kings to this pile.
•6 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  One card at a time may be moved. Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (below stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Similar Games

Thirty Six

Flow

Flow

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy  (95%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards into 4 sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace within the tableau.

Layout

•8 tableau piles (top) - build down in suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit.  Spaces can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game these piles are empty.

 

•8 reserve piles (below tableau) - build down in suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit.  Cards are available for play on the tableau (a group of cards that is in sequence down in suit may also be moved as a group to the tableau).  Spaces can be filled by any single card.   At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt to each pile (the first 4 piles are dealt 7).

Notes

•Play consists of moving cards from the reserve piles to the tableau in order to form 4 sequences down in suit from King to Ace.

Tips

•Try to begin by concentrating on grouping cards of one or two suits together.

History

Flow is an easier variation of Wave Motion.

Similar Games

Wave Motion

Wading Pool

FreeCell

Scorpion

Flower Garden

Flower Garden

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (25%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•6 tableau "Garden" piles (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are filled by any card.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•reserve "Bouquet" (left) - All cards available for play on the foundations or tableau.  Click on card to move it to the bottom of the stack, then move to either the foundations or tableau.   At the start of the game 16 cards are dealt to this pile.

Options

AutoPlay

Tips

•Don't automatically move cards from the Bouquet to the Garden.

History

Flower Garden is also known as "The Garden" or "Bouquet".

Similar Games

Brigade

Stonewall

Northwest Territory

Wildflower

Fly

Fly

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (25%).  Skill/luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up regardless of suit from Ace to King.  At the start of the game the Aces are dealt here.
•reserve (far left, below foundations) - top card is available for play on the foundations only.  At the start of the game 13 cards are dealt here.
•stock (next to reserve) - Top card is available for play on the foundations or waste piles.  No redeals.
•5 waste piles (right of stock) - can contain any cards.   You can build cards only from the stock.  Top card is available for play on the foundations only.

Options

AutoPlay

Tips

On the waste piles, you should try to build downward, if possible.  One pile should be reserved for Kings and Queens.  Don't put lots of cards of the same rank in the same pile.

History

Fly is a variation of Frog.

Similar Games

Gnat

Housefly

Frog

ForeCell

ForeCell

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (60%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•4 cells (top left) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.

 

•8 tableau piles (below foundations and cells) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color and if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.  Spaces can be filled only by Kings or a group of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt face up to the each pile.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Groups of cards in the tableau can only be moved as a group if there are a sufficient number of empty cells available to store the cards individually.  The ability to move cards as a group is only a shortcut to moving the group one card at a time.
•The game number deals #1 to #1000000 are compatible with the games in the standard Windows FreeCell.  For more information about FreeCell type games, see http://www.freecell.org.

Tips

•Try to keep as many cells empty as possible.

History

ForeCell is a predecessor to FreeCell.   It appeared in a 1945 Swedish book Världens bästa patienser och patiensspel by Einar Werner.  It was called Napoleon in St. Helena.  Since this is a very common name for a solitaire game, the name was changed here to ForeCell to emphasize it's relationship to FreeCell.   The differences between ForeCell and FreeCell are that 4 cards are dealt to the cells rather than the tableau, and only Kings can fill empty spaces in the the tableau.

Similar Games

FreeCell

Baker's Game

Blind FreeCell

Forsythia

Forsythia

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (50%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Aces to Kings.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color from the waste pile only.  Spaces may be filled by any card from the waste pile only.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (bottom, face down on left) - move 1 card to waste by clicking.  One redeal.
•waste (beside stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Fort

Fort

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (50%).  Skill/Luck Balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (left and right) - on left piles build up in suit from Ace to King, on right piles build down in suit from King to Ace.
•12 tableau piles (around the edge, between the Aces and Kings) - No building.  Top card is available for play on the foundations   Spaces are filled automatically.  The 4 cards each on the left and right sides are called the wall, the two cards in the top middle and bottom middle are called the gate. Spaces in the wall are filled automatically from the waste (or the stock if the waste is empty), spaces in the gate are filled automatically from the reserve.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (middle, face down on left) - move 1 card to waste by clicking.  Two redeals.
•waste (beside stock) - top card available for play on the foundations.
•reserve (middle) - top card fills spaces in the gate piles of the tableau or play to the foundations. The cards cannot otherwise be moved.  At the start of the game 21 cards are dealt to this pile.

Options

AutoPlay

Similar Games

Pigtail

Fortress

Fortress

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (11%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build up or down by suit.  Only the top card of each pile is available for play.  Spaces may be filled by any available card.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt face up to the leftmost 2 piles, 5 cards to each of the other piles.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Fortress is a close relative of Beleaguered Castle. Chessboard is a more strategic variation of Fortress.

Similar Games

Chessboard

Beleaguered Castle

Streets and Alleys

Citadel

Castles End

Bastion

Lasker

Fortress Moat

Fortress Moat

Fortress Moat

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (15%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build up or down by suit.  Only the top card of each pile is available for play.  Spaces may be filled only by a King.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (Top left, face down) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking. When the stock is empty, it becomes a cell, storage locations for 1 card with no building.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Fortress Moat is a variation of Fortress.

Similar Games

Fortress

Bastion

Fortress of Mercy

Fortress of Mercy

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (20%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (middle) - build up in suit from Ace to King.  At the start of the game two Aces are dealt to the first 2 piles.
•10 tableau piles (left and right of foundations) - build up or down by suit.  Only the top card of each pile is available for play, except that once per game a draw (or merci) is available.  Right-clicking on any buried card will move that card to the top of its pile.  This can only be done once in each game.  Spaces may be filled by any available card.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt to each pile.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Fortress of Mercy is a variation of Fortress.

Similar Games

Fortress

Chessboard

Beleaguered Castle

Fortunes Favor

Fortunes Favor

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Easy (100%).  All Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.  At the start of the game the Aces are dealt here.
•12 tableau piles (in box) - build down in suit.  The top card of each pile is available for play.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are filled from the waste or stock automatically.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (left, face down) - deal 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (below stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Fortune's Favor is a simple game related to Busy Aces, except it uses only 1 deck. This game is easy to win.

Similar Games

Preference

Busy Aces

The Bold

Forty and Eight

Forty and Eight

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (75%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces may be filled with any card.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt to each of the 8 piles.
•stock (bottom left, face down) - turn over cards 1 at a time to the waste by clicking.  One redeal.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

This is a variation of Forty Thieves.

Similar Games

Lower 48

Forty Bandits

Forty Bandits

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (40%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Move groups of cards only if they are in sequence down in suit. Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile.
•stock (bottom left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.  All cards in the waste are visible.

Options

AutoPlay

Tips

•Try to get a space in the tableau as quickly as possible.

History

Forty Bandits is a variation of Forty Thieves where groups of cards in sequence may be moved, making it a slightly easier game.

Forty Buccaneers

Forty Buccaneers

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (75%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved. Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile.
•stock (bottom left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  1 redeal.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

Tips

•Try to get a space in the tableau as quickly as possible.

History

Forty Buccaneers is Forty Thieves with a redeal.

Forty Pirates

Forty Devils

Forty Devils

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (2%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build left 4 piles up in suit from Ace to King,  drop 13 card sequences of same suit cards from the tableau on the right 4 piles.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Groups of cards in sequence down in suit may be moved as a unit. Spaces are filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - deal 1 card to the waste pile by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (right of stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•The first 4 foundations are built up in suit from Ace to King (using any suits for the 4 piles).   The last 4 foundations are built in the tableau.  Build 4 13-card sequences of same suit, from King down to Ace.  To move these cards to the foundations, pick up the entire 13-card sequence and drop it on the desired foundation pile.   Single cards are not allowed in these foundation piles.

History

Forty Devils was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Rouge Forty

Lady Cadogan

Rouge et Noir

Diavolo

Forty Eight and Cells

Forty Eight and Cells

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (10%).  Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•4 cells (top left) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.  At the start of the game one card is dealt to each cell.

 

•6 tableau piles (below foundations and cells) - build down by any suit but the same.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by any suit but the same and if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.  Spaces can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 8 cards are dealt face up to each pile.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Groups of cards in the tableau can only be moved as a group if there are a sufficient number of empty cells available to store the cards individually.  The ability to move cards as a group is only a shortcut to moving the group one card at a time.

Tips

•Try to keep as many cells empty as possible.

History

Forty Eight and Cells is a FreeCell type game similar to Six by Four.

Similar Games

FreeCell

Six by Four

Forty Eight Thieves

Forty Eight Thieves

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (20%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•12 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved. Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile.
•stock (bottom left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Tips

•Try to get a space in the tableau as quickly as possible.

History

Forty Eight Thieves is Forty Thieves with two additional tableau piles.

Similar Games

Forty Thieves

Forty Four Thieves

Forty Four Thieves

Forty Four Thieves

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (20%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•11 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved. Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile.
•stock (bottom left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Tips

•Try to get a space in the tableau as quickly as possible.

Forty Four Thieves is Forty Thieves with an additional tableau pile.

Forty Pirates

Forty Pirates

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (25%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved. Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile.
•stock (bottom left, face down) - turn over 3 cards at a time to the waste by clicking.  2 redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Tips

•Try to get a space in the tableau as quickly as possible.

History

Forty Pirates is Forty Thieves with a 3 card deal and 2 redeals.

Similar Games

Forty Thieves

Cadran

Forty Buccaneers

Forty Thieves

Forty Thieves

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (10%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved. Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Tips

•Try to get a space in the tableau as quickly as possible.

History

This is a classic solitaire game that probably dates back to the nineteenth century.  It is known by many names, such as Napoleon at St. Helena, Big Forty, Roosevelt at San Juan, and Le Cadran.  It has many variations, most of which are easier to win, since this game is very challenging.

Similar Games

Cadran

Josephine

San Juan Hill

Forty Bandits

Number Ten

Rank and File

Limited

Lucas

Forty Pirates

Forty Winks

Forty Winks

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (70%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  One redeal.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Forty Winks is Rectangular with a redeal.

Similar Games

Rectangular

Forty Thieves

Forty-Nine

Forty-Nine

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Very Hard (<1%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Only one card at a time may be moved, except when moving groups of cards down by alternate color into an empty space .  Spaces may be filled by any available card or group of cards.   At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (face down) - turn over cards one at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (below stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Forty-Nine is a variation of Interchange.

Similar Games

Ninety-Nine

Interchange

Unlimited

Breakwater

Crossroads

Forwards

Forwards

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (1%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the tableau.

Layout

•28 tableau piles - pair the top card of the stock with the top card of a pile where the ranks add to 14. Valid pairs are A-K, 2-Q, 3-J, 4-10, 5-9, 6-8, 7-7.  Piles may contain more than 2 cards (for example, the pile may begin with an 8, a 6 can be played on it, then another 8, and so on).  Cards cannot be moved from one pile to another.  The game ends if the top card of the stock cannot be played to a pile.  The game is won if all the cards are placed on the tableau .
•stock (top left corner) - cards are built on the tableau.

Valid Discards

•Ace-King, 2-Queen, 3-Jack, 4-10, 5-9, 6-8, 7-7

History

Forwards is a variation of Forwards and Backwards invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Forwards and Backwards

Forwards and Backwards

Forwards and Backwards

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Very Hard (<1%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To discard all the cards.

Layout

•20 tableau piles - in the first part of the game (the "Forwards" part), pair the top card of the stock with the top card of a pile where the ranks  add to 14. Valid pairs are A-K, 2-Q, 3-J, 4-10, 5-9, 6-8, 7-7.  Piles may contain more than 2 cards (for example, the pile may begin with an 8, a 6 can be played on it, then another 8, and so on).   Cards cannot be moved from one pile to another.  The game ends if the top card of the stock cannot be played to a pile.  If all the cards in the stock are played to the tableau, then the second part of the game (the "Backwards" part) begins.  Pairs of cards whose ranks add to 14 are removed from the tableau (cards can be paired by dropping one card on the other, or moving the cards to the reserve).  The two cards of the pair can both come from the same pile.  The game is won if all the cards are discarded.
•stock (top left corner) - cards are built on the tableau.
•waste (far right)  - Where paired cards go out of play.
•reserve (lower left) - where pairs of cards can be formed.

Valid Discards

•Ace-King, 2-Queen, 3-Jack, 4-10, 5-9, 6-8, 7-7

Similar Games

Forwards

Four by Five

Four by Five

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (2%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (center) - build each foundation in suit, regardless of order.  On the top foundation, any card of the same suit as the first card dealt may be played.  On the lower foundations, start with a card of the same rank as the first card dealt, then play any card of that suit where a card of the same rank has already been played to the foundation immediately above.
•4 reserve piles (left of foundations) - top card is available for play on the foundations.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt to each pile, the top card is face up.
•stock (face down, right) - Turn over cards 3 at a time to the waste pile.  Unlimited redeals.

 

•waste (below stock) - The top card of the waste pile is available for play on the foundations.

History

Four by Five is a variation of Osmosis.  Because there are more cards in the reserves and the stock is dealt 3 cards at a time instead of 1, it is a harder game.

Similar Games

Osmosis

Peek

Bridesmaids

Four by Ten

Four by Ten

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (50%).  Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 cells (middle) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.

 

•4 tableau piles (left) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color and if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.  Spaces can be filled by any card or legal group of cards .  At the start of the game 13 cards are dealt face up to each piles.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Groups of cards in the tableau can only be moved as a group if there are a sufficient number of empty cells available to store the cards individually.  The ability to move cards as a group is only a shortcut to moving the group one card at a time.

 

History

Four by Ten is a variation of FreeCell.

Similar Games

FreeCell

Ten by One

Four Colours

Four Colours

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck. Medium (60%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•4 cells (top) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.  Only 1 card of each suit is allowed in the cells.  First cell holds a ♣, 2nd a ♦, 3rd a ♥, 4th a ♠.
•7 tableau piles (below cells) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Fill spaces with any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 13 cards are dealt to each of the leftmost 4 piles (all cards of the same suit are dealt to the same pile).  The remaining 3 piles start the game empty.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Only one card is allowed at a time in a cell, and only one card of each suit is allowed in the cells.  Note that the cell that can only hold a ♣  is directly above the pile that starts the game with the 13 ♣ 's.  This is true for all the suits.

History

Four Colours is a Freecell type game of German origin.

Similar Games

Freecell

Four Leaf Clovers

Four Leaf Clovers

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (40%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundation.

Layout

•1 foundation pile (right) - build up regardless of suit from Ace to King, wrapping from King to Ace until the pile contains all 52 cards.
•13 tableau piles (left of foundation) - build up or down regardless of suit, wrapping from King to Ace or Ace to King if necessary.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are not filled.  At the start of the game 4 cards each are dealt to each pile.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Four Leaf Clovers has some similarities to Black Hole.

Similar Games

Black Hole

Four Seasons

Four Seasons

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (45%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (corners) - build up in suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•5 tableau piles (forming cross) - build down regardless of suit, wrapping from Ace to King as necessary.  Spaces are filled by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.

 

•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Similar Games

Czarina

Corners

Four Stacks

Four Stacks

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck. Hard (30%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the waste piles.

Layout

•4 tableau piles (left) - Build down by alternate color. Groups of cards may be moved as a unit if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  At the start of the game each pile contains 13 cards face up.  Spaces can be filled by any card or group of cards.
•6 waste piles (right) - build from the tableau down by alternate color.  Groups of cards may be moved as a unit if they are in sequence down by alternate color.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Four Stacks is a variation of Take Away.

Four Winds

Four Winds

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (83%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (on the 4 sides, the four "winds") - build up in suit from Ace to King.  At the start of the game the Aces are dealt here.
•16 tableau piles (4 each adjacent to each foundation) - No building.  Top card is available for play on the foundations   Spaces are filled from the waste or another tableau pile.  Spaces may only be filled by a card of the same suit as the suit of the foundation pile adjacent to the space.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (middle, face down on left) - move 1 card to waste by clicking.  1 redeal.
•waste (beside stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or spaces in the tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Similar Games

Carpet

Fours Up

Fours Up

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (45%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (in box at right) - build up in suit from Fours to King, wrapping to Ace, Two, Three.  At the start of the game the Fours are dealt to each pile.
•6 tableau piles (across top, left) - build down regardless of suit, wrapping from Ace to King as necessary.  Groups of cards may be moved if they are in a sequence down in suit, wrapping from Ace to King as necessary.  Spaces can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (bottom, face down on left) - move 1 card to waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (beside stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Fours Up is a member of the Busy Aces family.  Fours Up was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Busy Aces

Deuces

Three's Company

Penta

Sixes and Sevens

Eights Down

Cast Out Nines

Dimes

Jacks in the Box

Foursome

Foursome

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (20%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To collect all the cards in sets of 4 cards of the same rank.

Layout

•4 cells (top) - storage location for one card.  No building.  When all 4 cells contain cards of the same rank (for example, 4 Jacks), then the 4 cards are removed from play.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•6 tableau piles (below cells) - build up or down by alternate color, wrapping from Ace to King or King to Ace as necessary.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces can be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (face down on left) - Deals 1 card to each tableau pile.

Options

AutoPlay

Similar Games

Quartet

Rank FreeCell

Fourteen Demons

Fourteen Demons

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (80%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To discard all the cards.

Layout

•4 tableau piles - the top card is available for play.  Discard pairs of cards that have ranks that add to 14. Possible pairs are King-Ace, Queen-2, Jack-3, 10-4, 9-5, 8-6, 7-7.   Spaces are filled automatically from the stock.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over  3 cards at a time, by clicking.  Unlimited redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for pairing.
•reserve (left of tableau) - Top card always available for play.  At the start of the game 13 cards are dealt here.

Valid Discards

•A-K, 2-Q, 3-J, 4-10, 5-9, 6-8, 7-7

History

Fourteen Demons is an addition game with a tableau like Canfield.

Similar Games

Fifteen Rush

Canfield

Fourteen Out

Fourteen Out

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (50%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To pair up all cards and move them out of play to the waste pile.

Layout

•12 tableau piles - the top card of each pile is available.  Pair cards that total to 14.  For example, a King and an Ace, a Queen and a 2, or an 8 and a 6.  To remove a pair, pick up one card with the mouse and drop it on the other.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt face up to each of the first 4 piles, 4 cards are dealt face up to each of the remaining piles.

 

•waste pile (bottom of screen) - where paired cards go out of play.

Notes

Cards that pair to 14: King-Ace, Queen-2, Jack-3, 10-4, 9-5, 8-6, 7-7.

History

Fourteen Out is a simple game to play, and is fairly easy to win.

Similar Games

Double Fourteens

Triple Fourteens

Tens Out

Thirteen Out

Fourteen Peaks

Fourteen Peaks

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (80%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To pair up all cards and move them out of play to the waste pile.

Layout

•3 triangular peaks of cards and 8 piles of 3 cards each - the top card of each pile is available Only uncovered cards in the peaks are available for play.  Pair cards whose ranks total to 14.   To remove a pair, pick up one card with the mouse and drop it on the other.  At the start of the game 28 cards are dealt face up to the 3 triangular peaks and 3 cards are dealt face up to the 8 piles.

 

•waste pile - where paired cards go out of play.

Notes

Cards that pair to 14: King-Ace, Queen-2, Jack-3, 10-4, 9-5, 8-6, 7-7.

Similar Games

Fourteen Out

Fifteen Peaks

Fourteen Up

Fourteen Up

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (25%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To pair up all cards and move them out of play to the waste pile.

Layout

•5 tableau piles - discard pairs of cards whose ranks add to 14.  The top card of each pile is available for pairing.  The top card of any pile can also be moved into an empty space.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•2 reserve piles (bottom) - 2 additional cards that can be paired with the cards in the tableau.  Once paired, these cards are not replaced by the stock, nor can cards from the tableau be used to fill empty spaces.
•stock (far right, face down) - clicking deals 1 card to each of the 5 tableau piles.

Notes

•Any pair of cards whose values add to 14 can be discarded.  The valid pairs are King-Ace, Queen-Two, Jack-3, 10-4, 9-5, 8-6, 7-7.    When all possible pairs are discarded, deal another set of 5 cards onto the piles by clicking on the Stock.

 

Valid Discards

•A-K, 2-Q, 3-J, 4-10, 5-9, 6-8, 7-7.

 

History

Fourteen Up, also known as 14's, is a variation of Five Piles.  It was invented by Randy Rasa.

Similar Games

Five Piles

Fourteens

Fourteens

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Hard (<1%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To discard all the cards in pairs.

Layout

•25 Piles arranged in a 5x5 square - discard pairs of cards that add to 14, if they are in the same row or column.  For example, a King and an Ace, a Queen and a 2, or an 8 and a 6.  To remove a pair, pick up one card with the mouse and drop it on the other.   Spaces are filled automatically from the stock.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (far right, face down) - fills spaces in the piles automatically.
•Fill button - when all available pairs have been discarded and the stock is empty, clicking the fill button fills spaces from left to right in the top row with cards taken from right to left from the bottom row.

Notes

Cards that pair to 14: King-Ace, Queen-2, Jack-3, 10-4, 9-5, 8-6, 7-7.

History

Fourteens is a pair-elimination game similar to Monte Carlo.

Similar Games

Monte Carlo

Monaco

Fourteens Again

Fourteens Again

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (50%).  Skill/luck balanced.

Object

To discard all the cards.

Layout

•13 tableau piles - the top card is available for play.  Discard pairs of cards that have ranks that add to 14.  Spaces are automatically filled from the stock in the center 3 piles, otherwise in the outer 10 piles spaces are not filled.   Cards can be discarded by dropping one on the other.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt face up to 10 piles, 1 card is dealt face up to the center 3 piles.
•stock (face down, left) - fills spaces in the tableau.
•waste (far right)  - Where paired cards go out of play.

Valid Pairs

•A-K, 2-Q, 3-J, 4-10, 5-9, 6-8, 7-7

History

Fourteens Again is a cross between Fourteen Out and Seventeens.

Similar Games

Fourteen Out

Seventeens

Fred's Four

Fred's Four

 Top  Previous  Next

4 Decks.  Medium (80%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•16 foundation piles (left and right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•16 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Move groups of cards only if they are in sequence down in suit.  Fill spaces with any card.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Fred's Four is a 4 deck version of Fred's Spider.

Similar Games

Fred's Spider

Spidike

Fred's Spider

Fred's Spider

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Easy (96%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Move groups of cards only if they are in sequence down in suit.  Fill spaces with any card.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Fred's Spider was invented by Fred Lunde of Livonia, Michigan.  It is related to Spider and the one deck Spidike.

•12 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•13 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Move groups of cards only if they are in sequence down in suit.  Fill spaces with any card.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.
