Free Fan

Free Fan

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Easy (99%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•2 cells (top left) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.  Card is available for play on the foundations or fans.
•18 fans (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved to the foundations or another fan.  Spaces are filled only by Kings.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt face up to each pile (the last 2 piles only have 2 cards).

Options

AutoPlay

History

Free Fan is a variation of Fan invented by Gregg Seelhoff.

Similar Games

Free Fan Hard

Fan

La Belle Lucie

Three Shuffles and a Draw

Lucky Fan

Free Fan Hard

Free Fan Hard

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (90%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•2 cells (top left) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.  Card is available for play on the foundations or fans.
•18 fans (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved to the foundations or another fan.  Spaces cannot be filled.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt face up to each pile (the last 2 piles only have 2 cards).

Options

AutoPlay

History

Free Fan Hard is a variation of Free Fan invented by Gregg Seelhoff.

Similar Games

Free Fan

Fan

La Belle Lucie

Three Shuffles and a Draw

Lucky Fan

Free Parking

Free Parking

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (5%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To create 4 sequences of 12 cards of the same suit, running from Twos to Kings.

Layout

•52 card spaces  - Fill in gaps (spaces) by moving the next highest ranking card in suit to the card to the left of the space into the space, or the next lower ranking card in suit to the card to the right of the space into the space.  Do this by clicking on the card to you want to move.  At the start of the game 13 cards each are dealt to 4 rows and the Aces are removed.   The object is to rearrange the cards so that each row contains a in-suit sequence starting with Two on the far left and going up to Kings.
•Shuffle (top) - When clicked, all cards that are not in suit sequence starting from a Two in the leftmost position of the pile will be picked up and moved randomly to another location (that is, once a card is in a position it needs to be in to win the game, it will remain there thru a shuffle).  One Shuffle is allowed.

Notes

•A gap (space) can be filled by moving the next higher card in suit to the card immediately to the left of the space into the space, or by moving the next lower card in suit to the card immediately to the right of the space into the space.  This is done simply by clicking on the card you want to move.   For example, if there is a 4 ♦ followed by a space, click on the 5 ♦ (wherever it may be) and it will be moved to the right of the 4.  Or if there is a 10 ♦ to the right of a space, click on the 9 ♦ to move it to the left of the 10.  Gaps (spaces) on the far left that have no card to the left can be replaced by Twos (of any suit).  When the card to the left of a gap is a King, and there is no card to the right of the gap (for instance, the end of the row is to the right), then no card may be played there.

History

Free Parking is a variation of Gaps.

Similar Games

Gaps

Spaces and Aces

Park and Ride

FreeCell

FreeCell

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Easy (>99%).  Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•4 cells (top left) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.

 

•8 tableau piles (below foundations and cells) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color and if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.  Spaces can be filled by any card or legal group of cards (see KingOnly for option).  At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt face up to the leftmost 4 piles, 6 cards are dealt face up to the remaining piles.

Options

KingOnly AutoPlay

Notes

•Groups of cards in the tableau can only be moved as a group if there are a sufficient number of empty cells available to store the cards individually.  The ability to move cards as a group is only a shortcut to moving the group one card at a time.
•The game number deals #1 to #1000000 are compatible with the games in the standard Windows FreeCell.  FreeCell can almost always be won.  Only the games #11982, #146692, #186216, #455889, #495505, #512118, #517776, and #781948 are known to be unsolvable.  For more information about FreeCell and a catalog of solutions to well known game numbers, see http://www.freecell.org.

Tips

•Try to keep as many cells empty as possible.

History

FreeCell is a variation of Baker's Game.  It was invented by Paul Alfille.

Similar Games

Baker's Game

Sea Towers

ForeCell

Challenge FreeCell

Eight Off

Double FreeCell

Triple FreeCell

Three Cells

Two Cells

FreeCell Duplex

FreeCell Duplex

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Very Easy (>99%).  Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•8 cells (around top left corner) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.

 

•12 tableau piles (below foundations and cells) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color and if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.  Spaces can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 9 cards are dealt face up to the leftmost 8 piles, 8 cards are dealt face up to the remaining piles.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Groups of cards in the tableau can only be moved as a group if there are a sufficient number of empty cells available to store the cards individually.  The ability to move cards as a group is only a shortcut to moving the group one card at a time.

Tips

•Try to keep as many cells empty as possible.

History

FreeCell Duplex is a 2 deck version of FreeCell.

Similar Games

FreeCell

Double FreeCell

FreeCell Twice

Double Eight Off

Twenty Piles

FreeCell Twice

FreeCell Twice

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.   Easy (90%).  Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•6 cells (around top left corner) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.

 

•12 tableau piles (below foundations and cells) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color and if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.  Spaces can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 9 cards are dealt face up to the leftmost 8 piles, 8 cards are dealt face up to the remaining piles.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Groups of cards in the tableau can only be moved as a group if there are a sufficient number of empty cells available to store the cards individually.  The ability to move cards as a group is only a shortcut to moving the group one card at a time.

Tips

•Try to keep as many cells empty as possible.

History

FreeCell Twice is a 2 deck version of FreeCell.  It is the same as FreeCell Duplex except with 2 fewer cells, making it a harder game.

Similar Games

FreeCell

Double FreeCell

FreeCell Duplex

Twenty Piles

Friday

Friday

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (30%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To discard all the cards.

Layout

•13 tableau piles - the top card is available for play.  Discard pairs of cards that have ranks that add to 13. Kings are discarded singly.  Spaces are automatically filled from the stock in the center 3 piles, otherwise in the outer 10 piles spaces are not filled.   At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt face up to 10 piles, 1 card is dealt face up to the center 3 piles.
•stock (face down, left) - fills spaces in the tableau.
•waste (lower left)  - Where paired cards go out of play.

Valid Discards

•A-Q, 2-J, 3-10, 4-9, 5-8, 6-7, K

History

Friday is a variation of Seventeens.

Similar Games

Seventeens

The Ides of March

Frog

Frog

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (90%).  Skill/luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•reserve (left, below foundations) - top card is available for play on the foundations only.  At the start of the game 13 cards are dealt here.
•stock (face down, next to reserve) - turn over 1 card to the main waste pile.  No redeals.
•Main waste pile (below stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or regular waste piles.  Can hold only 1 card at a time.  If there is a card in this pile it must be moved before another card can be dealt from the stock.
•5 regular waste piles (right of stock) - can contain any cards.  Top card is available for play on the foundations only by double clicking or right clicking.

Options

AutoPlay

Tips

On the waste piles, you should try to build downward, if possible.  One pile should be reserved for Kings and Queens.  Don't put lots of cards of the same rank in the same pile.

History

This game is also known as Toad.

Similar Games

Fly

Housefly

Frustrating Pairs

Frustrating Pairs

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Hard (<1%).  All Luck.

Object

To discard all the cards in pairs of the same rank and same color.

Layout

•13 tableau piles  - discard pairs of cards of the same rank and same color (such as a pair of red Jacks) by dropping one of the cards onto the other.   The top card of each pile is available.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile.

History

Frustrating Pairs is a more difficult version of Patient Pairs.

Similar Games

Patient Pairs

Doublets

Nestor

Vertical

Simple Pairs

Doubtful Pairs

Galloway

Galloway

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (10%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color or of the same rank of alternate color.  For example, on a red Ten you can play a black 9 or a black Ten.   Single cards can be moved and also entire piles (regardless of sequence).  No partial piles can be moved.   Spaces can be filled with any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt each pile.
•stock (top left, face up) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.  No redeals.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Galloway is possibly of German origin, reported by Tania Galloway.  See Dumfries for a similar but easier game.

Similar Games

Dumfries

Gaps

Gaps

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Easy (>99%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To create 4 sequences of 12 cards of the same suit, running from Twos to Kings.

Layout

•52 card spaces  - Fill in gaps (spaces) by moving the next highest ranking card in suit to the card to the left of the space into the space.  Do this by clicking on the card to you want to move.  At the start of the game 13 cards each are dealt to 4 rows and the Aces are removed.   The object is to rearrange the cards so that each row contains a in-suit sequence starting with Two on the far left and going up to Kings.
•Shuffle (top) - When clicked, all cards that are not in suit sequence starting from a Two in the leftmost position of the pile will be picked up and moved randomly to another location (that is, once a card is in a position it needs to be in to win the game, it will remain there thru a shuffle).  Two Shuffles are allowed (or select Unlimited redeals in Options).

Notes

•A gap (space) can be filled by moving the next higher card in suit to the card immediately to the left of the space into the space.  This is done simply by clicking on the card you want to move.   For example, if there is a 4 ♦ followed by a space, click on the 5 ♦ (wherever it may be) and it will be moved to the right of the 4.  Gaps (spaces) on the far left that have no card to the left can be replaced by Twos (of any suit).  When the card to the left of a gap is a King, no card can be moved into its place.
•Eventually, all the gaps will be to the right of Kings.  When this occurs, the cards can be reshuffled by clicking on the Shuffle indicated in the top center of the playing field.

Options

Rules - 2 ReDeals or Unlimited ReDeals

History

Gaps is also known as Spaces.

Similar Games

Montana

Spaces and Aces

Free Parking

Maze

Garden Gate

Garden Gate

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (95%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Groups of cards may be moved.  Empty piles are filled from the reserves (or from the waste when the reserves are empty).  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•2 reserve piles (top, left and right of foundations) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 9 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (bottom, face down on left) - move 1 card to waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (beside stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Garden Gate is a two deck version of Gate.

Similar Games

Gate

Little Gate

Middle Gate

Canfield

Dutchess

Gargantua

Gargantua

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Easy (86%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•9 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Groups of cards in sequence down by alternate color may be moved as a unit.  Spaces are filled only by Kings or legal groups of cards headed by a King (see KingOnly for option).  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.  The top card is turned face up.
•stock (bottom left, face down) - turn over 1 card to the waste by clicking.  One redeal.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay KingOnly

History

Gargantua is a 2 deck version of Klondike.  It was invented by Albert H. Morehead and Geoffrey Mott-Smith.

Similar Games

Double Klondike

Klondike

Pantagruel

Batsford

Harp

Steps

Moving Left

Gate

Gate

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (97%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Groups of cards may be moved.  Empty piles are filled from the reserves (or from the waste when the reserves are empty).  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•2 reserve piles (top, left and right of foundations) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (bottom, face down on left) - move 1 card to waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (beside stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Similar Games

Little Gate

Middle Gate

Canfield

Dutchess

Generals Patience

Generals Patience

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Very Hard (<1%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (middle) - build up in suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•9 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Only the top card of each pile may be moved.  Spaces are filled from the stock.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•reserve (top) - top card is available for play on the foundations only. At the start of the game 13 cards are dealt to this pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over cards 1 at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals, except that when the stock is empty the waste may be turned over by clicking on the empty stock, and cards can then be played to the foundations or tableau if possible until a card comes up that cannot be played.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

General's Patience is a variation of Terrace.

Similar Games

Terrace

Colonel

Blondes and Brunettes

Redheads

Falling Star

Admiral's Patience

Genie

Genie

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Short Deck (32 cards).  Medium (30%). Mostly Luck.

Object

To discard all the cards in pairs of the same rank.

Layout

•8 tableau piles  - discard pairs of cards of the same rank.   The top card of each pile is available.   At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•waste (bottom) - Where paired cards go out of play.

Notes

Genie uses a short deck of 32 cards, the 2's, 3's, 4's, 5's and 6's have been removed.

History

Genie is an open (all cards visible) variation of The Wish.

Similar Games

The Wish

Doublets

Nestor

Vertical

Geoffrey

Geoffrey

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (30%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Move groups of cards regardless of any sequence.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.   At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt to the first 4 piles and 6 cards are dealt to the next 4 piles.  4 cards in the last 4 piles are face down.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Any face up card in the tableau may be built upon another, no matter how deep it is in a pile.  All cards covering it are moved together.  When a face down card is uncovered, it is automatically turned face up and is available for play.

History

Geoffrey is a variation of Yukon with a tableau similar to Scorpion.

Similar Games

Yukon

Caramel

Grigory

German Cross

German Cross

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (20%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (center, forming a cross) - build the Aces (in center down vertically) up in suit to Kings, build the Kings (in center across horizontally) down in suit to Aces.  At the start of the game an Ace and King of each suit is dealt here.
•12 tableau piles (upper left, upper right, lower left, lower right) - No building.  Top card is available for play on the foundations.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are filled only from the stock.  At the start of the game 1 card are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (left center, face down) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.  Two redeals.  On a redeal, the cards in the tableau are collected to reform the stock (not shuffled).

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•It is allowed to move cards from the Ace foundations to the King foundations.

History

German Cross comes from Germany.

German Patience

German Patience

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Very Hard (<1%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To create 8 piles in ascending sequence of 13 cards, regardless of suit, in the tableau.

Layout

•8 tableau piles (across top) - build up regardless of suit, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.   Only the top card of each pile may be moved.   At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (face down, bottom left) - turns over 1 card to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the tableau.

History

German Patience is a unique and very difficult game.

Similar Games

Bavarian Patience

Giant

Giant

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (20%).  Mostly Skill.

Objective

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) -   Build down by alternate color.  Groups of cards can be moved if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (bottom left) - Deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.  No redeals.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•When the stock is empty, the top card of each foundation pile is available for play to any tableau pile. (AutoPlay must be turned off for this to work).

Similar Games

Carlton

Miss Milligan

Little Giant

Gilbert

Gilbert

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (40%)  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top) - on the left 4 piles build up in suit from Aces, on the right 4 piles build down in suit in suit from Kings.  It does not matter where the two piles of the same suit meet.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations, right) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces are filled only by Sevens. At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.  The top card is face up.
•stock (left, face down) - turn over 3 cards at a time, by clicking.  Unlimited redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card always available for play on the tableau or foundations.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Gilbert is a variation of Lafayette.

Similar Games

Lafayette

Give and Take

Give and Take

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (5%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King (see KingOnly for option).   At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt to each pile, alternating face up and face down.
•stock (face down) - turn over 3 cards at a time to the waste by clicking during the first deal, 2 cards at a time during the 2nd deal, and 1 card at a time during the last deal.  Two redeals.
•waste (below stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

KingOnly     AutoPlay

History

Give and Take is a variation of Interchange with 3 diminishing deals.

Similar Games

Interchange

Single Interchange

Unlimited

Triple Interchange

Quadruple Interchange

Giza

Giza

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (10%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To pair up all the cards in the deck in pairs whose ranks total to 13.

Layout

•A Pyramid of 28 cards.  Only uncovered cards are available for play.  Cards are paired whose ranks add to 13. To remove a pair, pick up one of the cards and drag it onto the other.  Kings are removed singly by clicking.
•8 tableau piles - top card is available for pairing.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt face up to each pile.

Notes

•Any pair of cards whose values add to 13 can be discarded.  The valid pairs are Queen-Ace, Jack-Two, 10-3, 9-4, 8-5, 7-6.  Kings are discarded singly.  To discards Kings, simply click on them.

History

Giza is a variation of Pyramid.  It is a totally open game (meaning that all cards are visible from the initial deal) which gives greater opportunity for strategy than Pyramid does.  Giza was invented by Michael Keller.

Similar Games

Pyramid

Pharoahs

Triangle

Pyramid Dozen

Gloucestershire

Gloucestershire

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (86%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King, wrapping to Ace and then to King again, until each pile contains 26 cards.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color, wrapping from Ace to King as necessary.  Groups of cards in sequence down by alternate color may be moved as a unit.  Spaces are filled by any card.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt face up to each pile, then 1 card is dealt to the 2nd pile, 2 cards to the 3rd, and so on.
• 2 reserve piles (left and right) - All cards available for play on the foundations or tableau.  Click on card to move it to the bottom of the stack, then move to either the foundations or tableau.   At the start of the game 26 cards are dealt to each pile.

Options

AutoPlay

Similar Games

Cotswold

Flower Garden

Brigade

Stonewall

Gnat

Gnat

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (25%).  Skill/luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.  At the start of the game the Aces are dealt here.
•6 reserve cards (far right) - card is available for play on the foundations only.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt here.
•stock (top left) - Top card is available for play on the foundations or waste piles.  No redeals.
•4 waste piles (below foundations) - can contain any cards.  You can build cards only from the stock. Top card is available for play on the foundations only.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Gnat is a 1 deck version of Fly.

Similar Games

Fly

Frog

Housefly

Gold Mine

Gold Mine

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (50%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Fill spaces with any card. At the start of the game all of the tableau piles are empty.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 3 cards at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Gold Mine is a variation of Klondike where none of the cards are dealt out.

Sir Tommy

Gold Rush

Gold Rush

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (30%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Fill spaces with Kings or a group of cards headed by a King. At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 3 cards at a time to the waste by clicking during the first deal, 2 cards at a time during the 2nd deal, and 1 card at a time during the last deal.  Two redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Gold Rush is a variation of Klondike, with a variable number of cards dealt from the stock.

Similar Games

Klondike

Spike

Thieves Rush

Double Gold Rush

Aces Wild

Triple Gold Rush

Rush Left

Worldly

Golf

Golf

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Hard (2%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the waste pile.

Layout

•7 tableau piles (across top) - no building.  Top card of each pile is available for play on the waste pile.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (face down below tableau) - turn over 1 card to the waste by clicking.

 

•waste (next to stock) - build up or down in sequence regardless of suit.  No wraparound, only Twos can be played on Aces and nothing can be played on a King.

 

Notes

•Play cards from the tableau to the waste if possible.  Whenever there are no possible plays, turn over a card in the stock by clicking on it.  This card goes to the waste pile.

Tips

•Work out your sequences in advance.  Be careful to save queens for kings, and twos for aces.

History

Golf is a very simple game to play, but difficult to win.

Similar Games

Putt Putt

Kings Way

Black Hole

Panther Creek

Double Golf

Double Putt

Par 3

Night Golf

Quartermaster

Golf Rush

Golf Rush

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (10%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the waste pile.

Layout

•7 tableau piles (across top) - no building.  Top card of each pile is available for play on the waste pile. At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.  All cards are face up.
•stock (face down below tableau) - turn over 1 card to the waste by clicking.

 

•waste (next to stock) - build up or down in sequence regardless of suit.  No wraparound, only Twos can be played on Aces and nothing can be played on a King.

 

Notes

•Play cards from the tableau to the waste if possible.  Whenever there are no possible plays, turn over a card in the stock by clicking on it.  This card goes to the waste pile.

Tips

•Work out your sequences in advance.  Be careful to save queens for kings, and twos for aces.

History

Golf Rush is Golf with a Klondike layout.

Similar Games

Golf

Good Measure

Good Measure

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (5%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.  At the start of the game the first two Aces encountered are moved to the first two piles.

 

•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are not filled.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt face up to each pile (Kings are moved to the bottom of the piles).

Options

AutoPlay

History

Good Measure is a variation of Baker's Dozen.

Similar Games

Baker's Dozen

Spanish Patience

Castles in Spain

Martha

Castles End

Vineyard

Seven and Ten

Gotham

Gotham

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks. Easy (80%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Groups of cards in sequence down in suit may be moved as a unit.   Spaces may be filled only from the stock or a waste pile.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left, face up) - top card is available for play on the foundations, tableau, or waste piles.  No redeals.
•3 waste piles (below stock) - discard piles, cards are moved here from the stock only.  Top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Gotham is a variation of New York invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

New York

Dover

Big Apple

Gradations

Gradations

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (65%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Fill spaces with any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time, by clicking.  No redeals, but after the first time through the stock, clicking on the empty stock pile will turn the waste pile over onto the stock.  The top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.  If the top card cannot be played, the game is lost.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Gradations is a variation of Klondike, with dealing as in Terrace.

Similar Games

Klondike

Granada

Granada

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (50%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build first 4 up in suit from Ace to King, build last 4 down in suit from King to Ace. At the start of the game an Ace and King of each suit is dealt.
•8 reserve piles (below foundations) - No building.  Play cards to the foundations or cells.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile.
•stock (bottom left, face down) - deals 1 card to each cell by clicking.  Two redeals.
•4 cells (beside stock) - Build up or down by suit, wrapping as necessary (Aces may be built on Kings and Kings may be built on Aces).  The top card is available for play on the foundations.  An empty cell may be filled by any available card.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Granada is a variation of Alhambra.

Similar Games

Alhambra

Grand Duchess

Grand Duchess

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (20%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (left and right)  - build the left 4 piles up in suit from Ace to King (one for each suit), the right 4 down in suit from King to Ace (one for each suit).
•stock (top center, face down) - Deals 1 card face up to each tableau pile and (except for the last redeal), deals 1 card face down to each reserve pile.  3 redeals.
•4 tableau piles (below stock) - Cards are dealt here from the stock.  Top card is available for play on the foundations only.  No building, spaces are not filled.
•2 reserve piles (on either side of tableau piles) - Cards are dealt here face down from the stock.  When the stock is empty, the cards are turned face up and become available.  All cards are available for play on the foundations.  Click on card to move it to the bottom of the stack, then move to the foundations.

Grandfather

Grandfather

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Very Easy (97%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top)  - build the first 4 piles up in suit from Ace to King (one for each suit), the last 4 down in suit from King to Ace (one for each suit).
•20 tableau piles (below foundations) - top card is available for play on the foundations only. Each pile may contain up to 2 cards.  Spaces are filled automatically from the stock.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - Turn over 1 card to the waste by clicking.  One redeal.
•waste (below stock) - Top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

History

Grandfather is a 2 deck version of Sir Tommy and is closely related to Twenty.  It is a very simple game to play and win.

Similar Games

Father

Grandmother's

Sir Tommy

Twenty

Grandmothers

Grandmothers

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Very Easy (90%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (middle top)  - build the top 4 piles down in suit from the rank of the first card dealt, wrapping from Ace to King as necessary, build the bottom 4 piles up in suit from one rank higher than first card dealt, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary.
•22 tableau piles (left and right of foundations) - top card is available for play on the foundations only. Each pile may contain up to 2 cards.  Spaces are filled automatically from the stock.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (lower middle, face up) - Top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau or waste piles.  No redeals.
•4 waste piles (below stock) - Storage spaces for one card.  The card is available for play on the foundations.

History

Grandmother's is a variation of Grandfather.

Similar Games

Grandfather

Twenty

Great River

Great River

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (80%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards regardless of any sequence.  Fill spaces with any card or group of cards.   At the start of the game 1 card is dealt the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd pile, and so on.  The top card is face up.  Then 4 additional face up cards are dealt to the 2nd through 7th piles.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Any face up card in the tableau may be built upon another, no matter how deep it is in a pile.  All cards covering it are moved together.  When a face down card is uncovered, it is automatically turned face up and is available for play.

Tips

•Uncover the face down cards as soon as possible.  Don't let one foundation get too far ahead of the others.

History

Great River is a variation of Yukon.

Similar Games

Yukon

Volga

Great Triangle

Great Triangle

 Top  Previous  Next

3 Decks.  Medium (80%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•12 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•13 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Groups of cards may be moved if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Fill spaces with any card or group of cards.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to the first pile, 2 to the 2nd, and so on.
•stock (bottom left, face down) - deal one card to each tableau pile, by clicking.  No redeals.

History

Great Triangle is a 3 deck version of Carlton.  It was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Carlton

Eternal Triangle

Arabella

Great Wheel

Great Wheel

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (50%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•Ace foundation (top left) - build with Aces only, alternating in color until the pile contains all 8 Aces.
•Evens foundations (top) - build up in suit by twos, starting with Twos. (Two, Four, Six, Eight, Ten, Queen).
•Odds foundations (under Evens) - build up in suit by twos, starting with Threes. (Three, Five, Seven, Nine, Jack [there are no Kings]).
•8 tableau piles (under Odds) - top card is available for play on the foundations.  No building until the stock is empty.  At that time build down in suit.  Spaces are filled by 4 cards from the waste, unless the waste is empty, when they are filled by the stock (if the stock is empty, they are filled by any card).  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (bottom left, face down) - Turn over 1 card to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (under stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations.

History

Great Wheel is a unique and interesting game.

Similar Games

Greater Wheel

Mount Olympus

Carousel

Greater Wheel

Greater Wheel

 Top  Previous  Next

4 Decks.  Medium (50%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•Ace foundation (top left) - build with Aces only, alternating in color until the pile contains all 16 Aces.
•Evens foundations (top left) - build up in suit by twos, starting with Twos. (Two, Four, Six, Eight, Ten, Queen).
•Odds foundations (under Evens to right) - build up in suit by twos, starting with Threes. (Three, Five, Seven, Nine, Jack [there are no Kings]).
•12 tableau piles (under Odds) - top card is available for play on the foundations.  No building until the stock is empty.  At that time build down in suit.  Spaces are filled by 6 cards from the waste, unless the waste is empty, when they are filled by the stock (if the stock is empty, they are filled by any card).  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (bottom left, face down) - Turn over 1 card to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (under stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations.

History

Greater Wheel is 4 deck variation of Great Wheel.

Similar Games

Great Wheel

Carousel

Grigory

Grigory

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (15%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards into 4 sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - move entire 13-card King to Ace down in suit sequences from the tableau.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit, wrapping from Ace to King if necessary.  Move groups of cards regardless of any sequence.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards with headed by a King (see KingOnly for option).    At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt to the first 4 piles and 6 cards are dealt to the next 4 piles.  4 cards in the last 4 piles are face down.

Options

AutoPlay   KingOnly

Notes

•Any face up card in the tableau may be built upon another, no matter how deep it is in a pile.  All cards covering it are moved together.  When a face down card is uncovered, it is automatically turned face up and is available for play.

History

Grigory is Ukrainian Solitaire with a different opening layout (same as Geoffrey).

Similar Games

Ukrainian Solitaire

Geoffrey

Grounds for Divorce

Grounds for Divorce

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (50%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards in sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace.

Layout

•10 tableau piles - build down regardless of suit.  Groups of cards in sequence down in suit may be moved as a unit.  A space can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 5 cards each are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - deals 1 card to each non-empty tableau pile by clicking.  No cards are dealt to empty tableau piles.

Notes

•Whenever a sequence of 13 cards down in suit from King to Ace is formed, it will automatically be removed from play.

Tips

•Same suit sequences should be preferred even though building is down regardless of suit.  The object is to build down in suit sequences.
•Spaces should be made as soon as possible.  Note that since cards are not dealt to empty spaces from the stock, once a space is created it will remain until cards are moved there.

History

Grounds for Divorce is a variation of Spider.  It differs from Spider in the initial layout and most importantly, in that cards are not dealt to empty tableau spaces from the stock.

Similar Games

Incompatibility

Spider

Black Widow

Beetle

Guildford

Guildford

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (80%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Fill spaces with any card. At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 3 cards at a time to the waste by clicking.  One redeal.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.

History

Guildford is a variation of Lady Jane.

Similar Games

Lady Jane

Double Jane

Arabella

Inquisitor

Quizzie

HalfCell

HalfCell

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Easy (>99%).  Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•2 foundation piles (top right) - build up by alternate color from Ace to King, then wrapping to Ace to King again.  At the start of the game an Ace of each color is dealt here.
•4 cells (top left) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.  At the start of the game a card is dealt to 2 of the cells.

 

•8 tableau piles (below foundations and cells) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color and if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.  Spaces can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt face up to each pile.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Groups of cards in the tableau can only be moved as a group if there are a sufficient number of empty cells available to store the cards individually.  The ability to move cards as a group is only a shortcut to moving the group one card at a time.

Tips

•Try to keep as many cells empty as possible.

History

HalfCell is a variation of FreeCell with only 2 foundation piles.

Similar Games

FreeCell

QuarterCell

Harmony

Harmony

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (85%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.   Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King. At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - deal one card to each tableau pile, by clicking.  No redeals.
•2 cells (top left) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each cell.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Harmony is a variation of Klondike.

Similar Games

Klondike

Whitehorse

Harp

Harp

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (20%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•9 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Only one card at a time may be moved, except groups of cards down by alternate color may be moved as a unit into an empty space.  Spaces are filled by a King or a group of cards headed with a King (the only way a group of cards may be moved).  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 to the 2nd, and so on.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card to the waste by clicking.  Three redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Harp is a two deck variation of Klondike.

Similar Games

Harp Rush

Klondike

Triple Harp

Endless Harp

Steps

Gargantua

Double Klondike

Random

Quadruple Harp

Harp Rush

Harp Rush

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (15%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•9 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Only one card at a time may be moved, except groups of cards down by alternate color may be moved as a unit into an empty space.  Spaces are filled by a King or a group of cards headed with a King (the only way a group of cards may be moved).  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 to the 2nd, and so on.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 3 cards at a time to the waste by clicking during the first deal, 2 cards at a time during the 2nd deal, and 1 card at a time during the last deal.  Two redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Harp Rush is a variation of Harp similar to Gold Rush.

Similar Games

Harp

Gold Rush

Klondike

Triple Harp

Endless Harp

Hawaiian Solitaire

Hawaiian Solitaire

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (70%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards regardless of any sequence.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.   At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt face down to each pile, then 4 cards face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Any card in the tableau may be built upon another, no matter how deep it is in a pile.  All cards covering it are moved together.

History

Hawaiian Solitaire is a cross between Cornelius (Yukon type) and Australian Patience, placing it in the middle of the Pacific.

Similar Games

Yukon

Cornelius

Australian Patience

Maui Solitaire

Haystack

Haystack

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (80%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•reserve (top left) - storage locations for cards.  Only the top card is available for play.  Limit of 8 cards.  Any card can be moved to the reserve.  At the start of the game 8 cards are dealt here.

 

•9 tableau piles (below foundations and reserve) - build down by alternate color. Only one card at a time can be moved.  Fill spaces with any card.  At the start of the game 8 cards are dealt face up to the 1st, 2nd, 8th and 9th piles, 4 cards are dealt face up to the 3rd and 7th piles, and 2 cards are dealt face up to the 4th and 6th piles.  The 5th pile is left empty.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Haystack is a harder variation of Needle.

Similar Games

Needle

Pitchfork

Heads and Tails

Heads and Tails

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (10%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (left and right sides) - build the piles on the left up in suit from Ace to King, build the piles on the right down in suit from King to Ace.  Each group of 4 piles should have a pile of each suit.
•16 tableau piles (face up in the middle) - build up or down by suit, Aces and Kings are not consecutive (no wraparound).  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are filled automatically from the face down piles directly above or below. (If that reserve pile is empty, the pile is filled from another reserve pile).   At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•8 reserve piles (center, face down) - used to fill spaces in the tableau.  At the start of the game 11 cards are dealt face down to each pile.

Options

AutoPlay

Tips

•Be careful not to block yourself, since the foundations run both up and down.

History

Heads and Tails (also known as Regiment) is an excellent game of strategy.

Similar Games

Regimental

Hera

Hera

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (50%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King. At the start of the game two rows of cards are dealt face down and two more rows face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 3 cards at a time to the waste by clicking during the first deal, 2 cards at a time during the 2nd deal, and 1 card at a time during the last deal.  Two redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Hera is a variation of the game Athena.

Similar Games

Athena

Minerva

Klondike

Gold Rush

Aphrodite

Heracles

Heracles

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (50%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To pair up all the cards and move them to the waste pile.

Layout

•9 tableau piles (across top) - the top card is available for play.  Pair up cards of the same rank.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt face up to each pile.  The cards are dealt in such a way that no two cards of the same rank are dealt to the same pile.
•7 extra cards (below tableau) - each card is available for play to be paired with cards in the tableau.
•waste pile - Where paired cards go out of play.

History

Heracles is a variation of Nestor.

Similar Games

Nestor

Doublets

Vertical

Alcides

Hidden Treasures

Hidden Treasures

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (60%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top) - build the piles down regardless of suit until each pile contains 13 cards, starting with Jacks and wrapping from Ace to King down to Queens.  When the first Jack is played, the top card of two face down tableau piles are turned face up.  When each additional Jack is played, the next top card of a face down tableau pile is turned face up.
•12 tableau piles (middle right, face down) - when face up the top card is available for play on the foundations. No building.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are not filled.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile.   The top card of each pile begins the game face down.  The top card of the piles are turned face up when Jacks are played to the foundations as above, or when the top card of the last face up tableau is played to a foundation pile.
•8 reserve piles (below tableau) - top card is available for play on the foundations.  No building.  Spaces are filled automatically from the waste, or from the stock if the waste is empty.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (middle left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste pile by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (below stock) - top card available for play on the foundations.

Options

AutoPlay

House in the Wood

House in the Wood

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (60%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•35 fans (below foundations) - top card is available for play on the foundations or other fans. Fans are built up or down by suit.  Only 1 card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are not filled.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt face up to each pile (except for the last pile, which is dealt 2 cards).

Options

AutoPlay

Tips

•Watch out for higher cards underneath lower cards of the same suit in a fan.
•Note that while you can build fans up, doing so can make it very difficult to get the cards out to the foundations!
•Build up only when there is no other way to extract a card.
•This game can usually be won with best play.

History

House in the Wood is a 2 deck version of La Belle Lucie.

 

Similar Games

House on the Hill

La Belle Lucie

Buffalo Bill

Intelligence

House on the Hill

House on the Hill

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Easy (70%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top) - build left 4 piles up in suit from Ace to King, right 4 piles down in suit from Kings to Aces. Each group of 4 piles should have a pile of each suit.
•35 fans (below foundations) - top card is available for play on the foundations or other fans. Fans are built up or down by suit.  Only 1 card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are not filled.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt face up to each pile (except for the last pile, which is dealt 2 cards).

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•You may reverse direction as many times as you like within a fan.

Tips

•When the two foundation piles of the same suit meet, make sure that all remaining cards in the fans are built in the proper direction to be placed on the foundations.  This game can usually be won with best play.

History

House on the Hill is a 2 deck version of La Belle Lucie.

 

Similar Games

House in the Wood

La Belle Lucie

Buffalo Bill

Intelligence

Housefly

Housefly

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (50%).  Skill/luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.  At the start of the game the Aces are dealt here.
•6 reserve cards (far right) - card is available for play on the foundations only.  No building.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt here.
•stock (top left) - Top card is available for play on the foundations or waste piles.  No redeals.
•6 waste piles (below foundations) - can contain any cards.  You can build cards only from the stock. Top card is available for play on the foundations only.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Housefly is an easier version of Gnat.

Similar Games

Gnat

Fly

Frog

How They Run

How They Run

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (40%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards into 4 sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace within the tableau.

Layout

•10 tableau piles (top) - build down in suit.  Groups of cards (regardless of any sequence) can be moved.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.   At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt to each pile.  In the rightmost 3 piles, 3 cards are face down and 2 face up, in the other piles all cards are face up.

 

•2 cells (bottom left) -  storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.  Card is available for play on the tableau.

Notes

•Any face up card, regardless of where in a pile it is, can be moved, along with all cards above it (this is like Yukon).

History

How They Run is a variation of Three Blind Mice invented by Erik den Hollander.

Similar Games

Three Blind Mice

Farmer's Wife

Scorpion

Applegate

Huge Spider

Huge Spider

 Top  Previous  Next

4 Decks.  Medium (75%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards in sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace.

Layout

•20 tableau piles - build down regardless of suit.  Groups of cards in sequence down in suit may be moved as a unit.  A space can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt to the first 8 piles and 5 cards are dealt to the remaining piles.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.  All tableau piles must be filled before dealing.

Notes

•Whenever a sequence of 13 cards down in suit from King to Ace is formed, it will automatically be removed from play.

Tips

•Same suit sequences should be preferred even though building is down regardless of suit.  The object is to build down in suit sequences.
•Spaces should be made as soon as possible, and used to move cards into groups by suit.

History

Huge Spider is a 4 deck version of the classic 2 deck Spider.

Similar Games

Spider

Big Spider

Huge Spider One Suit

Huge Spider Two Suits

Huge Spider One Suit

Huge Spider One Suit

 Top  Previous  Next

4 Modified Decks (all cards Spades). Very Easy (99%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards in sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace.

Layout

•20 tableau piles - build down in suit.  Groups of cards in sequence down in suit may be moved as a unit.  A space can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt to the first 8 piles and 5 cards are dealt to the remaining piles.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.  All tableau piles must be filled before dealing.

Notes

•Whenever a sequence of 13 cards down in suit from King to Ace is formed, it will automatically be removed from play.

Tips

•Spaces should be made as soon as possible, and used to move cards into groups by suit.

History

Huge Spider One Suit is Huge Spider with only Spades.

Similar Games

Huge Spider

Huge Spider Two Suits

Spider

Big Spider

Huge Spider Two Suits

Huge Spider Two Suits

 Top  Previous  Next

4 Modified Decks (half Spades, half Hearts).   Easy (90%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards in sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace.

Layout

•20 tableau piles - build down regardless of suit.  Groups of cards in sequence down in suit may be moved as a unit.  A space can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt to the first 8 piles and 5 cards are dealt to the remaining piles.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.  All tableau piles must be filled before dealing.

Notes

•Whenever a sequence of 13 cards down in suit from King to Ace is formed, it will automatically be removed from play.

Tips

•Spaces should be made as soon as possible, and used to move cards into groups by suit.

History

Huge Spider Two Suits is Huge Spider with only Spades and Hearts.

Similar Games

Huge Spider

Huge Spider One Suit

Spider

Big Spider

Hypotenuse

Hypotenuse

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (10%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.   Spaces are filled by a King or a group of cards headed with a King.  At the start of the game 10 cards are dealt to the first pile, 9 to the 2nd, and so on down to 1 card in the 10th.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - deals one card to each tableau pile by clicking.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Hypotenuse is similar to Eternal Triangle.

Similar Games

Eternal Triangle

Right Triangle

Big Harp

Carlton

Small Triangle

Idle Aces

Idle Aces

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (50%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (center, with Twos and Kings) - on the Two foundations, build up regardless of suit from Twos to Kings. On the other 4 foundations,  build down regardless of suit from King to Ace.  At the start of the game a Two and a King of each suit are dealt here.
•4 Ace piles - Each pile may contain one Ace.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  One redeal.
•waste (next to stock) - the top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Imperial Guards

Imperial Guards

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (45%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Groups of cards may be moved if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Empty piles can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top, face down on left) - deals one card to each tableau pile by clicking.  No redeals.
•reserve (below stock) - storage for a card or sequence of cards, usable only after stock is empty.  Card or sequence is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

After all cards in the stock pile have been played, players may take advantage of the empty space beneath the stock pile (the reserve).  Any single card, or legal sequence of cards may be moved to that space.  Only one such card or sequence may be played to the reserve.

History

Imperial Guard is Miss Milligan with spaces in the tableau filled by any card instead of just Kings.

 

Similar Games

Miss Milligan

Incompatibility

Incompatibility

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (85%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles - build down regardless of suit.  Groups of cards in sequence down in suit may be moved as a unit.  A space can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 5 cards each are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - deals 1 card to each non-empty tableau pile by clicking.  No cards are dealt to empty tableau piles.

Tips

•Same suit sequences should be preferred even though building is down regardless of suit.  The object is to build down in suit sequences.
•Spaces should be made as soon as possible.  Note that since cards are not dealt to empty spaces from the stock, once a space is created it will remain until cards are moved there.  Also, this means that at the end of the game you need to hold cards back from the foundations if there are still cards remaining in the stock.  If you play all the cards up the foundations before the stock is empty, you won't be able to deal the cards out from the stock!

History

Incompatibility is a variation of Grounds for Divorce.

Similar Games

Grounds for Divorce

Indefatigable

Indefatigable

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Easy (99%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.  At the start of the game the Aces are dealt here.
•12 tableau piles (middle) - build up or down by suit.  Top card is available for play on the foundations or another tableau pile, only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are filled by any card.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left) - when no more moves can be played, click here to redeal.  All the remaining cards in the tableau will be picked up and redealt.  Two redeals.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Indefatigable is a variation of Royal Family.

Similar Games

Royal Family

Bisley

Indian

Indian

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Easy (80%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) -  build down in any suit but the same.  Only the top card of each pile may be moved.  Spaces filled by any card.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt to each pile, 1 face down and 2 face up.
•stock (top left) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste pile by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

 

History

Indian is very much like Forty Thieves, except that there are fewer cards in the original tableau, and the method of tableau building is down in any suit but the same.  It makes for a considerably easier game.

Similar Games

Indian Patience

Forty Thieves

Napoleon's Folly

Indian Carpet

Indian Carpet

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks. Medium (80%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations

Layout

•8 foundation piles (left and right) - build left piles up in suit from Aces to Kings, build right piles down in suit from Kings to Aces.
•tableau (center) -  At the start of the game 64 cards are dealt out in an 8x8 square, with every other card rotated 90 degrees.  Only cards which have a short side not blocked by another card are available.  In the initial configuration, 16 of the 28 cards on the outside edge are available.  As cards are removed, interior cards will become available.  Available cards from the tableau can be built onto the foundation piles.  Also, an available card in the tableau can be played on the waste pile if it is in sequence up or down by suit.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over cards one at a time to the waste pile by clicking.  Two redeals.
•waste (beside stock) - top card available for play on the foundations. An available card in the tableau can be played on the waste pile if it is in sequence up or down by suit.

History

Indian Carpet is Crazy Quilt with an additional redeal.

Similar Games

Crazy Quilt

Persian Rug

Indian Patience

Indian Patience

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (50%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) -  build down in any suit but the same.  Only the top card of each pile may be moved.  When a face down card is exposed in the tableau, the card is turned face up and becomes a "protected" card.        Protected cards may only be moved to a foundation and no cards may be played upon them.  When a protected card is moved to a foundation, the empty space will be filled from the stock with one face down card and two more face up (for as long as the stock contains the cards to do so).  Protected cards remain protected until the stock is empty, then they become available for play on other tableau piles, and other cards may be played upon them.  After the stock is empty, spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt to each pile, 1 face down and 2 face up.
•stock (top left) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste pile by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

 

History

Indian Patience is a variation of Indian, described by David Parlett.  It differs from Indian with the addition of "protected" cards, which adds more skill to the game and makes it harder to win.

Similar Games

Indian

Mumbai

Taj Mahal

Forty Thieves

Old Moon

Inquisitor

Inquisitor

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (30%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•9 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit.  Fill spaces with any card.   At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 3 cards at a time to the waste by clicking.  Two redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.

History

Inquistor is a variation of Lady Jane and was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Lady Jane

Quizzie

Intelligence

Intelligence

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (50%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•18 fans (below foundations) - build up or down by suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved to a foundation, or to another fan.  Spaces are filled automatically from with 3 cards from the stock.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt face up to each pile.  During the deal, any Aces encountered are automatically moved to the foundations and replaced with another card.
•stock (face down) - fills spaces in fans automatically with 3 cards. Redeal by clicking on the stock in the upper left corner (the stock may or may not have cards in it).  All the cards in the fans are reshuffled. The foundations remain.  As in the original deal, any Aces encountered are automatically moved to the foundations and replaced with another card.  2 redeals.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•There are two ways to move cards between fans, depending on the settings under Rules in the Options menu.  If Drag and Drop is set, the cards are dragged with the mouse.  If Click is set, clicking on a card in a fan automatically moves it to the one other fan that it can move to.

History

This is a 2 deck version of La Belle Lucie.

Similar Games

La Belle Lucie

House on the Hill

House in the Wood

Buffalo Bill

Interchange

Interchange

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Very Hard (<0.1%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King (see KingOnly for option).   At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt to each pile, alternating face up and face down.
•stock (face down) - turn over cards one at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (below stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

KingOnly     AutoPlay

History

This game follows the classic pattern of a Forty Thieves type game, its main difference being the pattern of face up, face down cards in the tableau.  It is extremely difficult to win.  For a similar game that is somewhat easier to win, see Unlimited.

Similar Games

Single Interchange

Unlimited

Triple Interchange

Quadruple Interchange

Breakwater

Forty-Nine

Forty Thieves

Crossroads

Give and Take

Interchange Puzzle

Interchange Puzzle

 Top  Previous  Next

3 Decks.   Easy (85%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move two decks (or 8 suits) of cards to the foundations, to move the other deck (or 4 suits) of cards into 13 piles of 4 cards of the same rank.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top left) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.   At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt to each pile, alternating face up and face down.
•13 reserve piles (on right) - Cards may be played on other cards of the same rank.  At most 4 cards are allowed in any pile.  Empty piles may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time, by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•In the reserve piles, cards may be played on other cards of the same rank.  For example, if the top card of a pile is a Three, another Three can be played on top of it.  The object is to move the cards so that there are 13 piles of 4 cards of the same rank, that is, one pile of 4 Kings, one pile of 4 Queens, and so on.
•8 suits of cards are played to the foundations.  Note that you do not necessarily have to play two piles of each suit to the foundations, any 8 suits out of the 12 suits in 3 decks may be played to the foundations based on the suits of the starting Aces.  The remaining 4 suits are played to the 13 reserve piles.   It is important to keep track of which suits are needed in the reserve piles.

History

Interchange Puzzle is a combination of the games Interchange and Fifteen Puzzle.  It was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Interchange

Fifteen Puzzle

Yukon Puzzle

Klondike Puzzle

Interment

Interment

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Easy (75%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are filled automatically from the stock (When the stock is empty, may be filled by any card).  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•Up reserve (left of foundations, face up) - All 5 cards available for play.  Click on card to move it to the bottom of the stack, then move to either foundations or tableau.  The Up reserve is limited to 5 cards.  The Up reserve is filled by the Down reserve.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt to this pile.
•Down reserve (left of Up reserve, face down) - contains 13 cards to fill spaces in the Up reserve. At the start of the game 13 cards are dealt to this pile.
•stock (below Down reserve) - Top card is available for play on the foundations, tableau, or waste piles.  No redeals.
•3 waste piles (below stock) - unplayable cards may be placed here from the stock. Top card is available for play on the foundations, tableau.  Cards may not be moved from one waste pile to another.

Options

AutoPlay

Interregnum

Interregnum

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Easy (33%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (center row) - build up regardless of suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•8 Indicator cards (top row) - indicate the top card for each foundation.  Must be the last card played to the foundation directly below it.  This row indicates what the bases of the foundation piles will be.  The card in the indicator row is the last card that will be played on the foundation pile below it.  If the indicator card is a Five, for example, then the foundation pile below it must start with a Six.
•8 tableau piles (bottom row) - top card available for play on the foundations only.
•stock (far left) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.

History

Interregnum is a rather unique game.  I suggest using double-clicking to move the cards to the foundations, although note that this will always move the card to the leftmost possible foundation.

Similar Games

Primrose

German Patience

Inverted Canfield

Inverted Canfield

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (20%)  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build down in suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from Ace to King as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•4 tableau piles (below foundations) - build up by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence up by alternate color.  Spaces are filled from the reserve if possible, then by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 or 3 cards at a time, by clicking.  Unlimited redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card always available for play on the tableau or foundations.
•reserve (left of tableau) - Top card always available for play on the tableau or foundations.  At the start of the game 13 cards are dealt here.

Options

•Rules - selects whether 1 card or 3 cards at a time are turned over from the stock.  This option is set in the options menu.

AutoPlay

History

Inverted Canfield is simply Canfield with the directions of building reversed.  Although it is mathematically the same game as Canfield, it will seem much harder.

Similar Games

Canfield

Inverted FreeCell

Inverted FreeCell

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Easy (>99%).  Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build down in suit from King to Ace.
•4 cells (top left) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.

 

•8 tableau piles (below foundations and cells) - build up by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence up by alternate color and if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.  Spaces can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt face up to the leftmost 4 piles, 6 cards are dealt face up to the remaining piles.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Groups of cards in the tableau can only be moved as a group if there are a sufficient number of empty cells available to store the cards individually.  The ability to move cards as a group is only a shortcut to moving the group one card at a time.
•The game number deals #1 to #1000000 are compatible with the games in the standard Windows FreeCell.  Game number #11982, which is impossible in FreeCell, is quite winnable in Inverted FreeCell.

 

Tips

•Try to keep as many cells empty as possible.

History

Inverted FreeCell is FreeCell with building in opposite directions.

Similar Games

FreeCell

Kingsley

Jacks in the Box

Jacks in the Box

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (10%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (in box at right) - build up in suit from Jacks to King, wrapping to Ace to Tens.  At the start of the game the Jacks are dealt to each pile.
