•6 tableau piles (across top, left) - build down in suit, wrapping from Ace to King as necessary.  Groups of cards may be moved if they are in a sequence down in suit, wrapping from Ace to King as necessary.  Spaces can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (bottom, face down on left) - move 1 card to waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (beside stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

 

•4 cells (bottom) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Jacks in the Box is a member of the Busy Aces family.  Jacks in the Box was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Busy Aces

Deuces

Three's Company

Fours Up

Penta

Sixes and Sevens

Eights Down

Cast Out Nines

Dimes

Janet's Bisley

Janet's Bisley

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck. Very Easy (95%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (right) - build the left column up in suit starting with Aces, build the right column down in suit starting with Kings.  It does not matter where the two piles of the same suit meet.  At the start of the game an Ace of each suit is dealt to the left column.
• 12 tableau piles (left of foundations) - build up or down by suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt face up to each pile.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Janet's Bisley is an easy version of Bisley created by a user named Janet.

Similar Games

Bisley

Double Bisley

Josephine

Josephine

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (27%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.   Groups of cards can be moved if they are in sequence down in suit.  Spaces filled by any card or any legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste pile by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

 

History

Josephine is very much like Forty Thieves, except that groups of cards forming a sequence down in suit may be moved as a unit.  It makes for a somewhat easier game.

Similar Games

Forty Thieves

Cadran

Marie Rose

Robespierre

Jumping Spider

Jumping Spider

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium  (80%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards in sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace within the tableau.

Layout

•9 tableau piles - build down regardless of suit.  Groups of cards in sequence down regardless of suit may be moved as a unit.  A space can be filled by any card or legal group of cards. At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile, alternating face down and face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.  All tableau piles must have at least one card in them before you can do this.

Notes

•  The objective is to group all the cards in sets of 13 cards, from King to Ace down in suit.  Whenever such a group is formed in a pile, it is automatically removed from play.
•  When the stock is empty and you are unable to form the tableaus into sets of 13 cards of each suit, the game is lost.

History

Jumping Spider is a variation of the classic game Spider.  It is similar to Black Widow but is harder due to one fewer tableau piles.

Similar Games

Spider

Black Widow

Junction

Junction

 Top  Previous  Next

4 Decks of 32 cards.  Medium (40%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•16 foundation piles (left and right) - build up in suit from Ace to Seven to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) -  build down by alternate color.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are filled by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste pile by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Notes

Junction uses 4 Piquet packs of 32 cards.  The Twos, Threes, Fours, Fives, and Sixes are removed from each deck.  Thus the Ace is actually next to the Seven in rank.  After an Ace is played on a foundation pile, a Seven of the same suit can be played on it.

History

Junction is a 4 deck, Piquet pack extension of games such as Single Rail and Double Rail.

Kettle Hill

Kettle Hill

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (40%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.  At the beginning of the game the Aces are dealt here.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved. Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile.
•stock (bottom left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau. All cards in the waste are visible.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Kettle Hill is a variation of San Juan Hill.  The only difference between Kettle Hill and San Juan Hill is that the entire waste pile is visible to the player, rather than just the top card.

Similar Games

San Juan Hill

Forty Thieves

Cadran

Josephine

Kiev

Kiev

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (10%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards into 4 sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - move entire 13-card King to Ace down in suit sequences from the tableau.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Move groups of cards regardless of any sequence.  Fill spaces with any card.   At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt face down to each pile and one card is dealt is face up.
•stock (top left) - deals one card to each tableau pile by clicking.  No redeals.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Any face up card in the tableau may be built upon another, no matter how deep it is in a pile.  All cards covering it are moved together.  When a face down card is uncovered, it is automatically turned face up and is available for play.

History

Kiev is a variation of Ukrainian Solitaire.

Similar Games

Dnieper

Ukrainian Solitaire

Russian Solitaire

King Albert

King Albert

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (10%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•9 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Only the top card of each pile may be moved.  Spaces may be filled by any available card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd pile, and so on.
•7 reserve cards (across bottom) - each card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.

Options

AutoPlay

History

This game is also known as Idiot's Delight.

Similar Games

Queen Victoria

Raglan

Somerset

Fan Albert

Morehead

Muse

Seymour

Prince Albert

KingCell

KingCell

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (98%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•4 cells (top left) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.

 

•8 tableau piles (below foundations and cells) - build down regardless of suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit and if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.  Spaces can be filled only by a King or group of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt face up to the leftmost 4 piles, 6 cards are dealt face up to the remaining piles.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Groups of cards in the tableau can only be moved as a group if there are a sufficient number of empty cells available to store the cards individually.  The ability to move cards as a group is only a shortcut to moving the group one card at a time.  Although building is down regardless of suit, groups can only be moved if they are down in suit.

Tips

•Try to keep as many cells empty as possible.

History

KingCell is a variation of FreeCell.

Similar Games

FreeCell

ForeCell

Kingdom

Kingdom

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Very Hard (<1%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (middle) - build up regardless of suit from Ace to King.
•8 tableau piles (top) - No building.  Top card available for play on the foundations.  Spaces are filled automatically from the stock.
•stock (bottom, face down) - move 1 card to waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations.

Similar Games

Dominion

Republic

Carpet

Odd and Even

Kings and Queens

Kings

Kings

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (75%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up regardless of suit from Ace to King.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - build up or down regardless of suit.  Top card is available for play on the foundations or another tableau pile.  Spaces are filled by any card.  At the start of the game 13 cards are dealt to each pile.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•During the deal if a card can be played to the foundation directly above it, it is played there.  Hence many of the foundations will already have several cards in them at the beginning of the game.

History

This game is of German origin.

Similar Games

Rittenhouse

Kings and Aces

Kings and Aces

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Very Hard (1%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (right) - build up regardless of suit from Ace to King.   At the start of the game the Aces are dealt here.
•8 tableau piles (left) - No building, consists only of Kings.  The Kings may be played to the foundations when possible.  Spaces are not filled.
•stock (center left, face down) - move cards 1 at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste pile (next to stock) - Top card is available for play on the foundations.

Kings and Queens

Kings and Queens

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (12%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from King, wrapping to Ace, then up to Queen.   At the start of the game the Kings are dealt here.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - the top card is available for play on the foundations. Build down in suit from Queens.  At the start of the game the Queens are dealt here.
•stock (bottom left, face down) - move cards 1 at a time to the waste by clicking.  One redeal.
•waste pile (next to stock) - Top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

History

Kings and Queens is an extremely simple game.

Similar Games

Kingdom

Kings in the Corners

Kings in the Corners

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (80%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To place all the Kings, Queens, and Jacks in their places.

Layout

•16 tableau piles - the four corners are for Kings, top and bottom are for Queens, left and right are for Jacks.  Pair cards that add to 10 (after the tableau is filled).
•stock (face down, left) - top card is available for play in the tableau.
•waste (far right)  - Where paired cards go out of play.

Valid Discards

Ace-9, 2-8, 3-7, 4-6, 5-5, Tens singly.

Play

Play by moving the top card of the stock to an empty pile in the tableau.  The object is the place the Kings in the piles marked for Kings in the corners, Queens in the piles marked for Queens, and Jacks in the piles marked for Jacks.  Any card (except Kings, Queens, or Jacks) may be played to the other piles.

Cards are to be placed in the tableau and the tableau must be completely filled before cards can be removed in pairs.

Two cards that add to 10 may be paired and removed from play (Tens are removed singly).  Cards other than the King, Queen, or Jack may be placed in the edge piles, but you will need to remove them in a pair so that a King, Queen, or Jack can later be played there.  Once a card has been placed, it cannot be moved except to create a pair that adds to 10 (Tens are removed by themselves).

When all possible pairs have been removed, fill the tableau again from the stock.  When the tableau is once again filled, cards can be paired once again.

Repeat the process. The game is won if the 12 Kings, Queens, and Jacks are all placed in their proper places.  The game is lost if a King, Queen, or Jack appears and there is no proper place to put it, or if the tableau fills up and there are no pairs to remove.

Notes

Place Kings, Queens, and Jacks in their marked places when they appear (you cannot place them on any other pile)  Fill the center first with lower cards, pairing out cards that add to 10 when possible.  When the center is full, you will need to place lower cards on the spaces for Kings, Queens, and Jacks.  Fill up places where there are the most other options available (for example, if there are 3 empty King spaces but only two empty Queen and Jack spaces, fill the King space first).   Note that you will always be able to remove a 10 once the

tableau is filled.

Once the tableau is filled, try to pair off the blocking low cards as quickly as possible as if a King, Queen, or Jack is needed for that space and there are no other places to put them, you will lose.  When all possible pairs have been removed, fill the tableau again and then remove pairs again.

King's Way

King's Way

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (17%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards except Kings in the tableau and Aces in the reserve to the waste pile.

Layout

•8 tableau piles (across top) - no building.  Top card of each pile is available for play on the waste pile.  At the start of the game the Kings are dealt here, then a row of face down cards, then 4 face up cards are dealt to each pile.
•stock (face down below tableau) - turn over 1 card to the waste by clicking.  1 redeal.  In the redeal, the number of Aces in the reserve is counted and that number of cards are taken from the bottom of the waste to form a new stock.

 

•waste (next to stock) - build up or down by alternate color.  No wraparound, only Twos can be played on Aces and only Jacks can be played on Queens.
•reserve (below stock) - Any Ace dealt to the waste from the stock can be played here.

Notes

•Play cards from the tableau to the waste if possible.  Whenever there are no possible plays, turn over a card in the stock by clicking on it.  This card goes to the waste pile.
•The game is won if the tableau is cleared except for Kings.
•The redeal only redeals the number of cards in the reserve.  It is important to place as many Aces in the reserve as possible, however it may be necessary to leave some Aces in the waste in order to play Twos on them.

History

King's Way is a 2 deck varation of Golf.

Similar Games

Golf

Putt Putt

Kingsdown Eights

Kingsdown Eights

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (11%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (left) - build the piles up in suit from Ace to King.
•8 tableau piles (across top) - top card is available for play on the foundations or another tableau pile.  Build down by alternate color.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces may be filled by any available card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•8 reserve piles (below tableau) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.  No building.  Spaces are not filled except by the stock (when the stock is clicked).  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - clicking deals 4 cards to each reserve pile.  No redeals.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Kingsdown Eights is a variation of Tournament and Cicely.

Similar Games

Tournament

Cicely

Kingsley

Kingsley

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (1%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build down in suit from King to Ace.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build up by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence up by alternate color.  Fill spaces with Aces or groups of cards with an Ace at the bottom. At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time, by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Kingsley is a reverse Klondike.

Similar Games

Klondike

Double Kingsley

Triple Kingsley

King of Egypt

King of Egypt

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (35%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Groups of cards in sequence down in suit may be moved as a unit.  Spaces may be filled only by Kings.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 3 to the 2nd, 5 to the 3rd, 7 to the 4th, 9 to the 5th, 10 to the 6th, 8 to the 7th, 6 to the 8th, 4 to the 9th, and 2 to the 10th.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  One redeal.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

King of Egypt is a harder version of Thieves of Egypt.  Like Thieves of Egypt it was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Thieves of Egypt

Alexandria

Cleopatra

Swiss Patience

Forty Thieves

King Tut

King Tut

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Hard (3%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To clear the pyramid by pairing up all the cards in the pyramid.

Layout

•A Pyramid of 28 cards.  Only uncovered cards are available for play.  Discard pairs of cards whose ranks add to 13.  Kings are discarded singly.  To discard a pair, drop one card on the other, or right-click on one of the cards.
•stock (top left) - turn over cards 3 at a time to the waste by clicking.  Unlimited redeals.
•waste (beside stock) - The top card is available for play.

Notes

•Any pair of cards whose values add to 13 can be discarded.  The valid pairs are Queen-Ace, Jack-Two, 10-3, 9-4, 8-5, 7-6.  Kings are discarded singly.  To discards Kings, simply click on them.

History

This is a variation of Pyramid.

Similar Games

Pyramid

Giza

Pharaohs

Pyramid Golf

Triangle

Kleine Napoleon

Kleine Napoleon

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Easy (98%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (center) - build up in suit or down in suit from the rank of first card dealt to each pile, wrapping from King to Ace or Ace to King as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.  At the start of the game 4 cards of a random rank are dealt here.  The first card played to any of these piles determines whether building is up in suit or down in suit.  Once the direction of building has been established all 4 piles are built in the same direction and it cannot be changed.
•10 tableau piles (left and right) - build up or down regardless of suit.  Top card is available for play on the foundations, tableau, or reserve.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are filled by any available card, including from the reserve.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt face up to each pile, except the bottom 2 piles which are dealt 4 cards.
•reserve (center, below foundations) - storage location for cards.  Any number of cards may be played here from the tableau, however the top card is available for play only on the foundations or any empty tableau pile.  Cards in the reserve cannot be played to non-empty tableau piles.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Kleine Napoleon is of German origin.

Similar Games

Napoleon

Beleaguered Castle

Zerline

Klondike

Klondike

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (80%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards with a King at the bottom. (See KingOnly for option).  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 or 3 cards (see rules below) at a time, by clicking.  Unlimited redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

Rules - selects whether 1 card or 3 cards at a time are turned over from the stock. (See Options menu)

KingOnly   AutoPlay

History

Klondike is basic Windows solitaire (the game that comes with Windows).  It probably dates back to the Klondike gold rush of the late 19th century.  It is known by many names, including Chinaman, Fascination, Triangle, Patience, and Solitaire.  In England it is often called Canfield.  This version is actually a variation of the real Klondike, which does not allow redeals.

The earliest known reference to Klondike under this name appears in the 1914 book Lady Cadogan's Illustrated Games of Solitaire or Patience.

Similar Games

Double Klondike

Triple Klondike

Quadruple Klondike

Gargantua

Steps

Yukon

Triangular

Small Triangle

Klondike Deal 2

Klondike 13

Klondike 13

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (85%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To discard all the cards.

Layout

•7 tableau piles - the top card is available for play.  Discard pairs of cards that have ranks that add to 13. Possible pairs are Queen-Ace, Jack-Two, 10-3, 9-4, 8-5, 7-6.  Kings are discarded singly. Spaces are filled from the stock, or the top card of the waste if the stock is empty.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over  3 cards at a time, by clicking.  Unlimited redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for pairing.

Valid Discards

•Queen-Ace, Jack-Two, 10-3, 9-4, 8-5, 7-6, King.

History

Klondike 13 is an addition game like Pyramid with a tableau like Klondike.

Similar Games

Fifteen Rush

Thirteens

Klondike Deal 2

Klondike Deal 2

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (75%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards with a King at the bottom.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 2 cards at a time, by clicking.  Unlimited redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Klondike Deal 2 is the game Klondike with a two card deal.

Similar Games

Klondike

Klondike Mini

Klondike Mini

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (75%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•4 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards with a King at the bottom.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time, by clicking.  2 redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

History

Klondike Mini is a 4 pile version of Klondike.

Similar Games

Klondike

Klondike Puzzle

Klondike Puzzle

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Very Easy (95%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move one deck of cards to the foundations, to move the other deck of cards into 13 piles of 4 cards of the same rank.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards with a King at the bottom. At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.  The top card is face up.
•13 reserve piles (on right) - Cards may be played on other cards of the same rank.  At most 4 cards are allowed in any pile.  Empty piles may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 3 cards at a time, by clicking.  Unlimited redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•In the reserve piles, cards may be played on other cards of the same rank.  For example, if the top card of a pile is a Three, another Three can be played on top of it.  The object is to move the cards so that there are 13 piles of 4 cards of the same rank, that is, one pile of 4 Kings, one pile of 4 Queens, and so on.  Note that the 4 cards must all be of different suits.

History

Klondike Puzzle is a combination of the games Klondike and Fifteen Puzzle.  It was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Klondike

Fifteen Puzzle

Yukon Puzzle

Interchange Puzzle

Klondike Territory

Klondike Territory

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (30%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces can be filled with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.  The top card is face up.
•reserve pile (top left) - All cards available for play.  Click on a card to move it to the bottom of the stack, then move to either the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 24 cards are dealt face up to this pile.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

To move a card from the reserve pile, click on a card to move it to the bottom of the stack, then move the card to where you want to play it.  You can also right click on a card in the stack and if there is a legal move for the card the game will make that move.

History

Klondike Territory is a variation of Northwest Territory.

Similar Games

Northwest Territory

Klondike

Flower Garden

Klondike Twice

Klondike Twice

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Easy (80%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Groups of cards in sequence down by alternate color may be moved.  Spaces are filled by a King or legal group of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - turns over 3 cards at a time to the waste by clicking.  Unlimited redeals.
•waste (below stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Klondike Twice is a two deck variation of Klondike suggested by Bastiko Pradhana.

Similar Games

Steps

Seven Steps

Klondike

Harp

Gargantua

Double Klondike

Knitting Pairs

Knitting Pairs

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck. Medium (60%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To pair up all the cards in the deck in pairs of cards of the same ranks.

Layout

•tableau (center) - Pair up cards of the same rank. At the start of the game 36 cards are dealt out in an 6x6 square, with every other card rotated 90 degrees.  Only cards which have a short side not blocked by another card are available.  In the initial configuration, 12 of the cards on the outside edge are available.  As cards are removed, interior cards will become available.  Available cards from the tableau or reserve can be paired.
•4 reserve piles - No building, the top card is available for pairing with the tableau .  Two cards from the reserve piles cannot be paired.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt face up to each pile.

 

History

Knitting Pairs is an Addition type version of the game Crazy Quilt based on an idea by Bastiko Pradhana.

 

 

Similar Games

Crazy Quilt

Indian Carpet

Persian Rug

Knotty Nines

Knotty Nines

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck. Very Hard (<1%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the tableau.

Layout

•9 tableau piles  - build down regardless of suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are filled automatically from the stock.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (left, face down) - automatically fills spaces in the tableau.

Notes

The idea is to get all of the cards in play by grouping cards in piles down regardless of suit, which brings more cards into play via the empty spaces created.  The game is won if all cards are moved from the stock onto the tableau.

History

Knotty Nines is a harder variation of Trusty Twelve.

Similar Games

Trusty Twelve

Sweet Sixteen

Bunker

Up and Up

La Belle Lucie

La Belle Lucie

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (40%).  Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•18 fans (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are not filled.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt face up to each pile (except for the last pile, which just has 1 card).
•stock (upper left, no cards) -  There are two redeals.  After all possible plays have been made, redeal by clicking on the green arrow in the upper left corner.  All the cards in the fans are reshuffled. The foundations remain.  2 redeals.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•There are two ways to move cards between fans, depending on the settings under Rules in the Options menu.  If Drag and Drop is set, the cards are dragged with the mouse.  If Click is set, clicking on a card in a fan automatically moves it to the one other fan that it can move to.

Tips

This game is tough.  Once you move a card onto a fan, the cards below are blocked until a redeal, unless they can be played to a foundation.  Kings block all cards below them as well.  Play cards to the foundation when they are available.

History

La Belle Lucie is a classic variation of Fan.

Similar Games

Three Shuffles and a Draw

Fan

Shamrocks

Trefoil

Clover Leaf

Super Flower Garden

Linus

Three Shuffles and a Cell

La Nivernaise

La Nivernaise

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (5%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top) - build the piles on the left up in suit from Ace to King, build the piles on the right down in suit from King to Ace.  Each group of 4 piles should have a pile of each suit.
•6 tableau piles (face up in the middle) - top card is available for play on the foundations or reserves.  Spaces are filled by a group of 4 cards from the stock.  No building.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile, only the top card is visible.
•8 reserve piles (left and right sides) - each pile can contain 1 card from the tableau, available for play on the foundations.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top, face down) - clicking deals 4 cards to each tableau pile.  There are 2 redeals.  (During a redeal all the cards in the tableau are collected and all the cards are redealt to the tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

 

Notes

When the foundations piles of the same suit meet, is its allowable (and encouraged) to move cards from one foundation to the other.

Tips

Try to keep at least one reserve open.  Don't put cards on the reserve that will stay there for a long time.

History

La Nivernaise is an older version of Tournament.

Similar Games

Tournament

Kingsdown Eights

Cicely

Ladies Battle

Ladies Battle

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Hard (5%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (right) - build up in suit from Queens to Kings to Aces up to Jacks.
•6 tableau piles (across) - build down by alternate color.  One card at a time may be moved. Spaces are filled automatically from the stock.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.
•4 Jacks (far left) - available for play on the foundations only.

Options

AutoPlay

Similar Games

Gate

Lanes

Lady Betty

Lady Betty

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (70%).  Skill/luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundations (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•6 waste piles (below foundations) - cards are played here from the stock.  The top card of each pile is available for play.  Move cards to the foundations by clicking.
•stock (far left, below foundations) - Top card is available for play on the waste piles or foundations.  No redeals.

History

Lady Betty is a variation of Sir Tommy.

Similar Games

Last Chance

Strategy

Colours

Lady Cadogan

Lady Cadogan

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Very Easy (90%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build left 4 piles up in suit from Ace to King,  drop 13 card sequences of same suit cards from the tableau on the right 4 piles.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Groups of cards in sequence down in suit may be moved as a unit. Spaces are filled by Kings or legal groups of cards headed by a King (see KingOnly for option).  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd pile, and so on.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - deal 1 card to the waste pile by clicking.  Unlimited redeals.
•waste (right of stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

KingOnly   AutoPlay

Notes

•The first 4 foundations are built up in suit from Ace to King (using any suits for the 4 piles).   The last 4 foundations are built in the tableau.  Build 4 13-card sequences of same suit, from King down to Ace.  To move these cards to the foundations, pick up the entire 13-card sequence and drop it on the desired foundation pile.   Single cards are not allowed in these foundation piles.

History

Lady Cadogan is a variation of Rouge et Noir invented by Thomas Warfield.  It is named after Lady Adelaide Cadogan, who published one of the first books on solitaire in the 1870s.

Similar Games

Rouge et Noir

Forty Devils

Numeration

Lady Jane

Lady Jane

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Very Easy (>99%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit.  Fill spaces with any card. At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 3 cards at a time to the waste by clicking.  One redeal.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.

History

Lady Jane was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Lady of the Manor

Lady of the Manor

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks. Medium (30%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across bottom) - build up regardless of suit from the founding Aces to Kings.  At the start of the game the Aces are dealt here.
•4 tableau piles (middle) - top card is available for play on the foundations.  No building.  At the start of the game 12 cards are dealt to each pile (the top card is face up).
•12 reserve piles (left, top, right) - each pile contains cards of the same rank, starting from Twos in the lower left around to Kings on the lower right.  The top card of each pile is available for play on the foundations.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•After the tableau piles are dealt, the remainder of the cards are dealt to 12 reserve piles, one for of each of the ranks from Two to King.  The number of cards in each of these reserve piles will vary depending on how many cards of that rank remain after the tableau piles are dealt.  The top card of each Reserve pile is available for play on the Foundations.
•Play consists entirely of moving cards to the foundations.

Tips

•Since the cards in the reserve are always available, you should play to remove as many cards from the tableau piles as possible.

History

Lady of the Manor is also known as La Chatelaine.  The game Archway is an open version of this game.

Similar Games

Archway

Lady Palk

Lady Palk

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (30%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Groups of cards in sequence down regardless of suit can be moved as a unit.  Spaces are filled by Kings or any legal group of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (bottom left) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste pile by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Lady Palk is a variation of Diplomat and Forty Thieves.

Similar Games

Diplomat

Congress

Octave

Forty Thieves

Lafayette

Lafayette

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (40%)  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top) - on the left 4 piles build up in suit from Aces, on the right 4 piles build down in suit in suit from Kings.  It does not matter where the two piles of the same suit meet.
•4 tableau piles (below foundations, right) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces are filled from the reserve if possible, then only by Sevens.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (left, face down) - turn over 3 cards at a time, by clicking.  Unlimited redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card always available for play on the tableau or foundations.
•reserve (left of tableau) - Top card always available for play on the tableau or foundations.  At the start of the game 13 cards are dealt here.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Lafayette is a variation of Canfield.

Similar Games

Gilbert

Canfield

Bisley

Lake Towers

Lake Towers

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (80%).  All Skill.

Object

To group all the cards into 4 sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace within the tableau.

Layout

•4 cells (top center) - storage location for one card.   Only 1 card allowed in each cell.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the center two cells.
•10 tableau piles (below cells) - build down in suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit and if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.   Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt face up to each pile.

 

Options

AutoPlay

History

Lake Towers is Sea Towers with no foundations.

Similar Games

Sea Towers

Scorpion Towers

Sea Scorpion

Lake Victoria

Lake Victoria

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (75%).  Skill/Luck Balanced.

Object

To pair up all the cards in the deck in pairs of cards whose ranks total to 13.

Layout

•7 tableau piles - Discard pairs of cards whose ranks add to 13.  Kings are discarded singly.  To discard a pair, drop one card on the other, or right-click on one of the cards.   At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) -  turn over cards one to each waste pile by clicking.  No redeals.
•3 waste piles (below stock) - The top card is available for play. Discard pairs of cards whose ranks add to 13.  Kings are discarded singly.

Notes

•Any pair of cards whose values add to 13 can be discarded.  The valid pairs are Queen-Ace, Jack-Two, 10-3, 9-4, 8-5, 7-6.  Kings are discarded singly.  To discards Kings, simply click on them.

History

Lake Victoria is variation of Nile.

Similar Games

Nile

Five Stacks

Thirteens

Five Piles

Pyramid

Triangle

Lancaster

Lancaster

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (10%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards in sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace.

Layout

•12 tableau piles - build down regardless of suit, wrapping from Ace to King as necessary.  Groups of cards in sequence down in suit may be moved as a unit.  A space can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 8 cards are dealt face up to each pile, then 1 more card is dealt face up to the middle 8 piles.

Notes

•Whenever a sequence of 13 cards down in suit from King to Ace is formed, it will automatically be removed from play.

Tips

•Same suit sequences should be preferred even though building is down regardless of suit.  The object is to build down in suit sequences.
•Spaces should be made as soon as possible, and used to move cards into groups by suit.

History

Lancaster is an open version of Spider.

Similar Games

Spider

Mrs Mop

Lanes

Lanes

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (55%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.  At the start of the game the Aces are dealt here.
•6 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Only one card at a time may be moved. Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  One redeal.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Lanes is a standard solitaire game, much like Thirty-Six.  Lanes dates back to at least the early 1900s.

Similar Games

Thirty-Six

Ladies Battle

The Bold

Lasker

Lasker

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (40%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from the rank of the first card moved to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build up or down by suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence up or down by suit.  Spaces may be filled by any available card.  At the start of the game 6 cards each are dealt to the first 2 piles, 5 cards each to the remaining piles.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•To begin the game, choose a card to move to the first foundation pile (far left at top).  All the other foundation piles will then begin with the same rank as this card.

History

Lasker is a variation of Chessboard.

Similar Games

Chessboard

Fortress

Last Chance

Last Chance

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (85%).  Skill/luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 waste piles (below foundations) - cards are played here from the stock.  The top card of each pile is available for play on the foundations or an empty waste pile.  Empty waste piles can be filled from the stock or the top card of another waste pile.  At the start of the game one card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (far left of foundations) - Top card is available for play on the waste piles or foundations.  No redeals.
•1 reserve pile (face down between stock and foundations) - when the stock is empty, click on this card to turn it face up.  It is available for play on the foundations.

Notes

Play consists of moving cards from the stock to the waste piles and foundations.  A card from the stock can be played on any waste pile, but once placed on a waste pile a card can only be moved to the foundations or an empty waste pile.  Avoid playing higher cards on a waste pile which already has lower cards of the same suit, as that can block the game.  When the stock is empty, click on the face down reserve card.  This card represents the last chance for victory, as if this card does not allow you to move all the cards to the foundations the game is lost.

History

Last Chance is a variation of Lady Betty.

Similar Games

Lady Betty

Sir Tommy

Strategy

Layers

Layers

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks (with the 2's thru 6's removed).  Medium (30%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace, then Sevens to Kings.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  A space may be filled by any available card.   At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) -  Clicking deals 1 card to each tableau pile.

Similar Games

Strata

Junction

Leap Year

Leap Year

 Top  Previous  Next

4 Decks.  Hard (2%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•16 foundation piles (left, top, right) - build up regardless of suit from Ace to King.  At the start of the game the Aces are dealt here.
•8 reserve piles (between and below foundations) - cards are dealt here from the stock.  The top card of each pile is available for play.  Move cards to the foundations by clicking.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (face down) - deal 1 card to each reserve pile by clicking.  No redeals.

History

Leap Year is a 4 deck version of Auld Lang Syne.

Similar Games

Auld Lang Syne

Acquaintance

Tam O'Shanter

Quadrennial

Left Side Story

Left Side Story

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Easy (80%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) -   build down by alternate color.   Groups of cards can be moved if they are in sequence down by alternate color. Spaces are filled automatically by the face up card or group of cards in the pile immediately to the right of the open space.  The rightmost pile, if empty, may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile, 3 face down and 1 face up.
•stock (top left) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste pile by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

 

Options

AutoPlay

 

History

Left Side Story is a variation of Rank and File with the space filling rules of Moving Left.

Similar Games

Rank and File

Moving Left

Emperor

Number Ten

Forty Thieves

Leicester

Leicester

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks. Medium (15%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•9 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Groups of cards may be moved if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Fill spaces with any card or group of cards.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to the first pile, 2 to the 2nd, and so on.
•stock (top left, face down) - deal one card to each tableau pile, by clicking.  No redeals.

History

Leicester is a variation of Carlton.

Similar Games

Carlton

Old Carlton

Leprechaun

Leprechaun

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (10%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.

 

•18 fans (below foundations) -  build down by alternate color, wrapping from Ace to King as necessary, with a limit of 3 cards per fan.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  In the first 2 rows spaces are not filled.  In the bottom row, spaces may be filled by any card. At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt face up to each pile, except the last row, which is dealt two cards per pile.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Leprechaun is a Fan type game with some similarities to Shamrocks.

Similar Games

Shamrocks

La Belle Lucie

Lucky Fan

Letter H

Letter H

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (60%).  Skill/Luck Balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•13 foundation piles (in the form of a letter H) - build up regardless of suit from the first card until each pile contains 8 cards, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary.  At the start of the game one card of each rank is dealt to these piles.
•stock (top middle) - Top card available for play on the foundations or waste piles.  No redeals.
•2 waste piles (below stock) - top card available for play on the foundations.  Cards that cannot be played to the foundations are played here from the stock.

Options

AutoPlay

Similar Games

Contradance

Light and Shade

Light and Shade

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Easy (50%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up by alternate color from the Aces to Kings.  At the start of the game the Aces are dealt here.
•4 tableau piles (below foundations, on right) - build down by alternate color.  Groups of cards can be moved if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces are filled only by a card from a cell.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (below foundations on left, face down) - turn over 1 card to waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.
•4 cells (below stock and waste) - storage locations for cards. Spaces are automatically filled from the waste (or stock if empty). Only 1 card allowed in each cell.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Notice that the foundations are built up by alternate color, an unusual method of foundation building.

 

History

Light and Shade is a variation of Red and Black.

Similar Games

Red and Black

Lily

Lily

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (10%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards in sets of 13 cards in sequence down by alternate color from King to Ace.

Layout

•13 tableau piles - build down by alternate color.  Groups of cards in sequence down by alternate color may be moved as a unit.   Spaces can be filled only with a King or group of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile, alternating face up and face down.
•stock (bottom center) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.  No redeals.

 

Notes

•Whenever a sequence of 13 cards down by alternate color from King to Ace is formed, it will automatically be removed from play.

 

History

Lily is a variation of Trillium.

Similar Games

Trillium

Curds and Whey

Limestone

Limestone

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (80%)  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up regardless of suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.   At the start of the game a card is dealt to each pile.
•4 cells (top left) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.  The card is available for play on the foundations only.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations and cells) - No building is allowed.  The top card is available for play on the foundations or cells.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are not filled.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt to each pile.

Notes

•The first card of each foundation pile is offset so you can tell when each pile is full.  The pile is full when it contains 13 cards, which will be when the top card is one rank lower than the offset bottom card.

Tips

•Try to keep as many cells empty as possible.

History

Limestone is an easier variation of Stalactites.

Similar Games

Stalactites

Stalagmites

Limited

Limited

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (65%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•12 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Only one card at a time can be moved.  Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Limited is a variation of Forty Thieves.

Lincoln Greens

Lincoln Greens

 Top  Previous  Next

4 Decks.  Easy (90%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the waste pile.

Layout

•12 tableau piles (across top) - no building.  Top card of each pile is available for play on the waste pile.  At the start of the game 12 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (face down below tableau) - turn over 1 card to the waste by clicking.

 

•waste (next to stock) - build up or down regardless of suit, wrapping from Ace to King or King to Ace as necessary.

 

Notes

•Play cards from the tableau to the waste if possible.  Whenever there are no possible plays, turn over a card in the stock by clicking on it.  This card goes to the waste pile.

History

Lincoln Greens is a four deck version of Putt Putt.

Similar Games

Golf

Putt Putt

Panther Creek

Double Golf

Links

Links

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (5%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To pair up all the cards in the deck in pairs of cards whose ranks total to 13.

Layout

•7 tableau piles (across top) - no building.  Discard pairs of cards whose ranks add to 13.  Kings are discarded singly.  To discard a pair, drop one card on the other, or right-click on one of the cards.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt face up to each pile, except for the first and last pile, which are dealt only 4 cards.
•stock (face down below tableau) - turn over 1 card to the waste by clicking.

 

•waste (next to stock) - The top card is available for pairing.

 

History

Links has a method of play like Pyramid with an initial tableau similar to Golf.  It was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Pyramid

Golf

Verge

Linus

Linus

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (50%).  Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•18 fans (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are not filled.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt face up to each pile (except for the last pile, which just has 1 card).
•stock (upper left, no cards) -  There are two redeals.  After all possible plays have been made, redeal by clicking on the green arrow in the upper left corner.  All the cards in the fans are reshuffled. The foundations remain.  2 redeals.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•There are two ways to move cards between fans, depending on the settings under Rules in the Options menu.  If Drag and Drop is set, the cards are dragged with the mouse.  If Click is set, clicking on a card in a fan automatically moves it to the one other fan that it can move to.

History

Linus is a variation of La Belle Lucie.

Similar Games

La Belle Lucie

Three Shuffles and a Draw

Fan

Little Billie

Little Billie

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Easy (95%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build left 4 piles up in suit from Ace to King, right 4 piles down in suit from Kings to Aces.
•24 Fans (below foundations) - top card is available for play on the foundations or reserves.  No building on the fans.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile.
•8 reserve piles (bottom) - each pile may hold one card from the fans. Cards from the reserves may be played to the foundations (but not to the fans).  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (upper left, no cards) -  There are two redeals.  After all possible plays have been made, redeal by clicking on the green arrow in the upper left corner.  All the cards in the fans are reshuffled. The foundations remain.  2 redeals.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Play in the game consists of moving cards to the foundations, putting cards in the reserves in order to get at blocked cards in the fans.

History

This game was described in a book by Mary Whitmore Jones circa 1900.

Similar Games

Buffalo Bill

Little Forty

Little Forty

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Very Easy (97%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Groups of cards can be moved if they are in sequence down by suit.  Spaces filled from the stock or waste only, unless both are empty in which case spaces may be filled by any available card.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left) - turn over 3 cards at a time to the waste pile by clicking.  3 redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Little Forty is a variation of Forty Thieves.

Similar Games

Forty Thieves

Little Gate

Little Gate

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (25%).  Skill/luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•4 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Groups of cards may be moved.  Empty piles are filled from the reserves (or from the waste when the reserves are empty).  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•2 reserve piles (left and right of tableau) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left) - move 1 card to waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (beside stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Similar Games

Objective

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•6 tableau piles (below foundations) -   Build down by alternate color.  Groups of cards can be moved if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left) - Deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.  No redeals.

Little Milligan

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (15%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Groups of cards may be moved if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Empty piles can be filled by a King or a legal group of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top, face down on left) - deals one card to each tableau pile by clicking.  No redeals.

Little Napoleon

Little Napoleon

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Easy (86%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit. Groups of cards may be moved if they form a sequence down in suit.  Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile, 3 face down, 1 face up.
•stock (bottom left) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste pile by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Little Napoleon is a variation of Forty Thieves.

Similar Games

McClellan

Forty Thieves

Little Picture Gallery

Little Picture Gallery

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Easy (99%).  Skill/luck balanced

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (left) - build left 4 piles down regardless of suit from Queens, build right 4 piles up regardless of suit from Aces.
•4 tableau piles (right) - At the start of the game a King is dealt to the first pile.  Cards are dealt on the first pile until another King appears The next King is placed to begin the next tableau pile and cards are dealt upon it until another King appears, and the process repeats until all the Kings appear and all cards are dealt.  Build up or down regardless of suit.  Any card can be played on a King.

Notes

In order to get all the cards to the foundations, first build the Aces up and the Queens down until they meet, then transfer all the cards onto the Ace piles.  When the Queen is transferred, you can then play a King to the pile to complete it.

Little Spider

Little Spider

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Hard (2%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (middle) - build left two piles up in suit from Ace to King, right two piles down in suit from King to Ace.  See Notes for restrictions on building.
•8 tableau piles (above and below foundations) - build up or down regardless of suit, wrapping from Ace to King or King to Ace as necessary.  Spaces are not filled.  Building on the tableau is allowed only after the initial deal of the stock is complete.
•stock (left, face down) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.

Notes

•At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each tableau pile.  After each set of 8 cards, 2 Aces of one color and 2 Kings of the other color are placed on the foundations as they become available.  Any cards dealt to the top row of the tableau that can be built to the foundations may be placed on the foundations.  Any card dealt to the bottom row of the tableau that can be built on a foundation pile directly above it may be placed there.   After the deal, the top card of each tableau pile is available for play on any foundation pile or any other tableau pile.

History

Despite its name, this game has no similarity to Spider.

Little Thieves

Little Thieves

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Hard (1%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (left side) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•5 tableau piles (right) - build down in suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved. Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile.
•stock (top, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (below stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Little Thieves is a one deck version of Forty Thieves.

Similar Games

Forty Thieves

Sixty Thieves

Long Tail

Long Tail

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (40%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards in sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace.

Layout

•5 tableau piles - build down regardless of suit.  Groups of cards in sequence down in suit may be moved as a unit.  A space can be filled by any card or legal group of cards. At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.

 

•stock (top left) - Clicking deals 1 card to each tableau pile.
•reserve (the long tail, far right) - storage for cards or sequence of cards. Any number of cards can be played here, but only the top card or sequence is available for play on the foundations or tableau. At the start of the game 2 cards are dealt here.

Notes

•Whenever a sequence of 13 cards down in suit from King to Ace is formed in the tableau, it will automatically be removed from play.

History

Long Tail is a variation of Spiderette.

 

Similar Games

Spiderette

Spider

Loopy

Loopy

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (50%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Groups of cards in sequence down by alternate color may be moved.  Spaces may be filled by any card or a legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (bottom, face down on left) - move 1 card at a time to waste by clicking.  1 redeal.
•waste (beside stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Loopy is a variation of Red Hand and Twister.

Similar Games

Red Hand

Twister

Eight by Eight

Lower 48

Lower 48

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Easy (80%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces may be filled with any card.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt to each of the 8 piles.
•stock (bottom left, face down) - turn over cards 1 at a time to the waste by clicking.  One redeal.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Lower 48 is a variation of Forty and Eight.

Similar Games

Forty and Eight

Eight by Five

Lucas

Lucas

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Easy (97%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (left) - build up in suit from Ace to King.  At the start of the game the Aces are dealt here.
•13 tableau piles (to the right of the foundations) - build down in suit. Groups of cards in sequence down in suit may be moved as a unit.  Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Lucas is a variation of Forty Thieves and is very similar to Waning Moon.

Similar Games

Waning Moon

Limited

Forty Thieves

Shining Star

Old Moon

Luckier Thirteen

Luckier Thirteen

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (25%).  Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•13 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces may be filled by any available card.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt face up to each pile.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Luckier Thirteen is also known as "Thirteen by Zero".  It is a variation of FreeCell with 13 piles and no cells.

Similar Games

FreeCell

Lucky Thirteen

Lucky Eight

Lucky Eight

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks. Hard (15%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top,bottom,left,right) - build the Aces up in suit to King.  At the start of the game the Aces are dealt here.
•4 fans (in the corners) - build down in suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are filled from the waste.  At the start of the game 8 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (face down, middle) - turn over 1 card to the waste by clicking.  2 redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card is available for play on the foundations or fans.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Lucky Eight is a harder version of Octagon.

Similar Games

Octagon

Single Rail

Lucky Fan

Lucky Fan

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (25%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•2 cells (top left) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.  Card is available for play on the foundations or fans.
•18 fans (below foundations) - build down in suit, with a limit of 3 cards per fan.  Only one card at a time may be moved to the foundations or another fan.  Spaces are filled only by Kings.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt face up to each pile (the last 2 piles only have 2 cards).

Options

AutoPlay

History

Lucky Fan is a variation of Free Fan and Shamrocks.

Similar Games

Free Fan

Fan

La Belle Lucie

Shamrocks

Lucky Piles

Lucky Piles

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (90%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (bottom) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•13 tableau piles - build up or down regardless of suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces can be filled only with a King.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Lucky Piles is a variation of Lucky Thirteen suggested by a player.

Similar Games

Lucky Thirteen

Cruel

Lucky Thirteen

Lucky Thirteen

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Hard (1%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•13 tableau piles (center) - build down regardless of suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are not filled.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile.

Options

AutoPlay

Similar Games

Cruel

Lucky Piles

Luckier Thirteen

Lyre

Lyre

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (60%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.   Spaces are filled by a King or a group of cards headed with a King.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 to the 2nd, and so on.  All cards are face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Lyre is a variation of Big Harp.

Similar Games

Big Harp

Harp

Endless Harp

Madame

Madame

 Top  Previous  Next

3 Decks.  Medium (50%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•12 foundation piles (left and top) - build up by alternate color from the rank of first card moved to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Only the top card of each pile may be moved.  Spaces are filled automatically from the waste, or stock if the waste is empty.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•reserve (directly below foundations) - top card is available for play on the foundations only. At the start of the game 15 cards are dealt here.
•stock (middle left, face down) - turn over cards 1 at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•The game begins by choosing a card to move to the first foundation pile.  The rank of this card becomes the base card for all the other

foundation piles.  This first move is very important.

History

Madame is a 3 deck version of Signora.

Similar Games

Signora

Empress of Italy

Roman Patience

Blondes and Brunettes

Terrace

Magnum

Magnum

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (30%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•11 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Only one card at a time may be moved. Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile.
•stock (bottom left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Tips

•Try to get a space in the tableau as quickly as possible.

History

Magnum is a slightly easier variation of Forty Four Thieves.

Similar Games

Forty Four Thieves

Forty Thieves

Cadran

Robespierre

Forty Eight Thieves

Malmaison

Malmaison

 Top  Previous  Next

4 Decks.  Hard (10%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•16 foundation piles (across top, left, right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.   Groups of cards can be moved if they are in sequence down in suit.  Spaces filled by any card.  At the start of the game 8 cards are dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Malmaison is a 4 deck variation of Josephine invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Josephine

Marie Rose

Eighty Thieves

Rueil

Bonmaison

Mamy Susan

Mamy Susan

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (20%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.
•reserve (bottom) - top card may be played only to the foundations.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt to this pile (the top card is face up)

Options

AutoPlay

History

Mamy Susan is a variation of the classic game Forty Thieves.  Its origin is unknown, but it is played in France.  It was sent to Pretty Good Solitaire by Francois Jammes of France.

Similar Games

Forty Thieves

Maria

Maria

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (4%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•9 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Only the top card of each pile may be moved.  Spaces filled by any card.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste pile by clicking.   No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

 

Options

AutoPlay

History

Maria (also sometimes known as Maria Luisa) is closely related to Midshipman.

Similar Games

Midshipman

Forty Thieves

Bandit

Marie Rose

Marie Rose

 Top  Previous  Next

3 Decks.  Hard (20%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•12 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•12 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.   Groups of cards can be moved if they are in sequence down in suit.  Spaces filled by any card.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste pile by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

 

History

Marie Rose is a 3 deck version of Josephine.

Similar Games
