Napoleon

Napoleon

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (50%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (center) - build up in suit or down in suit from the rank of first card dealt to each pile, wrapping from King to Ace or Ace to King as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.  At the start of the game 4 cards of a random rank are dealt here.  The first card played to any of these piles determines whether building is up in suit or down in suit.  Once the direction of building has been established all 4 piles are built in the same direction and it cannot be changed.
•8 tableau piles (left and right in 4 rows) - build up or down in suit.  Top card is available for play on the foundations, tableau, or cells.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are filled by any available card.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•2 reserves (left and right, bottom row) - top card is available for play on the foundations, tableau, or cells.  No building, empty spaces cannot be filled.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•2 cells (center bottom, below foundations) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.  The card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Similar Games

Kleine Napoleon

Napoleon's Folly

Napoleon's Folly

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (70%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in any suit but the same.  Only one card at a time can be moved.  Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Napoleon's Folly is a variation of Forty Thieves.

Similar Games

Forty Thieves

Streets

Indian

Napoleon's Square

Napoleon's Square

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Easy (77%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•12 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit. Groups of cards in sequence down in suit may be moved as a unit. Spaces can be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (face down, top left) - move one card to waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (beside stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Napoleon's Square is a variation of Forty Thieves.  See also Carre Napoleon for a more challenging version.

Similar Games

Carre Napoleon

Forty Thieves

Limited

Union Square

Nationale

Nationale

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (30%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (left and right) - on left piles build up in suit from Ace to King, on right piles build down in suit from King to Ace.
•12 tableau piles (middle) - build up or down by suit, wrapping from Ace to King or King to Ace as necessary.  Top card is available for play on the foundations or another tableau pile, only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are filled by any card.  At the start of the game 8 cards are dealt to each pile.  During the deal, as each card is dealt it is moved to the foundations if possible and not replaced.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•During the deal if a card can be played to the foundations, it is played there and not replaced.  Hence many of the foundations will already have several cards in them at the beginning of the game, and there will be varying numbers of cards in each tableau pile.

Similar Games

Capricieuse

Needle

Needle

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (90%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•reserve (top left) - storage locations for cards.  Only the top card is available for play. Limit of 18 cards.  Any card can be moved to the reserve.  At the start of the game 8 cards are dealt here.

 

•9 tableau piles (below foundations and reserve) - build down by alternate color. Only one card at a time can be moved.  Fill spaces with any card.  At the start of the game 8 cards are dealt face up to the 1st, 2nd, 8th and 9th piles, 4 cards are dealt face up to the 3rd and 7th piles, and 2 cards are dealt face up to the 4th and 6th piles.  The 5th pile is left empty.

Options

AutoPlay

Similar Games

Haystack

Pitchfork

FreeCell

Baker's Dozen

Neptune

Neptune

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck. Medium (30%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To pair cards until the stock is empty.

Layout

•8 tableau piles (center) - Pair up cards of consecutive rank.  Ace and King are not consecutive.  Cards are immediately replaced from the stock.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top) - cards automatically replaced removed pairs in the tableau.

Notes

•Pair cards of consecutive ranks, such as Aces with Twos, Queens with Kings, Jacks with Queens, and so on.  Removed pairs are replaced with two new cards from the stock.  The game is won when the stock is empty.  Note that Aces can only be paired with Twos, Kings can only be paired with Queens, but all other cards can be paired with ranks either one higher or one lower.

Similar Games

Triton

Nestor

Nestor

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (18%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To pair up all the cards and move them to the waste pile.

Layout

•8 tableau piles (across top) - the top card is available for play.  Pair up cards of the same rank.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt face up to each pile.  The cards are dealt in such a way that no two cards of the same rank are dealt to the same pile.
•4 extra cards (below tableau) - each card is available for play to be paired with cards in the tableau.
•waste pile - Where paired cards go out of play.

History

Nestor is a simple game to play, but it is not necessarily simple to win.

Similar Games

Doublets

Vertical

Heracles

Double Vertical

Double Nestor

Alcides

New York

New York

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks. Medium (45%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces may be filled only from the stock or a waste pile.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left, face up) - top card is available for play on the foundations, tableau, or waste piles.  No redeals.
•3 waste piles (below stock) - discard piles, cards are moved here from the stock only.  Top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

New York is a two deck relative of Bristol.

Similar Games

Bristol

Dover

Big Apple

Gotham

Night Golf

Night Golf

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.   Hard (2%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the waste pile.

Layout

•7 tableau piles (across top) - no building.  Top card of each pile is available for play on the waste pile.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt to each pile, only the top card is face up.
•stock (face down below tableau) - turn over 1 card to the waste by clicking.

 

•waste (next to stock) - build up or down in sequence regardless of suit.  No wraparound, only Twos can be played on Aces and nothing can be played on a King.

 

Notes

•Play cards from the tableau to the waste if possible.  Whenever there are no possible plays, turn over a card in the stock by clicking on it.  This card goes to the waste pile.

Tips

•Work out your sequences in advance.  Be careful to save queens for kings, and twos for aces.

History

NIght Golf is a version of Golf with only the top card of each tableau pile face up.

Similar Games

Golf

Nile

Nile

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (80%).  Skill/Luck Balanced.

Object

To pair up all the cards in the deck in pairs of cards whose ranks total to 13.

Layout

•7 tableau piles - Discard pairs of cards whose ranks add to 13.  Kings are discarded singly.  To discard a pair, drop one card on the other, or right-click on one of the cards.   At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt face up to each pile, except for the first and last piles, which are dealt only 4 cards.
•stock (top left, face down) -  turn over cards one to each waste pile by clicking.  No redeals.
•2 waste piles (below stock) - The top card is available for play. Discard pairs of cards whose ranks add to 13.  Kings are discarded singly.

Notes

•Any pair of cards whose values add to 13 can be discarded.  The valid pairs are Queen-Ace, Jack-Two, 10-3, 9-4, 8-5, 7-6.  Kings are discarded singly.  To discards Kings, simply click on them.

History

Nile is a game of addition to 13 invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Lake Victoria

Five Stacks

Thirteens

Five Piles

Pyramid

Triangle

Nine by Five

Nine by Five

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (99%).  Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•5 cells (top left) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.

 

•9 tableau piles (below foundations and cells) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color and if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.  Spaces can be filled by any card or legal group of cards (see KingOnly for option).  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt face up to the leftmost 7 piles, 5 cards are dealt face up to the remaining piles.

Options

KingOnly AutoPlay

Notes

•Groups of cards in the tableau can only be moved as a group if there are a sufficient number of empty cells available to store the cards individually.  The ability to move cards as a group is only a shortcut to moving the group one card at a time.

Tips

•Try to keep as many cells empty as possible.

History

Nine by Five is FreeCell with nine tableau piles instead of eight, and five cells instead of 4.

Similar Games

FreeCell

Nine by Two

Nine by Four

Nine by Four

Nine by Four

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (99%).  Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•4 cells (top left) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.

 

•9 tableau piles (below foundations and cells) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color and if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.  Spaces can be filled by any card or legal group of cards (see KingOnly for option).  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt face up to the leftmost 7 piles, 5 cards are dealt face up to the remaining piles.

Options

KingOnly AutoPlay

Notes

•Groups of cards in the tableau can only be moved as a group if there are a sufficient number of empty cells available to store the cards individually.  The ability to move cards as a group is only a shortcut to moving the group one card at a time.

Tips

•Try to keep as many cells empty as possible.

History

Nine by Four is FreeCell with nine tableau piles instead of eight.

Similar Games

FreeCell

Nine by Two

Nine by Five

Nine by Two

Nine by Two

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (95%).  Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•2 cells (top left) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.

 

•9 tableau piles (below foundations and cells) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color and if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.  Spaces can be filled by any card or legal group of cards (see KingOnly for option).  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt face up to the leftmost 7 piles, 5 cards are dealt face up to the remaining piles.

Options

KingOnly AutoPlay

Notes

•Groups of cards in the tableau can only be moved as a group if there are a sufficient number of empty cells available to store the cards individually.  The ability to move cards as a group is only a shortcut to moving the group one card at a time.

Tips

•Try to keep as many cells empty as possible.

History

Nine by Two is FreeCell with nine tableau piles instead of eight, and two cells instead of 4.

Similar Games

FreeCell

Nine by Four

Nine by Five

Nine to Five

Nine to Five

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (50%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•9 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved. Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  One redeal.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Tips

•Try to get a space in the tableau as quickly as possible.

History

Nine to Five is a variation of Forty Thieves.

Similar Games

Forty Thieves

Cloud Nine

Nines

Nines

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Hard (5%).  All Luck.

Object

To discard all the cards.

Layout

•9 tableau piles - the top card is available for play.  Discard pairs of cards that have ranks that add to 9 (8-A, 7-2, 6-3, 5-4). Tens, Jacks, Queens, and Kings are discarded as a set (10-J-Q-K).  Nines are discarded singly.  Spaces are automatically filled from the stock.   To discard a set of cards, move each card to the reserve pile in the lower left.  When a 10-J-Q-K set is formed, or when cards of rank 8 or under add to 9, the cards are automatically discarded to the waste pile.   Pairs of cards that add to 9 can also be discarded by dropping one on the other.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (face down, left) - fills spaces in the tableau.
•waste (far right)  - Where paired cards go out of play.
•reserve (lower left) - where sets of cards are formed.

Valid Discards

•9, Ace-8, 2-7, 3-6, 4-5, 10-Jack-Queen-King

Similar Games

Block Ten

Elevens

Pyramid

Fourteen Out

Fifteens

Eighteens

Ninety-Nine

Ninety-Nine

 Top  Previous  Next

3 Decks.  Medium (10%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•12 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•11 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color. Groups of cards in sequence down by alternate color may be moved as a unit.  Spaces may be filled by any available card or group of cards.   At the start of the game 9 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (face down) - turn over cards one at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (below stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Ninety-Nine is a 3 deck version of Forty-Nine.

Similar Games

Forty-Nine

Interchange

Normandy

Normandy

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (30%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•8 tableau piles (under foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces may be filled by a King or any group of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt to each pile, only the top card is face up.
•stock (lower left, face down) - deals one card to each tableau pile by clicking.  No redeals.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Normandy is a Forty Thieves type game that is most similar to Rouen and Dieppe.

Similar Games

Rouen

Dieppe

Double Easthaven

Northwest Territory

Northwest Territory

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (50%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  If KingOnly is set, fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King, otherwise fill spaces with any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.  The top card is face up.
•reserve pile (left) - All cards available for play.  Click on card to move it to the bottom of the stack, then move to either the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 16 cards are dealt face up to this pile.

Options

AutoPlay   KingOnly

History

Northwest Territory is a cross between Klondike and Flower Garden.

Similar Games

Klondike

Flower Garden

Brigade

Stonewall

Klondike Territory

Number Ten

Number Ten

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (70%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.   Groups of cards may be moved if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces filled by any card.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile, 2 face down and 2 face up.
•stock (top left) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste pile by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Number Ten is one of the classic variations on Forty Thieves.  The differences are that 2 of the 4 cards in the original tableau are dealt face down, the tableau are built down by alternate color instead of down in suit, and groups of cards in sequence down by alternate color can be moved as a unit.

Similar Games

Forty Thieves

Rank and File

Downing Street

Numeration

Numeration

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (90%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build left 4 piles up in suit by ones, twos, threes or fours depending on the starting card of the pile.

 

1:  A 2 3 4 5 6 7 8 9 T J Q K

2:  2 4 6 8 T Q A 3 5 7 9 J K

3:  3 6 9 Q 2 5 8 J A 4 7 T K

  4:  4 8 Q 3 7 J 2 6 T A 5 9 K

For the right 4 piles, drop entire 13 card sequences built in the tableau on the the piles.  These sequences are built down in suit by ones, twos, threes or fours, whichever is set by the pile of the same suit on the left 4 piles.  If ♠'s are in the 2nd pile on the left and build by twos, for example, then a sequence of 13 ♠'s drop on the right must build down by twos.

•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit by ones, twos, threes or fours, wrapping as necessary.  Any card of the same suit that is 4 ranks or less lower can be played.  For example, on a 10 ♠  a 9,8,7, or 6 ♠ may be played.   Groups of cards in sequence down in suit may be moved as a unit if they are built down by the same sequence as that suit is built up in the foundations.  For example, if ♥'s are in the 3rd foundation pile and build by threes, then a group of ♥'s built down by threes can be moved as a unit, such as the Jack, 8, 5, 2, and Queen.  Spaces are filled by any card or legal groups of cards.  At the start of the game 8 cards are dealt to the first pile, 7 cards to the 2nd pile, and so on until 1 card is dealt to the 8th and 9th piles.  The 10th pile is left empty.  The top card of each pile is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.

Tips

•Keep in mind at all times that you are not only trying to build on the left 4 foundations, but also you must build 4 complete 13-card sequences in the tableau.

History

Numeration is a cross between Calculation and Rouge et Noir.  It is similar to Abacus, a game in the program Absolute Yukon invented by Randy Rasa.  Numeration was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Rouge et Noir

Calculation

Nunavut

Nunavut

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (95%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  When only one card remains in a tableau pile, the card becomes a "protected" card.  Protected cards may only be moved to a foundation and no cards may be played upon them.   Protected cards remain protected until the stock is empty, then they become available for play on other tableau piles, and other cards may be played upon them. Groups of cards may be moved regardless of any sequence.  Fill spaces with any card or group of cards.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd pile, and so on.
•stock (top left, face down) -Deal one card to each tableau pile, by clicking.  No redeals.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Nunavut is a variation of Queenie invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Queenie

Taj Mahal

Northwest Territory

Octagon

Octagon

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks. Medium (45%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top,bottom,left,right) - build the Aces up in suit to King.  At the start of the game the Aces are dealt here.
•4 fans (in the corners) - build down in suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are filled from the waste.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (face down, middle) - turn over 1 card to the waste by clicking.  3 redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card is available for play on the foundations or fans.

Options

AutoPlay

Similar Games

Single Rail

Lucky Eight

Octave

Octave

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks. Easy (80%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards of rank 10 or less to the foundations, and to have 8 piles consisting of 3 cards (King, Queen, Jack) down by alternate color in the tableau below the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top) - build the Aces up in suit to Tens.  At the start of the game the Aces are dealt here.
•8 tableau (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces can be filled by any card. At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (face down, bottom left) - turn over 1 card to the waste by clicking.  1 redeal.  When the stock is redealt, it is dealt out to 8 waste piles.  Each card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.  Spaces are filled automatically from the stock.  When no more moves can be played from these waste piles, clicking on the stock will turn over 1 card to the original waste pile.  If this card cannot be played the game is lost.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

Octave is unusual in that not all cards are played to the foundations.  Only Ace thru 10 are played up to the foundations, the King, Queen, and Jacks remain in the tableau.

Similar Games

Congress

Diplomat

Lady Palk

Wheatsheaf

Forty Thieves

Odd and Even

Odd and Even

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (7%).  All Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top) - build leftmost 4 piles up in suit by twos starting with Ace (Ace, 3,5,7,9,J,K,2,4,6,8,10,Q), build rightmost 4 piles up in suit by twos starting with Twos (2,4,6,8,10,Q,A,3,5,7,9,J,K).
•9 tableau piles (middle) - each pile can contain 1 card.  No building.  Spaces are filled from the waste (if empty, from the stock).  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (center left, face down) - turn over 1 card to waste by clicking.  One redeal.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Similar Games

Royal Cotillion

Old Arch

Old Arch

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (40%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards from the other tableau piles to the center Keystone pile.

Layout

•7 tableau piles (center) - no building, except on the center pile (called the "Keystone").  On the Keystone, build up or down by suit, or up or down by twos regardless of suit (a Two can be played on a King, an Ace can be played on a Queen, a vice versa).  Only one card at a time can be moved.  Spaces are not filled.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to the first and seventh piles, 3 cards are dealt to the second and sixth piles, 2 cards are dealt to the third and fifth piles, and once card is dealt to the center Keystone pile.  All cards are face up.

 

•stock (face down, top left) - Turn over cards one at a time to the waste pile.  No redeals.

 

•waste (beside stock) - The top card of the waste pile is available for play on the Keystone.

Notes

The game is won when all of the cards in the tableau are in the center Keystone pile.  There may be cards left over in the stock and waste piles, these cards do not matter.  The object is just to move all of the cards out of the other 6 tableau piles.

Old Calculation

Old Calculation

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (80%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (across top) - build first pile up regardless of suit by ones, second pile up regardless of suit by twos, third pile up regardless of suit by threes, and fourth pile up regardless of suit by fours.  See chart below.  At the start of the game an Ace, Two, Three, and Four are dealt.

1:  A 2 3 4 5 6 7 8 9 T J Q K

2:  2 4 6 8 T Q A 3 5 7 9 J K

3:  3 6 9 Q 2 5 8 J A 4 7 T K

  4:  4 8 Q 3 7 J 2 6 T A 5 9 K

•4 reserve piles (below foundations) - cards are played here from the stock.  The top card of each pile is available for play on the foundations or an empty reserve pile.  Move cards to the foundations by clicking.  Spaces can be filled by any available card.
•stock (face down) - Top card is available for play on the reserves or foundations.  No redeals.

History

Old Calculation is a slightly easier version of Calculation, allowing cards from other reserve piles to fill empty reserve piles.

Similar Games

Calculation

Sir Tommy

Betsy Ross

One234

Numeration

Calculation FreeCell

Calculation Klondike

Old Carlton

Old Carlton

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Very Easy (98%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards regardless of any sequence.  Fill spaces with any card or group of cards.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to the first pile, 2 to the 2nd, and so on.
•stock (bottom left, face down) - deal one card to each tableau pile, by clicking.  No redeals.

Similar Games

Carlton

McCarver

Old Fashioned

Old Fashioned

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (1%).  All Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - build up regardless of suit from Ace to King.  At the start of the game the Aces are dealt here.
•6 reserve piles (below foundations) - cards are dealt here from the stock.  The top card of each pile is available for play.  Move cards to the foundations by clicking.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (face down) - deal 1 card to each reserve pile by clicking.  No redeals.

History

Old Fashioned is an easier variation of Auld Lang Syne.

Similar Games

Auld Lang Syne

Acquaintance

Sir Tommy

Antique

Old Moon

Old Moon

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks. Medium (60%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (left) - build up in suit from Ace to King.  At the start of the game the Aces are dealt here.
•13 tableau piles (to the right of the foundations) -build down in any suit but the same.  Only the top card of each pile may be moved.  When a face down card is exposed in the tableau, the card is turned face up and becomes a "protected" card.  Protected cards may only be moved to a foundation and no cards may be played upon them.  When a protected card is moved to a foundation, the empty space will be filled from the stock with one face down card and two more face up (for as long as the stock contains the cards to do so).  Protected cards remain protected until the stock is empty, then they become available for play on other tableau piles, and other cards may be played upon them.  After the stock is empty, spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt to each pile, 1 face down and 2 face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Old Moon is a cross between Indian Patience and Lucas.

Similar Games

Indian Patience

Lucas

Waning Moon

Shining Star

One Cell

One Cell

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (10%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•1 cell (top left) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in the cell.

 

•8 tableau piles (below foundations and cell) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color and if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.  Spaces can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.   At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt face up to the leftmost 4 piles, 6 cards are dealt face up to the remaining piles.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Groups of cards in the tableau can only be moved as a group if there are a sufficient number of empty cells available to store the cards individually (meaning if the cell is empty, you can move 2 cards) .  The ability to move cards as a group is only a shortcut to moving the group one card at a time.
•The game number deals #1 to #1000000 are compatible with the games in the standard Windows FreeCell.  For more information about FreeCell type games, see http://www.freecell.org.

Tips

•Try to keep the cell as empty as possible.

History

One Cell is FreeCell with only 1 cell.

Similar Games

FreeCell

Three Cells

Two Cells

One234

One234

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Hard (<1%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (across top) - build first pile up by ones from the starting card dealt (for example: 4, 5, 6, etc), second pile up by twos from the starting card dealt (for example: 3, 5, 7, etc.), third pile up by threes from the starting card dealt (for example: 5, 8, J, etc.), and fourth pile up by fours from the starting card dealt (for example: 7, J, etc.). All building is regardless of suit, until the pile contains 13 cards.  The starting card for each pile will vary based on the 4 cards dealt at the start of the game.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) -   The top card of each pile is available for play.  Move cards to the foundations by clicking.  There is no building on the tableau.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt face up to each pile.

History

One234 is related to Calculation.

Similar Games

Calculation

Betsy Ross

Open Doublets

Open Doublets

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (35%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To discard all the cards in pairs of the same rank.

Layout

•12 tableau piles  - discard pairs of cards of the same rank.   The top card of each pile is available.  Spaces are automatically filled from the reserve.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•reserve (far right, face down) - Used to fill spaces in the tableau.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt face up to this pile.

History

Open Doublets is an open (all cards face up) version of Doublets.

Similar Games

Doublets

Nestor

Vertical

Open Peek

Open Peek

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Hard (1%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (center) - build each foundation in suit, regardless of order.  On the top foundation, any card of the same suit as the first card dealt may be played.  On the lower foundations, start with a card of the same rank as the first card dealt, then play any card of that suit where a card of the same rank has already been played to the foundation immediately above.
•4 left reserve piles (left of foundations) - top card is available for play on the foundations.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•8 right reserve piles (right of foundations) - top card is available for play on the foundations.  No building.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt face up to three piles, 4 cards are dealt face up to the remaining piles.

Notes

If any card of the same rank as the first foundation base card is dealt to any reserve pile below a card of the same suit, then the card of the same rank as the first foundation base card is moved to the top of the pile.  Otherwise the game would automatically be impossible to win.

History

Open Peek is played the same way as Peek or Osmosis, except that all cards are visible at the start of the game.

Similar Games

Peek

Osmosis

Open Peek Cell

Open Peek Cell

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Hard (3%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (center) - build each foundation in suit, regardless of order.  On the top foundation, any card of the same suit as the first card dealt may be played.  On the lower foundations, start with a card of the same rank as the first card dealt, then play any card of that suit where a card of the same rank has already been played to the foundation immediately above.
•4 left reserve piles (left of foundations) - top card is available for play on the foundations.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•8 right reserve piles (right of foundations) - top card is available for play on the foundations.  No building.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt face up to three piles, 4 cards are dealt face up to the remaining piles.
•1 cell (bottom) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.

 

Notes

If any card of the same rank as the first foundation base card is dealt to any reserve pile below a card of the same suit, then the card of the same rank as the first foundation base card is moved to the top of the pile.  Otherwise the game would automatically be impossible to win.

History

Open Peek Cell is a variation of Open Peek, with a cell added to make the game easier.

Similar Games

Open Peek

Peek

Osmosis

Opus

Opus

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (10%).  Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (right) - build up in suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.  At the start of the game the first 3 piles are dealt base cards of the same rank.
•5 cells (bottom) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.  The card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

 

•7 tableau piles - build down in suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit and if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.   Spaces can be filled only by cards one rank below the base card of the foundations (or Kings if foundations start with Aces).  At the start of the game the remaining base card of the foundations is always dealt first to the first pile, then 7 cards are dealt face up to each pile.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•You must free the remaining foundation base card buried in the first tableau pile in order to build the fourth foundation.

Tips

•Try to keep as many cells empty as possible.

History

Opus is a more challenging variation of Penguin.  It was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Penguin

Tuxedo

Eight Off

FreeCell

Emperor Penguin

Order Time

Order Time

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Easy (85%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To arrange all the cards in the form of a clock, with all the Queens in a pile at the top, then clockwise around Aces, Twos, up to Jacks, and Kings in the middle.

Layout

•13 tableau piles (the clock) - build in the same rank, or up or down by suit, wrapping from Ace to King or King to Ace as necessary. Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces may be filled only by a card of the same rank as the clock position of the pile (Queens for the top pile, Aces for the next, and so on, and Kings in the middle).  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile.

Notes

Play consists of re-ordering the cards to get each card into the pile that corresponds to its clock position.  Allowable building is up or down by suit (wrapping if necessary), or of the same rank.  For example, on the 5 ♥, the 6 ♥ , 4 ♥ , 5 ♦ , 5 ♣ , or  5 ♠  could be played.

History

This is an fully open variation of the game Clock.  It was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Clock

Orwell

Orwell

 Top  Previous  Next

3 Decks.  Medium (35%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•12 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•12 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color. Groups of cards may be moved if they are in sequence down by alternate color. Spaces may be filled by a King or any group of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt face up to each pile, for a total of 84 cards.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Orwell is a variation of Sixty Bandits.

Similar Games

Sixty Bandits

Sixty Thieves

Osmosis

Osmosis

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (32%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (center) - build each foundation in suit, regardless of order.  On the top foundation, any card of the same suit as the first card dealt may be played.  On the lower foundations, start with a card of the same rank as the first card dealt, then play any card of that suit where a card of the same rank has already been played to the foundation immediately above.
•4 reserve or tableau piles (left of foundations) - top card is available for play on the foundations.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile, the top card is face up.
•stock (face down, right) - Turn over cards one at a time to the waste pile.  Unlimited redeals.

 

•waste (below stock) - The top card of the waste pile is available for play on the foundations.

Notes

•Play consists entirely of playing cards to the foundations.
•For example, suppose the first card dealt to the first foundation is the 10 ♥.  Then any ♥ from the reserve or waste could be played to the first foundation pile.  Suppose you can play the Ace, Five, and King ♥.  The 3 foundations below must be founded with the other 3 Tens, as they become available.  Suppose the 10 ♠ is available.  It is played to start the second foundation.  Then only the Ace, Five, or King ♠ could be played to the second foundation, since these are the only ranks in the first foundation pile.  Suppose the Ace ♠ can be played to the Second foundation.  Then in the 3rd foundation, first a remaining Ten and then only the Ace of the same suit could be played.   The effect is that the ranks filter down through the foundations by "osmosis", hence the name of the game.

History

Osmosis is also sometimes called "Treasure Trove".

Similar Games

Osmosis Deal 3

Peek

Open Peek

Bridesmaids

Diffusion

Four by Five

Osmosis Deal 3

Osmosis Deal 3

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (20%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (center) - build each foundation in suit, regardless of order.  On the top foundation, any card of the same suit as the first card dealt may be played.  On the lower foundations, start with a card of the same rank as the first card dealt, then play any card of that suit where a card of the same rank has already been played to the foundation immediately above.
•4 reserve or tableau piles (left of foundations) - top card is available for play on the foundations.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile, the top card is face up.
•stock (face down, right) - Turn over cards three at a time to the waste pile.  Unlimited redeals.

 

•waste (below stock) - The top card of the waste pile is available for play on the foundations.

Notes

•Play consists entirely of playing cards to the foundations.
•For example, suppose the first card dealt to the first foundation is the 10 ♥.  Then any ♥ from the reserve or waste could be played to the first foundation pile.  Suppose you can play the Ace, Five, and King ♥.  The 3 foundations below must be founded with the other 3 Tens, as they become available.  Suppose the 10 ♠ is available.  It is played to start the second foundation.  Then only the Ace, Five, or King ♠ could be played to the second foundation, since these are the only ranks in the first foundation pile.  Suppose the Ace ♠ can be played to the Second foundation.  Then in the 3rd foundation, first a remaining Ten and then only the Ace of the same suit could be played.   The effect is that the ranks filter down through the foundations by "osmosis", hence the name of the game.

History

Osmosis Deal 3 is the game Osmosis with a 3 card draw.

Similar Games

Osmosis

Peek

Open Peek

Osmotic Cell

Osmotic Cell

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Easy (>99%).  Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.  On the first (leftmost) foundation pile, the next card of the same suit as the first card may be played.  On the next (to the right) foundations, only cards where a card of the same rank has already been played to the foundation immediately to the left may be played.  This means that an Ace cannot be played to the 2nd pile until an Ace is played to the 1st.  Similarly, a Four cannot be played to the 2nd pile until a Four is played to the 1st, and so on.
•4 cells (top left) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.

 

•8 tableau piles (below foundations and cells) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color and if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.  Spaces can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt face up to the leftmost 4 piles, 6 cards are dealt face up to the remaining piles.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Groups of cards in the tableau can only be moved as a group if there are a sufficient number of empty cells available to store the cards individually.  The ability to move cards as a group is only a shortcut to moving the group one card at a time.
•Foundation building is similar to the game Osmosis.  You can only play cards to a foundation pile if the pile immediately to the left has already been built up to that rank.  For example, suppose that the first foundation pile is played up to the 6 ♥.  Suppose the next pile has Spades.  The next pile can only then be played to the 6 ♠ until the 7 ♥ is played to the first pile, allowing the 7 ♠ to be played.  The effect is that the ranks filter down through the foundations by "osmosis".

History

Osmotic Cell is a cross between FreeCell and Osmosis.  It was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

FreeCell

Osmosis

Outback

Outback

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (10%).  Skill/Luck Balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - Build down in suit.  Groups of cards may be moved regardless of sequence. Spaces filled by Kings or groups of cards headed by a King. At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt to each pile.

 

•stock (top left) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste pile by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Outback is a 2 deck version of Australian Patience invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Australian Patience

Darwin

Ozymandias

Ozymandias

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (30%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•5 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down regardless of suit.  Spaces are filled from the reserve, or if the reserve is empty by any card. At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.
•reserve (left of tableau) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 13 cards are dealt here.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Ozymandias is a slightly easier version of Rainbow.

Similar Games

Rainbow

Canfield

Chameleon

Storehouse

Palace

Palace

 Top  Previous  Next

4 Decks.  Medium (30%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•16 foundation piles (left) - build up in suit from Ace to King.  At the start of the game the Aces are dealt here.
•18 tableau piles (right) - build down regardless of suit.  Groups of cards can be moved if they are in sequence down in suit.  Spaces may be filled by any available card.  At the start of the game 11 cards are dealt face up to the first 12 piles, and 10 cards are dealt to the remaining piles.

Options

AutoPlay

History

This is a 4 deck variation of Beleaguered Castle invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Pantagruel

Pantagruel

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (20%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•9 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Groups of cards in sequence down by alternate color may be moved as a unit.  Spaces can be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.  The top card is turned face up.
•stock (bottom left, face down) - turn over 1 card to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Pantagruel is a variation of Gargantua.  It is a more difficult game.

Similar Games

Gargantua

Double Klondike

Klondike

Panther Creek

Panther Creek

 Top  Previous  Next

4 Decks.  Hard (10%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the waste pile.

Layout

•12 tableau piles (across top) - no building.  Top card of each pile is available for play on the waste pile.  At the start of the game 12 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (face down below tableau) - turn over 1 card to the waste by clicking.

 

•waste (next to stock) - build up or down in sequence regardless of suit.  No wraparound, only Twos can be played on Aces and nothing can be played on a King.

 

Notes

•Play cards from the tableau to the waste if possible.  Whenever there are no possible plays, turn over a card in the stock by clicking on it.  This card goes to the waste pile.

Tips

•Work out your sequences in advance.  Be careful to save queens for kings, and twos for aces.

History

Panther Creek is a four deck version of Golf.

Similar Games

Golf

Lincoln Greens

Double Golf

Par 3

Parallels

Parallels

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (5%).  Skill/Luck Balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (left and right) - build the piles on the left up in suit from Ace to King, build the piles on the right down in suit from King to Ace.  An Ace or a King of each suit is dealt here at the start of the game.
•tableau piles (middle) - At the start of the game one card each is dealt to 10 piles.  There is no building within the tableau.  All cards in the top and bottom rows are available for play on the foundations.  Cards in the middle rows are available if there is no card immediately above or immediately below it (that is, there is at least one empty space either above or below the card).
•stock (top left, face down) - clicking fills empty spaces in the tableau.  If there are no empty spaces (all the rows are complete), then clicking deals another row of 10 cards to the bottom of the tableau.

 

 

Notes

•Play proceeds by moving any available cards to the foundations.  When there are no more moves, click on the stock to fill any empty spaces and make any new possible moves to the foundations.  When there are no more spaces and no more moves, clicking on the stock will deal another row of 10 cards to the bottom of the tableau.  Cards in the tableau are always available unless they are blocked by having another card both above and below.  These cards remained blocked until one of the cards either immediately above or below is moved.

 

•When the foundations piles of the same suit meet, is its allowable (and encouraged) to move cards from one foundation to the other.

Park and Ride

Park and Ride

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (30%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To create 4 sequences of 12 cards of the same suit, running from Twos to Kings.

Layout

•52 card spaces  - Fill in gaps (spaces) by moving the next highest ranking card in suit to the card to the left of the space into the space, or the next lower ranking card in suit to the card to the right of the space into the space.  Do this by clicking on the card to you want to move.  At the start of the game 13 cards each are dealt to 4 rows and the Aces are removed.   The object is to rearrange the cards so that each row contains a in-suit sequence starting with Two on the far left and going up to Kings.
•Shuffle (top) - When clicked, all cards that are not in suit sequence starting from a Two in the leftmost position of the pile will be picked up and moved randomly to another location (that is, once a card is in a position it needs to be in to win the game, it will remain there thru a shuffle).  Two shuffles are allowed.

Notes

•A gap (space) can be filled by moving the next higher card in suit to the card immediately to the left of the space into the space, or by moving the next lower card in suit to the card immediately to the right of the space into the space.  This is done simply by clicking on the card you want to move.   For example, if there is a 4 ♦ followed by a space, click on the 5 ♦ (wherever it may be) and it will be moved to the right of the 4.  Or if there is a 10 ♦ to the right of a space, click on the 9 ♦ to move it to the left of the 10.  Gaps (spaces) on the far left that have no card to the left can be replaced by Twos (of any suit).  When the card to the left of a gap is a King, and there is no card to the right of the gap (for instance, the end of the row is to the right), then no card may be played there.

History

Park and Ride is a variation of Free Parking.

Similar Games

Free Parking

Gaps

Spaces and Aces

Parliament

Parliament

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (50%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (in center box) - build up in suit from Ace to King.  At the start of the game, the Aces are dealt here.
•8 tableau piles (to left and right of foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Spaces are filled from the waste.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (upper left, face down) - 1 card at a time moved to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Tips

•Do not move cards to the foundations unnecessarily; they may be needed for lower cards in the tableau.

History

Parliament is a variation of Congress.

Similar Games

Congress

Wheatsheaf

Par 3

Par 3

 Top  Previous  Next

3 Decks.  Medium (20%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the waste pile.

Layout

•13 tableau piles (across top) - no building.  Top card of each pile is available for play on the waste pile.  At the start of the game 8 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (face down below tableau) - turn over 1 card to the waste by clicking.

 

•waste (next to stock) - build up or down in sequence regardless of suit.  No wraparound, only Twos can be played on Aces and nothing can be played on a King.

 

Notes

•Play cards from the tableau to the waste if possible.  Whenever there are no possible plays, turn over a card in the stock by clicking on it.  This card goes to the waste pile.

Tips

•Work out your sequences in advance.  Be careful to save queens for kings, and twos for aces.

History

Par 3 is a 3 deck variation of the classic game Golf.

Object

•6 tableau piles (across top) - Build down by alternate color.  Groups of cards may be moved if they form a sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces filled by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste pile by clicking.  No redeals.

•stock (top left, face down) - Deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.  No redeals.

Object

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•13 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Spaces may be filled only by Kings or a group of cards headed by a King.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - Deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.  No redeals.

Patient Pairs

Patient Pairs

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (50%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To discard all the cards in pairs of the same rank.

Layout

•13 tableau piles  - discard pairs of cards of the same rank by dropping one of the cards onto the other.   The top card of each pile is available.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile.

Patriarchs

Patriarchs

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (30%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (left and right) - build piles starting with Aces up in suit to Kings, build piles starting with Kings down in suit to Aces.  At the start of the game an Ace and a King of each suit are dealt here.
•9 tableau piles (middle) - each pile can contain 1 card.  No building.  Spaces are filled from the waste (if empty, from the stock).  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (center bottom, face down) - turn over 1 card to waste by clicking.  One redeal.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Similar Games

Payday

Payday

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (30%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (left and right) - on left piles build up in suit from Ace to King, on right piles build down in suit from King to Ace.
•15 tableau piles (middle) - build up or down by suit, no wrapping.  Top card is available for play on the foundations or another tableau pile, only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are filled by an Ace or a King.  At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt to each pile, except for the last pile, which is only dealt 6.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Payday is a more difficult version of Fifteen.

Similar Games

Peek

Peek

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (40%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (center) - build each foundation in suit, regardless of order.  On the top foundation, any card of the same suit as the first card dealt may be played.  On the lower foundations, start with a card of the same rank as the first card dealt, then play any card of that suit where a card of the same rank has already been played to the foundation immediately above.
•4 reserve or tableau piles (left of foundations) - top card is available for play on the foundations.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (face down, right) - Turn over cards one at a time to the waste pile.  Unlimited redeals.

 

•waste (below stock) - The top card of the waste pile is available for play on the foundations.

Notes

•Peek is played exactly in the same way as Osmosis.

History

Peek is a somewhat easier version of Osmosis.  The difference between the two games is that Peek allows you to "peek" at the covered cards in the reserve.

Similar Games

Osmosis

Bridesmaids

Open Peek

Osmosis Deal 3

Pelmanism

Pelmanism

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Easy (100%).  Skill.

Object

To discard all the cards in pairs of the same rank.

Layout

52 face down cards in 4 rows of 13  - click on a card to turn it face up.  When two cards are face up, they will then be turned face down.  Object is to turn two cards of the same rank face up (for example, 2 Aces).  When this happens, the cards are discarded.  The object is to discard all the pairs of the same rank until no cards are left in the layout.

Notes

•Pelmanism can be won every time.

History

Pelmanism is an old puzzle card game dating back at least to England in the 1930s.

Penelope's Web

Penelope's Web

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Hard (1%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (middle) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•8 tableau piles (around foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Only the top card of each pile is available for play.  Spaces may be filled only by Kings.  At the start of the game the first 4 piles are dealt 7 cards each face up, and the next 4 piles are dealt 6 cards each face up.

Options

AutoPlay

History

This is a variation of Streets and Alleys that is harder to win since the only Kings can be played to open spaces.

Similar Games

Streets and Alleys

Beleaguered Castle

Penguin

Penguin

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Easy (96%).  Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (right) - build up in suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.  At the start of the game the first 3 piles are dealt base cards of the same rank.
•7 cells or "flipper" piles (bottom) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.  The card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

 

•7 tableau piles - build down in suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit.  Spaces can be filled only by cards one rank below the base card of the foundations (or Kings if foundations start with Aces).  At the start of the game the remaining base card of the foundations is always dealt first to the first pile (this card is called the "beak"), then 7 cards are dealt face up to each pile.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•You must free the "beak" card in order to build the fourth foundation.

Tips

•Try to keep as many cells empty as possible.

History

Penguin was invented by David Parlett.

Similar Games

Emperor Penguin

Opus

Tuxedo

Eight Off

Eight On

FreeCell

Baker's Game

Sea Towers

ForeCell

Penta

Penta

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (50%).  Skill/luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (vertically on left and right) - 4 piles on the left build up in suit from Fives to King, wrapping to Ace up to Four.  4 piles on the right build down in suit from Fives to Aces, wrapping to King down to Six.  At the start of the game the Fives are dealt here.
•6 tableau piles (across top) - the first 3 piles (left of the line) build down regardless of suit, wrapping from Ace to King as necessary. The 2nd 3 piles (right of the line) build up regardless of suit, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Empty piles can be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (bottom, face down) - move 1 card to waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (beside stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Penta is the 5th game in the series Busy Aces, Deuces, Three's Company, and Fours Up.  Penta was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Busy Aces

Deuces

Three's Company

Fours Up

Sixes and Sevens

Eights Down

Cast Out Nines

Dimes

Jacks in the Box

Perpetual Motion

Perpetual Motion

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Easy (>99%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the waste pile.

Layout

•4 tableau piles (across top) - move cards of the same rank together in the same pile (moving cards from the right to the left).  Only the top card of each pile is available.  When all 4 cards of the same rank are dealt out on the 4 piles when the stock is clicked, they are moved to the waste pile by clicking on one of the cards.
•stock (face down to the right of the tableau) - deal one card to each tableau pile by clicking.

 

•waste pile - where cards go out of play.
•redeal button - After all 52 cards in the deck have been dealt out and moved (if possible), click on the ReDeal button.  This starts a complicated process that puts all the cards in the tableau once again back in the stock.  (note that the cards are not reshuffled, just picked up in a certain way).

Options

•The Rules option in the Options menu allows you to choose between drag and drop and clicking.  If clicking is set, instead of dragging the card you want to move, simply click on it.

Notes

•If any cards in the tableau have the same rank (such as, two of the cards are Jacks), the rightmost of the pair is moved on top of the leftmost (pick up the right card with the mouse and drop it on the left).    Once all possible pairs have been doubled up in this way, deal another row of 4 cards on top of the tableau by clicking on the face-down stock pile.

History

Perpetual Motion is a very simple game.  In fact, there is no strategy to it at all.  But totally mindless games have their uses.

Perseverance

Perseverance

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (96%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.  At the start of the game the Aces are dealt here.

 

•12 tableau piles (left of foundations) - build down in suit.  Groups of cards in sequence down in suit may be moved as a unit.  Spaces are not filled.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt face up to each pile.  Kings are immediately moved to the bottom of their piles.
•stock (top left, contains no cards)  - The cards remaining in the tableau are picked up and redealt by clicking.  2 redeals.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Perseverance is a variation of Baker's Dozen.

Similar Games

Baker's Dozen

Busy Aces

Persian Rug

Persian Rug

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks. Medium (50%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations

Layout

•8 foundation piles (left and right) - build left piles up in suit from Aces to Kings, build right piles down in suit from Kings to Aces.
•tableau (center) -  At the start of the game 64 cards are dealt out in an 8x8 square, with every other card rotated 90 degrees.  Only cards which have a short side not blocked by another card are available.  In the initial configuration, 16 of the 28 cards on the outside edge are available.  As cards are removed, interior cards will become available.  Available cards from the tableau can be built onto the foundation piles.  Also, an available card in the tableau can be played on the reserves if it is in sequence up or down by suit.
•8 reserves (left and right, between foundations and tableau) - build up or down by suit. Top card is available for play on the foundations or other reserves.  An empty space may be filled with any card. At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt face up to each pile.

History

Persian Rug is a variation of Crazy Quilt.

 

Similar Games

Crazy Quilt

Indian Carpet

Persimmon

Persimmon

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (50%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color. Spaces are filled with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.  The top card is face up.

 

•reserve upper (left of stock) - Top card always available for play on the tableau or foundations.  At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt here.
•reserve lower (left of tableau) - All cards available for play.  Click on card to move it to the bottom of the stack, then move to either the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 9 cards are dealt face up to this pile.

 

•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 3 cards at a time to the waste by clicking during the first deal, 2 cards at a time during the 2nd deal, and 1 card at a time during the last deal.  Two redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Persimmon was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Klondike

Klondike Territory

Phantom Blockade

Phantom Blockade

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Easy (90%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•13 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color. Groups of cards can be moved as a unit if the are in sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces may be filled by a King or group of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - deal one card to each tableau pile by clicking.  No redeals.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Phantom Blockade is a variation of Blockade suggested by a Pretty Good Solitaire player.

Similar Games

Blockade

Waning Moon

Eclipse

Pharaohs

Pharaohs

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (10%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To pair up all cards and move them out of play to the waste pile.

Layout

•3 Pyramids of 28 cards, 21 cards, and 3 cards each.  Only uncovered cards are available for play.  Cards are paired in 2 ways: cards of the same rank may be paired, or cards whose ranks add to 13 may be paired. To remove a pair, pick up one of the cards and drag it onto the other.  Kings are removed singly by clicking.
•1 waste pile (starts empty) - where paired cards go out of play.

Notes

•Any pair of cards whose ranks add to 13 can be discarded.  The valid pairs are Queen-Ace, Jack-Two, 10-3, 9-4, 8-5, 7-6.  Kings are discarded singly.  To discards Kings, simply click on them.  Also, any pair of cards of the same rank may be paired, such as two 8's or two Queens.

History

Pharaohs is a variation of Pyramid.  It is a totally open game (meaning that all cards are visible from the initial deal) which gives greater opportunity for strategy than Pyramid does.  Pharaohs was invented by Bryan Stout.

Similar Games

Pyramid

Giza

Phoenix

Phoenix

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (50%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - build the piles up in suit from Ace to King.
•6 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Groups of cards may be moved as a unit if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt to each pile.
•16 reserve piles (left and right) - each pile contains 1 card, available for play on the foundations or tableau.  Spaces are not filled.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Phoenix is a harder version of Arizona.

Similar Games

Arizona

Picture Patience

Picture Patience

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Very Hard (1%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (left and right) - build piles starting with Aces up in suit to Kings, build piles starting with Kings down in suit to Aces.
•9 tableau piles (middle) - each pile can contain 1 card.  No building.  Spaces are filled from the waste (if empty, from the stock).  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (center bottom, face down) - turn over 1 card to waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

Pigtail

Pigtail

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (4%).  Skill/Luck Balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (left and right) - build up in suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•12 tableau piles (in the corners between the foundations and beside the reserve) - No building.  Top card is available for play on the foundations   Spaces are filled automatically.  The 4 cards each on either side of the reserve are called the sides, and the 4 cards in each of the corners near the foundations are called the corners.  Spaces in the sides are filled automatically from the stock only, spaces in the corners are filled automatically from the reserve.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (middle, face down on left) - move 1 card to waste by clicking.  Two redeals.
•waste (below stock) - top card available for play on the foundations.
•reserve (middle) - top card fills spaces in the gate piles of the tableau or can be played to the foundations. The cards cannot otherwise be moved.  At the start of the game 20 cards are dealt to this pile.

Options

AutoPlay

Similar Games

Fort

Pitchfork

Pitchfork

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (15%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•reserve (top left) - storage locations for cards.  Only the top card is available for play.  No building.  At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt here.

 

•9 tableau piles (below foundations and reserve) - build down by alternate color. Only one card at a time can be moved.  Fill spaces with any card.  At the start of the game 8 cards are dealt face up to the 1st, 2nd, 8th and 9th piles, 4 cards are dealt face up to the 3rd and 7th piles, and 2 cards are dealt face up to the 4th and 6th piles.  The 5th pile is left empty.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Pitchfork is a harder variation of Haystack and Needle invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Haystack

Needle

Pitt the Younger

Pitt the Younger

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (5%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (middle) - build up in suit from Aces to Kings.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Groups of cards in descending sequence down by alternate color may be moved as a unit.  Spaces are filled only by Kings or a group of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first and 10th piles, 2 cards to the 2nd and 9th piles, 3 cards to the 3rd and 8th piles, 4 cards to the 4th and 7th piles, and 5 cards to the 5th and 6th piles.  Only the top card is face up.
•reserve (top) - top card is available for play on the foundations only. At the start of the game 11 cards are dealt here.
•stock (top left, face down) - deals one card to each tableau pile that is not headed by a King by clicking.  No redeals.

 

Options

AutoPlay

History

Pitt the Younger is a harder version of Prime Minister.
