Pizzica

Pizzica

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks. Medium (50%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right, starting with Aces) - build up in suit from Ace to King, back to Ace to King again, until each pile contains 26 cards.  At the start of the game an Ace of each suit is dealt here.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - Build down by alternate color, wrapping from Ace to King as necessary.  Groups of cards in sequence down by alternate color may be moved as a unit.  Spaces may be filled by any card or legal sequence of cards.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt to each pile, in the first and 10th piles, the top card is face up, in the 2nd and 9th piles 2 cards are face up, in the 3rd and 8th piles 3 cards are face up, in the 4th and 7th piles 4 cards are face up, and in the 5th and 6th piles all the cards are face up.
•reserve - (left of foundations) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 10 cards are dealt to this pile.
•stock (left of reserve) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Pizzica is a harder version of Tarantella invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Tarantella

Klondike

Spider

Blondes and Brunettes

Point Sable

Point Sable

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (20%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top) - build left 4 piles up in suit from Ace to King, build right 4 piles down in suit from King to Ace.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build up or down by suit.  Groups of cards may be moved if they are in sequence up or down by suit (if the direction changes in the middle of the group, the group can still be moved as a unit).  Fill spaces with any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 2 cards are dealt face down to the middle 5 piles, 2 more cards are dealt face down to the middle 3 piles, 2 more cards are dealt face down to the middle pile, then 1 card is dealt face up to all the piles.
•stock (top left, face down) - deal one card to each tableau pile, by clicking.  The last deal (2 cards) is dealt to the cells rather than the tableau (regardless of whether there are any cards in the cells).   No redeals.
•2 cells (top left) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell (except when the last deal from the stock deals a card to each cell).  Cards may be played to the foundations or tableau.

History

Point Sable has similarities to Miss Milligan and Carlton and was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Carlton

Miss Milligan

Milligan Cell

Polytope

Polytope

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (20%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundation.

Layout

•1 foundation pile (top) - sets of 4 cards of the same rank are moved here automatically.
•5 tableau piles  - build cards of the same rank.  For example, a Jack can be played on another Jack.  The top card of each pile is available for play.  When all 4 cards of the same rank are built, the cards are automatically removed to the foundation.  Spaces are filled automatically by the top card of the waste (or the stock if the waste is empty).  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top, face down) - deal 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the tableau.

History

Polytope is a much harder variation of Simplex.

Similar Games

Simplex

Portuguese Solitaire

Portuguese Solitaire

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (90%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•13 tableau piles (left of foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces can be filled only with Kings.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt face up to each pile.

Options

AutoPlay

Tips

•Don't let one foundation get too far ahead of the others.
•Watch for piles that contain a lower card of a suit below a higher card of the same suit.

History

Portuguese Solitaire is halfway between Baker's Dozen and Spanish Patience.  It is harder than Spanish Patience since only Kings are allowed in empty tableau piles, but is easier than Baker's Dozen, which does not allow any cards to be played to empty tableau piles at all.

Similar Games

Baker's Dozen

Spanish Patience

Castles in Spain

Good Measure

Catalan

Precedence

Precedence

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks. Hard (8%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top) - build down regardless of suit, wrapping from Ace to King as necessary, from King (first pile), Queen (2nd pile), Jack (3rd pile), etc.  The last pile begins with a Six.  The first King that comes up in play may be placed on the first foundation.  Other foundations cannot be started until the foundation to its immediate left has been started.
•stock (bottom, face down) - move 1 card to waste by clicking.  Two redeals.
•waste (below stock) - top card available for play on the foundations.

History

Precedence actually has two variations: according to some rules a King is laid out at the beginning of the game in the leftmost foundation pile, making the game a little easier (see the game Succession for these rules).  Since the game is not difficult in any case, this version requires the King to come up in play.

Similar Games

Succession

Preference

Preference

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (80%).  All Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King. At the start of the game the Aces are dealt here.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  The top card of each pile is available for play.  Spaces are filled automatically from the waste or stock.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (left, face down) - deal 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (below stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Preference is a variation of Fortune's Favor.

Similar Games

Fortune's Favor

The Bold

Prime Minister

Prime Minister

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (20%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (middle) - build up in suit from Aces to Kings.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Groups of cards in descending sequence down by alternate color may be moved as a unit.  Spaces are filled only by Kings or a group of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first and 10th piles, 2 cards to the 2nd and 9th piles, 3 cards to the 3rd and 8th piles, 4 cards to the 4th and 7th piles, and 5 cards to the 5th and 6th piles.  Only the top card is face up.
•reserve (top) - top card is available for play on the foundations only. At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt here.
•stock (top left, face down) - deals one card to each tableau pile that is not headed by a King by clicking.  No redeals.

 

Options

AutoPlay

History

Prime Minister is a Terrace type game.

Similar Games

General's Patience

Signora

Terrace

Pitt the Younger

Primrose

Primrose

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (50%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (center row) - build up regardless of suit from the rank of first card played to each pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•8 Indicator cards (top row) - indicate the top card for each foundation.  Must be the last card played to the foundation directly below it.  This row indicates what the bases of the foundation piles will be.  The card in the indicator row is the last card that will be played on the foundation pile below it.  If the indicator card is a Five, for example, then the foundation pile below it must start with a Six.
•8 tableau piles (bottom row) - top card available for play on the foundations only.  At the start of the game 12 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (far left) - Redeals.  The tableau is redealt in the following way by clicking on the empty stock: the cards in the first pile are picked up and turned over.  The cards are then dealt out one at a time to each pile across to the right, and then back again to the leftmost pile  until the cards run out.  This is repeated for each pile in the tableau, moving from the leftmost pile to next pile to its right.  There are 8 redeals, one for each pile.

History

Primrose is a variation of Interregnum.

Similar Games

Interregnum

Princess Patience

Princess Patience

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (20%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (middle) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•32 tableau piles (left and right of foundations) -  build down in suit.  Only cards that have no cards between them and the foundations may be moved, although any card can be built upon.  Only the top card of each pile may be moved.  Spaces are filled by an available King or by the top card of the waste.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste pile by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

 

 

Notes

In the tableau, only cards that have no cards between them and the foundations are available.  This means that at the start of the game only the cards in the innermost 8 tableau piles next to the foundations are available to be moved. When a card next to a foundation is moved, it then makes available the cards in the next pile over away from the foundations.   You can build on cards in any pile.

 

History

Princess Patience is an elaborate variation of Diplomat.

Similar Games

Diplomat

Prince Albert

Prince Albert

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (50%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•13 tableau piles (top and bottom) - build down by alternate color. Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color and if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.  Spaces may be filled by a King or any legal group headed by a King.   At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to the 1st pile, 5 cards to the 2nd pile, 6 cards to the 3rd pile, 7 cards to the 4th pile, 6 cards to the 5th pile, 5 cards to the 6th pile, 4 cards to the 7th pile, then 1 card to the 8th pile, 2 cards to the 9th pile, 3 cards to the 10th and 11th piles, 2 cards to the 12th pile and 1 card to the 13th pile.  All cards are face up.

 

•3 cells  (left) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each cell.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Prince Albert is similar to King Albert and Agnes Bernauer.

Similar Games

King Albert

Agnes Bernauer

Prince Serg

Prince Serg

 Top  Previous  Next

2 separate decks.  Medium (70%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Aces to Kings.
•7 Left tableau piles (below foundations, on left) - On the left part, build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Fill spaces with Kings (or groups of cards headed by a King) that come from either the Left waste pile or another Left tableau pile. At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.  The top card is face up.
•6 Right tableau piles (below foundations, on right) - build down in suit.  Groups of cards can be moved if they are in sequence down in suit.  Spaces filled by any card or group of cards from the Right waste pile or another Right tableau pile.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•Left stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the Left waste pile by clicking.  No redeals.
•Left waste (next to Left stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.  Top card can only fill spaces in the Left tableau, it cannot fill spaces in the Right tableau.

 

•Right stock (top right, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the Right waste pile by clicking.  No redeals.
•Right waste (next to Right stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.  Top card can only fill spaces in the Right tableau, it cannot fill spaces in the Left tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Prince Serg starts with 2 separate decks.  The first deck is dealt to the Left tableau and Left stock, the other deck is dealt to the Right tableau and Right stock.
•The tableau piles are divided into two parts: the Left tableau and the Right tableau, divided by a line.  The Left tableau piles are built down by alternate color.  The Right tableau piles are built down in suit.  Groups of cards may be moved from one tableau pile to another, if they form a legal descending sequence in their current pile.  For example, a sequence down by alternate color may be moved from the Left tableau to the Right, since that is the legal sequence for the Left tableau.  However, a sequence down by alternate color cannot be moved from the Right tableau to the Left, since that sequence is not legal on the Right.  These kinds of groups transfers are called "shifts".  Shifts of groups down by alternate color are allowed from Left to Right, while shifts of down in suit cards are allowed from Right to Left.  Once an shift has been made, the cards in the groups cannot again be moved as a group, since they will no longer be a legal group for their side of the tableau.
•Empty tableau piles can only be filled by a card from the same side of the line.  Empty piles on the Left can only be filled by a card or group of cards from the Left side, empty piles on the Right can only be filled by a card or group of cards from the Right side.  In addition, on the Left empty piles can only be filled by a King (or group of cards headed by a King).

History

Prince Serg was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Klondike

Forty Thieves

Boots

Private Lane

Private Lane

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (50%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (middle) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•8 tableau piles (around foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Only the top card of each pile is available for play.  Spaces may be filled by any available card.  At the start of the game the first 4 piles are dealt 7 cards each face up, and the next 4 piles are dealt 6 cards each face up.
•2 cells (top) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.  The card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Private Lane is Streets and Alleys with two cells that makes the game somewhat easier.

Similar Games

Streets and Alleys

Beleaguered Castle

Stronghold

Pumpkin

Pumpkin

 Top  Previous  Next

3 Decks.  Medium (50%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•12 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•13 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces can be filled only by a King or a group of cards headed by a King. At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.

History

Pumpkin is a 3 deck variation of Lady Jane and Arabella invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Lady Jane

Arabella

Pumpkin Spice

Pumpkin Spice

Pumpkin Spice

 Top  Previous  Next

3 Decks.  Medium (80%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•12 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•13 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces can be filled only by a King or a group of cards headed by a King. At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 3 cards at a time to the waste by clicking during the first deal, 2 cards at a time during the 2nd deal, and 1 card at a time during the last deal.  Two redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.

History

Pumpkin Spice is a variation of Pumpkin invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Pumpkin

Lady Jane

Arabella

Push Pin

Push Pin

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (10%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To discard all the cards except the first and last cards.

Layout

•stock (top left, face down) -  Turn over 1 card at a time to the tableau by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (bottom right) - where cards are automatically moved out of play.
•tableau  - where cards are dealt from the stock.  Cards are dealt in a row.  Cards may be discarded if a single card is between two cards of the same suit or rank, or two cards are between two cards of the same suit or rank.  To discard a single card, simply click on it.  To discard a pair of cards, drag and drop one card onto the other.  The game is won when all cards are discarded except for the first and last cards.  When cards reach the end of the screen the cards will go down to the next row in serpentine fashion.

Similar Games

Royal Marriage

Accordion

Puss in the Corner

Puss in the Corner

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (84%).  Skill/luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (in the middle) - build up in color from Ace to King.  At the start of the game the Aces are dealt here.
•4 reserve piles (in the corners) - cards are played here from the stock.  The top card of each pile is available for play on the foundations.
•stock (top middle) - Top card is available for play on the reserves or foundations.  One redeal.

Tips

•The skill in this game is deciding which reserve pile to put each card in.  You do not want to block yourself by putting higher cards on top of lower cards, unless absolutely necessary.

History

Puss in the Corner is a variation of Sir Tommy.

Similar Games

Sir Tommy

Putt Putt

Putt Putt

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (22%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the waste pile.

Layout

•7 tableau piles (across top) - no building.  Top card of each pile is available for play on the waste pile.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (face down below tableau) - turn over 1 card to the waste by clicking.

 

•waste (next to stock) - build up or down regardless of suit, wrapping Ace to King or King to Ace as necessary.

History

Putt Putt is an easy variation of Golf.

Similar Games

Golf

Double Putt

Pyramid

Pyramid

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (14%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To pair up all the cards in the deck in pairs of cards whose ranks total to 13.

Layout

•A Pyramid of 28 cards.  Only uncovered cards are available for play.  Discard pairs of cards whose ranks add to 13.  Kings are discarded singly.  To discard a pair, drop one card on the other, or right-click on one of the cards.
•stock (top left) - turn over cards one at a time to the waste by clicking.  Two redeals.
•waste (below stock) - The top card is available for play.

Notes

•Any pair of cards whose values add to 13 can be discarded.  The valid pairs are Queen-Ace, Jack-Two, 10-3, 9-4, 8-5, 7-6.  Kings are discarded singly.  To discards Kings, simply click on them.

History

This is a classic solitaire game of addition.  For more strategic versions, see Giza and Pharaohs.  Also see Pyramid Golf.

Similar Games

Double Pyramid

Giza

Pharaohs

Pyramid Golf

Triangle

Pyramid Seven

Cheops

Apophis

Pyramid Dozen

Pyramid Rank

Pyramid Clear

Pyramid Clear

Pyramid Clear

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (30%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To pair up all the cards in the pyramid in pairs of cards whose ranks total to 13.

Layout

•A Pyramid of 28 cards.  Only uncovered cards are available for play.  Discard pairs of cards whose ranks add to 13.  Kings are discarded singly.  To discard a pair, drop one card on the other, or right-click on one of the cards.
•stock (top left) - turn over cards one at a time to the waste by clicking.  Two redeals.
•waste (below stock) - The top card is available for play.

Notes

•Any pair of cards whose values add to 13 can be discarded.  The valid pairs are Queen-Ace, Jack-Two, 10-3, 9-4, 8-5, 7-6.  Kings are discarded singly.  To discards Kings, simply click on them.

 

•This game differs from Pyramid in that only the pyramid of 28 needs to be cleared to win the game - cards left in the stock or waste do not matter.

History

Pyramid Clear is Pyramid where you win by just clearing the pyramid of cards rather than pairing all cards.

Similar Games

Pyramid

Pyramid Dozen

Pyramid Dozen

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (30%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To pair up all the cards in the deck in pairs whose ranks total to 12.

Layout

•A Pyramid of 28 cards.  Only uncovered cards are available for play.  Cards are paired whose ranks add to 12, pair Queens with Kings. To remove a pair, pick up one of the cards and drag it onto the other.
•6 tableau piles - top card is available for pairing.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt face up to each pile.

Notes

•Any pair of cards whose values add to 12 can be discarded.  The valid pairs are Ace-Jack, Two-10, 3-9, 4-8, 5-7, 6-6, Q-K.

History

Pyramid Dozen is a variation of Pyramid and Giza.

Similar Games

Pyramid

Giza

Pyramid Golf

Pyramid Golf

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (4%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the waste pile.

Layout

•A Pyramid of 28 cards.  Only uncovered cards are available for play.  No building.  Top card of each pile is available for play on the waste pile.
•stock (face down on left) - turn over cards one at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (below stock) - build up or down in sequence regardless of suit, wrapping from Ace to King or King to Ace as necessary.

Notes

•Play cards from the Pyramid to the waste if possible.  Whenever there are no possible plays, turn over a card in the stock by clicking on it.  This card goes to the waste pile.
•The game is won if the Pyramid is cleared.  If the Pyramid is not cleared, the object is to leave as few cards as possible.

History

Pyramid Golf is a cross between Pyramid and Golf.

Similar Games

Pyramid

Golf

Giza

Pharaohs

Triangle

Pyramid Rank

Pyramid Rank

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard  (15%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To pair up all the cards in the deck into pairs of cards.

Layout

•A Pyramid of 28 cards.  Only uncovered cards are available for play.  Discard pairs of cards of the same rank.   To discard a pair, drop one card on the other, or right-click on one of the cards.
•stock (bottom left) -  move cards one at a time to the waste by clicking.  Two redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - The top card is available for play.

Notes

•Any pair of cards of the same rank can be paired and removed from play.  Be careful when choosing pairs because it is very easy to pair off cards in such a way that you are left with some cards that cannot be paired.

History

Pyramid Rank is a variation of Pyramid.

Similar Games

Pyramid

Pyramid Golf

Cheops

Pyramid Seven

Pyramid Seven

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (40%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To pair up all the cards in the deck in pairs of cards whose ranks total to 13.

Layout

•A Pyramid of 28 cards.  Only uncovered cards are available for play.  Discard pairs of cards whose ranks add to 13.  Kings are discarded singly.  To discard a pair, drop one card on the other, or right-click on one of the cards.
•7 reserve piles (below Pyramid).  Each of the 7 cards is available for pairing.  When paired, the cards are not replaced.
•stock (top left) - turn over cards one at a time to the waste by clicking.  Two redeals.
•waste (below stock) - The top card is available for play.

Notes

•Any pair of cards whose values add to 13 can be discarded.  The valid pairs are Queen-Ace, Jack-Two, 10-3, 9-4, 8-5, 7-6.  Kings are discarded singly.  To discards Kings, simply click on them.

History

Pyramid Seven is a variation of Pyramid.

Similar Games

Pyramid

Giza

Pharaohs

Pyramid Golf

Triangle

Q.C.

Q.C.

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (5%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•6 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are filled immediately from the waste.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  One redeal.
•waste (below stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.  If the top card can be played to the foundations, it must be played there (it will be played there automatically).

Options

AutoPlay

Similar Games

Taking Silk

Thirty-Six

Quadrangle

Quadrangle

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (15%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (right) -  build up in suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•12 tableau piles (left of foundations) - build down in suit, wrapping from Ace to King as necessary.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are filled from the waste.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (face down, top left) - turn over 1 card to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (under stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Quadrangle is a variation of Corona.

Similar Games

Corona

Triple Line

Busy Aces

Limited

Forty Thieves

Quadrennial

Quadrennial

 Top  Previous  Next

4 Decks.  Medium (50%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•16 foundation piles (left, top, right) - build up regardless of suit from Ace to King.  At the start of the game the Aces are dealt here.
•8 reserve piles (between and below foundations) - cards are dealt here from the stock.  The top card of each pile is available for play.  Move cards to the foundations by clicking.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (face down) - deal 1 card to each reserve pile by clicking.   Two redeals.

History

Quadrennial is Leap Year with 2 redeals .  It is a 4 deck version of Acquaintance.

Similar Games

Leap Year

Auld Lang Syne

Acquaintance

Tam O'Shanter

Quadruple Canfield

Quadruple Canfield

 Top  Previous  Next

4 Decks.  Easy (98%).  Skill/luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations

Layout

•16 foundation piles (left and right) - build up in suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•8 tableau piles (center) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces are filled from the reserve if possible, else by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (left of tableau, face down) - turn over 3 cards at a time to the waste, by clicking.  Unlimited redeals.
•waste (below stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.
•reserve (below waste) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 39 cards are dealt here.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Quadruple Canfield is a four-deck version of the classic game Canfield, invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Canfield

Double Canfield

Triple Canfield

Quadruple Demons

Quadruple Demons

 Top  Previous  Next

4 Decks. Medium (80%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 26 cards (twice around each suit). Only two piles for each suit allowed.
•12 tableau piles (below foundations) - build first 5 piles (left of line) down by alternate color.  Build remaining 7 piles (right of line) down in suit, wrapping from Ace to King if necessary in both cases.  Move groups of cards if they form a legal descending sequence for that pile.  Spaces can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt each to the left 5 piles, and 12 cards are dealt to each of the remaining 7 piles.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  Two redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.
•reserve (below stock, next to tableau) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 21 cards are dealt here.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•The tableau piles are divided into two parts: the Left tableau and the Right tableau, divided by a line.  The 5 Left tableau piles are built down by alternate color.  The 7 Right tableau piles are built down in suit.  Groups of cards may be moved from one tableau pile to another, if they form a legal descending sequence in their current pile.  For example, a sequence down by alternate color may be moved from the Left tableau to the Right, since that is the legal sequence for the Left tableau.  However, a sequence down by alternate color cannot be moved from the Right tableau to the Left, since that sequence is not legal on the Right.  These kinds of groups transfers are called "shifts".  Shifts of groups down by alternate color are allowed from Left to Right, while shifts of down in suit cards are allowed from Right to Left.  Once an shift has been made, the cards in the groups cannot again be moved as a group, since they will no longer be a legal group for their side of the tableau.

 

 

Tips

•The secret to success is strategic shifting between the the left tableau and the right tableau.

 

History

Quadruple Demons is a 4 deck version of Demons and Thieves invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Demons and Thieves

Triple Demons

Quadruple FreeCell

Quadruple FreeCell

 Top  Previous  Next

4 Decks.  Medium (80%).  Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King, wrapping to Ace and then to King again, until each pile contains 26 cards.  Only two piles for each suit allowed.
•9 cells (top left) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.  The card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.
•12 tableau piles (below foundations and cells) - The piles are built down by alternate color, wrapping Kings on Aces if necessary.  The top card is available for play on the foundations, cells, or another tableau pile.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color and if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.  Fill spaces with Kings or legal groups of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 18 cards are dealt face up to the first 4 piles, 17 cards are dealt face up to the remaining piles.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Note that groups of cards in the tableau can only be moved as a group if there are a sufficient number of empty cells available to store the cards individually.  The ability to move cards as a group is only a shortcut to moving the group one card at a time.

Tips

•Try to keep as many cells empty as possible.

History

Quadruple FreeCell is a four-deck version of FreeCell.  It was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

FreeCell

Triple FreeCell

Quadruple Harp

Quadruple Harp

 Top  Previous  Next

4 Decks.  Hard (10%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•12 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•16 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.   Only one card at a time may be moved, except groups of cards down by alternate color may be moved as a unit into an empty space.  Spaces are filled by a King or a group of cards headed with a King (the only way a group of cards may be moved).  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 to the 2nd, and so on.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card to the waste by clicking.  Three redeals.
•waste (below stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Quadruple Harp is a four deck variation of Harp invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Harp

Klondike

Triple Harp

Quadruple Interchange

Quadruple Interchange

 Top  Previous  Next

4 Decks.  Medium (50%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•16 foundation piles (across top and sides) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•11 tableau piles (between foundations) - build down in suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit.  Fill spaces with any card or legal group of cards.   At the start of the game 11 cards are dealt to each pile, alternating face up and face down.
•stock (face down) - turn over cards one at a time to the waste by clicking.  Unlimited redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Quadruple Interchange is a 4 deck version of Interchange.

Similar Games

Interchange

Single Interchange

Triple Interchange

Unlimited

Quadruple Klondike

Quadruple Klondike

 Top  Previous  Next

4 Decks.  Very Easy (98%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations

Layout

•16 foundation piles (left and right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•16 tableau piles (between foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Fill spaces with Kings or a legal group of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 to the 2nd pile, and so on.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 3 cards at a time to the waste, by clicking.  Unlimited redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Quadruple Klondike is a four-deck variation of Klondike invented by Thomas Warfield.

Quadruple Klondike Strict

Quadruple Klondike Strict

Quadruple Klondike Strict

 Top  Previous  Next

4 Decks.  Medium (80%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations

Layout

•16 foundation piles (left and right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•16 tableau piles (between foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Fill spaces with Kings or a legal group of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 to the 2nd pile, and so on.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste, by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

History

Quadruple Klondike Strict is Quadruple Klondike with only a one card deal from the stock and no redeals.

Quadruple Left

Quadruple Left

 Top  Previous  Next

4 Decks.  Medium (30%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•16 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•14 tableau piles (between foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces are filled automatically by the face up card or group of cards in the pile immediately to the right of the open space.  The rightmost pile, if empty, may be filled with a King or a legal group of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 to the 2nd pile, and so on.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over cards one at a time to the waste, by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Quadruple Left is a 4 deck version of Moving Left invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Moving Left

Single Left

Triple Left

Quadruple Russian

Quadruple Russian

 Top  Previous  Next

4 Decks.  Medium (75%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•16 foundation piles (left and right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•16 tableau piles (between foundations) - build down in suit.  Move groups of cards regardless of any sequence.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.   At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd pile, and so on.  The top card is face up.  Then 5 additional face up cards are dealt to each of the 2nd through 13th piles, and 4 additional cards are dealt to the 14th to 16th piles.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Any face up card in the tableau may be built upon another, no matter how deep it is in a pile.  All cards covering it are moved together.  When a face down card is uncovered, it is automatically turned face up and is available for play.

History

Quadruple Yukon is a 4 deck version of Russian Solitaire invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Russian Solitaire

Double Russian

Triple Russian

Quadruple Scorpion

Quadruple Scorpion

 Top  Previous  Next

4 Decks.  Medium (10%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards into 16 sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace within the tableau.

Layout

•21 tableau piles - build down in suit.  Groups of cards may be moved regardless of any sequence.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 9 cards are dealt to each pile.  In the first 7 piles, 6 cards are face down, all others are face up.
•reserve (top left, face down) - Clicking deals 1 card to each of the first 19 tableau piles (this can be done only once).

Notes

The object of play is to manipulate the tableau into 16 piles, one for each suit, with the cards down in sequence from King to Ace.

History

Quadruple Scorpion is a four-deck version of the game Scorpion invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Scorpion

Double Scorpion

Triple Scorpion

•16 tableau piles (between foundations) - build down in suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit.  Fill spaces with Kings or a legal group of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 to the 2nd pile, and so on.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste, by clicking.  Unlimited redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.

 Top  Previous  Next

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

•16 foundation piles (left and right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•16 tableau piles (between foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards regardless of any sequence.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.   At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd pile, and so on.  The top card is face up.  Then 5 additional face up cards are dealt to each of the 2nd through 13th piles, and 4 additional cards are dealt to the 14th to 16th piles.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Any face up card in the tableau may be built upon another, no matter how deep it is in a pile.  All cards covering it are moved together.  When a face down card is uncovered, it is automatically turned face up and is available for play.

QuarterCell

QuarterCell

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (90%).  Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•2 foundation piles (top right) - build up by alternate color from Ace to King, then wrapping to Ace to King again.  At the start of the game an Ace of each color is dealt here.
•2 cells (top left) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.  At the start of the game a card is dealt to each cell.

 

•8 tableau piles (below foundations and cells) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color and if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.  Spaces can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt face up to each pile.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Groups of cards in the tableau can only be moved as a group if there are a sufficient number of empty cells available to store the cards individually.  The ability to move cards as a group is only a shortcut to moving the group one card at a time.

Tips

•Try to keep as many cells empty as possible.

History

QuarterCell is a variation of HalfCell with only 2 cells.

Similar Games

HalfCell

FreeCell

Quartermaster

Quartermaster

 Top  Previous  Next

4 Decks. Medium (80%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the waste pile.

Layout

•14 tableau piles (across top) - no building.  Top card of each pile is available for play on the waste pile.  At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt to the 1st and 14th piles, 9 cards to the 2nd and 13th, 11 cards to the 3rd and 12th, 13 cards to the 4th and 11th, 15 cards to the 5th and 10th, 17 cards to the 6th and 9th, and 19 cards to the 7th and 8th piles.  Only the top card is face up.
•stock (face down below tableau) - turn over 1 card to the waste by clicking.

 

•waste (next to stock) - build up or down regardless of suit, wrapping from Ace to King or King to Ace as necessary.

 

Notes

•Play cards from the tableau to the waste if possible.  Whenever there are no possible plays, turn over a card in the stock by clicking on it.  This card goes to the waste pile.

History

Quartermaster is a 4 deck Golf type game invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Golf

Putt Putt

Panther Creek

Double Golf

Quartermaster Open

Quartermaster Open

Quartermaster Open

 Top  Previous  Next

4 Decks. Medium (80%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the waste pile.

Layout

•14 tableau piles (across top) - no building.  Top card of each pile is available for play on the waste pile.  At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt to the 1st and 14th piles, 9 cards to the 2nd and 13th, 11 cards to the 3rd and 12th, 13 cards to the 4th and 11th, 15 cards to the 5th and 10th, 17 cards to the 6th and 9th, and 19 cards to the 7th and 8th piles.  All cards are face up.
•stock (face down below tableau) - turn over 1 card to the waste by clicking.

 

•waste (next to stock) - build up or down regardless of suit, wrapping from Ace to King or King to Ace as necessary.

 

Notes

•Play cards from the tableau to the waste if possible.  Whenever there are no possible plays, turn over a card in the stock by clicking on it.  This card goes to the waste pile.

History

Quartermaster Open is a variation of Quartermaster will all cards face up in the tableau.

Similar Games

Quartermaster

Golf

Putt Putt

Panther Creek

Double Golf

Quartet

Quartet

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (50%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To collect all the cards in sets of 4 cards of the same rank.

Layout

•4 cells (top) - storage location for one card.  No building.  When all 4 cells contain cards of the same rank (for example, 4 Jacks), then the 4 cards are removed from play.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•6 tableau piles (below cells) - build down regardless of suit.  Groups of cards can be moved if they are in sequence down regardless of suit.  Spaces can be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (face down on left) - Deals 1 card to each tableau pile .

Options

AutoPlay

Similar Games

Foursome

Rank FreeCell

Queen Of Italy

Queen Of Italy

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Easy (90%). Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (middle) - build up by alternate color from the rank of first card moved to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•9 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Only the top card of each pile may be moved.  Spaces may be filled by any card not from the reserve.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to the first 4 piles.  One of these cards is selected to be the foundation base card by moving it to the first foundation pile.  After a card is so moved 1 card is dealt face up to the remaining empty piles.
•reserve (top) - top card is available for play on the foundations only.  At the start of the game 11 cards are dealt here.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over cards 1 at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals, except that when the stock is empty the waste may be turned over to form a new stock by clicking on the empty stock.  Cards may then then be played to the foundations or tableau until an unplayable card is reached (which ends the game).
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Queen of Italy is a variation of Terrace.  There are two differences between Queen of Italy and Terrace which make Queen of Italy an easier game.  In Queen of Italy any card may be played to an empty tableau pile, and cards may be moved from the foundations back to the tableau.  These changes make it possible to win Queen of Italy most of the time.

Similar Games

Terrace

Venice

Queen Victoria

Queen Victoria

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (50%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•9 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces may be filled by any available card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd pile, and so on.
•7 reserve cards (across bottom) - each card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Queen Victoria is a variation of King Albert.

Similar Games

King Albert

Queenie

Queenie

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Easy (98%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Groups of cards may be moved regardless of any sequence.  Fill spaces with Kings or a group of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd pile, and so on.
•stock (top left, face down) -Deal one card to each tableau pile, by clicking.  No redeals.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Queenie was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Yukon

Nunavut

Monarch

Queens and Jacks

Queens and Jacks

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks. Very Hard (<1%).  All Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Kings to Aces then up to Queens.
•8 tableau piles (under foundations) - build down in suit from Queens.  Spaces are not filled.  At the start of the game the Queens are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (bottom center, face down) - turn over 1 card to waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (bottom center, next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Quizzie

Quizzie

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (40%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•9 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit.  Fill spaces with any card.   At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 3 cards at a time to the waste by clicking during the first deal, 2 cards at a time during the 2nd deal, and 1 card at a time during the last deal.  Two redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.

History

Quizzie is a variation of Inquisitor invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Inquisitor

Lady Jane

Racing Aces

Racing Aces

 Top  Previous  Next

3 Decks.  Hard (15%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•16 foundation piles (left) - build the first 4 piles from Aces to Kings up regardless of suit, the next 4 piles from Sixes to Aces down regardless of suit, the next 4 piles from Sevens to Kings up regardless of suit, and last 4 piles from Kings to Aces down regardless of suit.
•6 tableau piles (bottom right) - storage spaces for cards.  Only one card allowed per pile.  Spaces are filled from the stock.  When the stock is empty, spaces are filled by any card.  One card is dealt to each pile at the start of the game.
•3 reserve piles (top right) - Top card available for play on the foundations.  13 cards are dealt to each reserve at the start of the game.
•stock (middle right, face down) -  Turn over 1 card at a time to the waste pile by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•  It is allowed (in fact is it necessary in order to win)  to move cards from one foundation pile to another.
•Play consists of moving cards from the reserves, waste, and tableau to the foundations, and especially in strategic movement of cards within the foundations to allow more cards to be played there.

History

Racing Aces is a 3 deck variation of Aces and Kings invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Aces and Kings

Double Aces and Kings

Deuces and Queens

Raglan

Raglan

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (25%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•9 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Only the top card of each pile may be moved.  Spaces may be filled by any available card.  At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt face up to the first 3 piles, then 6 cards to the 4th pile, 5 cards to the 5th pile, and so on until the last pile is dealt 1 card.
•6 reserve cards (across bottom) - each card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Raglan is a variation of King Albert.

Similar Games

King Albert

Somerset

Morehead

Rail Fence

Rail Fence

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Easy. (99%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•8 tableau piles (middle) - build down by alternate color. Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces are filled only by a King or a group of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste, by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (below stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.

 

•10 reserve piles (columns left and right of tableau) - Card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.  Spaces are filled from the waste if possible, then by the stock.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.

Options

AutoPlay

Rainbow

Rainbow

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (20%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•4 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down regardless of suit.  Spaces are filled from the reserve, or if the reserve is empty by any card. At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.
•reserve (left of tableau) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 13 cards are dealt here.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Rainbow is a variation of Canfield.

Similar Games

Canfield

Chameleon

Storehouse

Ozymandias

Turnover the Rainbow

Rainbow Fan

Rainbow Fan

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks. Easy (96%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (left and right) - on the left 4 piles build up in suit from the Aces to Kings, on the right 4 piles build down in suit from the Kings to Aces.  Cards (other than the starting base cards)  may be transferred from one foundation to another.  At the start of the game an Ace and King of each suit are dealt here.
•20 fans (between foundations) - build up or down by suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are filled automatically from the stock unless the stock is empty, in which case they are not filled.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (face down) - fills spaces in fans automatically with 3 new cards.  Clicking on the empty or non-empty stock does a redeal.  There are 3 redeals.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Building on the fans can be reversed multiple times on the same pile.

 

•Spaces made by playing all the cards of a fan are automatically filled from the stock (this is the only way new cards come into the game).  If the stock is empty, spaces are not filled.

 

•In this game a redeal actually only slightly rearranges the cards in the fan.  The exposed card of each fan is placed at the bottom of the fan during each redeal. The other cards in the fan remain in the same order.

History

This is a 2 deck member of the Fan family of games.  It is actually called "Rainbow", but since there is another game of that name it has been renamed "Rainbow Fan".

 

Similar Games

House on the Hill

House in the Wood

Intelligence

Buffalo Bill

La Belle Lucie

Random

Random

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (80%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile (the foundation base card), wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•9 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces are filled only by a card one rank lower than the foundation base card (or by Kings if the base card is an Ace.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 to the 2nd, and so on.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 3 cards at a time to the waste by clicking during the first deal, 2 cards at a time during the 2nd deal, and 1 card at a time during the last deal.  Two redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Random is a variation of Harp.

Similar Games

Harp

Gold Rush

Rank and File

Rank and File

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Easy (80%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) -   build down by alternate color.   Groups of cards can be moved if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces are filled by any card.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile, 3 face down and 1 face up.
•stock (top left) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste pile by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

 

Options

AutoPlay

 

History

Rank and File is one of the classic variations on Forty Thieves.  The differences are that 3 of the 4 cards in the original tableau are dealt face down, the tableau are built down by alternate color instead of down in suit, and groups of cards forming a sequence down by alternate color can be moved as a unit.  Rank and File is also very similar to Number Ten.

Similar Games

Emperor

Number Ten

Forty Thieves

Left Side Story

Rank FreeCell

Rank FreeCell

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (15%).  Skill.

Object

To collect all the cards in sets of 4 cards of the same rank.

 

Layout

•4 cells (top) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell. When all 4 cells contain cards of the same rank (for example, 4 Jacks), then the 4 cards are removed from play.

 

•8 tableau piles (below cells) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color and if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.  Spaces can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt face up to the leftmost 4 piles, 6 cards are dealt face up to the remaining piles.

Notes

•Groups of cards in the tableau can only be moved as a group if there are a sufficient number of empty cells available to store the cards individually.  The ability to move cards as a group is only a shortcut to moving the group one card at a time.

History

Rank FreeCell is FreeCell with aspects of the games Foursome and Quartet.

Similar Games

FreeCell

Foursome

Quartet

Rank Spider

Rank Spider

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Easy (85%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards in sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace.

Layout

•10 tableau piles - build down in suit, or in the same rank.  Groups of cards in sequence down in suit (or of the same rank) may be moved as a unit (groups moved as a unit cannot contain both cards descending in sequence and multiple cards of the same rank at the same time).  A space can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 6 cards each are dealt to the first 4 piles, 5 cards each to the remaining piles.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.  All tableau piles must be filled before dealing.

Notes

•Whenever a sequence of 13 cards down in suit from King to Ace is formed, it will automatically be removed from play.

History

Rank Spider is a slightly more difficult version of Aracnida.

Similar Games

Aracnida

Spider

Curds and Whey

Raw Prawn

Raw Prawn

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Easy (99%).  Skill/Luck Balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - Build down in suit.  Groups of cards may be moved regardless of sequence. Spaces may be filled by any card. At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile.

 

•stock (top left) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste pile by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Rectangular

Rectangular

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (30%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards with a King at the bottom.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Rectangular is Forty Thieves where the tableau is built down regardless of suit while only groups down in suit may be moved.

Red and Black

Red and Black

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Very Easy (90%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up by alternate color from the Aces to Kings.  At the start of the game the Aces are dealt here.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Groups of cards can be moved if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces are filled by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (bottom left) - turn over 1 card to waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Notice that the foundations are built up by alternate color, an unusual method of foundation building.

 

History

This game is also known as Rouge et Noir.

Similar Games

Red Hand

Red Hand

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (50%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Groups of cards in sequence down by alternate color may be moved.  Spaces may be filled by Kings or a legal group of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (bottom, face down on left) - move 1 card at a time to waste by clicking.  2 redeals.
•waste (beside stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Redheads

Redheads

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.   Very Hard (1%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (middle) - build up in suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Only the top card of each pile may be moved.  Spaces are filled by the reserve.  When the reserve is empty, spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•reserve (top) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 21 cards are dealt here.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over cards 1 at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Redheads is variation of Blondes and Brunettes, a member of the Terrace family of games.  It was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Blondes and Brunettes

Terrace

General's Patience

Falling Star

Regimental

Regimental

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks. Medium (20%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (left and right sides) - build the piles on the left up in suit from Ace to King, build the piles on the right down in suit from King to Ace.  Each group of 4 piles should have a pile of each suit.
•16 tableau piles (face up in the middle) - build up or down by alternate color, Aces and Kings are not consecutive (no wraparound).  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are filled automatically from the face down piles directly above or below. (If that reserve pile is empty, the pile is filled from another reserve pile).   At the start of the game 2 cards are dealt to each pile.
•8 reserve piles (center, face down) - used to fill spaces in the tableau.  At the start of the game 9 cards are dealt face down to each pile.

Options

AutoPlay

Tips

•Be careful not to block yourself, since the foundations run both up and down.

History

Regimental is a variation of Heads and Tails invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Heads and Tails

Repair

Repair

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (36%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•4 cells (in the 4 corners) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.  The card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each cell.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Fill spaces with any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 10 cards are dealt face up to each pile.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Repair is a two deck variation of Freecell.

Similar Games

Double Freecell

Freecell

Replace

Replace

Replace

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (20%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•5 cells (left side) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.  The card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each cell.
•9 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Fill spaces with any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 11 cards are dealt face up to each pile.

Options

History

Republic

Republic

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (50%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top) - build up regardless of suit from Ace to King.
•8 tableau piles (middle) - build cards of same rank and color.  Top card available for play on the foundations.  Spaces can be filled from the waste only.
•stock (bottom, face down) - move 1 card to waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Reserved Pyramid

Reserved Pyramid

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (90%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (left and right at bottom) - build up in suit from Ace to King. At the start of the game the Aces are dealt here.
•15 reserve piles (in the form of a pyramid) - No building.  Play cards to the foundations.  Spaces are filled automatically from the stock.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top, face down) - move 1 card to waste by clicking.  1 redeal.
•waste (beside stock) -   The top card is available for play on the foundations.

Options

AutoPlay

Reserves

Reserves

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Very Hard (<1%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (left and right) - build the left 4 up in suit from Ace to King, build the right 4 down in suit from King to Ace. At the start of the game an Ace and King of each suit is dealt.
•4 reserve piles (between foundations) - No building.  Play cards to the foundations or waste.  At the start of the game 12 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (middle left, face down) - move 1 card to waste by clicking.  Two redeals.
•waste (beside stock) - Build up or down regardless of suit, wrapping as necessary (Aces may be built on Kings and Kings may be built on Aces).  The top card is available for play on the foundations.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Reserves is a variation of Alhambra.

Similar Games

Alhambra

Reveillion

Reveillion

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck. Hard (1%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - build up or down by alternate color, wrapping Ace to King or King to Ace as necessary.  At the start of the game one card is dealt to each pile.  With the exception of the first card dealt to the pile, cards may be moved from one pile to another.
•4 reserve piles (below foundations) - No building.  Cards are dealt here from the stock.  The top card of each pile is available for play.  Cards are available for play on the foundations only.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (face down) - deal 1 card to each reserve pile by clicking.  No redeals.

History

Reveillion is a difficult version of Cup of Kindness, which is a variation of the game Auld Lang Syne.

Similar Games

Cup of Kindness

Auld Lang Syne

Acquaintance

Sir Tommy

Tam O'Shanter

Richard's Patience

Richard's Patience

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Easy (90%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•12 tableau piles (left of foundations) - build down in suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are filled from the waste, or the stock if the waste is empty.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (face down, top left) - turn over 1 card to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (under stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.
•1 cell (bottom left) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Richard's Patience is Corona with the addition of a cell.  It was invented by Richard Mechen.

Similar Games

Corona

Quadrangle

Triple Line

Busy Aces

Limited

Forty Thieves

Right and Left

Right and Left

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (11%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (center) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•8 tableau piles (right and left) - build down regardless of suit.  Top card is available for play on the foundations or another tableau pile, only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are filled only by a King.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile.  Each pile's 4 cards are dealt at the same time.  If the 1st card is less than a 7, the 4 cards are dealt so that it is on top.  If the 1st card is an 8 or more, the 4 cards are dealt so that this card is on the bottom.  This serves to increase the chances of winning (tends to make lower cards available quicker).
•stock (bottom left, face down) - turn over cards 1 at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Similar Games

Diplomat

Congress

Right Triangle

Right Triangle

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (80%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.   Spaces are filled by a King or a group of cards headed with a King.  At the start of the game 10 cards are dealt to the first pile, 9 to the 2nd, and so on down to 1 card in the 10th.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - deals one card to each tableau pile by clicking.  When the stock is empty, it becomes a storage location for any number of cards.  Cards may be moved to the stock one at a time.  Only the top card is available for play.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Right Triangle is a variation of Hypotenuse.

Similar Games

Hypotenuse

Eternal Triangle

Ripple Fan

Ripple Fan

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck. Easy (85%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•13 tableau piles  - build down in suit.  Groups of cards can be moved if they are in sequence down in suit.  Spaces are not filled.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile.
•stock (left, no cards) - clicking on the stock collects all the cards from the tableau and redeals them.  Unlimited redeals.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•When play on the tableau comes to a standstill, the tableau can be redealt by clicking on the stock.  The cards are collected from the tableau starting with the last pile (lower right) of the tableau back to the first pile (top left), with the cards from the last pile on the bottom.  They are then redealt 4 cards to a pile starting with the first pile.
•Because of the way the cards are redealt, if no moves are made in the tableau the cards will be redealt back exactly the same way they were previously.  Therefore, after every deal you must be able to make at least one move in the tableau or the game is lost.  Also, some moves may not affect the order of the redeal.

Similar Games

Cruel

Bitter Fan

Rittenhouse

Rittenhouse

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (55%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top) - build the first 4 piles up regardless of suit from Ace to King, build the last 4 piles down regardless of suit from Kings to Aces.  At the start of the game 4 Aces and 4 Kings (of any suit) are dealt here.
•9 tableau piles (below foundations) - Build up or down regardless of suit.  Only 1 card at a time may be moved.  Spaces may be filled by any card.  The top card of each pile may be played to any other tableau pile, or the foundation pile directly above it.  Cards in the middle pile (with no foundation pile above it) can be played to any foundation pile.  All the cards are dealt face up to these piles.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•During the initial deal if any card dealt to the tableau can be played on the foundation immediately above it, it is played there.  Also, during the game cards can only be played to a foundation pile from the tableau pile immediately below it (except for the center tableau pile, which can play cards to any foundation pile).

History

Rittenhouse was invented by Captain Jeffrey T. Spaulding.

Similar Games

Spaulding

River Doon

River Doon

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.   Hard (10%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - build up regardless of suit from Ace to King.
•4 reserve piles (below foundations) - cards are moved here from the stock.  The top card of each pile is available for play on the foundations.  Move cards to the foundations by clicking.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (face down) - deal 1 card to each reserve pile by clicking.  Two redeals.

History

River Doon is Tam O'Shanter with 2 redeals, or Acquaintance without the Aces dealt to the foundations at the start of the game.

Similar Games

Tam O'Shanter

Auld Lang Syne

Acquaintance

Sir Tommy

Robert

Robert

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Hard (<1%).  All Luck.

Object

Move all cards to the foundation pile.

Layout

•1 foundation pile (top) - build up or down regardless of suit, wrapping from Ace to King if necessary.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt here.
•stock (face down) - turn over 1 card to the waste by clicking.  Two redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundation.

History

Solitaire doesn't get any simpler than this.

Similar Games

Bobby

Black Hole

Four Leaf Clovers

Robespierre

Robespierre

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (50%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•11 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit. Spaces may be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile.
•stock (bottom left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Tips

•Try to get a space in the tableau as quickly as possible.

History

Robespierre is an easier version of Forty Four Thieves.

Similar Games

Forty Four Thieves

Josephine
