Cadran

Robie

Robie

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (50%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved. Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start all piles are empty.
•stock (bottom left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.  All cards in the waste are visible.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Robie is a variation of Forty Thieves where the tableau is not dealt.  It was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Forty Thieves

Rochester

Rochester

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (30%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in color from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Fill spaces with cards of rank one below the foundation base card (or Kings if the base card is an Ace).  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste, by clicking.  Two redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.

History

Rochester is a variation of Springfield.

Similar Games

Springfield

Chatham

Little Napoleon

Forty Thieves

Roman Patience

Roman Patience

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (30%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (middle) - build up in suit from the rank of first card moved to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•9 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit, wrapping from Ace to King if necessary.  Only the top card of each pile may be moved.  Spaces are filled automatically from the waste, or stock if the waste is empty.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•reserve (top) - top card is available for play on the foundations only. At the start of the game 11 cards are dealt here.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over cards 1 at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•The game begins by choosing a card to move to the first foundation pile.  The rank of this card becomes the base card for all the other

foundation piles.  This first move is very important.

History

Roman Patience is a variation of Signora invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Signora

Blondes and Brunettes

Terrace

Romanian Solitaire

Romanian Solitaire

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (20%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards into 4 sets of 13 cards in sequence down by alternate color from King to Ace.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - move entire 13-card King to Ace down by alternate color sequences from the tableau.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color, wrapping from Ace to King if necessary.  Move groups of cards regardless of any sequence.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards with headed by a King.   At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt to each pile, with 1 card face down in the second pile, 2 cards face down in the 3rd pile, and so on.  Then one additional face up card is dealt to each of the three rightmost piles.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Any face up card in the tableau may be built upon another, no matter how deep it is in a pile.  All cards covering it are moved together.  When a face down card is uncovered, it is automatically turned face up and is available for play.

History

Romanian Solitaire is a variation of Ukrainian Solitaire.

Similar Games

Ukrainian Solitaire

Kiev

Dnieper

Russian Solitaire

Roosevelt

Roosevelt

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.   Very Hard (1%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Only one card at a time may be moved. Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile.
•stock (bottom left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Tips

•Try to get a space in the tableau as quickly as possible.

Roslyn

Roslyn

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (80%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build up or down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards regardless of any sequence.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.   At the start of the game 1 card is dealt the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd pile, and so on.  The top card is face up.  Then 4 additional face up cards are dealt to the 2nd through 7th piles.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Any face up card in the tableau may be built upon another, no matter how deep it is in a pile.  All cards covering it are moved together.  When a face down card is uncovered, it is automatically turned face up and is available for play.

History

Roslyn is to Yukon as Alaska is to Russian Solitaire.

Similar Games

Yukon

Russian Solitaire

Alaska

Rouen

Rouen

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (25%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•8 tableau piles (under foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces may be filled by any available card.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt to each pile.
•stock (lower left, face down) - 1 card at a time moved to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Rouen is a variation of Dieppe.

Similar Games

Dieppe

Normandy

Congress

Diplomat

Rouge et Noir

Rouge et Noir

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (15%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build left 4 piles up in color from Ace to King (2 leftmost with red X's start with red Aces, next 2 in green with black Aces), drop entire 13 card sequences down by alternate color from the tableau on the right 4 piles (2 starting with red X's with red Kings, 2 rightmost in green with black Kings).
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Groups of cards in sequence down by alternate color may be moved as a unit.  Spaces are filled only by Kings or legal groups of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 8 cards are dealt to the first pile, 7 cards to the 2nd pile, and so on until 1 card is dealt to the 8th and 9th piles.  The 10th pile is left empty.  The top card of each pile is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.

Notes

•The first 4 foundations are built up card by card as is normal, but the right 4 foundations are built in the tableau.  When an entire 13 card sequence from King to Ace is built, it can be dropped on the right 4 foundations.

 

•There is no AutoPlay in this game, so all cards must be moved by dragging or right-clicking on the card.

Tips

•Keep in mind at all times that you are not only trying to build on the left 4 foundations up in color, but also you must build 4 complete 13-card sequences down by alternate color, much like they are built in Spider.  Whether to move a card to the 4 left foundations or to keep it in the tableau for building one of the sequences is a choice you are faced with often.  Also, note that when a new row of cards is dealt from the stock, you are likely to have many cards buried.

History

Rouge et Noir was invented by Charles Jewell.

Similar Games

Diavolo

Lady Cadogan

Forty Devils

Rouge Forty

Numeration

Royal Noir

Rouge Forty

Rouge Forty

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (15%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build left 4 piles up in color from Ace to King (2 leftmost with red X's start with red Aces, next 2 in green with black Aces), drop entire 13 card sequences down by alternate color from the tableau on the right 4 piles (2 starting with red X's with red Kings, 2 rightmost in green with black Kings).
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Groups of cards in sequence down by alternate color may be moved as a unit.  Spaces are filled only by Kings or legal groups of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt face up to the each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.

Notes

•The first 4 foundations are built up card by card as is normal, but the right 4 foundations are built in the tableau.  When an entire 13 card sequence from King to Ace is built, it can be dropped on the right 4 foundations.

 

•There is no AutoPlay in this game, so all cards must be moved by dragging or right-clicking on the card.

Tips

•Keep in mind at all times that you are not only trying to build on the left 4 foundations up in color, but also you must build 4 complete 13-card sequences down by alternate color, much like they are built in Spider.  Whether to move a card to the 4 left foundations or to keep it in the tableau for building one of the sequences is a choice you are faced with often.  Also, note that when a new row of cards is dealt from the stock, you are likely to have many cards buried.

History

Rouge Forty is a variation of Rouge et Noir invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Rouge et Noir

Forty Devils

Rough Rider

Rough Rider

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (10%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved. Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile, one card face down and 3 cards face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Tips

•Try to get a space in the tableau as quickly as possible.

History

Rough Rider is a variation of Forty Thieves.

Rows of Four

Rows of Four

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Easy (95%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (center) - build up in suit from Aces to Kings.
•8 tableau piles (left and right) - build down regardless of suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are filled by any card.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
• stock (top face down) - Turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  Two redeals.
• waste (next to stock) - Top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Rows of Four is Diplomat with two redeals.

Similar Games

Diplomat

Zerline

Royal Cotillion

Royal Cotillion

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (45%).  All Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (middle) - build left 4 piles up in suit by twos starting with Ace (Ace, 3,5,7,9,J,K,2,4,6,8,10,Q), build right 4 piles up in suit by twos starting with Twos (2,4,6,8,10,Q,A,3,5,7,9,J,K).  At the start of the game an Ace and a Two of each suit are dealt here.
•16 reserve piles (right) - each pile can contain 1 card.  No building.  The top card is available for play on the foundations.  Spaces are filled from the waste (if empty, from the stock).  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•4 more reserve piles (left) - No building. The top card is available for play on the foundations.  Spaces are not filled.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card to waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (top left, next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations.

Options

AutoPlay

Similar Games

Odd and Even

Royal Family

Royal Family

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Easy (98%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (right) - build down in suit from King to Ace.  At the start of the game the Kings are dealt here.
•12 tableau piles (middle) - build up or down by alternate color,  Top card is available for play on the foundations or another tableau pile, only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are filled by any card.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left) - when no more moves can be played, click here to redeal.  All the remaining cards in the tableau will be picked up and redealt.  One redeal.

Options

AutoPlay

Similar Games

Indefatigable

Royal Marriage

Royal Marriage

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (35%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To discard all the cards except the Queen and King of Hearts.

Layout

•stock (top left, face down) -  Turn over 1 card at a time to the tableau by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (bottom right) - where cards are automatically moved out of play.
•tableau  - where cards are dealt from the stock.  Cards are dealt in a row.  The first card dealt is the Queen of Hearts, the last card in the deck is the King of Hearts.  Cards may be discarded if a single card is between two cards of the same suit or rank, or two cards are between two cards of the same suit or rank.  To discard a single card, simply click on it.  To discard a pair of cards, drag and drop one card onto the other.  The game is won when all cards are discarded between the Queen and King of Hearts.  When cards reach the end of the screen the cards will go down to the next row in serpentine fashion.

Similar Games

Push-Pin

Accordion

Royal Noir

Royal Noir

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (20%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build left 4 piles up in color from Ace to King (2 leftmost with red X's start with red Aces, next 2 in green with black Aces), drop entire 13 card sequences down by alternate color from the tableau on the right 4 piles (2 starting with red X's with red Kings, 2 rightmost in green with black Kings).
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Groups of cards in sequence down by alternate color may be moved as a unit.  Spaces are filled only by Kings or legal groups of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 8 cards are dealt to the first pile, 7 cards to the 2nd pile, and so on until 1 card is dealt to the 8th and 9th piles.  The 10th pile is left empty.  The top card of each pile is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

 

Notes

•The first 4 foundations are built up card by card as is normal, but the right 4 foundations are built in the tableau.  When an entire 13 card sequence from King to Ace is built, it can be dropped on the right 4 foundations.

 

•There is no AutoPlay in this game, so all cards must be moved by dragging or right-clicking on the card.

Tips

•Keep in mind at all times that you are not only trying to build on the left 4 foundations up in color, but also you must build 4 complete 13-card sequences down by alternate color, much like they are built in Spider.  Whether to move a card to the 4 left foundations or to keep it in the tableau for building one of the sequences is a choice you are faced with often.

History

Royal Noir is a variation of Rouge et Noir invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Rouge et Noir

Diavolo

Royal Parade

Royal Parade

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (10%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•Twos foundations (first row),  Threes foundations (second row), Fours foundations (third row) - Build up in suit by threes.  Two piles (top row) are built  2, 5, 8, Jack, Three piles (second row) are built 3, 6, 9, Queen, Four piles (third row) are built 4, 7, 10, King.   An empty space can only be filled by a Two (top row), a Three (second row), or a Four (third row).  Top card only is available for play.  At the beginning of the game one card is dealt to each pile.
• A Two, Three, or Four outside its proper row may be interchanged with another Two, Three, or Four outside its proper row if by interchanging them they are moved to their proper rows (To interchange cards, just drop one on the other).
•Ace foundation (below stock) - build Aces only until the pile contains all 8 Aces.
•8 reserve piles (bottom row) - top card is available for play on any of the foundations. No building.  Spaces are not filled except by a deal from the stock.
•stock (top left, face down) - Deals 1 card to each reserve pile.  No redeals.

Notes

•The objective is to get all Twos to start piles in the top row, all Threes to start piles in the second row, and all Fours to start piles in the third row.
•Once a Two, Three, or Four is placed in its proper row, you can build up in suit by threes on it, at the end each pile will contain 4 cards.   Aces are removed and placed in the Ace pile.
•Aces can be immediately played to the Ace foundation.
•Spaces in the reserve can only be filled by a deal from the stock.

History

Royal Parade is a very old game that was improved with the newer game Virginia Reel.

Similar Games

Virginia Reel

Three Up

Blue Jacket

Royal Rendezvous

Royal Rendezvous

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Easy (60%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 Top Ace foundations (across top, with Aces) - build up in suit from Aces to Kings.  At the start of the game an Ace of each suit is dealt here.
•4 Lower Ace foundations (below top Ace foundations) - build up in suit by twos to Jacks (Ace, 3, 5, 7, 9, Jack).  At the start of the game an Ace of each suit is dealt here.
•4 Twos foundations (left and right of Lower Ace foundations) - build up in suit by twos to Queens (2, 4, 6, 8, 10, Queen).  At the start of the game a Two of each suit is dealt here.
•4 King Piles (left and right of Top Ace foundations) - place a King of each suit in these piles, as they become available.
•16 tableau piles (under the foundations) - top card is available for play on the foundations.  No building.  Spaces are immediately filled from the waste, or the stock if the waste is empty.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (left, face down) - Turn over 1 card to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (under stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations.

Similar Games

Twenty

Carpet

Rueil

Rueil

 Top  Previous  Next

4 Decks.  Medium (20%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•16 foundation piles (across top, left, right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.   Groups of cards can be moved if they are in sequence down in suit.  Spaces filled by any card.  At the start of the game 8 cards are dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  One redeal.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Rueil is an easier version of Malmaison.

Similar Games

Bonmaison

Malmaison

Josephine

Marie Rose

Eighty Thieves

Runner

Runner

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (25%)  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Aces to Kings. At the beginning of the game the Aces are dealt here.
•5 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are filled from the reserve if possible, then by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time, by clicking.  2 redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card always available for play on the tableau or foundations.
•reserve (left of tableau) - Top card always available for play on the tableau or foundations.  At the start of the game 16 cards are dealt here.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Runner is an easier variation of Acme.

Similar Games

Acme

Canfield

Coyote

Rush Left

Rush Left

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (25%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•9 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces are filled automatically by the face up card or group of cards in the pile immediately to the right of the open space.  The rightmost pile, if empty, may be filled with a King or a legal group of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 to the 2nd pile, and so on.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 3 cards at a time to the waste by clicking during the first deal, 2 cards at a time during the 2nd deal, and 1 card at a time during the last deal.  Two redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Rush Left is a combination of Moving Left and Gold Rush.

Similar Games

Moving Left

Gold Rush

Russian Cell

Russian Cell

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (45%).   Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Move groups of cards regardless of any sequence.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd pile, and so on.  The top card is face up.  Then 4 additional face up cards are dealt to the 2nd through 7th piles.
•2 cells (top left) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Any face up card in the tableau may be built upon another, no matter how deep it is in a pile.  All cards covering it are moved together.  When a face down card is uncovered, it is automatically turned face up and is available for play.

History

Russian Cell is a variation of Russian Solitaire invented by Thomas Warfield.  The addition of 2 cells to Russian Solitaire makes a difficult game slightly easier.

Similar Games

Yukon

Russian Solitaire

Ukrainian Solitaire

Russian Twist

Russian Solitaire

Russian Solitaire

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (5%).   Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Move groups of cards regardless of any sequence.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd pile, and so on.  The top card is face up.  Then 4 additional face up cards are dealt to the 2nd through 7th piles.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Any face up card in the tableau may be built upon another, no matter how deep it is in a pile.  All cards covering it are moved together.  When a face down card is uncovered, it is automatically turned face up and is available for play.

History

Russian Solitaire is a variation of Yukon.  It is even more challenging that Yukon since the tableau is built down in suit rather than down by alternate color.  This gives the player half the possible moves that Yukon has.  This game is highly recommended for fans of Yukon.

Similar Games

Yukon

Double Russian

Russian Cell

Ukrainian Solitaire

Moosehide

Samara

Quadruple Russian

Russian Twist

Volga

Bonanza Creek

Russian Twist

Russian Twist

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck. Medium (35%).   Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Move groups of cards regardless of any sequence.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.   At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt to each pile, in the first and 10th piles, the top card is face up, in the 2nd and 9th piles 2 cards are face up, in the 3rd and 8th piles 3 cards are face up, in the 4th and 7th piles 4 cards are face up, and in the 5th and 6th piles all the cards are face up.
•2 cells (top left) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Any face up card in the tableau may be built upon another, no matter how deep it is in a pile.  All cards covering it are moved together.  When a face down card is uncovered, it is automatically turned face up and is available for play.

History

Russian Twist is a variation of Russian Solitaire.

Similar Games

Russian Solitaire

Yukon

Russian Cell

Samara

Salic Law

Salic Law

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (50%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 Queen foundations (across top) - Place Queens here as they come up in the deal. No building.
•8 Ace foundations (below top Queen foundations) - build up regardless of suit by from Aces to Jacks.
•8 tableau piles (under the foundations) - At the start of the game a King is dealt to the first pile.  Cards from the stock are placed on the first pile until another King appears (cards from the stock or tableau may be played to the foundations at any time if possible).  The next King is placed to begin the next tableau pile and the cards from the stock are played upon it until another King appears, and the process repeats until all the Kings appear and the stock is empty.  When the stock is empty, any Kings that have no cards played on them become open spaces.  Any single card can then be played on a bare King.  Otherwise after the stock is empty there is no building in the tableau.
•stock (left) - Move cards from here to the tableau.

Notes

•When dealing from the stock, all Aces and Queens should be immediately played to the foundations.  Kings must start a new tableau pile and all other cards must be played to the current King pile or to the foundations, if possible. Tableau piles will have differing numbers of cards in them depending on how the Kings play out.
•This game is entirely mechanical except for deciding whether to play cards to the foundations or not.  The skill in the game is deciding when it is best to leave a card in the tableau.

Sally

Sally

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (75%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top) -  build up in suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•11 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color, wrapping from Ace to King if necessary.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Fill spaces with a card or group of cards headed by a card of the rank one less than the rank of the first card dealt to the first foundation pile (Kings if the foundation base is an Ace).  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 to the 2nd pile, and so on.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 3 cards at a time to the waste, by clicking.  Unlimited redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Sally is a variation of Double Klondike.

Similar Games

Double Klondike

Gargantua

Samara

Samara

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (10%).   Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Move groups of cards regardless of any sequence.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt the first pile,  3 cards to the 2nd pile, 5 to the 3rd, 7 to the 4th, 5 to the 5th, 3 to the 6th, and 1 to the 7th.  The top card is face up.

 

•stock (top left, face down) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Any face up card in the tableau may be built upon another, no matter how deep it is in a pile.  All cards covering it are moved together.  When a face down card is uncovered, it is automatically turned face up and is available for play.

History

Samara is a variation of Russian Solitaire.

Similar Games

Russian Solitaire

Yukon

San Juan Hill

San Juan Hill

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (20%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.  At the beginning of the game the Aces are dealt here.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved. Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

San Juan Hill is Forty Thieves with the Aces dealt to the foundations, making it an easier game.

Similar Games

Kettle Hill

Forty Thieves

Cadran

Josephine

Saratoga

Saratoga

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (25%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards with a King at the bottom.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.  All cards are dealt face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 3 cards at a time, by clicking.  Unlimited redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Saratoga is Klondike with all the cards in the tableau visible.

Similar Games

Klondike

Yorktown

Saxony

Saxony

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Easy (90%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.  An Ace is dealt to each pile at the start of the game.
•8 tableau piles (face up in the middle) - top card is available for play on the foundations or reserves.  Spaces are not filled.  No building.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•8 reserve piles (left and right sides) - on the left 4 piles build down in suit, on the right 4 piles each pile can contain only 1 card (no building).  Spaces can be filled by any card.  Top card is available for play on the foundations or other reserves.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top, face down) - clicking deals 1 card to each tableau pile.  No redeals.

Options

AutoPlay

 

History

Saxony is a variation of Tournament.

Similar Games

Tournament

Kingsdown Eights

Scorpion

Scorpion

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (35%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards into 4 sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace within the tableau.

Layout

•7 tableau piles (top) - build down in suit.  Groups of cards (regardless of any sequence) can be moved.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King (see KingOnly for option).  At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt to each pile.  In the first 4 piles, 3 cards are face down and 4 face up, in the next 3 piles all cards are face up.

 

•reserve (top left, face down) - Clicking deals 1 card to each of the first 3 tableau piles (this can be done only once).

Options

KingOnly

Notes

•Any face up card, regardless of where in a pile it is, can be moved, along with all cards above it (this is like Yukon).

Tips

•It is imperative that the face down cards be uncovered as soon as possible.  There are often several choices of builds to make and it is beneficial to work through possibilities.  This is very much a game of skill, and it is difficult.

History

This game is related to Spider.   The first reference to Scorpion is in the 1949 book The Complete Book of Solitaire & Patience Games.

Similar Games

Scorpion II

Double Scorpion

Scorpion Tail

Spider

Antares

Applegate

Scorpion Head

Three Blind Mice

Triple Scorpion

Suits in Line

Book Scorpion

Quadruple Scorpion

Scorpion Row

Serket

Wood Scorpion

Scorpion Cells

Scorpion Cells

Scorpion Cells

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (80%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards into 4 sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace within the tableau.

Layout

•7 tableau piles (top) - build down in suit.  Groups of cards (regardless of any sequence) can be moved.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt to each pile.  In the first 4 piles, 3 cards are face down and 4 face up, in the next 3 piles all cards are face up.

 

•reserve (top left, face down) - Clicking deals 1 card to each of the first 3 tableau piles (this can be done only once).

 

•3 cells (left) - storage location for one card.   Only 1 card allowed in each cell.

Notes

•Any face up card, regardless of where in a pile it is, can be moved, along with all cards above it (this is like Yukon).

Tips

•It is imperative that the face down cards be uncovered as soon as possible.  There are often several choices of builds to make and it is beneficial to work through possibilities.  This is very much a game of skill, and it is difficult.

History

This is Scorpion with 3 cells.

Similar Games

Scorpion

Scorpion II

Scorpion Head

Scorpion II

Scorpion II

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (65%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards into 4 sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace within the tableau.

Layout

•7 tableau piles (top) - build down in suit.  Groups of cards (regardless of any sequence) can be moved.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King (see KingOnly for option).  At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt to each pile.  In the first 3 piles, 3 cards are face down and 4 face up, in the next 4 piles all cards are face up.

 

•reserve (top left, face down) - Clicking deals 1 card to each of the first 3 tableau piles (this can be done only once).

Options

KingOnly

Notes

•Any face up card, regardless of where in a pile it is, can be moved, along with all cards above it (this is like Yukon).

Tips

•It is imperative that the face down cards be uncovered as soon as possible.  There are often several choices of builds to make and it is beneficial to work through possibilities.  This is very much a game of skill, and it is difficult.

History

Scorpion II is a variation of Scorpion.  It varies from Scorpion only in how the cards are initially dealt.

Similar Games

Scorpion

Scorpion Row

Scorpion Head

Scorpion Head

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (50%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards into 4 sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace within the tableau.

Layout

•  7 tableau piles (top) - build down in suit.  Groups of cards (regardless of any sequence) can be moved.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 8 cards are dealt face up to the first 3 piles, in the rest of the piles 4 cards are face down and 3 cards are face up.

 

4 cells (left) - storage location for one card.   Only 1 card allowed in each cell.

Notes

•Any face up card, regardless of where in a pile it is, can be moved, along with all cards above it (this is like Yukon).

History

Scorpion Head is similar to Scorpion with cells.

Similar Games

Scorpion Towers

Scorpion Row

Scorpion Row

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (35%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards into 4 sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace within the tableau.

Layout

•7 tableau piles (top) - build down in suit.  Groups of cards (regardless of any sequence) can be moved.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King (see KingOnly for option).  At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt to each pile, the first card is face down and the remaining 6 cards are face up.

 

•reserve (top left, face down) - Clicking deals 1 card to each of the first 3 tableau piles (this can be done only once).

Options

KingOnly

Notes

•Any face up card, regardless of where in a pile it is, can be moved, along with all cards above it (this is like Yukon).

Tips

•It is imperative that the face down cards be uncovered as soon as possible.  There are often several choices of builds to make and it is beneficial to work through possibilities.  This is very much a game of skill, and it is difficult.

History

This is Scorpion with only one row of face down cards.

Similar Games

Scorpion

Scorpion II

Scorpion Tail

Scorpion Tail

Scorpion Tail

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (65%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards into 4 sets of 13 cards in sequence down by alternate color from King to Ace within the tableau.

Layout

•7 tableau piles (top) - build down by alternate color.  Groups of cards (regardless of any sequence) can be moved.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt to each pile.  In the first 4 piles, 3 cards are face down and 4 face up, in the next 3 piles all cards are face up.

 

•reserve (top left, face down) - Clicking deals 1 card to each of the first 3 tableau piles (this can be done only once).

Notes

•Any face up card, regardless of where in a pile it is, can be moved, along with all cards above it (this is like Yukon).

Tips

•It is imperative that the face down cards be uncovered as soon as possible.  There are often several choices of builds to make and it is beneficial to work through possibilities.  This is very much a game of skill, and it is difficult.

History

Scorpion Tail is Scorpion with building down by alternate color rather than down in suit.

Similar Games

Scorpion

Scorpion Towers

Scorpion Towers

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (85%).  All Skill.

Object

To group all the cards into 4 sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace within the tableau.

Layout

•4 cells (top center) - storage location for one card.   Only 1 card allowed in each cell.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the center two cells.
•10 tableau piles (below cells) - build down in suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit OR if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.  That is, any group of cards in sequence down in suit can be moved, or also any group of cards regardless of sequence if there are enough open cells or tableau spaces to move the cards individually.  Spaces can only be filled by Kings or legal groups of cards headed by a King, until all 4 Kings are heading a column, at which time spaces can then be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt face up to each pile.

 

Options

AutoPlay

Tips

•Creating empty spaces in the tableau is the key to victory.  The more empty spaces there are, the more cards you can move as a group.  Also, keep as few cards in the cells as possible as this also allows more cards to be moved.

History

Scorpion Towers is a cross between Scorpion and Sea Towers invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Scorpion

Sea Towers

Scorpion Head

Sea Scorpion

Lake Towers

Towers of Ilium

Scotch Patience

Scotch Patience

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (30%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (right) - build up by alternate color from Ace to King.
•18 tableau piles (left of foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are not filled.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt face up to each pile.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Scotch Patience is a member of the Baker's Dozen and Fan families of games.

Similar Games

Fan

La Belle Lucie

Baker's Dozen

Scottish Canister

Scottish Canister

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (80%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•2 cells (top left) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.

 

•8 tableau piles (below foundations and cells) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.   At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt face up to the leftmost 4 piles, 6 cards are dealt face up to the remaining piles.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Groups of cards in the tableau in sequence down by alternate color can be moved as a group regardless of the number of empty cells.  This is different from most FreeCell type games and makes the game easier than Two Cells.
•The game number deals #1 to #1000000 are compatible with the games in the standard Windows FreeCell.  For more information about FreeCell type games, see http://www.freecell.org.

History

Scottish Canister is Two Cells with unlimited group moving.

Similar Games

Two Cells

American Canister

British Canister

FreeCell

Three Cells

Sea Scorpion

Sea Scorpion

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (90%).  All Skill.

Object

To group all the cards into 4 sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace within the tableau.

Layout

•4 cells (top center) - storage location for one card.   Only 1 card allowed in each cell. .
•10 tableau piles (below cells) - build down in suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit OR if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.  That is, any group of cards in sequence down in suit can be moved, or also any group of cards regardless of sequence if there are enough open cells or tableau spaces to move the cards individually.  Spaces can only be filled by Kings or legal groups of cards headed by a King, until all 4 Kings are heading a column, at which time spaces can then be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt face up to each pile, except for the first and last pile, which are dealt 6 cards.

 

Options

AutoPlay

Tips

•Creating empty spaces in the tableau is the key to victory.  The more empty spaces there are, the more cards you can move as a group.  Also, keep as few cards in the cells as possible as this also allows more cards to be moved.

History

Sea Scorpion is a slightly easier variation of Scorpion Towers.

Similar Games

Scorpion

Sea Towers

Scorpion Towers

Lake Towers

Sea Towers

Sea Towers

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (94%).  All Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top, 2 on far left, 2 on far right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•4 cells (top center) - storage location for one card.   Only 1 card allowed in each cell.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the center two cells.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations and cells) - build down in suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit and if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.  Spaces can be filled by any card or legal group of cards (see KingOnly for option).  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt face up to each pile.

 

Options

AutoPlay   KingOnly

Notes

•Groups of cards in the tableau can only be moved as a group if there are a sufficient number of empty cells available to store the cards individually.  The ability to move cards as a group is only a shortcut to moving the group one card at a time.

Tips

•Try to keep as many cells empty as possible.

History

Sea Towers is very similar to FreeCell.  It was invented by Art Cabral.

Similar Games

FreeCell

Double SeaTowers

Baker's Game

ForeCell

Eight Off

Lake Towers

Selective Canfield

Selective Canfield

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (50%)  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) -  build up in suit from the rank of the first card moved to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•4 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces are filled from the reserve if possible, then by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 3 cards at a time, by clicking.  Unlimited redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card always available for play on the tableau or foundations.
•reserve (left of tableau) - Top card always available for play on the tableau or foundations.  At the start of the game 13 cards are dealt here.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Play begins by selecting one card from the 4 available cards in the tableau and the top card of the reserve and moving it to the leftmost foundation to be the base card of the foundations.

History

Selective Canfield is Canfield without a card dealt to the foundations at the start of the game.  Instead, you have your choice of the first card played to the foundations, which adds an extra element of skill to the game.

Similar Games

Canfield

Superior Canfield

Selective Castle

Selective Castle

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (15%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (middle) - build up in suit from the rank of the first card moved to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•8 tableau piles (around foundations) - build down regardless of suit, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary.  Only the top card of each pile is available for play.  Spaces may be filled by any available card.  At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt face up to the first 4 piles, 6 cards to the next 4 piles.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Selective Castle is Beleaguered Castle without the Aces dealt to the foundations at the start of the game.  Instead, you have your choice of the first card played to the foundations, which adds an extra element of skill to the game.

Similar Games

Beleaguered Castle

Chessboard

Selective FreeCell

Selective FreeCell

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Easy (>99%).  Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from the rank of the first card moved to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•4 cells (top left) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.

 

•8 tableau piles (below foundations and cells) - build down by alternate color, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color and if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.  Spaces can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt face up to the leftmost 4 piles, 6 cards are dealt face up to the remaining piles.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Groups of cards in the tableau can only be moved as a group if there are a sufficient number of empty cells available to store the cards individually.  The ability to move cards as a group is only a shortcut to moving the group one card at a time.

History

Selective FreeCell is a variation of FreeCell where you have your choice of the first card played to the foundations, which adds an extra element of skill to the game.

Similar Games

FreeCell

Senate

Senate

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (18%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.  At the start of the game the Aces are dealt here.
•4 tableau piles (across top on left) - build down in suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit. Spaces may be filled by any card from the reserve piles .  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (top right, face down) - deals 1 card to each reserve pile by clicking. No redeals.
•8 reserve piles (middle) - cards are dealt here from the stock.  The cards are available for play on the foundations or tableau. No building.

Options

AutoPlay

Similar Games

Kingsdown Eights

Cicely

Tournament

Algerian Patience

Senior Wrangler

Senior Wrangler

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Deck.  Hard (2%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (middle) - build first pile up regardless of suit by ones, second pile up regardless of suit by twos, third pile up regardless of suit by threes, and fourth pile up regardless of suit by fours, etc..  See chart below.  At the start of the game an Ace, Two, Three, and Four, Five, Six, Seven, and Eight are dealt above each pile as an indicator for the building interval of the pile below.

1:  A 2 3 4 5 6 7 8 9 T J Q K

2:  2 4 6 8 T Q A 3 5 7 9 J K

3:  3 6 9 Q 2 5 8 J A 4 7 T K

  4:  4 8 Q 3 7 J 2 6 T A 5 9 K

  5:  5 10 2 7 Q 4 9 A 6 J 3 8 K

  6:  6 Q 5 J 4 10 3 9 2 8 A 7 K

  7:  7 A 8 2 9 3 10 4 J 5 Q 6 K

  8:  8 3 J 6 A 9 4 Q 7 2 10 5 K

•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - No building.  The top card of each pile is available for play on the foundations.
•stock (top, no cards) - Click to redeal.  On the first redeal, all the remaining cards in the first tableau pile are picked up and redealt to the tableau starting with the first pile.  On the 2nd redeal, all the remaining cards in the 2nd tableau pile are picked up and redealt to the tableau starting with the 2nd pile, and so on.  There are 8 redeals.

Similar Games

Calculation

Serket

Serket

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (40%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards into 4 sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace within the tableau.

Layout

•8 tableau piles (top) - build down in suit.  Groups of cards (regardless of any sequence) can be moved.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt to each pile.  In the first 4 piles, 3 cards are face down and 3 face up, in the next 4 piles all cards are face up.

 

•reserve (top left, face down) - Clicking deals 1 card to each of the first 4 tableau piles (this can be done only once).

Notes

•Any face up card, regardless of where in a pile it is, can be moved, along with all cards above it (this is like Yukon).

Tips

•It is imperative that the face down cards be uncovered as soon as possible.  There are often several choices of builds to make and it is beneficial to work through possibilities.  This is very much a game of skill, and it is difficult.

History

Serket is an 8 pile version of Scorpion invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Scorpion

Wood Scorpion

Seven and Ten

Seven and Ten

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (10%).   Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.

 

•10 tableau piles (below foundations) -  build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color and there are enough empty tableau piles that the cards could be moved individually.  Spaces are filled by any card.  At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt to the first 7 piles, then one card to the final 3 piles.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Seven and Ten is a variation of Good Measure with FreeCell characteristics.

Similar Games

Good Measure

FreeCell

Seven by Five

Seven by Five

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Easy (99%).  Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•5 cells (top) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.

 

•7 tableau piles (below cells) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color and if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.  Spaces can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 8 cards are dealt face up to the leftmost 3 piles, 7 cards are dealt face up to the remaining piles.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Groups of cards in the tableau can only be moved as a group if there are a sufficient number of empty cells available to store the cards individually.  The ability to move cards as a group is only a shortcut to moving the group one card at a time.

Tips

•Try to keep as many cells empty as possible.

History

Seven by Five is a variant of FreeCell.

Seven by Four

Seven by Three

Seven by Four

Seven by Four

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Easy (99%).  Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•4 cells (top left) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.

 

•7 tableau piles (below foundations and cells) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color and if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.  Spaces can be filled by any card or legal group of cards (see KingOnly for option).  At the start of the game 8 cards are dealt face up to the leftmost 3 piles, 7 cards are dealt face up to the remaining piles.

Options

KingOnly AutoPlay

Notes

•Groups of cards in the tableau can only be moved as a group if there are a sufficient number of empty cells available to store the cards individually.  The ability to move cards as a group is only a shortcut to moving the group one card at a time.

Tips

•Try to keep as many cells empty as possible.

History

Seven by Four is FreeCell with seven tableau piles instead of eight, making it a somewhat harder game.

Similar Games

FreeCell

Seven by Five

Seven by Three

Seven by Seven

Seven by Seven

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (50%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•3 cells (left) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.

 

•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build up or down by suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence up or down by suit and if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.  Spaces can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left) - clicking redeals the tableau. The cards are picked up starting with the rightmost pile moving to the left, with the cards in the cells picked up last.  The cards are then redealt out to the tableau a row at a time, starting with the cards that were in the cells, then the cards that were in the leftmost tableau pile and ending with the cards that were in the rightmost tableau pile, then the last 3 cards are dealt to the cells.  The result is that cards that were in the cells or on the left side end up buried deepest in the piles, while the cards that were on the right side end up on top of the piles.  Two redeals.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Groups of cards in the tableau can only be moved as a group if there are a sufficient number of empty cells available to store the cards individually.  The ability to move cards as a group is only a shortcut to moving the group one card at a time.

History

Seven by Seven is of Danish origin.

Similar Games

FreeCell

Seven by Seven Alt

Seven by Seven Alt

Seven by Seven Alt

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (50%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•3 cells (left) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.

 

•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color and if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.  Spaces can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left) - clicking redeals the tableau. The cards are picked up starting with the rightmost pile moving to the left, with the cards in the cells picked up last.  The cards are then redealt out to the tableau a row at a time, starting with the cards that were in the cells, then the cards that were in the leftmost tableau pile and ending with the cards that were in the rightmost tableau pile, then the last 3 cards are dealt to the cells.  The result is that cards that were in the cells or on the left side end up buried deepest in the piles, while the cards that were on the right side end up on top of the piles.  Two redeals.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Groups of cards in the tableau can only be moved as a group if there are a sufficient number of empty cells available to store the cards individually.  The ability to move cards as a group is only a shortcut to moving the group one card at a time.

History

Seven by Seven Alt is a variation of Seven by Seven, where the tableau building is done via the more normal rule of down by alternate color, making it more like a typical FreeCell type game.

Similar Games

FreeCell

Seven by Three

Seven by Three

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Easy (97%).  Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•3 cells (top left) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.

 

•7 tableau piles (below foundations and cells) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color and if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.  Spaces can be filled by any card or legal group of cards (see KingOnly for option).  At the start of the game 8 cards are dealt face up to the leftmost 3 piles, 7 cards are dealt face up to the remaining piles.

Options

KingOnly AutoPlay

Notes

•Groups of cards in the tableau can only be moved as a group if there are a sufficient number of empty cells available to store the cards individually.  The ability to move cards as a group is only a shortcut to moving the group one card at a time.

Tips

•Try to keep as many cells empty as possible.

History

Seven by Three is FreeCell with seven tableau piles instead of eight and only three cells, making it a harder game.

Seven Devils

Seven Devils

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Very Hard (<1%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•reserve (left, under foundations) - any card is available for play on the foundations only, by double-clicking or right-clicking on the card.  To move a card that is not the top card, click on it to move it to the top of the pile.  At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt face up to this pile (these are the "Seven Devils").
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces filled by any card not from the reserve.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 to the 2nd, and so on.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left) - turn over 1 card to waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Seven Devils is a 2 pack cross between Klondike and Canfield.  It is an extremely difficult game to win.

Similar Games

Seven Steps

Seven Saints

Klondike

Canfield

The Plot

Seven Piles

Seven Piles

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (15%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To pair up all cards and move them out of play.

Layout

•7 Piles (surprise!) - discard pairs of cards that add to 13, Kings singly.  The top card of each pile is available.  At the start of the game 4 cards are deal to the outer 4 piles, and 5 card dealt to the innermost 2 piles.  All cards are face up.
•stock (far right, face down) - clicking deals 1 card to each of the 7 piles.

Notes

•Any pair of cards whose values add to 13 can be discarded.  The valid pairs are Queen-Ace, Jack-Two, 10-3, 9-4, 8-5, 7-6.  Kings are discarded singly.  To discards Kings, simply click on them.  When all possible pairs are discarded, deal another set of 5 cards onto the piles by clicking on the Stock.

 

History

Seven Piles is a variation of the classic game Five Piles.

Similar Games

Five Piles

Thirteens

Pyramid

Five Stacks

Seven Saints

Seven Saints

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (5%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•reserve (left, under foundations) - any card is available for play on the foundations only, by double-clicking or right-clicking on the card.  To move a card that is not the top card, click on it to move it to the top of the pile.  At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt face up to this pile (these are the "Seven Saints").
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces filled by any card or sequence of cards not from the reserve.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 to the 2nd, and so on.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left) - turn over 1 card to waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Seven Saints is an easier version of Seven Devils.

Similar Games

Seven Devils

Seven Steps

Klondike

Canfield

The Plot

Seven Steps

Seven Steps

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (20%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•reserve (left, under foundations) - any card is available for play on the foundations or on an empty tableau pile.  At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt face up to this pile (these are the "Seven Steps").
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces may be filled by any card or sequence of cards from another tableau pile or from the reserve.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 to the 2nd, and so on.  The top card is face up.
•stock (bottom left) - turn over 1 card to waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Seven Steps is a cross between Seven Devils and Steps invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Seven Devils

Steps

Seven Saints

Seventeens

Seventeens

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (30%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To discard all the cards.

Layout

•13 tableau piles - the top card is available for play.  Discard pairs of cards that have ranks that add to 17. Aces, Twos, and Threes are discarded as a set (A-2-3).  Spaces are automatically filled from the stock in the center 3 piles, otherwise in the outer 10 piles spaces are not filled.   To discard a set of cards, move each card to the reserve pile in the lower left.  When a A-2-3 set is formed, or when pairs of cards of rank 4 or over add to 17, the cards are automatically discarded to the waste pile.   As a shortcut, pairs of cards that add to 17 (4-K, 5-Q, 6-J, 7-10, 8-9) can be discarded by dropping one on the other.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt face up to 10 piles, 1 card is dealt face up to the center 3 piles.
•stock (face down, left) - fills spaces in the tableau.
•waste (far right)  - Where paired cards go out of play.
•reserve (lower left) - where sets of cards are formed.

Valid Discards

•A-2-3, 4-K, 5-Q, 6-J, 7-10, 8-9

History

Seventeens was invented by Randy Rasa.

Similar Games

Fourteen Out

Fifteens

Eighteens

Friday

The Ides of March

Seymour

Seymour

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (50%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces are filled by a card or legal group of cards headed by a card one rank below the foundation base card.  At the start of the game, 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, up to 7 cards dealt to the 7th pile.  Only the top card of each pile is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - Deals 1 card to each reserve pile, by clicking.  No redeals.
•7 reserve piles (bottom) - top card is available for play on the tableau or foundations. No building.

History

Seymour is a variation of Agnes Bernauer.

Similar Games

Agnes Bernauer

King Albert

Shady Lanes

Shady Lanes

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (14%).  Skill/Luck Balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (left) - build up in color from Ace to King.  At the start of the game the 8 Aces are dealt here.
•4 tableau piles (top) - build down by alternate color.  Only one card at a time may be moved.   Spaces are filled only from the reserve piles.    At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (middle right, face down) - move 1 card to waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (below stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or non-empty tableau piles.
•4 reserve piles (far right) - No building.  Each pile may hold only one card.  The card is available for play on the foundations or tableau. Spaces are filled automatically from the waste, or if the waste is empty, the stock.

Options

AutoPlay

Similar Games

Squadron

Shamrocks

Shamrocks

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (40%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•18 fans (below foundations) - build up or down regardless of suit, with a limit of 3 cards per fan.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are not filled.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt face up to each pile, except the last pile, which is dealt one card.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•The maximum of 3 cards in a fan means that at the beginning of the game, if no Ace can be played to a foundation, and no card can be played on top of the single card, the position is blocked.

Tips

•The foundations should be kept as even as possible; don't play cards to the foundations until necessary.

History

Shamrocks is similar to La Belle Lucie, but is easier to win.

Similar Games

La Belle Lucie

Three Shuffles and a Draw

Fan

Trefoil

Clover Leaf

Super Flower Garden

Lucky Fan

Leprechaun

Shaula

Shaula

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck. Medium (50%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•4 cells (top left) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.

 

•8 tableau piles (below foundations and cells) - on the left most 4 piles (called the Forty Thieves piles), build down in suit.  Groups of cards down in suit can be moved as a unit.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.  On the rightmost 4 piles (called the FreeCell piles), build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt face up to the Forty Thieves piles, 7 cards are dealt face up to the FreeCell piles.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•The tableau piles are divided into two parts: the Forty Thieves piles (left) and the FreeCell piles (right), divided by a line.  The Forty Thieves piles are built down in suit while the FreeCell piles are built down by alternate color. Groups of cards may be moved from one tableau pile to another, if they form a legal sequence in their current pile.  For example, a sequence down by alternate color may be moved from the FreeCell piles to the Forty Thieves piles, since that is the legal sequence for the FreeCell piles.  Also, any group of cards may be moved from the Forty Thieves piles to the FreeCell piles (assuming the head card of the group can be moved there).   These kinds of groups transfers are called "shifts".  Shifts of groups down by alternate color are allowed from FreeCell piles to Forty  Thieves piles, while shifts of groups down in suit are allowed from Forty Thieves piles to FreeCell piles.  Once a shift has been made from Forty Thieves piles to FreeCell piles, the cards in the groups cannot again be moved as a group unless they are of sequence down by alternate color.

 

Tips

•Try to keep as many cells empty as possible.

History

Shaula is a variation of the game Antares was invented by Thomas Warfield.  It is named after the 2nd brightest star in the constellation Scorpius.

Similar Games

Antares

FreeCell

Demons and Thieves

Shifting

Shifting

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (44%).  Skill/luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (across top) - build up regardless of suit from Ace to King.
•4 tableau piles (below foundations) - cards are played here from the stock.  A card from the stock may be played to any tableau pile.  The top card of each tableau pile is available for play on the foundations or built down regardless of suit on another tableau pile.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are filled by a card from the stock or by a King.
•stock (face up on left) - Top card is available for play on the tableau or foundations.  No redeals.

History

Shifting is a version of Sir Tommy.  Unlike Sir Tommy, cards may be shifted among the tableau piles.

Similar Games

Sir Tommy

Auld Lang Syne

Shining Star

Shining Star

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks. Medium (75%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (left) - build up in suit from Ace to King.  At the start of the game the Aces are dealt here.
•13 tableau piles (to the right of the foundations) - build down by alternate color. Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Shining Star is similar to Lucas and Waning Moon.

Similar Games

Waning Moon

Limited

Forty Thieves

Old Moon

Shuffle

Shuffle

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (50%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To discard cards in pairs until the stock is empty.

Layout

•8 tableau piles - the top card is available for play.  Pair up cards that have ranks that are adjacent (up or down regardless of suit).  Aces are adjacent to Kings.  Spaces are automatically filled from the stock.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (face down, left) - fills spaces in the tableau.
•waste (bottom)  - Where paired cards go out of play.

Siberia

Siberia

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (70%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards into 4 sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace within the tableau.

Layout

•7 tableau piles (top) - build down in suit, wrapping King on Ace if necessary.  Groups of cards may be moved regardless of any sequence.  Fill spaces with Kings or a group of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd pile, and so on.
•stock (top left, face down) -Deal one card to each tableau pile, by clicking.  No redeals.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Siberia was invented by Anne Warfield.

Similar Games

Ukrainian Solitaire

Queenie

Signora

Signora

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (30%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (middle) - build up by alternate color from the rank of first card moved to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•9 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color, wrapping from Ace to King if necessary.  Only the top card of each pile may be moved.  Spaces are filled automatically from the waste, or stock if the waste is empty.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•reserve (top) - top card is available for play on the foundations only. At the start of the game 11 cards are dealt here.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over cards 1 at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•The game begins by choosing a card to move to the first foundation pile.  The rank of this card becomes the base card for all the other

foundation piles.  This first move is very important.

History

Signora is a variation of Blondes and Brunettes and Terrace.

Similar Games

Double Signora

Roman Patience

Madame

Blondes and Brunettes

Terrace

Silver Mine

Silver Mine

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (80%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Fill spaces with any card. At the start of the game all of the tableau piles are empty.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 3 cards at a time to the waste by clicking.  One redeal.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Silver Mine is the game Gold Mine with a redeal.
