Simon Jester

Simon Jester

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (75%). Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards into 8 sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace within the tableau.

Layout

•14 tableau piles - build down regardless of suit.  Groups of cards in sequence down in suit may be moved as a unit.  Spaces are filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 13 cards are dealt face up to the first 2 piles, 12 cards to the 3rd pile, 11 cards to the 4th pile, and so on until 1 card is dealt to the last pile.

Tips

•Same suit sequences should be preferred even though building is down regardless of suit.  The object is to build in suit sequences.

History

Simon Jester is a two deck variation of Simple Simon.  It was invented by Adam Selene.

Similar Games

Simple Simon

Scorpion

Simon Says

Simon Says

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (85%). Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards into 4 sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace within the tableau.

Layout

•8 tableau piles - build down regardless of suit, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary.  Groups of cards in sequence down in suit may be moved as a unit.  Spaces are filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt face up to the leftmost 4 piles, 6 cards are dealt face up to the remaining piles.

 

•2 cells (top left) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.

 

Tips

•Same suit sequences should be preferred even though building is down regardless of suit.  The object is to build in suit sequences.

History

Simon Says is a varation of Simple Simon with some elements of FreeCell invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Simple Simon

Simon Jester

FreeCell

Simple Pairs

Simple Pairs

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (37%).  All Luck.

Object

To discard all the cards in pairs.

Layout

•9 tableau piles - the top card is available for play.  Pair up cards of the same rank.  Spaces are automatically filled from the stock.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (face down, left) - fills spaces in the tableau.
•waste (under stock)  - Where paired cards go out of play.

History

Simple Pairs was probably one of the first pairing games. Vertical and Nestor are more complicated versions of this type of game.

Similar Games

Vertical

Nestor

Block Ten

Simple Simon

Simple Simon

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (82%). Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards into 4 sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace within the tableau.

Layout

•10 tableau piles - build down regardless of suit.  Groups of cards in sequence down in suit may be moved as a unit.  Spaces are filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 8 cards are dealt face up to the first 3 piles, 7 cards to the 4th pile, 6 cards to the 5th pile, and so on until 1 card is dealt to the last pile.

Tips

•Same suit sequences should be preferred even though building is down regardless of suit.  The object is to build in suit sequences.

History

Simple Simon bears some resemblance to Scorpion.

Similar Games

Scorpion

Spider

Simon Jester

Simon Says

Simplex

Simplex

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Easy (99%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundation.

Layout

•1 foundation pile (top) - sets of 4 cards of the same rank are moved here automatically.
•9 tableau piles  - build cards of the same rank.  For example, a Jack can be played on another Jack.  The top card of each pile is available for play.  When all 4 cards of the same rank are built, the cards are automatically removed to the foundation.  Spaces are filled automatically by the top card of the waste (or the stock if the waste is empty).  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top, face down) - deal 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the tableau.

History

Simplex is a very easy game of building cards of the same rank.

Similar Games

Polytope

Simplicity

Simplicity

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Easy (>99%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (in the 4 corners) - build up in suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•12 tableau piles (middle) - build down by alternate color.  The top card of each pile is available for play.  Spaces are filled with any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top, face down) - deal 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Simplicity is a variation of Four Seasons.  It is very easy to win.

Similar Games

Four Seasons

Single Interchange

Single Interchange

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (4%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•5 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.   At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt to each pile, alternating face up and face down.
•stock (face down) - turn over cards one at a time to the waste by clicking.  Unlimited redeals.
•waste (beside stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Single Interchange is a one deck version of Interchange invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Interchange

Quadruple Interchange

Unlimited

Single Interchange Cell

Single Interchange Cell

Single Interchange Cell

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (30%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•5 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.   At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt to each pile, alternating face up and face down.
•stock (face down) - turn over cards one at a time to the waste by clicking.  Unlimited redeals.
•waste (beside stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.

 

•1 cell (top left) - storage location for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in the cell.  The card is available for play on the tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Single Interchange Cell is an easier version of the game Single Interchange.

Similar Games

Single Interchange

Interchange

Quadruple Interchange

Unlimited

Single Left

Single Left

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (15%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces are filled automatically by the face up card or group of cards in the pile immediately to the right of the open space.  The rightmost pile, if empty, may be filled with a King or a legal group of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 to the 2nd pile, and so on.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over cards one at a time to the waste, by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Single Left is a one deck variation of Moving Left.  It is essentially Klondike with no redeals and an unusual method of filling empty spaces in the tableau.  Single Left was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Moving Left

Triple Left

Klondike

Different Left

Quadruple Left

Single Plot

Single Plot

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (5%).  Skill/luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (right) - build up in suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.  No cards can be played on the 2nd through 4th piles until all 13 cards have been played to the first pile.  The first pile is offset to the left of the other 3 piles.
•7 tableau piles (center) - build down in suit, wrapping from Ace to King as necessary.  Groups of cards can be moved if they are in sequence down in suit.  Spaces may be filled only from the waste.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.  Until the first foundation pile contains 13 cards, cards of the same rank as the first card of the first foundation pile cannot be built on other cards or built upon.
•stock (bottom left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste, by clicking.  One redeal.
•waste (below stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.
•reserve (top left, above stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt here.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Single Plot is a one deck variation of Family Plot.

Similar Games

Family Plot

The Plot

Single Rail

Single Rail

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (18%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•4 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Groups of cards may be moved if they are in sequence down regardless of suit.  Spaces are filled by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste pile by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Similar Games

Double Rail

Sleepers

Triple Rail

Single Spark

Single Spark

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (33%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (across top) - build down in suit from King to Ace.
•6 tableau piles (below foundations on right) - build up in suit.  Only top card available for play.  Empty piles can be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (below foundations, face down on left) - move 3 cards to each waste pile by clicking.  No redeals.
•2 waste piles (below stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt to each pile.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Note that the building foundations and tableau is highly unusual.  Building is backwards from most solitaire games.   Also, there are 2 waste piles rather than the usual one.

History

Single Spark is a variation of The Spark.

Similar Games

The Spark

Busy Aces

Sir Tommy

Sir Tommy

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (30%).  Skill/luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (across top) - build up regardless of suit from Ace to King.
•4 reserve piles (below foundations) - cards are played here from the stock.  The top card of each pile is available for play.  Move cards to the foundations by clicking.
•stock (face up on left) - Top card is available for play on the reserves or foundations.  No redeals.

Tips

•The skill in this game is deciding which reserve pile to put each card in.  You do not want to block yourself by putting higher cards on top of lower cards, unless absolutely necessary.

History

This is an old and classic solitaire game.  It is closely related to Auld Lang Syne, but requires more skill and is easier to win, and is also related to Strategy.

Similar Games

Auld Lang Syne

Strategy

Acquaintance

Lady Betty

Tam O'Shanter

Strategerie

Cup of Kindness

Six by Four

Six by Four

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (10%).  Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•4 cells (top left) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.

 

•6 tableau piles (below foundations and cells) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color and if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.  Spaces can be filled by any card or legal group of cards (see KingOnly for option).  At the start of the game 9 cards are dealt face up to the leftmost 4 piles, 8 cards are dealt face up to the remaining piles.

Options

KingOnly AutoPlay

Notes

•Groups of cards in the tableau can only be moved as a group if there are a sufficient number of empty cells available to store the cards individually.  The ability to move cards as a group is only a shortcut to moving the group one card at a time.

Tips

•Try to keep as many cells empty as possible.

History

Six by Four is FreeCell with six tableau piles instead of eight, making it a much harder game.

Similar Games

FreeCell

Seven by Four

Forty Eight and Cells

Three Strikes

Sixes and Sevens

Sixes and Sevens

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (37%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•16 foundation piles (on left) - build piles starting with Sixes down in suit to Aces, build piles starting with Sevens up in suit to Kings.  At the start of the game the Sixes and Sevens are dealt here.
•9 tableau piles (on right) - each pile can contain 1 card.  No building.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (bottom right, face down) - turn over 1 card to waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (bottom right, next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

This game is easy to win.  It is related to the Busy Aces family.

Similar Games

Busy Aces

Eights Down

Cast Out Nines

Dimes

Jacks in the Box

Sixteen

Sixteen

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (10%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top)  - build the first 4 piles up in suit from Ace to King, the last 4 down in suit from King to Ace.  At the start of the game an Ace and King of each suit is dealt here.
•16 tableau piles (below foundations) - top card is available for play on the foundations.  Spaces are filled automatically from the stock until the stock is empty, then spaces are filled by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.  No redeals.

History

Sixteen is a harder version of Twenty.

Similar Games

Twenty

Colorado

Carpet

Sixteen Piles

Sixteen Piles

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (50%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.  At the start of the game the Aces are dealt here.
•16 fans (below foundations) - Cards may be played on other cards of the same rank.   Spaces are not filled.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (upper left, no cards) -  There are two redeals.  After all possible plays have been made, redeal by clicking on the green arrow in the upper left corner.  All the cards in the fans are reshuffled. The foundations remain.  2 redeals.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Sixteen Piles is a Fan type game.

Similar Games

Fan

Linus

Sixteen Puzzle

Sixteen Puzzle

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks. Medium (22%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the tableau.

Layout

•16 tableau piles  - build down regardless of suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces can be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (center, face up) - top card is available for play on the tableau.

Notes

The idea is to get all of the cards in play by grouping cards in piles down regardless of suit, which brings more cards into play via the empty spaces created.  The game is won if all cards are moved from the stock onto the tableau.

History

Sixteen Puzzle is a variation of Trusty Twelve.  It was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Trusty Twelve

Sixteens

Sixteens

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (30%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To discard all the cards in pairs.

Layout

•20 Piles arranged in a 5x4 rectangle - discard pairs of cards that add to 16 that are adjacent to each other, either horizontally, vertically, or diagonally (to discard a pair, drop one of the cards on the other, or right-click on one of the cards). Discard Aces and Twos in a pair of one Ace and one Two.

Notes

•Pairs of cards that add to 16 are King-3, Queen-4, Jack-5, Ten-6, 9-7, 8-8.
•Whenever a pair is discarded, the remaining cards will be moved to the top in the following way: spaces are filled by moving cards to the left.  If there are spaces on a higher row, a card is moved from the leftmost pile of the lower row to the rightmost pile of the higher row.  New cards are dealt to fill the spaces at the bottom.  All the cards are moved in this way until all the spaces are at the bottom.

Valid Discards

•A-2, 3-K, 4-Q, 5-J, 6-10, 7-9, 8-8.

History

Sixteens is a variation of Monte Carlo.  It was invented by Randy Rasa.

Similar Games

Monte Carlo

Monaco

Sixty Bandits

Sixty Bandits

 Top  Previous  Next

3 Decks.  Hard (10%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•12 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•12 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Only one card at a time may be moved. Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Sixty Bandits is an easier version of Sixty Thieves.

Similar Games

Sixty Thieves

Forty Thieves

Marie Rose

Orwell

Sixty Thieves

Sixty Thieves

 Top  Previous  Next

3 Decks.  Hard (5%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•12 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•12 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved. Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Sixty Thieves is a 3 deck variation of Forty Thieves invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Forty Thieves

Marie Rose

Orwell

Skippy

Skippy

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Easy (98%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•16 fans (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved to the foundations or another fan, or a cell.  Spaces are filled only by cards of one rank below the foundation base.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•4 cells (left) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.  The card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.
•stock (top left, face down) - Move cards to the waste by 1 at a time by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste piles (next to stock) - Top card is available for play on the foundations, fans, or cells.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Skippy was invented by Lillian Davies and Christa Baran.

Sleepers

Sleepers

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (30%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•6 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Groups of cards may be moved if they are in sequence down regardless of suit.  Spaces are filled by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste pile by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Similar Games

The Bold

Small Triangle

Small Triangle

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (20%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King. At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - deal 1 card to each tableau pile, by clicking.  No redeals.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Small Triangle is Klondike with a stock that deals one card to each tableau pile.  It is a one deck version of Hypotenuse.

Similar Games

Klondike

Hypotenuse

Acute Triangle

Smokey

Smokey

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (35%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit.  Fill spaces with a card one rank below the rank of the first card dealt to the foundations. For example, if the first card dealt to the foundations is a Three, fill spaces with Twos.  If the first card dealt is an Ace, fill spaces with Kings.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time, by clicking. 3 redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Smokey is a Klondike variation invented by Ann Edwards.

Similar Games

Klondike

Snake

Snake

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (45%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down regardless of suit.  Fill spaces with any card or legal group of cards.   At the start of the game 8 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (face down, top left) - turn over cards one at a time to the first tableau pile (which is also the waste pile) by clicking.  No redeals.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

The first tableau pile is also the waste pile.  It begins the game with 8 cards and cards are dealt to it one at a time from the stock.  A card or group of cards can also be moved to this pile from other tableau piles (assuming the group follows the building rules for the tableau piles).

Similar Games

Viper

Solid Square

Solid Square

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Easy (90%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (in the corners)  - build up in suit from Ace to King, then down in suit from King to Ace.  (After the first King is played, the next King is played on the first).  At the start of the game an Ace of each suit is dealt here.
•20 tableau piles (middle) - build up or down by suit, wrapping from Ace to King or King to Ace as necessary.  The top card is available for play on the foundations or another tableau pile.  Spaces are filled automatically from the stock.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - deals 1 card to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (below stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Similar Games

Twenty

Colorado

Carpet

Solstice

Solstice

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (37%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•5 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved. Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•2 reserve piles (left and right of tableau, with green arrows) - reserve pile on left may be filled by any Queen. reserve pile on right may be filled by any King.  No building.
•stock (top left) - move 1 card to waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (beside stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Similar Games

Gate

Somerset

Somerset

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (11%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Aces to Kings.
•10 tableau piles - build down by alternate color.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are filled by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on, until the the 9th and 10th piles, which are dealt 8 cards each.

History

Somerset is a variation of Klondike, without the stock and waste piles.

Similar Games

Bath

King Albert

Raglan

Usk

Klondike

Souter

Souter

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (50%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces are filled automatically by the face up card or group of cards in the pile immediately to the right of the open space.  The rightmost pile, if empty, may be filled with a King or a legal group of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 to the 2nd pile, and so on.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over cards one at a time to the waste, by clicking.  One redeal.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Souter is a variation of Moving Left.

Similar Games

Moving Left

Spaces and Aces

Spaces and Aces

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Hard (1%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To create 4 sequences of 13 cards of the same suit, running from Aces to Kings.

Layout

•56 card spaces  - Fill in gaps (spaces) by moving a card of higher rank and of the same suit as the card to the left of the space into the space.  Spaces at the far left of each row are filled with Aces.  No card may be played to a space to the right of a King.  At the start of the game 13 cards each are dealt to 4 rows of 14 spaces, with the leftmost space empty.   The object is to rearrange the cards so that each row contains a in-suit sequence starting with an Ace on the far left and going up to Kings.

Notes

•A gap (space) can be filled by moving a higher card in suit to the card immediately to the left of the space.  For example, if there is a 4 ♦ followed by a space, you can move any higher ♦ to that space, for example the 10 ♦.  Spaces on the far left are filled with an Ace (of any suit).  When the card to the left of a gap is a King, no card can be moved into its place.
•If all the spaces are to the right of Kings, the game is lost.

History

Spaces and Aces is a variation of Gaps invented by Robert Harbin.

Similar Games

Gaps

Free Parking

Maze

Spanish Patience

Spanish Patience

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Easy (99%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.

 

•13 tableau piles (left of foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces may be filled with any card.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt face up to each pile.

Options

AutoPlay

History

This is a variation of Baker's Dozen.  The differences are that in Spanish Patience, spaces may be filled with a card and the Kings are not moved to the bottom of tableau piles as they are in Baker's Dozen.

Similar Games

Baker's Dozen

Portuguese Solitaire

Castles in Spain

Good Measure

Aragonese Patience

Catalan

Barcelona

Spaulding

Spaulding

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (60%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top) - build the first 4 piles up regardless of suit from Ace to King, build the last 4 piles down regardless of suit from Kings to Aces.  At the start of the game 4 Aces and 4 Kings (of any suit) are dealt here.
•9 tableau piles (below foundations) - Build up or down regardless of suit, wrapping from Ace to King or King to Ace if necessary.  Only 1 card at a time may be moved.  Spaces may be filled by any card.  The top card of each pile may be played to any other tableau pile, or the foundation pile directly above it.  Cards in the middle pile (with no foundation pile above it) can be played to any foundation pile.  All the cards are dealt face up to these piles.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•During the initial deal if any card dealt to the tableau can be played on the foundation immediately above it, it is played there.  Also, during the game cards can only be played to a foundation pile from the tableau pile immediately below it (except for the center tableau pile, which can play cards to any foundation pile).

History

Spaulding is a variation of Rittenhouse.

Speculation

Speculation

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (45%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (left and right) - on left piles build up in suit from Ace to King, on right piles build down in suit from King to Ace.
•13 tableau piles (middle) - build up or down by suit, wrapping from Ace to King or King to Ace as necessary.  Top card is available for play on the foundations or another tableau pile, only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are filled by any card.  At the start of the game 8 cards are dealt to each pile.  During the deal, as each card is dealt it is moved to the foundations if possible and not replaced.
•stock (top) - One redeal by clicking.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

During the deal if the card dealt to the last tableau pile can be played to the foundations, it is played there and replaced.

Similar Games

Nationale

Capricieuse

Spider

Spider

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (20%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards in sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace.

Layout

•10 tableau piles - build down regardless of suit.  Groups of cards in sequence down in suit may be moved as a unit.  A space can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 6 cards each are dealt to the first 4 piles, 5 cards each to the remaining piles.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.  All tableau piles must be filled before dealing.

Notes

•Whenever a sequence of 13 cards down in suit from King to Ace is formed, it will automatically be removed from play.

Tips

•Same suit sequences should be preferred even though building is down regardless of suit.  The object is to build down in suit sequences.
•Spaces should be made as soon as possible, and used to move cards into groups by suit.

History

Spider is one of the classic solitaire games.

Similar Games

Black Widow - Spider One Suit

Tarantula - Spider Two Suits

Beetle

Brown Recluse

Spider Web

Scorpion

Spiderette

Trapdoor Spider

Huge Spider

Microbe

Lancaster

Spider Motion

Spider Motion

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium  (35%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards into 4 sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace within the tableau.

Layout

•8 tableau piles (top) - build down regardless of suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit.  Spaces can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game these piles are empty.

 

•8 reserve piles (below tableau) - No building.  Top card is available for play on the tableau (a group of cards that is in sequence down in suit may also be moved as a group to the tableau).  Spaces are not filled.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt to each pile (the first 4 piles are dealt 7).

Notes

•Play consists of moving cards from the reserve piles to the tableau (and then moving cards within the tableau) in order to form 4 sequences down in suit from King to Ace.

Tips

•Try to begin by concentrating on grouping cards of one or two suits together.

History

Spider Motion is a slightly easier version of Wave Motion.

Similar Games

Wave Motion

Flow

Spider One Suit

Spider One Suit

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Modified Decks (all cards Spades).  Easy (90%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards in sets of 13 cards in sequence down from King to Ace.

Layout

•10 tableau piles - build down.  Groups of cards in sequence down may be moved as a unit.  A space can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 6 cards each are dealt to the first 4 piles, 5 cards each to the remaining piles.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.  All tableau piles must be filled before dealing.

Notes

•Whenever a sequence of 13 cards down from King to Ace is formed, it will automatically be removed from play.

Tips

•Spaces should be made as soon as possible, and used to move cards into groups by suit.

History

Spider One Suit is Spider with only Spades.  See also Black Widow for this game with 4 suits.

Similar Games

Spider

Black Widow

Tarantula - Spider Two Suits

Spider Two Suits

Spider Two Suits

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Modified Decks (half Spades, half Hearts).  Medium (65%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards in sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace.

Layout

•10 tableau piles - build down regardless of suit.  Groups of cards in sequence down in suit may be moved as a unit.  A space can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 6 cards each are dealt to the first 4 piles, 5 cards each to the remaining piles.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.  All tableau piles must be filled before dealing.

Notes

•Whenever a sequence of 13 cards down in suit from King to Ace is formed, it will automatically be removed from play.

Tips

•Same suit sequences should be preferred even though building is down regardless of suit.  The object is to build down in suit sequences.
•Spaces should be made as soon as possible, and used to move cards into groups by suit.

History

Spider Two Suits is Spider with only Spades and Hearts.  See also Tarantula for this game with 4 suits.

Spider Web

Spider Web

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Easy (85%).  Skill/luck balanced.

Object

To group all the cards in sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace.

Layout

•7 tableau piles - build down regardless of suit.  Groups of cards in sequence down in suit may be moved as a unit.  A space can be filled by any card or legal group of cards. At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt face up to the first 3 piles, 3 cards to the remaining piles.

 

•stock (top left, face down) - Clicking deals 1 card to each tableau pile.  All empty spaces must be filled before a deal.
•reserve or Web (below stock) - storage location for any number of cards.  Any available card or legal group of cards may be moved here.  The top card is available for play on the tableau.

Notes

•Whenever a sequence of 13 cards down in suit from King to Ace is formed, it will automatically be removed from play.

Tips

•Same suit sequences should be preferred even though building is down regardless of suit.  The object is to build down in suit sequences.

History

Spider Web is a one deck variation of Spider.

Similar Games

Spider

Charlotte

Spidercells

Spidercells

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (65%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To create 4 King-to-Ace sequences down by alternate color in the tableau.

Layout

•4 cells (top left) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cells.  The card is available for play on the tableau.
•8 tableau piles (below cells) - The entire deck is dealt to these 8 piles (7 cards to the first 4 piles, 6 cards to the next 4 piles) .  The piles are built down by alternate color.  The top card is available for play on the cells or another tableau pile.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Fill spaces with any available card.

Notes

•The object of this game is different from most games.  In this game, the final winning position consists of having 4 tableau piles headed by Kings, with each pile having 13 cards down by alternate color down to Ace.
•The game number deals #1 to #1000000 are compatible with the games in the standard Windows FreeCell.  For more information about FreeCell type games, see http://www.freecell.org.

History

Spidercells is a cross between FreeCell and popular two-deck game Spider.

Similar Games

FreeCell

Spiderette

Spiderette

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (15%).  Skill/luck balanced.

Object

To group all the cards in sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace.

Layout

•7 tableau piles - build down regardless of suit.  Groups of cards in sequence down in suit may be moved as a unit (see Rules option below).  A space can be filled by any card or legal group of cards. At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.  The top card is face up.

 

•stock (above the tableau) - Clicking deals 1 card to each tableau pile.  All empty spaces must be filled before a deal.

Options

•Rules (Options menu) - choose between Regular Spiderette and Baby Spiderette (which allows groups of cards in sequence down regardless of suit to be moved as a unit).

Notes

•Whenever a sequence of 13 cards down in suit from King to Ace is formed, it will automatically be removed from play.
•Since pure Spiderette is fairly difficult to win, the program offers a rules option that is easier to win.  To change the rules, select "Rules" from the Options menu.  Baby Spiderette is considerably easier than regular Spiderette.  In Baby Spiderette, the tableau is the same as regular Spiderette, as are all the rules except one.  In Baby Spiderette, you are allowed to move a group of cards as a block if they are in sequence down regardless of suit.  In Spiderette, they must all be down in suit.  This makes it easier to move cards around, and easier to win the game.

Tips

•Same suit sequences should be preferred even though building is down regardless of suit.  The object is to build down in suit sequences.

History

Spiderette is a cross between the popular games Klondike and Spider. The game Will o the Wisp is also closely related.  First known reference to Spiderette is in The Complete Book of Solitaire & Patience Games in 1949.

 

Similar Games

Will o the Wisp

Spider

Klondike

Spidike

Empire Spider

Spiderette One Suit

Spiderette Two Suits

Spiderette One Suit

Spiderette One Suit

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Modified Decks (all cards Spades).  Easy (99%).  Skill/luck balanced.

Object

To group all the cards in sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace.

Layout

•7 tableau piles - build down regardless of suit.  Groups of cards in sequence down in suit may be moved as a unit.  A space can be filled by any card or legal group of cards. At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.  The top card is face up.

 

•stock (above the tableau) - Clicking deals 1 card to each tableau pile.  All empty spaces must be filled before a deal.

Notes

•Whenever a sequence of 13 cards down in suit from King to Ace is formed, it will automatically be removed from play.

History

Spiderette One Suit is Spiderette with only Spades.

Spiderette Two Suits

Spiderette Two Suits

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Modified Decks (half Spades, half Hearts).  Medium (80%).  Skill/luck balanced.

Object

To group all the cards in sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace.

Layout

•7 tableau piles - build down regardless of suit.  Groups of cards in sequence down in suit may be moved as a unit.  A space can be filled by any card or legal group of cards. At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.  The top card is face up.

Spidike

Spidike

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (60%).  Skill/luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Move groups of cards only if they are in sequence down in suit.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King (see KingOnly for option).  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.
•stock (top left, face down) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.

Options

KingOnly   AutoPlay

Tips

•Same suit sequences should be preferred even though building is down regardless of suit.  The foundations are built up in suit.

History

Spidike is a type of cross between Spider and Klondike.  The tableau building rules and the dealing of cards to the tableau is Spider (or Spiderette) like, but the tableau starts out much like Klondike.  The game is much more challenging with the KingOnly option set.  Spidike was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Spider

Klondike

Spiderette

Spidike Light

Double Spidike

Triple Spidike

Spidike Light

Spidike Light

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck. Easy (20%).  Skill/luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down regardless of suit.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King (see KingOnly for option).  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.
•stock (top left, face down) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.

Options

KingOnly   AutoPlay

History

Spidike Light is Spidike with group moving down regardless of suit.

Similar Games

Spidike

Spike

Spike

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (10%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards with a King at the bottom. At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card to each of the 3 waste piles by clicking. No redeals.
•3 waste piles (next to stock) - top card of each pile available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Spike is Klondike with 3 waste piles.

Similar Games

Springfield

Springfield

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Very Hard (<1%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in color from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Fill spaces with cards of rank one below the foundation base card (or Kings if the base card is an Ace).  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste, by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.

History

Springfield was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Little Napoleon

Forty Thieves

Chatham

Rochester

Squadron

Squadron

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks. Easy (82%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (middle) - build down in suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Empty piles can be filled by any available card.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - Move cards to the waste by 1 at a time by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste pile (next to stock) - Top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.
•3 reserve piles (below waste) - may contain one card.  The card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Squadron is a Forty Thieves type game with the addition of the 3 card reserve.

Similar Games

Forty Thieves

Shady Lanes

Square

Square

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks. Medium (55%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations

Layout

•8 foundation piles (lower middle) - build up in suit from Deuces (Twos) to King to Ace.
•12 tableau piles (in a square around the foundations) - build down in suit.  Only the top card available for play.  Empty piles can be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (middle left, face down) - move 1 card to waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Similar Games

Deuces

Busy Aces

Squares and Pairs

Squares and Pairs

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (70%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To pair up all the cards and move them to the waste pile.

Layout

•10 tableau piles - the top card is available for play.  Pair up cards of the same rank.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt face up to the top 6 piles and 4 cards are dealt face up to the bottom 4 piles.
•waste pile - Where paired cards go out of play.

Similar Games

Doublets

Vertical

Nestor

St Helena

St Helena

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks. Hard (30%). Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (in center box) - build top 4 down in suit from King to Ace (King-foundations) and bottom 4 up in suit from Ace to King (Ace-foundations).  At the start of the game an Ace and King of each suit is dealt here.  See building restriction note below.
•12 tableau piles (around foundations) - build up or down regardless of suit (no wrapping).  The top card is available for play on the foundations (see building restriction below) or another tableau pile.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Empty piles are not filled.  At the start of the game 8 cards are dealt face up to each pile (only the top card can be seen).
•redeal indicator (top left, no cards with green) - click to redeal the cards.  There are two redeals.  (redeals in this game cannot be Undone).

Notes

•The top card of each tableau pile is available for play on the foundations, with one exception: until the first redeal, cards from the piles above the King-foundations can only be played to the King-foundations, and cards from the piles below the Ace-foundations can only be played to the Ace-foundations.  Cards from the sides can be played anywhere, and after the first redeal, cards from any tableau pile can be played to any foundation.

 

•In a redeal the cards are not shuffled.  Rather, each tableau pile is picked up in counter-clockwise order, and then the cards are dealt back to each pile clockwise.  You cannot undo a redeal.

History

St. Helena is a classic solitaire game known by many other names, such as Napoleon's Favorite or Washington's Favorite.

Similar Games

Box Kite

Stages

Stages

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Easy (90%).  Mostly Skill.

 

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•12 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Groups of cards in sequence down in suit may be moved as a unit.  Empty piles can be filled by any card. At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (face down top left) - move 1 card to waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (beside stock) - top card available for play.

Options

AutoPlay

Similar Games

Busy Aces

Stalactites

Stalactites

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (35%)  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up regardless of suit from the rank of first card dealt to each pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.   At the start of the game a card is dealt to each pile.
•2 cells (top left) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.  The card is available for play on the foundations only.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations and cells) - No building is allowed.  The top card is available for play on the foundations or cells.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are not filled.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt to each pile.

Notes

•The first card of each foundation pile is offset so you can tell when each pile is full.  The pile is full when it contains 13 cards, which will be when the top card is one rank lower than the offset bottom card.

Tips

•Try to keep as many cells empty as possible.

History

Stalactites is also known as Old Mole or Grampus.

Similar Games

Limestone

Stalagmites

FreeCell

Stalagmites

Stalagmites

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (30%)  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build down regardless of suit from Kings to Aces.   At the start of the game the Kings are dealt here.
•2 cells (top left) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.  The card is available for play on the foundations only.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations and cells) - No building is allowed.  The top card is available for play on the foundations or cells.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are not filled.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt to each pile.

Tips

•Try to keep as many cells empty as possible.

History

Stalagmites is a variation of Stalactites.

Similar Games

Stalactites

Limestone

Stalemate

Stalemate

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (90%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•6 tableau piles (below foundations) - Build down by alternate color.  Groups of cards may be moved if they form a sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt to each pile, 2 face down and 1 face up.
•stock (top left) - turn over 3 cards at a time to the waste pile by clicking.  Unlimited redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

History

Stalemate is a variation of Blind Alleys.

Similar Games

Blind Alleys

Pas Seul

Stepping Stone

Stepping Stone

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Very Easy (88%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top right, starting with Aces) - build up in suit from Ace to King.  Only cards from the Landing may be played to the foundations.
•The Landing (10 piles, below foundations) - Reserve cells, limited to one card each.  Cards in the Landing may only be played to the foundations (Stepping up).  Spaces may be filled from the Staircase.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile, except for the last pile, which begins empty.
•The Staircase (9 piles, below the Landing) -  build down by alternate color.  Only one card at a time may be moved.   The top card of each pile is available for play elsewhere in the Staircase or to step up by filling spaces in the Landing.  Spaces may be filled from other Staircase piles or from the waste.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (left of Staircase) - turn over cards 1 at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (below stock) -  top card is available for play on the Staircase only.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•The game is called Stepping Stone because cards move up from the waste, stepping up to the Staircase, then to the Landing, and finally to the foundations.  A card must flow thru each step in order to reach the top.

History

The original version of Stepping Stone was invented by Mary Whitmore Jones around 1900 under the name "Step Up". David Parlett modified the rules somewhat and changed the name to Staircase in his book "Card Games for One".  In order to make the game more easily playable on computer, Thomas Warfield again modified the rules and changed the name to Stepping Stone.

Steps

Steps

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Very Easy (85%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Groups of cards in sequence down by alternate color may be moved.  Spaces are filled by any available card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card to the waste by clicking.  One redeal.
•waste (below stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Steps is a two deck variation of Klondike.

Similar Games

Klondike

Harp

Gargantua

Double Klondike

Klondike Twice

Steve

Steve

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (45%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Groups of cards may be moved if they are in sequence down in suit.  Fill spaces with any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to the first pile, 2 to the 2nd, and so on.
•stock (top left, face down) - deal one card to each tableau pile, by clicking.  No redeals.

History

Similar Games
