Old Carlton

Lady Jane

Stewart

Stewart

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (25%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.

 

•12 tableau piles (left of foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces can be filled by any single card (not a sequence).  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile, alternating face up and face down.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Stewart is a variation of Martha.

Similar Games

Martha

Vineyard

Baker's Dozen

Beleaguered Castle

Sticko

Sticko

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Short Deck (32 cards, Ace, Seven through Kings).  Very Hard (2%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the waste pile.

Layout

•16 reserve piles  - no building.  Cards are available for play on the waste pile.  Cards are automatically replaced from the stock. At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (face down) - replaces empty spaces in the reserve.

 

•waste (bottom) - Building is done any one of three ways:  1)  build up in suit,  or 2) build down in the other suit of the same color, or 3) build the same rank of the opposite color.  Wrapping allowed, Aces are consecutive with Kings and Sevens.

 

Notes

•Play consists of moving cards to the waste.  If a card is the 7 Diamonds, you could play an 8 Diamonds on it (up in suit), or an Ace of Hearts (down other suit of the same color), or a 7 Spades or 7 Clubs (same rank of opposite color).

History

Sticko was invented by David Parlett (inventor of Penguin and other games).

Stonewall

Stonewall

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (7%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•6 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Groups of cards in sequence down by alternate color may be moved as a unit.  Spaces are filled by any card.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt to each pile, alternating face up and face down.
•reserve (left) - All cards available for play.  Click on card to move it to the bottom of the stack, then move to either foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 16 cards are dealt here.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Stonewall is a variation of Flower Garden.

Similar Games

Flower Garden

Brigade

Northwest Territory

Klondike Territory

Double Stonewall

Stonewall Gate

Stonewall Gate

Stonewall Gate

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (7%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•6 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Groups of cards in sequence down by alternate color may be moved as a unit.  Spaces are filled by Kings or legal group of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt to each pile, all cards face up.
•reserve (left) - All cards available for play.  Click on card to move it to the bottom of the stack, then move to either foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 16 cards are dealt here.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Stonewall Gate is an open version of Stonewall.

Similar Games

Stonewall

Flower Garden

Brigade

Northwest Territory

Klondike Territory

Double Stonewall

Storehouse

Storehouse

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.   Medium (50%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Twos up to Kings, then Aces.  At the start of the game the Twos are dealt here.
•4 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit, wrapping from Ace to King as necessary.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit.  Spaces are filled from the Storehouse if possible, then by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste, by clicking.  Two redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.
•reserve (the "Storehouse", left of tableau) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 13 cards are dealt to this pile.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Storehouse is a variation of Canfield.  The first reference to Storehouse is in 100 Games of Solitaire in 1939.

Similar Games

Double Storehouse

Triple Storehouse

Canfield

Chameleon

Rainbow

American Toad

Straights and Pairs

Straights and Pairs

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (75%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (bottom) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•13 tableau piles - while there are cards remaining in the stock, discard pairs of cards of the same rank to the waste pile. Spaces will be automatically filled from stock.  When the stock is empty, build down regardless of suit.  Spaces may be filled by Kings.
•stock (face down, left) - fills spaces in the tableau.
•waste (lower left)  - Where paired cards go.  Once the stock is empty, these cards may be played to the foundations or tableau.

History

Straights and Pairs was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Seventeens

Strata

Strata

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks (with the 2's thru 6's removed).  Medium (30%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace, then Sevens to Kings.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  A space may be filled by any available card.   At the start of the game 8 cards are dealt to each pile.
•stock (bottom, empty) -  2 redeals.  Click on the stock to redeal.   The cards in the tableau are picked up and then dealt out again.

Strategerie

Strategerie

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (85%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (right) - build up regardless of suit from Ace to King.
•4 cells (across top) - storage locations for cards from the stock.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.  Cards can only be moved to the cells from the stock.  A card in a cell is available for play to the tableau or foundations.
•4 tableau piles (below cells) - cards are played here from the stock or cells.  The top card of each pile is available for play on the foundations only.  Once a card has been played to the tableau, it can only be moved to the foundations.
•stock (face up on left) - Top card is available for play on the cells, tableau, or foundations.  No redeals.

Tips

•The skill in this game is deciding which cell or tableau pile to put each card in.   Once cards are played to the tableau they can only be removed to the foundations. You do not want to block yourself by putting higher cards on top of lower cards in the tableau, unless absolutely necessary.

History

Strategerie is similar to Sir Tommy and Strategy.   It was invented by George W. Bush especially for this game.

Similar Games

Strategy

Sir Tommy

Strategy

Strategy

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Easy (99%).  All Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.  Other than Aces (which are moved here from the stock automatically when they appear), cards cannot be played here until the stock is empty.   When the stock is empty, cards are moved here from the tableau automatically.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - cards are played here from the stock. Any card may be played to any pile.  Cards cannot be moved once placed.  Once all the cards are played the cards will be moved to the foundations automatically.
•stock (top left, face up) - Top card is available for play on the tableau.  Aces, when they appear, are automatically moved to the foundations.  No redeals.

Notes

•Play begins by moving cards from the stock to the tableau.  Each card may be put in any tableau pile.  To move the top card on the stock to a tableau pile, simply click on that pile, or drag and drop the card on the desired pile.  Aces are automatically moved to the foundations for you as they come up in the stock.

 

•After all the cards in the stock have been moved to the tableau, the cards are then moved to the foundations in the following way:  Only the top card of each tableau pile is available.  The foundations are built up in suit from the Ace up to the King.  If at any time no card can be placed on the foundations, you lose.  

 

•In effect, the entire game is played while placing the cards on the tableau.  If any card is placed on a tableau pile that contains a card of the same suit and lower value, the game will be lost.  This is almost entirely a game of skill.

 

History

Strategy is a more advanced version of Sir Tommy.  It was invented by Alfred Morehead and Geoffrey Mott-Smith.

Similar Games

Strategy Plus

Sir Tommy

Strategerie

Strategy Plus

Strategy Plus

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (7%).  All Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.  Other than Aces (which are moved here from the stock automatically when they appear), cards cannot be played here until the stock is empty.   When the stock is empty, cards are moved here from the tableau automatically.
•6 tableau piles (below foundations) - cards are played here from the stock. Any card may be played to any pile.  Cards cannot be moved once placed.  Once all the cards are played the cards will be moved to the foundations automatically.
•stock (top left, face up) - Top card is available for play on the tableau.  Aces, when they appear, are automatically moved to the foundations.  No redeals.

Notes

•Play begins by moving cards from the stock to the tableau.  Each card may be put in any tableau pile.  To move the top card on the stock to a tableau pile, simply click on that pile, or drag and drop the card on the desired pile.  Aces are automatically moved to the foundations for you as they come up in the stock.

 

•After all the cards in the stock have been moved to the tableau, the cards are then moved to the foundations in the following way:  Only the top card of each tableau pile is available.  The foundations are built up in suit from the Ace up to the King.  If at any time no card can be placed on the foundations, you lose.  

 

•In effect, the entire game is played while placing the cards on the tableau.  If any card is placed on a tableau pile that contains a card of the same suit and lower value, the game will be lost.  This is almost entirely a game of skill.

History

Strategy Plus is a more difficult variation of Strategy.  It was suggested as a variation on Albert Morehead & Geoffrey Mott-Smith's game by David Parlett.

Similar Games

Strategy

Sir Tommy

Strategerie

Streets

Streets

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (18%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Only one card at a time can be moved.  Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Streets is a variation of Forty Thieves.  It is also closely related to Number Ten and Rank and File.

Similar Games

Number Ten

Rank and File

Forty Thieves

Napoleon's Folly

Easy Street

Alleys

Streets and Alleys

Streets and Alleys

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (7%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (middle) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•8 tableau piles (around foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Only the top card of each pile is available for play.  Spaces may be filled by any available card.  At the start of the game the first 4 piles are dealt 7 cards each face up, and the next 4 piles are dealt 6 cards each face up.

Options

AutoPlay

History

This is a variation of Beleaguered Castle that is harder to win since the Aces are not dealt at the beginning of the game.

Similar Games

Beleaguered Castle

Penelope's Web

Stronghold

Private Lane

Striptease

Striptease

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck. Hard (2%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards (except Queens) to the waste piles.

Layout

•4 tableau piles (left) - Each pile contains 13 cards, first card a Queen, 2nd card face down, the rest face up.  Face down cards are not available until all face up cards (except Queens) in all piles have been played. Then the 4 cards are turned over for play.
•4 waste piles (right) - build up or down regardless of suit from the tableau.  Aces may be played on Kings, Kings may be played on Aces, and Kings and Jacks are considered consecutive. Once a card has been played to a waste pile it cannot be moved.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Striptease was invented by David Parlett.  The name comes from the objective of the game, which is to strip the Queens of all their covering cards.

Similar Games

Take Away

Four Stacks

Stronghold

Stronghold

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (35%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (middle) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•8 tableau piles (around foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Only the top card of each pile is available for play.  Spaces may be filled by any available card.  At the start of the game the first 4 piles are dealt 7 cards each face up, and the next 4 piles are dealt 6 cards each face up.
•1 cell (top) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in the cell.  The card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Stronghold is Streets and Alleys with a cell that makes the game somewhat easier.  Stronghold was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Streets and Alleys

Beleaguered Castle

Private Lane

Succession

Succession

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks. Medium (15%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top) - build down regardless of suit, wrapping from Ace to King as necessary, from King (first pile), Queen (2nd pile), Jack (3rd pile), etc.  The last pile begins with a Six.  At the beginning of the game a King is dealt to the first foundation.  Other foundations cannot be started until the foundation to its immediate left has been started.
•stock (bottom, face down) - move 1 card to waste by clicking.  Two redeals.
•waste (below stock) - top card available for play on the foundations.

History

Succession is an easier variation of Precedence.

Similar Games

Precedence

Suit Elevens

Suit Elevens

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (15%).  All Luck.

Object

To discard all the cards.

Layout

•15 tableau piles - the top card is available for play.  Pair up cards of the same suit that have ranks that add to 11 (Ace-10, 2-9, 3-8, 4-7, 5-6).  Jacks, Queens, and Kings are grouped as a triplet of the same suit  (J-Q-K).  Spaces are automatically filled from the stock.   To discard a J-Q-K triplet, move each card to the reserve pile in the lower left.  When all 3 cards have been moved, the J-Q-K suit triplet is removed from play.   At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.

               

•stock (face down, left) - fills spaces in the tableau.
•waste (far right)  - Where paired cards go out of play.
•reserve (lower left) - where J-Q-K suit triplets are formed.

Valid Discards

•Ace-10, 2-9, 3-8, 4-7, 5-6, Jack-Queen-King all of same suit.

History

Suit Elevens is a variation of Elevens.

Similar Games

Elevens

Suit Triangle

Suit Triangle

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (25%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards with a King at the bottom.   At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - deals three cards to the waste pile, by clicking.  Unlimited redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Suit Triangle is a two deck, in suit version of Klondike.

Similar Games

Klondike

Double Klondike

Gargantua

Suit Yourself

Suit Yourself

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Easy (98%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•13 foundation piles (top) - build in rank by alternate color. (that is, all Aces go in the Aces pile, Twos in the Twos pile, and so on).  At the start of the game one card is dealt to its appropriate foundation piles.  All empty foundation piles must begin with the same suit as this first card dealt (ie. if the first card is the 6 ♥, then all the remaining empty foundation piles must be filled with ♥'s, then cards from the other 3 suits can be played on the ♥'s by alternate color.
•stock (bottom left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  One redeal.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations.

 

Options

AutoPlay

Suits in Line

Suits in Line

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (15%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards into 4 sets of 13 cards in sequence up in suit from Ace to King within the tableau.

Layout

•  7 tableau piles (top) - build up in suit, wrapping from King to Ace is allowed.  Groups of cards (regardless of any sequence) can be moved.  Fill spaces with Aces or groups of cards headed by an Ace.  At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt to each pile.  In the 2nd and 6th pile, one card is face down, in the 3rd and 5th pile two cards are face down, and in the 4th pile 3 cards are face down.

 

•3 reserve cards (left) - Each card is available for play on the tableau.  These cards cannot be replaced.

Notes

•Any face up card, regardless of where in a pile it is, can be moved, along with all cards above it (this is like Yukon).

History

Suits in Line is similar to Scorpion, with the major difference being that building is up in suit rather than down in suit.

Similar Games

Scorpion

Applegate

Suits Up

Suits Up

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Easy (99%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To remove all the cards from the tableau except for 4 cards of different suits.

Layout

•4 tableau piles (top) - cards are dealt here 1 to each pile from the stock.  The top card of each pile is available for play.  Pairs of cards of the same suit may be removed. Spaces are not filled.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (face down) - deal 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.  No redeals.

Notes

•The game is won when only 4 cards remain and they are of different suits.  The four cards can be arranged in any pile.

Similar Games

Aces Up

Firing Squad

Sultan of Turkey

Sultan of Turkey

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Very Easy (92%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•9 foundation piles (in center box) - build up in suit from King to Ace up to Queen, except for the center King (the Sultan), which is not built on at all.  At the start of the game the Kings and the Ace ♥ are dealt here.
•8 reserve piles (around the foundations) - can contain one card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (face down) - turn over cards one at a time to the waste pile by clicking.  There are 2 redeals.
•waste pile (next to stock) - The top card is available for play on the foundations or reserves.

Options

AutoPlay

History

This is a very old game.  It is easy to win and requires very little skill.

Super Challenge FreeCell

Super Challenge FreeCell

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (50%).  Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•4 cells (top left) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.

 

•8 tableau piles (below foundations and cells) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color and if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.  Spaces can be filled only by a King or a group of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game the Twos are dealt to the leftmost 4 piles, the Aces are dealt to the right 4 piles, then 6 cards are dealt face up to the leftmost 4 piles, 5 cards are dealt face up to the remaining piles.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Groups of cards in the tableau can only be moved as a group if there are a sufficient number of empty cells available to store the cards individually.  The ability to move cards as a group is only a shortcut to moving the group one card at a time.

History

Super Challenge FreeCell is a variation of Challenge FreeCell, where only Kings can be played in spaces.  This makes a challenging game even more challenging.

Similar Games

Challenge FreeCell

FreeCell

Super Flower Garden

Super Flower Garden

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (50%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•18 fans (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are not filled.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt face up to each pile (except for the last pile, which just has 1 card).
•stock (upper left, no cards) - There are two redeals.  After all possible plays have been made, redeal by clicking on the green arrow in the upper left corner.  All the cards in the fans are reshuffled. The foundations remain.  When the green arrow is x'ed out, there are no more redeals.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Despite its name, Super Flower Garden is not related to Flower Garden.  It is an easier version of La Belle Lucie, a classic variation of Fan.

Similar Games

La Belle Lucie

Fan

Shamrocks

Trefoil

Clover Leaf

Superior Canfield

Superior Canfield

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (44%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•4 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces are filled by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 or 3 cards at a time (see rules option), by clicking.  Unlimited redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card always available for play on the tableau or foundations.
•reserve (left of tableau) - Top card always available for play on the tableau or foundations.  At the start of the game 13 cards are dealt here.

Options

•Rules - selects whether 1 card or 3 cards at a time are turned over from the stock.  This option is set in the options menu.  The default is 3 cards.

AutoPlay

History

Superior Canfield is a variation of Canfield.  It is slightly easier in that the reserve pile is completely visible, and spaces in the tableau can be filled by any card, instead of having to be filled from the reserve.

Similar Games

Canfield

Variegated Canfield

Surprise

Surprise

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Easy (85%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•11 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Groups of cards may be moved if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Empty piles can be filled by a King or a legal group of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 1 card is played on the first, 2 on the second, 3 on the 3rd, 4 on the 4th, 5 on the 5th, 6 on the 6th, 5 on the 7th, 4 on the 8th, 3 on the 9th, 2 on the 10th, and 1 on the 11th.  The top card only is face up.
•stock (top left) - deals one card to each tableau pile (except any pile headed by a King).  No redeals.
•reserve (beside stock) - storage for up to 3 cards, usable only after the stock is empty.  The card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

After all cards in the stock pile have been played, players may take advantage of the empty space beside the stock pile called the reserve.  Any single card may be moved to the reserve, and the reserve may contain up to 3 cards at any one time.

History

Surprise is of German origin.

Similar Games

Miss Milligan

Grounds for Divorce

Suspenseful

Suspenseful

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (63%)  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top left, with X's) - build up in suit from first card (comes from center card of Groups below), wrapping from King to Ace as necessary.
•4 Groups (below foundations) - Each group contains 6 cards in a pyramid formation.  The middle card (the center)  is face down.  The two cards to either side of the center are the Wings.  When uncovered, the center is turned over automatically and becomes the base card of a foundation pile.  Only cards that are not blocked by another card are available.  Available cards in Groups can be played to the foundations, tableau, or waste, if possible.  Wing cards, when removed, can be replaced by a single card.
•4 tableau piles (far right) - build down in suit, wrapping from Ace to King as necessary. Groups of cards may be moved regardless of sequence.  Spaces can be filled by any card or group of cards. Top card is available for play on the foundations, waste, or Wings.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (right of foundations, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  Two redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on foundations, tableau, or Wings.  Cards may be built up or down regardless of suit, wrapping from King to Ace or Ace to King as necessary.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•The 4 center cards of the Groups will always be of different suits.

 

•Wing cards of the Groups are essentially free cells for cards, as in FreeCell.

Tips

•It is necessary to uncover the center cards (foundation base cards) as quickly as possible.  Play cards to the waste as necessary to uncover the center cards.  Once you get all the foundations started, then you will want to get the cards out of the waste pile again.

History

Suspenseful is loosely based on the game Suspense from Albert H. Morehead & Geoffrey Mott-Smith's book The Complete Book of Solitaire & Patience Games. The layout is similar, but the rules have been greatly modified.

 

Sweet Sixteen

Sweet Sixteen

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck. Medium (66%).  Luck/Skill Balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the tableau.

Layout

•16 tableau piles  - build down by alternate color.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are filled automatically from the stock.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (left, face down) - automatically fills spaces in the tableau.

Notes

The idea is to get all of the cards in play by grouping cards in piles down by alternate color, which brings more cards into play via the empty spaces created.  The game is won if all cards are moved from the stock onto the tableau.

Similar Games

Trusty Twelve

Knotty Nines

Bunker

Up and Up

Swiss Patience

Swiss Patience

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (45%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Two to King to Ace.
•9 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Groups of cards in sequence down by alternate color may be moved as a unit.  Spaces may be filled only by Aces.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 to the 2nd, 3 to the 3rd, 4 to the 4th, 5 to the 5th, 4 to the 6th, 3 to the 7th, 2 to the 8th, and 1 to the 9th.
•stock (top left, face down) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking. No redeals.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Swiss Patience has a pyramid shaped tableau like Thieves of Egypt.

Similar Games

Thieves of Egypt

Taj Mahal

Taj Mahal

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (75%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) -  build down in any suit but the same.  Groups of cards may be moved if they are in sequence down in any suit but the same.  When only one card remains in a tableau pile, the card becomes a "protected" card. Protected cards may only be moved to a foundation and no cards may be played upon them.   Protected cards remain protected until the stock is empty, then they become available for play on other tableau piles, and other cards may be played upon them.  Spaces may be filled by any card. At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste pile by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

 

History

Taj Mahal is a cross between Klondike and Indian Patience.  It was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Indian Patience

Klondike

Nunavut

Take Away

Take Away

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck. Hard (30%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the waste piles.

Layout

•4 tableau piles (left) - No building. At the start of the game each pile contains 13 cards face up.  The top card of each pile is available.  Spaces are not filled.
•6 waste piles (right) - build from the tableau up or down regardless of suit, wrapping from Ace to King or King to Ace as necessary.     Once a card has been played to a waste pile it cannot be moved.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Take Away is a less risque version of Striptease.

Similar Games

Striptease

Four Stacks

Taking Silk

Taking Silk

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (15%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•6 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Groups of cards in sequence down regardless of suit may be moved as a unit.  Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (below stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Similar Games

Tam O Shanter

Tam O Shanter

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Hard (<0.1%).  All Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - build up regardless of suit from Ace to King.
•4 reserve piles (below foundations) - cards are moved here from the stock.  The top card of each pile is available for play on the foundations.  Move cards to the foundations by clicking.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (face down) - deal 1 card to each reserve pile by clicking.  No redeals.

History

This is an old and classic solitaire game.  It is a more difficult variation of Auld Lang Syne.

Similar Games

Auld Lang Syne

Acquaintance

Acquaintance One

Sir Tommy

Alloway Kirk

River Doon

Millennium

Tarantella

Tarantella

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Easy (75%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right, starting with Aces) - build up in color from Ace to King, back to Ace to King again, until each pile contains 26 cards.  At the start of the game an Ace of each suit is dealt here.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - Build down by alternate color, wrapping from Ace to King as necessary.  Groups of cards in sequence down by alternate color may be moved as a unit.  Spaces may be filled by any card or legal sequence of cards.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt to each pile, in the first and 10th piles, the top card is face up, in the 2nd and 9th piles 2 cards are face up, in the 3rd and 8th piles 3 cards are face up, in the 4th and 7th piles 4 cards are face up, and in the 5th and 6th piles all the cards are face up.
•reserve - (left of foundations) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 10 cards are dealt to this pile.
•stock (left of reserve) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Tarantella has some elements of Klondike, Spider, and Blondes and Brunettes.  It is named after an Italian dance that is supposed to be like being bitten by a Tarantula.  It was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Klondike

Spider

Blondes and Brunettes

Pizzica

Tarantula

Tarantula

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (70%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards in sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace within the tableau.

Layout

•10 tableau piles - build down regardless of suit.  Groups of cards in sequence down in color may be moved as a unit.  A space can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt to the first 4 piles, and 5 cards to the remaining piles.  Only the top card is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.  All tableau piles must have at least one card in them before you can do this.

Notes

•  The objective is to group all the cards in sets of 13 cards, from King to Ace down in suit.  Whenever such a group is formed in a pile, it is automatically removed from play.
•  When the stock is empty and you are unable to form the tableaus into sets of 13 cards of each suit, the game is lost.

History

Tarantula is a variation of the classic game Spider.  The difference between Spider and Tarantula is that in Spider only groups of cards down in suit may be moved, while in Tarantula any group in sequence down in color may be moved.  This makes Tarantula easier than Spider, but harder than Black Widow.

Similar Games

Spider

Black Widow - Spider One Suit

Spider Two Suits

Tasmanian Patience

Tasmanian Patience

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (50%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - Build down in suit.  Groups of cards may be moved regardless of sequence. Spaces filled by Kings or groups of cards headed by a King. At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile.

 

•stock (top left) - turn over 3 cards at a time to the waste pile by clicking.  Unlimited redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Tasmanian Patience is Australian Patience with unlimited redeals.

Similar Games

Australian Patience

Brisbane

Klondike

Yukon

Outback

Darwin

Canberra

Tens

Tens

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (33%).  All Luck.

Object

To discard all the cards.

Layout

•13 tableau piles - the top card is available for play.  Discard pairs of cards that have ranks that add to 10 (9-A, 8-2, 7-3, 6-4, 5-5). Tens, Jacks, Queens, and Kings are discarded in sets of the same rank (10-10-10-10, for example).   Spaces are automatically filled from the stock.   To discard a set of cards, move each card to the reserve pile in the lower left.  When a set is formed, or when cards of rank 9 or under add to 10, the cards are automatically discarded to the waste pile.   Pairs of cards that add to 10 can also be discarded by dropping one on the other if there are no cards in the reserve.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (face down, left) - fills spaces in the tableau.
•waste (far right)  - Where paired cards go out of play.
•reserve (lower left) - where sets of cards are formed.

Valid Discards

•A-9, 2-8, 3-7, 4-6, 5-5, 10-10-10-10, Jack-Jack-Jack-Jack, Queen-Queen-Queen-Queen, King-King-King-King.

Similar Games

Block Ten

Elevens

Tens Out

Tens Out

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (50%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To pair up all cards and move them out of play to the waste pile.

Layout

•11 tableau piles - the top card of each pile is available.  Pair cards whose ranks add to 10 and remove Tens, Jacks, Queens, and Kings in pairs of the same rank.  To remove a pair, pick up one card with the mouse and drop it on the other.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt face up to each of the first 8 piles, 4 cards are dealt face up to each of the remaining piles.

 

•waste pile (bottom of screen) - where paired cards go out of play.

Notes

Legal Pairs: Ace-9, 2-8, 3-7, 4-6, 5-5, 10-10, J-J, Q-Q, K-K.

History

Tens Out is a variation of Fourteen Out.

Similar Games

Fourteen Out

Thirteen Out

Ten By One

Ten By One

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (80%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Only one card at a time may be moved (unless there is an empty cell or tableau piles, see the notes).  Spaces may be filled by any available card.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt face up to each pile (6 cards to the first two piles).
•1 cell (top left) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in the cell.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Groups of cards in the tableau can only be moved as a group if there is an empty cell or tableau piles available to store the cards individually.  The ability to move cards as a group is only a shortcut to moving the group one card at a time.

History

Ten By One is a variation of FreeCell with similarities to Bastion and Fortress.

Similar Games

FreeCell

Bastion

Fortress

Four by Ten

Ten by Six

Ten by Six

Ten by Six

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck. Very Easy (99%).  Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Only one card at a time may be moved (unless there is an empty cell or tableau piles, see the notes).  Spaces may be filled by any available card.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt face up to each pile (6 cards to the first two piles).
•6 cells (top left) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Groups of cards in the tableau can only be moved as a group if there is an empty cell or tableau piles available to store the cards individually.  The ability to move cards as a group is only a shortcut to moving the group one card at a time.

History

Ten By Six is a variation of FreeCell.

Similar Games

FreeCell

Ten by One

Four by Ten

Terrace

Terrace

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (5%). Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (middle) - build up by alternate color from the rank of first card moved to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•9 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Only the top card of each pile may be moved.  Spaces may be filled by a card from the waste only.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to the first 4 piles.  One of these cards is selected to be the foundation base card by moving it to the first foundation pile.  After a card is so moved 1 card is dealt face up to the remaining empty piles.
•reserve (top) - top card is available for play on the foundations only.  At the start of the game 11 cards are dealt here.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over cards 1 at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals, except that when the stock is empty the waste may be turned over to form a new stock by clicking on the empty stock.  Cards may then then be played to the foundations or tableau until an unplayable card is reached (which ends the game).
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Tips

•The restriction on play of cards in the reserve makes this game difficult.  Note that it is extremely important which card you begin the game with by moving it to the first foundation pile.  Examine the reserve closely to make the best choice.  If there are several Sixes in the reserve, for example, you wouldn't want to pick a Six, or even a Five or Four as your foundation base.

History

Terrace is also known as Queen of Italy.

Similar Games

General's Patience

Blondes and Brunettes

Signora

Redheads

Bastille Day

Empress of Italy

TetSol

TetSol

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (6%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To discard all the cards in pairs.

Layout

•15 (or 12 in 640x480 resolution) tableau Piles arranged in a 3x5 rectangle- discard pairs of cards that are one rank different from each other (Aces and Kings are considered consecutive) and are adjacent to each other, either side by side or diagonally.  Spaces are filled as follows: any card above a space slides down to fill the space, empty spaces at the top are filled by the stock.
•stock (Face down, middle) - automatically fills spaces at the top of the layout.
•Discards (right) - all cards paired up and discarded from the layout are piled in 13 piles by rank, for easy counting of remaining cards.

Notes

•Discard pairs of cards that are one rank different from each other (for example, a Two may be paired with either an Ace or a Three) and are adjacent to each other, either side by side or diagonally.  Kings may be paired with Aces.  To discard a pair, drop one of the cards on the other, or right-click on one of the cards.  Spaces are filled as follows: any card above a space slides down to fill the space, empty spaces at the top are filled by the stock.  This is the same way that pieces fall in the game Tetris.
•Discarded pairs are moved to 13 piles to the right of the stock, grouped by rank.  This makes it easy to see what cards remain to be paired.  This is very important as it is very easy to make moves that will make it impossible to win.  For example, if you pair all the Tens with Nines and all the Queens with Kings, the Jacks have nowhere to go and can never be paired.

History

Tetsol is based on an earlier game of the same name in the 16-bit Pretty Good Solitaire.  That game had a different pairing method and was invented by Randy Rasa.  This game keeps the same tableau layout, but changes the pairing from cards that add to 13 to pairs of cards one rank different.  This makes for a more strategic game.

Thatcher

Thatcher

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (15%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (middle) - build up in suit from Aces to Kings.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Groups of cards in descending sequence down by alternate color may be moved as a unit.  Spaces are filled only by Kings or a group of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first and 10th piles, 2 cards to the 2nd and 9th piles, 3 cards to the 3rd and 8th piles, 4 cards to the 4th and 7th piles, and 5 cards to the 5th and 6th piles.  Only the top card is face up.
•reserve (top) - top card is available for play on the foundations only. At the start of the game 6 cards with ranks of Six or less are dealt here.
•stock (top left, face down) - deals one card to each tableau pile that is not headed by a King by clicking.  No redeals.

 

Options

AutoPlay

History

Thatcher is an easier version of Prime Minister.

Similar Games

Prime Minister

General's Patience

Signora

Terrace

Pitt the Younger

The Bold

The Bold

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (20%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.  At the start of the game the Aces are dealt here.
•6 tableau piles (in box) - build down in suit.  The top card of each pile is available for play.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Any card may be moved to a space.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (left, face down) - deal 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (below stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

The Bold is Fortune's Favor with only 6 tableau piles.

Similar Games

Fortune's Favor

Sleepers

The Ides of March

The Ides of March

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (20%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To discard all the cards.

Layout

•13 tableau piles - the top card is available for play.  Discard pairs of cards that have ranks that add to 15. Aces are discarded in pairs.  Spaces are automatically filled from the stock in the center 3 piles, otherwise in the outer 10 piles spaces are not filled.   At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt face up to 10 piles, 1 card is dealt face up to the center 3 piles.
•stock (face down, left) - fills spaces in the tableau.
•waste (lower left)  - Where paired cards go out of play.

Valid Discards

•A-A, 2-K, 3-Q, 4-J, 5-10, 6-9, 7-8

History

The Ides of March is a variation of Seventeens.

Similar Games

Seventeens

Friday

Fifteen Rush

The Plot

The Plot

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Very Hard (1%).  Skill/luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (right) - build up in suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.  No cards can be played on the 2nd through 8th piles until all 13 cards have been played to the first pile.  The first pile is offset to the left of the other 7 piles.
•12 tableau piles (center) - build down in suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces may be filled only from the waste.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.  Until the first foundation pile contains 13 cards, cards of the same rank as the first card of the first foundation pile cannot be built on other cards or built upon.
•stock (bottom left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste, by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (below stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.
•reserve (top left, above stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations only.  At the start of the game 13 cards are dealt here.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•The Plot has three restrictions that make things difficult: 1) you cannot play any cards to the 2nd to 8th foundation piles until the first foundation pile contains all 13 cards.  The first pile is offset from the others to make it more visible.  2) cards in the reserve can be played only to the foundations, not to the tableau, and 3) until the first foundation pile contains 13 cards, you cannot build or build upon cards of the same rank as the first card of the first foundation pile.

History

The Plot has similarities to Canfield and Seven Devils.

Similar Games

Family Plot

Single Plot

Canfield

Seven Devils

The Spark

The Spark

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (33%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build down in suit from King to Ace.
•12 tableau piles (below foundations on right) - build up in suit.  Only top card available for play.  Empty piles can be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (below foundations, face down on left) - move 3 cards to each waste pile by clicking.  No redeals.
•2 waste piles (below stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt to each pile.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Note that the building foundations and tableau is highly unusual.  Building in The Spark is backwards from most solitaire games.   Also, there are 2 waste piles rather than the usual one.

History

The Spark is an upside down variation of Busy Aces.

Similar Games

Busy Aces

Single Spark

The Wish

The Wish

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Short Deck (32 cards).  Medium (25%). Mostly Luck.

Object

To discard all the cards in pairs of the same rank.

Layout

•8 tableau piles  - discard pairs of cards of the same rank.   The top card of each pile is available.   At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile, only the top card is face up.
•waste (bottom) - Where paired cards go out of play.

Notes

The Wish uses a short deck of 32 cards, the 2's, 3's, 4's, 5's and 6's have been removed.

History

The Wish is related to Doublets, Nestor, and other pair-discard games.

Similar Games

Genie

Doublets

Nestor

Vertical

Thieves of Egypt

Thieves of Egypt

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (85%).  Skill/luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Groups of cards in sequence down by alternate color may be moved as a unit.  Spaces may be filled only by Kings.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 3 to the 2nd, 5 to the 3rd, 7 to the 4th, 9 to the 5th, 10 to the 6th, 8 to the 7th, 6 to the 8th, 4 to the 9th, and 2 to the 10th.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  One redeal.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Thieves of Egypt has a pyramid shaped tableau, but is a variation of Forty Thieves.

Thieves Rush

Thieves Rush

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (90%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved. Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 3 cards at a time to the waste by clicking during the first deal, 2 cards at a time during the 2nd deal, and 1 card at a time during the last deal.  Two redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Tips

•Try to get a space in the tableau as quickly as possible.

History

Thieves Rush is a variation of Forty Thieves invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Forty Thieves

Thirteen Down

Thirteen Down

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (15%)  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - No building.  Spaces are filled automatically from the reserve, or if the reserve is empty, from the waste, or if the waste is empty, from the stock.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time, by clicking.  Two redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations.
•reserve (left of tableau) - Top card always available for play on the foundations.  At the start of the game 13 cards are dealt here.

Options

AutoPlay

Thirteen Out

Thirteen Out

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (50%).  Skill/Luck Balanced.

Object

To pair up all cards and move them out of play to the waste pile.

Layout

•11 tableau piles - the top card of each pile is available.  Pair cards that total to 13.  Kings are discarded singly.  To discard a pair, drop one card on the other, or right-click on one of the cards.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt face up to each of the first 8 piles, 4 cards are dealt face up to each of the remaining piles.

 

•waste pile (bottom of screen) - where paired cards go out of play.

Notes

Any pair of cards whose values add to 13 can be discarded.  The valid pairs are Queen-Ace, Jack-Two, 10-3, 9-4, 8-5, 7-6.  Kings are discarded singly.  To discards Kings, simply click on them.

History

Thirteen Out is similar to the classic game Fourteen Out, with pairs adding to 13 instead of 14.

Similar Games

Fourteen Out

Tens Out

Thirteen Packs

Thirteen Packs

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Very Hard (2%).  Skill/luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build left 4 piles up in suit from Ace to King, right 4 piles down in suit from Kings to Aces. Each group of 4 piles should have a pile of each suit.
•13 tableau packs (below foundations) - piles are numbered from 1 to 13.  No building.  Top card is available for play on the foundations.  Empty piles can be filled only by a card of the same rank as the number of the pile.
•stock (bottom left, face down) - clicking turns over the top card.  The tableau pile corresponding to the rank of this card is spread out at the bottom of the screen.  All the cards in that pile become available for play on the foundations, including the top card of the stock, which is placed in position to become the bottom card of the tableau pile.  When all possible plays have been made, clicking on the stock again picks up all of the remaining cards, returns them in the same order to the tableau pile, and then the next card in the stock is turned over and the process repeats.  When the stock is empty there is no redeal.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•The Initial Deal - The 2 decks are dealt as follows: the cards are dealt in sequence to the 13 tableau packs.  If the card dealt to a pile is of the same rank as the number of the pile (for example, a Three on the 3rd pile), then the next card to deal is dealt face down to the stock, and the deal continues.  If the card dealt is an Ace or a King, then the next card to deal is dealt face down to the stock, and the deal continues.  When the deal reaches the end of the 13 piles, then a card is dealt face down to the stock, and the deal continues with the first pile again.  Note that if an Ace is dealt to the first pile, two cards are dealt face down to the stock, and if a King is dealt to the 13th pile, 3 cards are dealt face down to the stock.  The stock therefore will contain a variable number of cards from game to game.
•Play consists of playing all cards that are available to the foundations, then clicking on the stock to make more cards available based on the rank of the cards in the stock.

Similar Games

Carol

Thirteens

Thirteens

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (66%).  All Luck.

Object

To pair up all the cards in the deck in pairs of cards of ranks that add to 13.

Layout

•10 tableau Piles - Discard pairs of cards whose ranks add to 13.  Kings are discarded singly.  To discard a pair, drop one card on the other, or right-click on one of the cards.  Cards are replaced immediately from the stock.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (far right, face down) - automatically fills spaces in the tableau.

Notes

•Any pair of cards whose values add to 13 can be discarded.  The valid pairs are Queen-Ace, Jack-Two, 10-3, 9-4, 8-5, 7-6.  Kings are discarded singly.  To discards Kings, simply click on them.

History

Thirteens is a simple solitaire game of the type called "simple addition", which are games that involve adding values of cards together to reach a certain value.

Similar Games

Five Piles

Pyramid

Nile

Klondike 13

Seven Piles

Thirty Nine Steps

Thirty Nine Steps

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Easy (85%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•13 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit. Only one card at at time may be moved.  Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Thirty-Nine Steps is just like Waning Moon except one fewer card is dealt to each tableau pile.

Similar Games

Waning Moon

Lucas

Thirty Six

Thirty Six

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (67%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•6 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Groups of cards in sequence down regardless of suit may be moved as a unit. Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Similar Games

Floradora

Lanes

Q.C.

Three Bears

Three Bears

 Top  Previous  Next

3 Decks.  Medium (70%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•12 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•13 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit.  Fill spaces with Kings or a legal group of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 to the 2nd pile, and so on.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 3 cards at a time to the waste, by clicking.  Unlimited redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Three Bears is a variation of Triple Klondike invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Triple Klondike

Klondike

Three Blind Mice

Three Blind Mice

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (20%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards into 4 sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace within the tableau.

Layout

•10 tableau piles (top) - build down in suit.  Groups of cards (regardless of any sequence) can be moved.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.   At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt to each pile.  In the rightmost 3 piles, 3 cards are face down and 2 face up, in the other piles all cards are face up.

 

•reserve (bottom left) - both cards are available for play in the tableau at any time.

Notes

•Any face up card, regardless of where in a pile it is, can be moved, along with all cards above it (this is like Yukon).

History

Three Blind Mice is a variation of Scorpion.

Similar Games

Farmer's Wife

How They Run

Scorpion

Applegate

Three Cells

Three Cells

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Easy (99%).  Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•3 cells (top left) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.

 

•8 tableau piles (below foundations and cells) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color and if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.  Spaces can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.   At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt face up to the leftmost 4 piles, 6 cards are dealt face up to the remaining piles.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Groups of cards in the tableau can only be moved as a group if there are a sufficient number of empty cells available to store the cards individually.  The ability to move cards as a group is only a shortcut to moving the group one card at a time.
•The game number deals #1 to #1000000 are compatible with the games in the standard Windows FreeCell.  For more information about FreeCell type games, see http://www.freecell.org.

Tips

•Try to keep as many cells empty as possible.

History

Three Cells is FreeCell with only 3 cells.

Similar Games

FreeCell

Two Cells

Baker's Game

One Cell

Three Demons

Three Demons

 Top  Previous  Next

3 Decks.  Medium (60%).  Skill/luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•12 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•9 tableau piles (below foundations on right) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces are filled from the reserve until it is empty, then spaces are filled by a card or legal group of cards headed by a card one rank below the foundation base card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (left below foundations, face down) - turn over 3 cards at a time to the waste, by clicking.  Unlimited redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.
•reserve (left of tableau, next to Waste) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 48 cards are dealt here.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Three Demons is a variation of Triple Canfield and Demon, invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Triple Canfield

Demon

Canfield

Double Canfield

Quadruple Canfield

Three Pirates

Three Pirates

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (30%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved. Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile.
•stock (bottom left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to each waste pile by clicking.  No redeals.
•3 waste piles (next to stock) - top card of each pile is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Three Pirates is a variation of Forty Thieves with 3 waste piles.

Similar Games

Five Pirates

Forty Thieves

Bandit

Three Shuffles and a Cell

Three Shuffles and a Cell

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (50%).  Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•18 fans (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are not filled.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt face up to each pile (except for the last pile, which just has 1 card).
•stock (upper left, no cards) -  After all possible plays have been made, redeal by clicking on the green arrow in the upper left corner.  All the cards in the fans are reshuffled. The foundations remain.  2 redeals.
•1 cell (bottom right) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in the cell.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Three Shuffles and a Cell is La Belle Lucie with a cell, or Three Shuffles and a Draw with a cell instead of the draw.

Similar Games

La Belle Lucie

Three Shuffles and a Draw

Fan

Three Shuffles and a Draw

Three Shuffles and a Draw

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (65%).  Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•18 fans (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are not filled.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt face up to each pile (except for the last pile, which just has 1 card).  After the 2nd redeal, any one card that is not the top card of its pile may be moved to the top of its pile by right-clicking on the card.  This can only be done once (called the "draw").
•stock (upper left, no cards) -  After all possible plays have been made, redeal by clicking on the green arrow in the upper left corner.  All the cards in the fans are reshuffled. The foundations remain.  2 redeals.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•There are two ways to move cards between fans, depending on the settings under Rules in the Options menu.  If Drag and Drop is set, the cards are dragged with the mouse.  If Click is set, clicking on a card in a fan automatically moves it to the one other fan that it can move to.

 

•The name "Three Shuffles and a Draw" comes from the fact that there are 3 shuffles (counting the original starting shuffle plus the 2 redeals, and then a draw, where you can free any one single buried card.  This is done by right-clicking on the buried card.  It can only be done once.

History

Three Shuffles and a Draw is a variation of La Belle Lucie, which is the same game except that it has no draw.

Similar Games

La Belle Lucie

Fan

Shamrocks

Trefoil

Clover Leaf

Super Flower Garden

Three Shuffles and a Cell

Three Strikes

Three Strikes

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (20%).  Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•3 cells (top left) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.

 

•6 tableau piles (below foundations and cells) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 9 cards are dealt face up to the leftmost 4 piles, 8 cards are dealt face up to the remaining piles.

Options

AutoPlay

Tips

•Try to keep as many cells empty as possible.

History

Three Strikes is a typical FreeCell type game and is almost FreeCell with 6 piles and 3 cells - except groups of cards down by alternate color can be moved regardless of how many empty cells there are, making it somewhat easier than a Six by Three game would be.

Similar Games

FreeCell

Six by Four

Seven by Four

Three Up

Three Up

 Top  Previous  Next

3 Decks.  Hard (10%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•Twos foundations (first row),  Threes foundations (second row), Fours foundations (third row) - Build up in suit by threes.  Two piles (top row) are built  2, 5, 8, Jack, Three piles (second row) are built 3, 6, 9, Queen, Four piles (third row) are built 4, 7, 10, King.   An empty space can only be filled by a Two (top row), a Three (second row), or a Four (third row).  A Two, Three, or Four outside its proper row may be interchanged with another Two, Three, or Four outside its proper row if by interchanging them they are moved to their proper rows (To interchange cards, just drop one on the other).  All spaces in any row must be filled prior to the next deal from the stock.  Top card only is available for play.  At the beginning of the game a Two, Three, and Four of different suits are dealt to the first pile of each row, then one card is dealt to each of the remaining piles.
•Ace foundation (left) - build Aces only until the pile contains all 12 Aces.
•12 reserve piles (bottom row) - top card is available for play on any of the foundations. No building.  Spaces are not filled except by a deal from the stock.
•stock (top left, face down) - Deals 1 card to each reserve pile, only when all of the Two, Three, and Four foundation piles are filled.  No redeals.

Notes

•The objective is to get all Twos to start piles in the top row, all Threes to start piles in the second row, and all Fours to start piles in the third row.
•Once a Two, Three, or Four is placed in its proper row, you can build up in suit by threes on it, at the end each pile will contain 4 cards.   Aces are removed and placed in the Ace pile.
•The catch is that any space in the 3 foundation rows must be filled before you can deal out another set of cards to the reserve.  This means that before you can move any card in a foundation row to another foundation pile, you must have a Two, Three, or Four (depending on the row) available to move into the created space.  When all the cards in the stock have been dealt out, spaces are no longer an issue.
•Aces in the reserve can be immediately played to the Ace foundation.  Aces in the foundation rows can be moved when there is a Two, Three, or Four (depending on the row) available to fill the space.  It is useful to hold Aces in the foundation rows as long as possible so as to be available later when a Two, Three, or Four becomes available.
•Spaces in the reserve can only be filled by a deal from the stock.

History

Three Up is a 3 deck version of Virginia Reel.

Similar Games

Virginia Reel

Royal Parade

Blue Jacket

Three's a Crowd

Three's a Crowd

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Easy (90%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Threes to King, Ace, Two.  At the start of the game the Threes are dealt here.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Groups of cards may be moved if they are in sequence down in suit.  Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (bottom, face down on left) - move 1 card to waste by clicking.  No redeals
•waste (beside stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Three's a Crowd is a harder variation of the game Three's Company invented Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Three's Company

Busy Aces

Deuces

Fours Up

Penta

Three's Company

Three's Company

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (10%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Threes to King, Ace, Two.  At the start of the game the Threes are dealt here.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Groups of cards may be moved if they are in sequence down in suit.  Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (bottom, face down on left) - move 1 card to waste by clicking.  No redeals
•waste (beside stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Three's Company is more difficult to win than Deuces or Busy Aces.  Although multiple card moves are allowed in the tableau, there are fewer tableau piles (8 compared to 10 for Deuces).  Three's Company was invented Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games
