Threefold

Threefold

 Top  Previous  Next

3 Decks. Medium (60%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•12 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•3 cells (left) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.  The card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to first 2 cells.
•11 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  The top card is available for play on the foundations, cells, or another tableau pile.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color and if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.  Fill spaces with any card or legal group of cards.   At the start of the game 9 cards are dealt face down to each pile, then 5 more cards are dealt alternating face up and face down.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Note that groups of cards in the tableau can only be moved as a group if there are a sufficient number of empty cells available to store the cards individually.  The ability to move cards as a group is only a shortcut to moving the group one card at a time.

Tips

•Try to keep as many cells empty as possible.

History

Threefold is a 3 deck game invented by Thomas Warfield.

Thumb and Pouch

Thumb and Pouch

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Easy (95%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by any suit but the same.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by any suit but the same.  Fill spaces with any card or legal group of cards. At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card to waste pile by clicking. No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

This is a variation of Klondike.  It is fairly easy to win.

Similar Games

Klondike

Chinaman

Toni

Toni

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (45%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top and down middle)  - build the across top 4 piles up in suit from Ace to King, the down middle 4 down in suit from King to Ace.   An Ace and King of each suit is dealt at the start of the game.
•12 tableau piles (lower left and right) - top card is available for play on the foundations only.  No building.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (middle left, face down) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.  2 redeals.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Toni is a mechanical game from the Nineteenth century.

Tournament

Tournament

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (22%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top) - build the piles on the left up in suit from Ace to King, build the piles on the right down in suit from King to Ace.  Each group of 4 piles should have a pile of each suit.  An Ace or a King of each suit is dealt here at the start of the game.
•6 tableau piles (face up in the middle) - top card is available for play on the foundations or reserves.  Spaces are filled by a group of 4 cards from the stock.  No building.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•8 reserve piles (left and right sides) - each pile can contain 1 card, available for play on the foundations.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top, face down) - clicking deals 4 cards to each tableau pile.  There are 2 redeals.  (During a redeal all the cards in the tableau are collected and all the cards are redealt to the tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

 

Notes

When the foundations piles of the same suit meet, is its allowable (and encouraged) to move cards from one foundation to the other.

Tips

Try to keep at least one reserve open.  Don't put cards on the reserve that will stay there for a long time.

History

Tournament is an excellent game of strategy invented from the games La Nivernaise and Marechal Saxe by Albert Morehead and Geoffrey Mott-Smith.

Similar Games

La Nivernaise

Kingsdown Eights

Cicely

Saxony

Tower of Hanoi

Tower of Hanoi

 Top  Previous  Next

9 cards.  Easy (100%). Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to a single pile.

Layout

•3 tableau piles (center) - Any single card can be played on another card of higher rank (build down, but the ranks need not be consecutive).  Only one card may be moved at a time.  Fill spaces with any card.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt face up to each pile.

Notes

At the start of the game 9 cards of the same suit numbered Ace through Nine are dealt to 3 piles.  You can play any single card on any higher card (this is building down).  For example, an Ace, 2, 3, or 4 could be played on a 5.   You can play any card to an empty pile.  The object is get all 9 cards into one pile, from 9 down to Ace.

History

Tower of Hanoi is well known puzzle game, usually played with different sized blocks.

Tower of London

Tower of London

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (90%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•4 cells (top left) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.

 

•7 tableau piles (below foundations and cells) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color and if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.  Spaces can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.   At the start of the game 8 cards are dealt to the leftmost 3 piles, 7 cards are dealt to the remaining piles.  All cards are face up, except for the middle pile, where only the top card is face up.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Tower of London is a variation of FreeCell similar to Towers.  It was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Towers

FreeCell

Towers

Towers

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Easy (98%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (right) - build up in suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•6 tableau piles (top) - build down by color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by color and if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.  Fill spaces with any card.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•Middle Tower (face down, in tableau) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.  No building, spaces cannot be filled. At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt here, the top card is face up.
•Lower Towers (bottom left, face up) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.  No building, spaces cannot be filled.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile.
•5 free cells (bottom) - Storage cells for 1 card each.  No building. The card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Towers is a variation of FreeCell.  It was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Bell Towers

FreeCell

Tower of London

Towers of Ilium

Towers of Ilium

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (40%).  All Skill.

Object

To group all the cards into 4 sets of 13 cards in sequence down by alternate color from King to Ace within the tableau.

Layout

•4 cells (top center) - storage location for one card.   Only 1 card allowed in each cell.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the center two cells.
•10 tableau piles (below cells) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color and if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.  Spaces can be filled by any card or legal groups of cards.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt face up to each pile.

 

Options

AutoPlay

Tips

•Creating empty spaces in the tableau is the key to victory.  The more empty spaces there are, the more cards you can move as a group.  Also, keep as few cards in the cells as possible as this also allows more cards to be moved.

History

Towers of Ilium is similar to the games Scorpion Towers, Scorpion, and Sea Towers and was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Scorpion Towers

Scorpion

Sea Towers

Trapdoor Spider

Trapdoor Spider

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Easy (98%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards in sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace.

Layout

•9 tableau piles - build down regardless of suit.  Groups of cards in sequence down in suit may be moved as a unit.  Groups of cards in sequence down regardless of suit may be moved as a unit if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually. A space can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 6 cards each are dealt to the first 5 piles, 5 cards each to the remaining piles.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.  All tableau piles must be filled before dealing.
•4 cells, the "Trapdoors"  (left) - Only 1 card allowed in each cell.  Any available single card can be moved here.

Notes

•Whenever a sequence of 13 cards down in suit from King to Ace is formed, it will automatically be removed from play.

Tips

•Same suit sequences should be preferred even though building is down regardless of suit.  The object is to build down in suit sequences.

History

Trapdoor Spider is a variation of Spider.  Trapdoor Spider was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Spider

Black Widow

Travellers Clock

Travellers Clock

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (10%).  Luck.

Object

To arrange all the cards in the form of a clock, with all the Queens in a pile at the top, then clockwise around Aces, Twos, up to Jacks, and Kings in the middle.

Layout

•13 tableau piles (the clock) - build in the same rank on the pile corresponding to the clock face position for that rank. For example, Threes go in the far right pile, Sixes in the far bottom pile.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  When a card is moved to a pile it goes to the bottom of that pile and the top card of the pile is turned face up and is available for play on its proper pile.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile.

Notes

Play consists of re-ordering the cards to get each card into the pile that corresponds to its clock position.  Allowable building is of the same rank.  Kings go in the center pile.  Play continues until the 4th King is found or until all the cards in the correct clock face positions.  If the 4th King appears before all the other cards are correctly placed, the game is lost.

History

This game is also known as Travellers or just plain Clock.

Similar Games

Clock

Order Time

Trefoil

Trefoil

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (20%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.  At the start of the game the Aces are dealt here.
•16 fans (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are not filled.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (upper left, no cards) -  There are two redeals.  After all possible plays have been made, redeal by clicking on the green arrow in the upper left corner.  All the cards in the fans are reshuffled. The foundations remain.  When the green arrow becomes an x'ed out, there are no more redeals.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•There are two ways to move cards between fans, depending on the settings under Rules in the Options menu.  If Drag and Drop is set, the cards are dragged with the mouse.  If Click is set, clicking on a card in a fan automatically moves it to the one other fan that it can move to.

History

Trefoil is a variation of La Belle Lucie.  The difference is that in Trefoil the four Aces are dealt to the foundations at the beginning of the game.   This makes it slightly easier to win.

Similar Games

La Belle Lucie

Fan

Shamrocks

Clover Leaf

Super Flower Garden

Trevi Garden

Trevi Garden

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (30%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (2 on top left, 2 on top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•6 tableau "Garden" piles (below foundations, 3 on left, 3 on right) - build down by alternate color.  Groups of cards in sequence down by alternate color may be moved as a unit.  Spaces are filled by any card.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•reserve "Fountain" (center top) - All cards available for play on the foundations or tableau.  Click on card to move it to the bottom of the stack, then move to either the foundations or tableau.   At the start of the game 14 cards are dealt to this pile.
•2 cells (between foundations and reserve on each side) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Trevi Garden is a variation of Stonewall invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Stonewall

Flower Garden

Triangle

Triangle

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Hard (2%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To pair up all the cards in the deck in pairs of cards whose ranks total to 13.

Layout

•An inverted pyramid of 28 cards.  Only uncovered cards are available for play.  Discard pairs of cards whose ranks add to 13.  Kings are discarded singly.  To discard a pair, drop one card on the other, or right-click on one of the cards.
•stock (top right) - turn over cards one to each waste pile by clicking.  No redeals.
•2 waste piles (below stock) - The top card is available for play.

Notes

•Any pair of cards whose values add to 13 can be discarded.  The valid pairs are Queen-Ace, Jack-Two, 10-3, 9-4, 8-5, 7-6.  Kings are discarded singly.  To discards Kings, simply click on them.

History

This game is like Pyramid, except that the pyramid is inverted, and there are 2 waste piles.  It is more difficult to win.  Much depends on how quickly you can remove the tip of the pyramid.

Similar Games

Pyramid

Eleven Triangle

Giza

Pharaohs

Pyramid Golf

Triangulum

Triangular

Triangular

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (75%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards with a King at the bottom. At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time, by clicking.  Unlimited redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Triangular is Klondike where the tableau is built down regardless of suit while only groups down in suit may be moved.

Similar Games

Klondike

Trigon

Rectangular

Triangulum

Triangulum

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (15%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To pair up all the cards in the deck in pairs of cards whose ranks total to 13.

Layout

•An inverted pyramid of 28 cards.  Only uncovered cards are available for play.  Discard pairs of cards whose ranks add to 13.  Kings are discarded singly.  To discard a pair, drop one card on the other, or right-click on one of the cards.
•stock (top right) - turn over cards one to each waste pile by clicking.  No redeals.
•3 waste piles (below stock) - The top card is available for play.

Notes

•Any pair of cards whose values add to 13 can be discarded.  The valid pairs are Queen-Ace, Jack-Two, 10-3, 9-4, 8-5, 7-6.  Kings are discarded singly.  To discards Kings, simply click on them.

History

This is an easier version of Triangle.  Much depends on how quickly you can remove the tip of the pyramid.

Similar Games

Triangle

Pyramid

Eleven Triangle

Trigon

Trigon

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (50%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards with a King at the bottom. At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time, by clicking.  Unlimited redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Trigon is Klondike where the tableau is built down in suit

Trigon Left

Trigon Left

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (20%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit.  Spaces are filled automatically by the face up card or group of cards in the pile immediately to the right of the open space.  The rightmost pile, if empty, may be filled with a King or a legal group of cards headed by a King. At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time, by clicking.  Unlimited redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Trigon Left is Trigon with elements of Moving Left.

Similar Games

Trigon

Moving Left

Klondike

Double Trigon

Three Bears

Quadruple Trigon

Trillium

Trillium

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (65%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards into 8 sets of 13 cards in sequence down by alternate color from King to Ace within the tableau.

Layout

•13 tableau piles - build down by alternate color.  Groups of cards in sequence down by alternate color may be moved as a unit.   Spaces are filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile, alternating face up and face down..
•stock (bottom center) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.  No redeals.

 

Similar Games

Lily

Curds and Whey

Spider

Triple Alaska

Triple Alaska

 Top  Previous  Next

3 Decks.  Medium (30%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•12 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•13 tableau piles (below foundations) - build up or down by suit.  Move groups of cards regardless of any sequence.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.   At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd pile, and so on.  The top card is face up.  Then 5 additional face up cards are dealt to each of the 2nd through 10th piles.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Any face up card in the tableau may be built upon another, no matter how deep it is in a pile.  All cards covering it are moved together.  When a face down card is uncovered, it is automatically turned face up and is available for play.

History

Triple Alaska is a 3 deck version of Alaska.

Similar Games

Alaska

Triple Russian

Triple Yukon

Triple Canfield

Triple Canfield

 Top  Previous  Next

3 Decks.  Easy (99%).  Skill/luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations

Layout

•12 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations on right) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces are filled from the reserve if possible, else by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (left below foundations, face down) - turn over 3 cards at a time to the waste, by clicking.  Unlimited redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.
•reserve (left of tableau, next to Waste) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 26 cards are dealt here.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Triple Canfield is a three-deck version of the classic game Canfield, invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Canfield

Double Canfield

Quadruple Canfield

Three Demons

Triple Demons

Triple Demons

 Top  Previous  Next

3 Decks.  Medium (50%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•12 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•12 tableau piles (below foundations) - build first 5 (left of line) down by alternate color.  Build remaining 7 (right of line) down in suit, wrapping from Ace to King if necessary in both cases.  Move groups of cards if they form a legal descending sequence for that pile.  Spaces can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt each to the left 5 piles, and 8 cards are dealt to each of the remaining 7 piles.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (below stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.
•reserve (below waste) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 13 cards are dealt here.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•The tableau piles are divided into two parts: the Left tableau and the Right tableau, divided by a line.  The 5 Left tableau piles are built down by alternate color.  The 7 Right tableau piles are built down in suit.  Groups of cards may be moved from one tableau pile to another, if they form a legal descending sequence in their current pile.  For example, a sequence down by alternate color may be moved from the Left tableau to the Right, since that is the legal sequence for the Left tableau.  However, a sequence down by alternate color cannot be moved from the Right tableau to the Left, since that sequence is not legal on the Right.  These kinds of groups transfers are called "shifts".  Shifts of groups down by alternate color are allowed from Left to Right, while shifts of down in suit cards are allowed from Right to Left.  Once an shift has been made, the cards in the groups cannot again be moved as a group, since they will no longer be a legal group for their side of the tableau.

 

 

Tips

•The secret to success is strategic shifting between the the left tableau and the right tableau.

 

History

Triple Demon is a 3 deck variation of Demons and Thieves invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Demons and Thieves

Demonthief

Quadruple Demons

Triple Easthaven

Triple Easthaven

 Top  Previous  Next

3 Decks.  Easy (90%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations

Layout

•12 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•12 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Fill spaces with any card or legal sequence of cards.  At the start of the game, 3 cards are dealt to each pile, 2 face down and 1 face up.

 

•stock (top left, face down) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Triple Easthaven is a three deck version of Easthaven invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Easthaven

Double Easthaven

Triple Fourteens

Triple Fourteens

 Top  Previous  Next

3 Decks.  Easy (85%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To pair up all cards and move them out of play to the waste pile.

Layout

•24 tableau piles - the top card of each pile is available.  Pair cards that total to 14.  For example, a King and an Ace, a Queen and a 2, or an 8 and a 6.  To remove a pair, pick up one card with the mouse and drop it on the other.  At the beginning of the game 6 cards are dealt to each of the first 12 piles, and 5 cards are dealt the remaining 12 piles.

 

•waste pile (far right) - where paired cards go out of play.

Notes

•Cards that pair to 14: King-Ace, Queen-2, Jack-3, 10-4, 9-5, 8-6, 7-7.

History

Triple Fourteens is a three deck version of Fourteen Out invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Double Fourteens

Fourteen Out

Triple FreeCell

Triple FreeCell

 Top  Previous  Next

3 Decks.  Easy (99%).  Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations

Layout

•12 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 cells (below foundations) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.  The card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.
•13 tableau piles (below foundations and cells) - build down by alternate color.  The top card is available for play on the foundations, cells, or another tableau pile.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color and if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.  Fill spaces with any card or legal group of cards.   At the start of the game 12 cards are dealt to each pile.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Note that groups of cards in the tableau can only be moved as a group if there are a sufficient number of empty cells available to store the cards individually.  The ability to move cards as a group is only a shortcut to moving the group one card at a time.

Tips

•Try to keep as many cells empty as possible.

History

Triple FreeCell is a 3-deck version of FreeCell.  It was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

FreeCell

Double FreeCell

Cell 11

Quadruple FreeCell

Object

Layout

•12 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•5 cells (below foundations) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.  The card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.
•13 tableau piles (below foundations and cells) - build down by alternate color.  The top card is available for play on the foundations, cells, or another tableau pile.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color and if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.  Fill spaces with any card or legal group of cards.   At the start of the game 12 cards are dealt to each pile.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Note that groups of cards in the tableau can only be moved as a group if there are a sufficient number of empty cells available to store the cards individually.  The ability to move cards as a group is only a shortcut to moving the group one card at a time.

Tips

 Top  Previous  Next

3 Decks.  Easy (90%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•12 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•13 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Fill spaces with Kings or a group of cards headed by a King. At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.  The top card is face up.
•stock (bottom left, face down) - turn over 3 cards at a time to the waste by clicking during the first deal, 2 cards at a time during the 2nd deal, and 1 card at a time during the last deal.  Two redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Triple Harp

Triple Harp

 Top  Previous  Next

3 Decks.  Hard (10%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•12 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•12 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color. Only one card at a time may be moved, except groups of cards down by alternate color may be moved as a unit into an empty space. Spaces are filled by a King or a group of cards headed with a King (the only way a group of cards may be moved).  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 to the 2nd, and so on.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card to the waste by clicking.  Three redeals.
•waste (below stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Triple Harp is a three deck variation of Harp invented by Thomas Warfield.

Triple Minerva

Triple Minerva

 Top  Previous  Next

3 Decks.  Hard (10%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•12 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•12 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards with a King at the bottom.  At the start of the game 8 rows of cards are dealt alternately face down and face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time, by clicking.  One redeal.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.
•reserve (left of tableau) - Top card always available for play on the tableau or foundations.  At the start of the game 15 cards are dealt here.

AutoPlay

History

Triple Minerva is a three deck version of Minerva invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Double Minerva

Minerva

Triple Peaks

Triple Peaks

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.

Object

To move cards to the waste pile with the highest possible score.

Layout

•3 triangular peaks of cards - move cards to the waste by clicking.  Only uncovered cards are available for play.
•stock (bottom, face down) - move cards 1 at a time to the waste by clicking.
•waste (bottom, face up) - build up or down regardless of suit, wrapping from Ace to King and King to Ace as necessary.

Notes

•Scoring is as follows:  1 point for the first card moved from the peaks to the wastee, 2 points for the 2nd, 3 for the third and so on, until no more cards can be moved.  When a card is turned over from the stock, scoring returns to 1 point for the next card from the peaks.   Also, when a card is turned over from the stock, 5 points is subtracted from the score.   15 bonus points are awarded when the top of each of the first two peaks are moved to the waste, and 30 bonus points are awarded when all peaks have been moved.   If a new game is started, 5 points are subtracted for each card remaining in the peaks.

Similar Games

Pyramid Golf

Triple Rail

Triple Rail

 Top  Previous  Next

Object

•9 tableau piles (below foundations) -  build down regardless of suit.  Groups of cards can be moved if they are in sequence down regardless of suit.  Spaces are filled by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (bottom left) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste pile by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Similar Games

Triple Russian

Triple Russian

 Top  Previous  Next

3 Decks.  Medium (20%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•12 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•13 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Move groups of cards regardless of any sequence.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.   At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd pile, and so on.  The top card is face up.  Then 5 additional face up cards are dealt to each of the 2nd through 10th piles.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Any face up card in the tableau may be built upon another, no matter how deep it is in a pile.  All cards covering it are moved together.  When a face down card is uncovered, it is automatically turned face up and is available for play.

Triple Scorpion

Triple Scorpion

 Top  Previous  Next

3 Decks.  Hard (10%).  Skill.

Object

To group all the cards into 12 sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace within the tableau.

Layout

•13 tableau piles - build down in suit.  Groups of cards may be moved regardless of any sequence.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 12 cards are dealt to each pile.  In the first 6 piles, 5 cards are face down, all others are face up.

Notes

The object of play is to manipulate the tableau into 12 piles, one for each suit, with the cards down in sequence from King to Ace.

History

Triple Scorpion is a three-deck version of the game Scorpion invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Scorpion

Double Scorpion

Triple Spidike

Triple Spidike

 Top  Previous  Next

3 Decks.  Medium (60%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•12 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•13 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Move groups of cards only if they are in sequence down in suit.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.
•stock (top left, face down) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.

Options

AutoPlay

Tips

•Same suit sequences should be preferred even though building is down regardless of suit.  The foundations are built up in suit.

History

Triple Spidike is a 3 deck variation of the game Spidike.  Triple Spidike was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Double Spidike

Spidike

Triple Storehouse

Triple Storehouse

 Top  Previous  Next

3 Decks.  Medium (90%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•12 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Twos up to Kings, then Aces.
•9 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit, wrapping from Ace to King as necessary.  Spaces are filled from the Storehouse if possible, then by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste, by clicking.  One redeal.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.
•reserve (the "Storehouse", left of tableau) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 24 cards are dealt to this pile.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Triple Storehouse is a 3 deck version of Storehouse invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games
