Canfield

Triple Triangle

Triple Triangle

 Top  Previous  Next

3 Decks.  Hard (5%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•12 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•13 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.   Spaces are filled by a King or a group of cards headed with a King.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 to the 2nd, and so on.  All cards are face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - deals one card to each tableau pile by clicking.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Triple Triangle is a variation of Eternal Triangle invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Eternal Triangle

Triple Harp

Triple Yukon

Triple Yukon

 Top  Previous  Next

3 Decks.  Easy (90%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•12 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•13 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards regardless of any sequence.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.   At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd pile, and so on.  The top card is face up.  Then 5 additional face up cards are dealt to each of the 2nd through 10th piles.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Any face up card in the tableau may be built upon another, no matter how deep it is in a pile.  All cards covering it are moved together.  When a face down card is uncovered, it is automatically turned face up and is available for play.

History

Triple Yukon is a 3 deck version of Yukon invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Yukon

Double Yukon

Quadruple Yukon

Triple Russian

Triple Alaska

Triton

Triton

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Modified Decks (Queens Removed). Hard (10%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To pair cards until the stock is empty.

Layout

•16 tableau piles (center) - Pair up cards of consecutive rank.  Ace and King are not consecutive.  Cards are immediately replaced from the stock.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top) - cards automatically replaced removed pairs in the tableau.

Notes

•Pair cards of consecutive ranks, such as Aces with Twos, Fives with Sixes, and so on. Removed pairs are replaced with two new cards from the stock.

 

•Kings can never be paired and will block the tableau.  Jacks must be paired with Tens and Aces must be paired with Twos, while all cards in between can be paired on both sides.

 

• The game is won when the stock is empty.

 

History

Triton is a variation of Neptune invented by user Chris Stevens.

Similar Games

Neptune

Trusty Twelve

Trusty Twelve

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck. Medium (20%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the tableau.

Layout

•12 tableau piles  - build down regardless of suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are filled automatically from the stock.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (left, face down) - automatically fills spaces in the tableau.

Notes

The idea is to get all of the cards in play by grouping cards in piles down regardless of suit, which brings more cards into play via the empty spaces created.  The game is won if all cards are moved from the stock onto the tableau.

Similar Games

Sweet Sixteen

Knotty Nines

Bunker

Up and Up

Eleven Up

Turnover the Rainbow

Turnover the Rainbow

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (50%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•4 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down regardless of suit.  Spaces are filled from the reserve, or if the reserve is empty by any card. At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  Two redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.
•reserve (left of tableau) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 13 cards are dealt here.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Turnover the Rainbow is a variation of Rainbow with two redeals.

Similar Games

Rainbow

Canfield

Chameleon

Storehouse

Ozymandias

Tuxedo

Tuxedo

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Easy (98%).  Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 cells (bottom) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.  The card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

 

•7 tableau piles - build down in suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit.  Spaces can be filled only by Kings.  At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt face up to each pile, except the first, fourth, and seventh piles, which are dealt 8 cards.

Options

AutoPlay

Tips

•Try to keep as many cells empty as possible.

History

Tuxedo is an easier version of Penguin.

Similar Games

Opus

Penguin

Emperor Penguin

Twelve Piles

Twelve Piles

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (70%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.

 

•12 tableau piles (left of foundations) - build down in suit.  Groups of cards in sequence down in suit may be moved as a unit.   Spaces can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile, alternating face up and face down.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Twelve Piles is a more difficult version of Martha.

Similar Games

Martha

Stewart

Vineyard

Baker's Dozen

Beleaguered Castle

Twenty

Twenty

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (40%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top)  - build the first 4 piles up in suit from Ace to King, the last 4 down in suit from King to Ace.  At the start of the game an Ace and King of each suit is dealt here.
•20 tableau Piles (below foundations) - top card is available for play on the foundations.  Spaces are filled automatically from the stock.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.  No redeals.

History

Twenty is a very simple game involving no strategy whatsoever.

Similar Games

Colorado

Carpet

Sixteen

Twenty Piles

Twenty Piles

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Easy (90%).  Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (left) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•4 cells (right) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.  The card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game one card is dealt to each cell.
•20 tableau piles (between foundations and cells) - The piles are built down by alternate color.  The top card is available for play on the foundations, cells, or another tableau pile.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color and if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.  Fill spaces with Kings or legal groups of cards headed by a King)  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt to each pile.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Note that groups of cards in the tableau can only be moved as a group if there are a sufficient number of empty cells available to store the cards individually.  The ability to move cards as a group is only a shortcut to moving the group one card at a time.

Tips

•Try to keep as many cells empty as possible.

History

Twenty Piles is a two-deck version of FreeCell.  It was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Double FreeCell

FreeCell

Triple FreeCell

FreeCell Duplex

FreeCell Twice

Twin Queens

Twin Queens

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (70%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (in center) - build up in suit from King to Ace up to Queen.
•8 tableau piles (to left and right of foundations) - build down in suit.  Spaces are filled from the waste.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (upper left, face down) - 1 card at a time moved to the waste by clicking.  One redeal.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Twin Queens is a variation of Congress.  Its name comes from the final winning position, where pairs of Queens are lined up.

Similar Games

Diplomat

Twister

Twister

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Easy (85%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Groups of cards in sequence down by alternate color may be moved.  Spaces may be filled by Kings or a legal group of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (bottom, face down on left) - move 3 cards at a time to waste by clicking.  Unlimited redeals.
•waste (beside stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Twister was invented using the Solitaire Wizard by Heidi Good.

Similar Games

Little Napoleon

Springfield

Red Hand

Loopy

Twisty Thirteens

Twisty Thirteens

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck. Medium (40%).  Skill/Luck Balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the tableau.

Layout

•14 tableau piles  - build cards whose ranks add to 13, by alternate color.  Kings can be played on any card by alternate color.  Kings in alternate colors can be played on Kings, but no other card can be played on a King. Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are filled automatically from the stock.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left, face up) - automatically fills spaces in the tableau.  Top card is available for play on the tableau.

Notes

The idea is to get all of the cards in play by grouping cards in piles.  Allowable plays are A-Q, 2-J, 3-10, 4-9, 5-8, 6-7, and King on any card and K-K.  All plays must be of alternate color.  The game is won if all cards are moved from the stock onto the tableau.  Each tableau pile can regularly hold 4 cards, except if a King is played to it, in which case it can hold more (all Kings).

Similar Games

Trusty Twelve

Sweet Sixteen

Knotty Nines

Up and Up

Feisty Fifteens

Two Castles

Two Castles

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (60%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (middle) - build up in suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•10 tableau piles (left and right of foundations) - build down in suit.  Only the top card of each pile is available for play.  Spaces may be filled by any available card.  At the start of the game 1 card are dealt to each pile.
•stock (bottom center, face down) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.  No redeals.  When the stock has been dealt out for the final time, the single remaining card is turned face up and is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Two Castles was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Fortress

Beleaguered Castle

Two Cells

Two Cells

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (20%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•2 cells (top left) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.

 

•8 tableau piles (below foundations and cells) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color and if there are enough free cells that the cards could be moved individually.  Spaces can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.   At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt face up to the leftmost 4 piles, 6 cards are dealt face up to the remaining piles.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Groups of cards in the tableau can only be moved as a group if there are a sufficient number of empty cells available to store the cards individually.  The ability to move cards as a group is only a shortcut to moving the group one card at a time.
•The game number deals #1 to #1000000 are compatible with the games in the standard Windows FreeCell.  For more information about FreeCell type games, see http://www.freecell.org.

Tips

•Try to keep as many cells empty as possible.

History

Two Cells is FreeCell with only 2 cells.

Similar Games

Scottish Canister

FreeCell

Three Cells

Baker's Game

One Cell

Undercover Aces

Undercover Aces

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (50%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (center row) - build up in suit from Aces to Kings.
•8 reserve piles (top row) - top card becomes available for play when an Ace is played to the foundation pile directly below it.  top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile, top card face down.

 

 

•8 tableau piles (bottom row) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces may be filled by any card of group of cards.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt to each pile, the top card face up.
•stock (far left) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.

Similar Games

Undercover Aces Easy

Undercover Aces Easy

Undercover Aces Easy

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (60%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (center row) - build up in suit from Aces to Kings.
•8 reserve piles (top row) - top card becomes available for play when an Ace is played to the foundation pile directly below it, except for the last foundation, which becomes available when the 2nd to last Ace is played.  Top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile, top card face down.

 

 

•8 tableau piles (bottom row) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces may be filled by any card of group of cards.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt to each pile, the top card face up.
•stock (far left) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.

Notes

Undercover Aces Easy is a variation of Undercover Aces.  It is exactly like Undercover Aces, except that when the 2nd to last Ace is played to a foundation pile, both the reserve pile directly above that Ace and the reserve pile directly above the final remaining empty foundation pile become available.  This brings out the last cards in the reserve somewhat faster than in Undercover Aces.

Similar Games

Undercover Aces

Ukrainian Solitaire

Ukrainian Solitaire

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (13%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards into 4 sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - move entire 13-card King to Ace down in suit sequences from the tableau.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit, wrapping from Ace to King if necessary.  Move groups of cards regardless of any sequence.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King (see KingOnly for option).   At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt to each pile, with 1 card face down in the second pile, 2 cards face down in the 3rd pile, and so on.  Then one additional face up card is dealt to each of the three rightmost piles.

Options

AutoPlay   KingOnly

Notes

•Any face up card in the tableau may be built upon another, no matter how deep it is in a pile.  All cards covering it are moved together.  When a face down card is uncovered, it is automatically turned face up and is available for play.

History

Ukrainian Solitaire is a cross between Russian Solitaire and Spider.  Its origin is unknown.  It was reported to the author by Jay York, who learned the game from a college roommate who learned it from his Ukrainian grandmother.

Similar Games

Kiev

Dnieper

Russian Solitaire

Spider

Yukon

Siberia

Romanian Solitaire

Crimean Solitaire

Grigory

Uncanny

Uncanny

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (35%)  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top center) - build up regardless of suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.   At the start of the game an Ace is dealt to the first pile, a Five to the 2nd, an Eight to the 3rd, and a Jack to the 4th.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - No building is allowed.  The top card is available for play on the foundations.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are not filled.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking. No redeals.

Union Square

Union Square

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Easy (75%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•12 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit. Groups of cards in sequence down in suit may be moved as a unit. Spaces can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile, alternating face down and face up.
•stock (face down, top left) - move one card to waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (beside stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Union Square is a variation of Napoleon's Square.

Similar Games

Napoleon's Square

Carre Napoleon

Forty Thieves

Limited

Unlimited

Unlimited

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (34%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.   At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt to each pile, alternating face up and face down.
•stock (face down) - turn over cards one at a time to the waste by clicking.  Unlimited redeals.
•waste (below stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

This is a variation of Interchange.  It allows unlimited redeals which gives the player a much better chance of winning than in Interchange.

Similar Games

Interchange

Single Interchange

Triple Interchange

Quadruple Interchange

Breakwater

Forty-Nine

Unlimited Alternative

Unlimited Alternative

Unlimited Alternative

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (15%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Fill spaces with any card or legal group of cards.   At the start of the game 7 cards are dealt to each pile, alternating face up and face down.
•stock (face down) - turn over cards one at a time to the waste by clicking.  Unlimited redeals.
•waste (below stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Unlimited Alternatios is a variation of Alternations.

Similar Games

Interchange

Unlimited

Alternations

Breakwater

Forty-Nine

Unusual

Unusual

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (20%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.  At the start of the game the Aces are dealt here.
•24 tableau piles (center) - build down in suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are not filled.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt to each pile.
•stock (left, with green arrow) - clicking on the stock collects all the cards from the tableau and redeals them.  Unlimited redeals.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•When play on the tableau comes to a standstill, the tableau can be redealt by clicking on the stock.  The cards are collected from the tableau starting with the last pile (lower right) of the tableau back to the first pile (top left), with the cards from the last pile on the bottom.  They are then redealt 4 cards to a pile starting with the first pile.
•Because of the way the cards are redealt, if no moves are made in the tableau the cards will be redealt back exactly the same way they were previously.  Therefore, after every deal you must be able to make at least one move in the tableau or the game is lost.

Similar Games

Cruel

Up and Up

Up and Up

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck. Hard (10%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the tableau.

Layout

•10 tableau piles  - build up regardless of suit, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are filled automatically from the stock.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (left, face up) - automatically fills spaces in the tableau, top card is available for play on the tableau.

Notes

The idea is to get all of the cards in play by grouping cards in piles up regardless of suit, which brings more cards into play via the empty spaces created.  The game is won if all cards are moved from the stock onto the tableau.

Similar Games

Trusty Twelve

Sweet Sixteen

Knotty Nines

Bunker

Eleven Up

Up or Down

Up or Down

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (50%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build up or down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color and/or up by alternate color.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards with a King at the bottom. At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 3 cards at a time, by clicking.  Two redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Up or Down is Klondike with up or down building.

Similar Games

Klondike

Upside Down

Upside Down

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (50%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King. At the start of the game the Aces are dealt here.
•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Groups of cards in sequence down by alternate color may be moved as a unit.  Spaces may be filled only by Kings.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 3 to the 2nd, 5 to the 3rd, 7 to the 4th, 9 to the 5th, 10 to the 6th, 8 to the 7th, 6 to the 8th, 4 to the 9th, and 2 to the 10th.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 3 cards at a time to the waste by clicking.  Unlimited redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Upside Down is a variation of Thieves of Egypt.

Similar Games

Thieves of Egypt

Alexandria

Cleopatra

Swiss Patience

Forty Thieves

Usk

Usk

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (15%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Aces to Kings.
•10 tableau piles - build down by alternate color.  Groups of cards in sequence down by alternate color may be moved.  Spaces may be filled by Kings or a legal group of cards headed by a King. At the start of the game 8 cards are dealt to the first 3 piles, 7 cards to the 4th pile, 6 cards to the 5th, and so on down to 1 card to the last pile.
•stock (top left) - clicking redeals the tableau. The cards are picked up starting with the rightmost pile moving to the left.  The cards are then redealt out to the tableau.  One redeal.

History

Usk is similar to Somerset.

Similar Games

Somerset

King Albert

Raglan

Variegated Canfield

Variegated Canfield

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Very Hard (2%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Aces to Kings.  At the start of the game the Aces are dealt here.
•5 tableau piles (below foundations on right) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces are filled from the reserve if possible, else by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (left below foundations, face down) - turn over  3 cards at a time to the waste, by clicking.  2 redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.
•reserve (left of tableau, next to Waste) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 13 cards are dealt here.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Variegated Canfield is variation of Double Canfield and Canfield.

Similar Games

Double Canfield

Canfield

Superior Canfield

American Toad

Venice

Venice

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (70%). Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (middle) - build up by alternate color from the rank of first card moved to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•9 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces may be filled by any card not from the reserve.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to the first 4 piles.  One of these cards is selected to be the foundation base card by moving it to the first foundation pile.  After a card is so moved 1 card is dealt face up to the remaining empty piles.
•reserve (top) - top card is available for play on the foundations only.  At the start of the game 11 cards are dealt here.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over cards 1 at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals, except that when the stock is empty the waste may be turned over to form a new stock by clicking on the empty stock.  Cards may then then be played to the foundations or tableau until an unplayable card is reached (which ends the game).
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Venice is a variation of Queen of Italy.

Similar Games

Queen of Italy

Terrace

Verge

Verge

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck. Medium (15%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To pair up all the cards in the deck in pairs of cards whose ranks total to 13.

Layout

•7 tableau piles (across top) - no building.  Discard pairs of cards whose ranks add to 13.  Kings are discarded singly.  To discard a pair, drop one card on the other, or right-click on one of the cards.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt face up to each pile, except for the first and last pile, which are dealt only 4 cards.
•stock (face down below tableau) - turn over 1 card to the waste by clicking.  2 redeals.

 

•waste (next to stock) - The top card is available for pairing.

 

History

Verge is a variation of Links invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Links

Pyramid

Golf

Vertical

Vertical

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (40%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To pair up all the cards and move them to the waste pile.

Layout

•7 tableau piles (across top) - the top card is available for play.  Pair up cards of the same rank.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt face up to each pile (except for the center pile which is dealt 7 cards).   The cards are dealt in such a way that no two cards of the same rank are dealt to the same pile.
•9 extra cards (below tableau) - each card is available for play.
•waste pile - Where paired cards go out of play.

History

Vertical is a variation of Nestor.

Similar Games

Nestor

Doublets

Double Vertical

Double Nestor

Alcides

Vincent

Vincent

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (65%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•8 Fans (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.

 

•stock (face down) - Turn over cards 3 at a time, one to each waste pile.  There are no redeals.

 

•3 waste piles (to the right of the Stock) - The top card of each waste pile is available for play.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Vincent is a variation of Bristol.

Similar Games

Bristol

New York

Dover

Cardiff

Vineyard

Vineyard

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (6%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.

 

•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are filled by any card.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt face up to each pile (6 cards are dealt to the first 2 piles).

Options

AutoPlay

History

Vineyard is a variation of Good Measure.  It was invented using the Solitaire Wizard by Peter Voke.

Similar Games

Winery

Good Measure

Martha

Viper

Viper

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (60%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards regardless of any sequence (Yukon style group moving).  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.   At the start of the game 8 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (face down, top left) - turn over cards one at a time to the first tableau pile (which is also the waste pile) by clicking.  No redeals.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

The first tableau pile is also the waste pile.  It begins the game with 8 cards and cards are dealt to it one at a time from the stock.  A card or group of cards can also be moved to this pile from other tableau piles (assuming the group follows the building rules for the tableau piles).

Similar Games

Snake

Virginia Reel

Virginia Reel

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (10%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•Twos foundations (first row),  Threes foundations (second row), Fours foundations (third row) - Build up in suit by threes.  Two piles (top row) are built  2, 5, 8, Jack, Three piles (second row) are built 3, 6, 9, Queen, Four piles (third row) are built 4, 7, 10, King.   An empty space can only be filled by a Two (top row), a Three (second row), or a Four (third row).   All spaces in any row must be filled prior to the next deal from the stock.  Top card only is available for play.  At the beginning of the game a Two, Three, and Four of different suits are dealt to the first pile of each row, then one card is dealt to each of the remaining piles.
•A Two, Three, or Four outside its proper row may be interchanged with another Two, Three, or Four outside its proper row if by interchanging them they are moved to their proper rows (To interchange cards, just drop one on the other).
•Ace foundation (left) - build Aces only until the pile contains all 8 Aces.
•8 reserve piles (bottom row) - top card is available for play on any of the foundations. No building.  Spaces are not filled except by a deal from the stock.
•stock (top left, face down) - Deals 1 card to each reserve pile, only when all of the Two, Three, and Four foundation piles are filled.  No redeals.

Notes

•The objective is to get all Twos to start piles in the top row, all Threes to start piles in the second row, and all Fours to start piles in the third row.
•Once a Two, Three, or Four is placed in its proper row, you can build up in suit by threes on it, at the end each pile will contain 4 cards.   Aces are removed and placed in the Ace pile.
•The catch is that any space in the 3 foundation rows must be filled before you can deal out another set of cards to the reserve.  This means that before you can move any card in a foundation row to another foundation pile, you must have a Two, Three, or Four (depending on the row) available to move into the created space.  When all the cards in the stock have been dealt out, spaces are no longer an issue.
•Aces in the reserve can be immediately played to the Ace foundation.  Aces in the foundation rows can be moved when there is a Two, Three, or Four (depending on the row) available to fill the space.  It is useful to hold Aces in the foundation rows as long as possible so as to be available later when a Two, Three, or Four becomes available.
•Spaces in the reserve can only be filled by a deal from the stock.

History

Virginia Reel is a highly strategic and interesting game invented by Albert H. Morehead and Geoffrey Mott-Smith as an improvement to the game Royal Parade.

Similar Games

Royal Parade

Three Up

Blue Jacket

Volga

Volga

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (20%).   Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Move groups of cards regardless of any sequence.  Fill spaces with any card or group of cards.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd pile, and so on.  The top card is face up.  Then 4 additional face up cards are dealt to the 2nd through 7th piles.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Any face up card in the tableau may be built upon another, no matter how deep it is in a pile.  All cards covering it are moved together.  When a face down card is uncovered, it is automatically turned face up and is available for play.

History

Volga is an easier version of Russian Solitaire.

Similar Games

Russian Solitaire

Yukon

Great River

Wading Pool

Wading Pool

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (95%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards into 4 sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace within the tableau.

Layout

•8 tableau piles (top) - build down in suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit.  Spaces can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game these piles are empty.

 

•8 reserve piles (below tableau) - build down in suit.  Top card is available for play on the tableau or reserves.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are not filled.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt to each pile (the first 4 piles are dealt 7).

Notes

•Play consists of moving cards from the reserve piles to the tableau (and then moving cards within the tableau) in order to form 4 sequences down in suit from King to Ace.

Tips

•Try to begin by concentrating on grouping cards of one or two suits together.

History

Wading Pool is an easier version of Wave Motion.

Similar Games

Wave Motion

Waning Moon

Waning Moon

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (80%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•13 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit. Only one card at at time may be moved.  Spaces may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Waning Moon is a variation of Forty Thieves and is very similar to Lucas.

Similar Games

Waxing Moon

Eclipse

Thirty-Nine Steps

Lucas

Limited

Forty Thieves

Shining Star

Old Moon

Waterloo

Waterloo

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (20%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.  At the start of the game the Aces are dealt here.
•6 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Groups of cards can be moved if they are in sequence down in suit.  Spaces filled by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (bottom left) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste pile by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

Similar Games

Forty Thieves

Wave Motion

Wave Motion

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard  (15%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards into 4 sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace within the tableau.

Layout

•8 tableau piles (top) - build down in suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit.  Spaces can be filled by any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game these piles are empty.

 

•8 reserve piles (below tableau) - No building.  Top card is available for play on the tableau (a group of cards that is in sequence down in suit may also be moved as a group to the tableau).  Spaces are not filled.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt to each pile (the first 4 piles are dealt 7).

Notes

•Play consists of moving cards from the reserve piles to the tableau (and then moving cards within the tableau) in order to form 4 sequences down in suit from King to Ace.

Tips

•Try to begin by concentrating on grouping cards of one or two suits together.

History

Wave Motion is related to FreeCell and Scorpion.  It was invented by David Bernazzani.

Similar Games

FreeCell

Scorpion

Flow

Spider Motion

Waxing Moon

Waxing Moon

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (1%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•12 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Groups of cards in sequence down in suit may be moved as a unit.  Spaces may be filled by Kings or a legal group of cards headed by a King.   At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Waxing Moon is in the Forty Thieves family.  It was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Waning Moon

Lucas

Limited

Forty Thieves

Weddings

Weddings

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (85%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To discard all the cards in pairs.

Layout

•25 Piles arranged in a 5x5 square - discard pairs of cards of the same rank that are adjacent to each other, either horizontally, vertically, or diagonally.

Notes

•Whenever a pair is discarded, the remaining cards will be moved to the top in the following way: spaces are filled by moving cards to the left.  If there are spaces on a higher row, a card is moved from the leftmost pile of the lower row to the rightmost pile of the higher row.  New cards are dealt to fill the spaces at the bottom.  All the cards are moved in this way until all the spaces are at the bottom.

History

Weddings is a variation of Monte Carlo. Spaces in the layout are filled immediately, rather than only when the fill button is presses, making for a more dynamic game.

Similar Games

Monte Carlo

Monaco

Weeping Willow

Weeping Willow

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (5%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down in suit.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit.  Fill spaces with any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd pile, and so on.
•4 fans (left) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.  Build cards of same rank. Groups of cards headed by the same rank may be played from the tableau (but not other fans).  Spaces cannot be filled.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt face up to each pile.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Weeping Willow is a much harder version of Willow invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Willow

Fascination

Westcliff

Westcliff

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Very Easy (>99%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (middle) - build down by alternate color. Groups of cards in sequence down by alternate color may be moved as a unit.   Fill spaces with any card.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt to each pile, 2 face down and 1 face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste, by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (below stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Westcliff is a variation of Klondike.  It is fairly easy to win.

Similar Games

EastCliff

Westcliff Rush

Easthaven

Blind Alleys

Klondike

Westcliff Rush

Westcliff Rush

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (60%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•10 tableau piles (middle) - build down by alternate color.  Only one card at at time may be moved.  Fill spaces with any card.  At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt to each pile, 2 face down and 1 face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 3 cards at a time to the waste by clicking during the first deal, 2 cards at a time during the 2nd deal, and 1 card at a time during the last deal.  Two redeals.
•waste (below stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Westcliff Rush is a variation of Westcliff.

Similar Games

EastCliff

Westcliff

Easthaven

Blind Alleys

Klondike

Wheatsheaf

Wheatsheaf

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (3%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (in center) - build leftmost 4 piles up in suit from Ace to King, build rightmost 4 piles down in suit from King to Ace.
•8 tableau piles (to left and right of foundations) - build up or down by suit.  Spaces are filled from the waste.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (upper left, face down) - 1 card at a time moved to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Wheatsheaf is a variation of Congress.

Similar Games

Congress

Parliament

Diplomat

Lady Palk

Whistler

Whistler

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (50%)  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•6 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces are filled from the reserve if possible, then by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 3 cards at a time, by clicking.  Unlimited redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card always available for play on the tableau or foundations.
•reserve (left of tableau) - Top card always available for play on the tableau or foundations.  At the start of the game 13 cards are dealt here.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Whistler is an easier variation of the strict 3 card deal Canfield.  It is named after artist James Whistler, a friend of Richard Canfield.

Similar Games

Canfield

Candike

Cerulean

Whitehead

Whitehead

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (50%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down in suit.  Fill spaces with any card or legal groups of cards.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over one card at a time to the waste, by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card always available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

This is a variation of Klondike.  The ability to see all the cards in the tableau makes this game interesting.  It is more difficult to win than most of the Klondike variations.

Similar Games

Klondike

Whitehorse

Whitehorse

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (98%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Spaces are filled automatically from the waste or from the stock if the waste is empty. At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 3 cards at a time, by clicking.  Unlimited redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Whitehorse is a variation of Klondike.

Similar Games

Klondike

Wildflower

Wildflower

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (90%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•6 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down regardless of suit.  Groups of cards may be moved as a unit if they are in sequence down in suit.  Spaces are filled by any card.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•reserve (left) - All cards available for play on the foundations or tableau.  Click on card to move it to the bottom of the stack, then move to either the foundations or tableau.   At the start of the game 16 cards are dealt to this pile.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Wildflower is a variation of Flower Garden.

Similar Games

Flower Garden

Brigade

Stonewall

Northwest Territory

Will o the Wisp

Will o the Wisp

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (19%).  Skill/luck balanced.

Object

To group all the cards in sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace.

Layout

•7 tableau piles - build down regardless of suit.  Groups of cards in sequence down in suit may be moved as a unit.  A space can be filled by any card or legal group of cards. At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt to each pile, 2 face down and 1 face up.

 

•stock (above the tableau) - Clicking deals 1 card to each tableau pile.  All empty spaces must be filled before a deal.

Notes

•Whenever a sequence of 13 cards down in suit from King to Ace is formed, it will automatically be removed from play.

Tips

•Same suit sequences should be preferred even though building is down regardless of suit.  The object is to build down in suit sequences.

History

Will o' the Wisp is a variation of Spiderette where the cards are dealt in the same fashion as EastHaven.  With fewer face down cards to clear, the game becomes slightly easier.  Will o the Wisp was invented by Albert Morehead and Geoffrey Mott-Smith in their book The Complete Book of Solitaire & Patience Games in 1949.

Similar Games

Spiderette

EastHaven

Willow

Willow

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (20%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Fill spaces with any card or legal group of cards.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd pile, and so on.
•4 fans (left) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau or other fans.  Build cards of same rank. Spaces cannot be filled.  At the start of the game 6 cards are dealt face up to each pile.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Willow was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Fascination

Spike

Weeping Willow

Midnight Sun

Windmill

Windmill

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (18%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•5 foundation piles (1 in center, 4 others diagonally around it) - on the center foundation, which at the start of the game is dealt an Ace, build up regardless of suit, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until it contains 52 cards. On the other 4 foundations,  build down regardless of suit from King to Ace.
•8 tableau piles (extending in all 4 directions from the center foundation) - each pile may contain 1 card.  Spaces are filled immediately from the waste or stock.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - the top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Windmill is also known as Propeller.  Feed the big center pile every time you can.

Similar Games

Dutch Solitaire

Windsor Castle

Windsor Castle

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (10%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (middle) - build up in suit from Ace to King.

 

•10 tableau piles (around foundations) - build up or down by suit.  Only the top card of each pile is available for play.  Spaces may be filled by any available card.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt face up to each pile (6 cards to the first two piles).

Options

AutoPlay

History

Windsor Castle is a variation of Beleaguered Castle.

Similar Games

Beleaguered Castle

Winery

Winery

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (15%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.

 

•10 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are filled by any card.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•2 cells (top left) - storage locations for cards.  Only 1 card allowed in each cell.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each cell.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Winery is Vineyard with 2 cells.

Similar Games

Vineyard

Good Measure

Martha

Bastion

Wings

Wings

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (40%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top) - build up in suit from the rank of first card dealt to the first pile, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•8 tableau piles (the wings) - build down in suit, wrapping from Ace to King as necessary. Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are filled from the reserve (or Trunk) until it is empty, then by any card.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•reserve or Trunk (middle) - cards may be moved to the foundations or tableau.  At the start of the game 13 cards are dealt here.
•stock (face down, bottom left) - turn over cards one at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.

 

•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Wings is a variation of Eagle Wing.

Similar Games

Eagle Wing

Bald Eagle

Wood

Wood

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Hard (30%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (middle) - build up by alternate color, wrapping from King to Ace as necessary, until each pile contains 13 cards.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Only the top card of each pile may be moved.  Spaces may be filled only from the waste pile.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt face up to each pile.
•reserve (top) - top card is available for play on the foundations only.  At the start of the game 10 cards are dealt to this pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over cards 1 at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Wood is in the Terrace family of games.  It is closely related to Falling Star and Blondes and Brunettes.

Similar Games

Falling Star

Blondes and Brunettes

Terrace

Wood Scorpion

Wood Scorpion

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (50%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards into 4 sets of 13 cards in sequence down in suit from King to Ace within the tableau.

Layout

•8 tableau piles (top) - build down in suit.  Groups of cards (regardless of any sequence) can be moved.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt to each pile.  In the first 4 piles, 3 cards are face down and 2 face up, in the next 6 piles all cards are face up.

 

•reserve (top left, face down) - Clicking deals 1 card to each of the first 7 tableau piles (this can be done only once).

Notes

•Any face up card, regardless of where in a pile it is, can be moved, along with all cards above it (this is like Yukon).

Tips

•It is imperative that the face down cards be uncovered as soon as possible.  There are often several choices of builds to make and it is beneficial to work through possibilities.  This is very much a game of skill, and it is difficult.

History

Wood Scorpion is an 9 pile version of Scorpion invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Scorpion

Serket

Worldly

Worldly

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Easy (90%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by any suit but the same.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by any suit but the same.  Fill spaces with Kings or a group of cards headed by a King. At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.  The top card is face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 3 cards at a time to the waste by clicking during the first deal, 2 cards at a time during the 2nd deal, and 1 card at a time during the last deal.  Two redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Worldly is an easy variation of Gold Rush.

Similar Games

Klondike

Gold Rush

Thumb and Pouch

XV

XV

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (30%).  Mostly Luck.

Object

To discard all the cards.

Layout

•13 tableau piles - the top card is available for play.  Discard pairs of cards that have ranks that add to 15. Aces are discarded in pairs.  Spaces are automatically filled from the stock in the center 3 piles, otherwise in the outer 10 piles spaces are not filled.   At the start of the game 3 cards are dealt face up to 10 piles, 1 card is dealt face up to the center 3 piles.
•stock (face down, left) - fills spaces in the tableau.
•waste (lower left)  - Where paired cards go out of play.

Valid Discards

•A-A, 2-K, 3-Q, 4-J, 5-10, 6-9, 7-8

History

XV is a variation of Friday and Seventeens.

Similar Games

Seventeens

Friday

Yorktown

Yorktown

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (75%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards if they are in sequence down by alternate color.  Fill spaces with any card or groups of cards.  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd, and so on.  All cards are dealt face up.
•stock (top left, face down) - turn over 1 cards at a time, by clicking.  Unlimited redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - top card available for play on the foundations or tableau.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Yorktown is Klondike with all the cards in the tableau visible.

Similar Games

Klondike

Saratoga

Yucone

Yucone

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (30%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (right) - build up in suit from Ace to King, wrapping to Ace and then to King again, until each pile contains 26 cards.
•7 tableau piles (across top) - build down by alternate color, wrapping from Ace to King if necessary.   Move groups of cards regardless of any sequence. Spaces may be filled by any card or group of cards (All spaces must be filled before cards are dealt from the stock).  At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the 1st and 7th piles, 2 cards to the 2nd and 6th, 3 cards to the 3rd and 5th, and 4 cards to the 4th pile.
•stock (top left, face down) - deals 1 card to each tableau pile by clicking.  When only 4 cards remain, 1 card is dealt to each of the reserve piles. No redeals.
•4 reserve piles (below stock) - cards are dealt here from the stock when the stock contains only 4 cards.  The cards are available for play on the foundations or tableau. No building.

Options

AutoPlay

Similar Games

Cone

Carlton

Giant

Miss Milligan

Yukon

Yukon

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (35%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards regardless of any sequence.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.   At the start of the game 1 card is dealt the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd pile, and so on.  The top card is face up.  Then 4 additional face up cards are dealt to the 2nd through 7th piles.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Any face up card in the tableau may be built upon another, no matter how deep it is in a pile.  All cards covering it are moved together.  When a face down card is uncovered, it is automatically turned face up and is available for play.

Tips

•Uncover the face down cards as soon as possible.  Don't let one foundation get too far ahead of the others.

History

Yukon is a variation of Klondike. Russian Solitaire is the same game except with building down in suit, making it much harder.  Yukon originally appeared in the 1949 book The Complete Book of Solitaire & Patience Games.

Similar Games

Russian Solitaire

Double Yukon

Triple Yukon

Quadruple Yukon

Ukrainian Solitaire

Alaska

Yukon Puzzle

Ace of Hearts

Australian Patience

Cornelius

Numeration

Queenie

Klondike

Geoffrey

Yukon Spider

Moosehide

Roslyn

Great River

Bonanza Creek

Yukon Cells

Yukon Cells

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (70%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards regardless of any sequence.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.   At the start of the game 1 card is dealt the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd pile, and so on.  The top card is face up.  Then 4 additional face up cards are dealt to the 2nd through 7th piles.
•2 cells (above tableau) - storage locations for cards.  The top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.  A group of cards may be moved to a cell as a unit, but they can only be removed from the cell one card at a time.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Any face up card in the tableau may be built upon another, no matter how deep it is in a pile.  All cards covering it are moved together.  When a face down card is uncovered, it is automatically turned face up and is available for play.

History

Yukon Cells is Yukon with 2 cells to make the game easier.

Similar Games

Yukon

Yukon Kings

Yukon Kings

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Medium (30%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards into 4 sets of 13 cards in sequence down by alternate color from King to Ace.

Layout

•7 tableau piles  - build down by alternate color, wrapping from Ace to King if necessary,.  Move groups of cards regardless of any sequence.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.   At the start of the game 1 card is dealt the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd pile, and so on.  The top card is face up.  Then 4 additional face up cards are dealt to the 2nd through 7th piles.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Any face up card in the tableau may be built upon another, no matter how deep it is in a pile.  All cards covering it are moved together.  When a face down card is uncovered, it is automatically turned face up and is available for play.

History

Yukon Kings is Yukon Spider with the additional ability to play Kings on Aces, making the game somewhat easier.

Similar Games

Yukon

Yukon Spider

Australian Spider

Yukon One Suit

Yukon One Suit

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Modified Deck (All Spades).  Easy (99%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down.  Move groups of cards regardless of any sequence.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.   At the start of the game 1 card is dealt the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd pile, and so on.  The top card is face up.  Then 4 additional face up cards are dealt to the 2nd through 7th piles.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Any face up card in the tableau may be built upon another, no matter how deep it is in a pile.  All cards covering it are moved together.  When a face down card is uncovered, it is automatically turned face up and is available for play.

Tips

•Uncover the face down cards as soon as possible.  Don't let one foundation get too far ahead of the others.

History

Yukon One Suit is a simple variation of Yukon.

Similar Games

Yukon

Yukon Two Suits

Yukon Puzzle

Yukon Puzzle

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Very Easy (95%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move one deck of cards to the foundations, to move the other deck of cards into 13 piles of 4 cards of the same rank.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top middle) - build up in suit from Ace to King.  At the start of the game an Ace of each suit are dealt here.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards regardless of any sequence.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.   At the start of the game 1 card is dealt the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd pile, and so on.  The top card is face up.  Then 4 additional face up cards are dealt to the 2nd through 7th piles.
•15 reserve piles (on right - 3 begin empty) - Cards may be played on other cards of the same rank.  At most 4 cards are allowed in any pile.  Empty piles may be filled by any card.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt face up to 12 of the piles.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Any face up card in the tableau may be built upon another, no matter how deep it is in a pile.  All cards covering it are moved together.  When a face down card is uncovered, it is automatically turned face up and is available for play.
•In the reserve piles, cards may be played on other cards of the same rank.  For example, if the top card of a pile is a Three, another Three can be played on top of it.  The object is to move the cards so that there are 13 piles of 4 cards of the same rank, that is, one pile of 4 Kings, one pile of 4 Queens, and so on.  Note that the 4 cards must all be of different suits.

History

Yukon Puzzle is a combination of the games Yukon and Fifteen Puzzle.  It was invented by Thomas Warfield.

Similar Games

Yukon

Fifteen Puzzle

Klondike Puzzle

Interchange Puzzle

Yukon Spider

Yukon Spider

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (5%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To group all the cards into 4 sets of 13 cards in sequence down by alternate color from King to Ace.

Layout

•7 tableau piles  - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards regardless of any sequence.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.   At the start of the game 1 card is dealt the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd pile, and so on.  The top card is face up.  Then 4 additional face up cards are dealt to the 2nd through 7th piles.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Any face up card in the tableau may be built upon another, no matter how deep it is in a pile.  All cards covering it are moved together.  When a face down card is uncovered, it is automatically turned face up and is available for play.

History

Yukon Spider is Yukon played without foundations.

Similar Games

Yukon Twice

Yukon Twice

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (60%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (across top) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•8 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards regardless of any sequence.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.   At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd pile, and so on.  The top card is face up.  Then 10 additional face up cards are dealt to the 2nd thru 6th piles and 9 additional cards dealt to the 7th and 8th piles.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Any face up card in the tableau may be built upon another, no matter how deep it is in a pile.  All cards covering it are moved together.  When a face down card is uncovered, it is automatically turned face up and is available for play.

Tips

•Uncover the face down cards as soon as possible.  Don't let one foundation get too far ahead of the others.

History

Yukon Twice is a 2 deck version of Yukon that is more difficult than Double Yukon.

Similar Games

Yukon

Triple Yukon

Quadruple Yukon

Russian Solitaire

Yukon Two Suits

Yukon Two Suits

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Modified Deck (half Spades, half Hearts). Easy (99%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards regardless of any sequence.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.   At the start of the game 1 card is dealt the first pile, 2 cards to the 2nd pile, and so on.  The top card is face up.  Then 4 additional face up cards are dealt to the 2nd through 7th piles.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Any face up card in the tableau may be built upon another, no matter how deep it is in a pile.  All cards covering it are moved together.  When a face down card is uncovered, it is automatically turned face up and is available for play.

Tips

•Uncover the face down cards as soon as possible.  Don't let one foundation get too far ahead of the others.

History

Yukon Two Suits is a simple variation of Yukon.

Yukonic Plague

Yukonic Plague

 Top  Previous  Next

1 Deck.  Hard (15%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•4 foundation piles (top right) - build up in suit from Ace to King.
•7 tableau piles (below foundations) - build down by alternate color.  Move groups of cards regardless of any sequence.  Fill spaces with Kings or groups of cards headed by a King.   At the start of the game 1 card is dealt the first pile, 2 face down cards are dealt to the remaining piles, then 2 face up cards are dealt to the 2nd pile, 3 face up to the 3rd, 4 to the 4th, 5 to the 5th, and 6 to the 6th and 7th piles.
•reserve (left of foundations) - Top card always available for play on the tableau or foundations.  At the start of the game 13 cards are dealt here.

Options

AutoPlay

Notes

•Any face up card in the tableau may be built upon another, no matter how deep it is in a pile.  All cards covering it are moved together.  When a face down card is uncovered, it is automatically turned face up and is available for play.

History

Yukonic Plague is a variation of Yukon, with the same rules but a different opening layout, plus a reserve.  The result is that more cards begin out of play, which makes the game harder than Yukon.  Getting the cards in the reserve and the face down cards in the tableau into play is crucial in this game.

Similar Games

Yukon

Russian Solitaire

Zerline

Zerline

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (55%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (center) - build up in suit from Kings, then Aces up to Queens.
•8 tableau piles (left and right) - build down regardless of suit.  Only one card at a time may be moved.  Spaces are filled only with Queens.  At the start of the game 5 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
• stock (top face down) - Turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  No redeals.
• waste (next to stock) - Top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.
•reserve (to right of waste) - storage location for up to 4 cards.  Only the top card is available for play on the foundations or tableau.  Any available card from the tableau (not waste) may be played to the reserve.

Options

AutoPlay

History

Zerline is of German origin.

Similar Games

Rows of Four

Kleine Napoleon

Beleaguered Castle

Zeus

Zeus

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (30%).  Skill/Luck balanced.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•Odds foundations (top) - build up in suit by twos, starting with Aces. (Ace, Three, Five, Seven, Nine, Jack, King).  At the start of the game the Aces are dealt here.
•Evens foundations (under Odds) - build up in suit by twos, starting with Twos. (Two, Four, Six, Eight, Ten, Queen).  At the start of the game the Twos are dealt here.
•9 tableau piles (under Evens) - top card is available for play on the foundations.  Build down in suit by twos.  Groups of cards in sequence down in suit by twos may be moved as a unit.  Spaces are filled from the stock, when the stock is empty spaces are filled by Kings or Queens only, or groups headed by a King or a Queen.  At the start of the game 4 cards are dealt face up to each pile.
•stock (left, face down) - Deals one card to each tableau pile by clicking.

Options

AutoPlay

Similar Games

Great Wheel

Zodiac

Zodiac

 Top  Previous  Next

2 Decks.  Medium (40%).  Mostly Skill.

Object

To move all the cards to the foundations.

Layout

•8 foundation piles (middle, upper and lower)  - build the upper 4 piles up in suit from Ace to King (one for each suit), the lower 4 down in suit from King to Ace (one for each suit).  No cards can be played to the foundations until the stock and waste are empty.
•8 reserve piles, also known as the "Equator" (center) - storage location for one card.   Only 1 card allowed in each reserve.  The card is available for play on the tableau piles, and on the foundations when the stock and waste are empty. At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•24 tableau piles, also known as the "Zodiac" (around all the other piles) - build up or down by suit, Aces and Kings are not consecutive.  Sequences can change up or down within the same pile.  Top card is available for play on the foundations when the stock and waste are empty.  Cards cannot be moved from one tableau pile to another.  Once a card is played to a tableau pile it cannot be played anywhere except to the foundations. At the start of the game 1 card is dealt to each pile.
•stock (middle left, face down) - Turn over 1 card at a time to the waste by clicking.  Unlimited redeals.
•waste (next to stock) - Top card is available for play on the tableau or reserve piles.

Notes

Because cards cannot be played to the foundations until the stock and waste are empty, the game divides into two parts.  In the first part, the cards from the waste and reserve piles are played to the tableau piles until all the cards are either on the tableau or reserve piles.  If you cannot bring all the cards into play, then the game is lost.  In the second part, the cards are played from the tableau or reserve piles to the foundations.  Only if all the cards can be played up to the foundations without blocking can the game be won.

History

Zodiac is a very old game, originally appearing in Lady Adelaide Cadogan's patience books in the Nineteenth century.

Similar Games

Constellation
